Title: Lockdown effect: Recaps and reruns on Kannada TV channels
Content: With shooting and other production activities kept on hold, the Kannada television industry sure is in doldrums. Understandably then, innovation has become the key for channels to stay afloat until the circumstances get better.“We have begun playing the title songs of our popular daily soapsand. These go on for up to a minute or more and sum up the high points of the serial with corresponding visuals,” says Raghavendra Hunsur , business head of a regional TV channel.Following this will be reruns of hit fiction and non-fiction programmes, movies, audio launches and award shows. “We are also planning to introduce voiceovers that will narrate the story and even have the lead actors share anecdotes from the show. In terms of non-fiction, we have hits likeand, hoping to keep the audiences’ interest piqued through the lockdown,” adds Raghavendra.“A three-minute recap is being aired with every episode of our serials including Premaloka and Muddulakshmi, irrespective of the time. It’s played either in the beginning or in the end. These three-minute videos are like capsules which can be aired at any point of time, so if there is a short duration of fresh content in one of the serials, these capsules are being used as fillers,” shares a production house official of another channel. These unique measures, adds the source, will help in longer run time of the content they have on hand. Parmeshwar Gundkal, business head of another regional channel, insists that they are committed to give their viewers engaging content even amid the lockdown. “We have not started recaps or resorted to shorter runtime yet. Once we exhaust our original content, which will probably happen sometime in the first week of April, we may replay serials likeas well as cartoons and fairy tales for kids and even the latest season of,” he explains.

Title: Harassed, abused, spat at: Stop this racism, it’s not ok to taunt Northeast Indians with ‘corona’ slurs
Content:
‘A security guard at a bank told me I was the reason for the spread of coronavirus’

‘How many times do we have to prove that we are Indians?’

After working in 16-hour-shifts, it’s disheartening to be treated like untouchables: Medicos

‘I was the only one from my team to be asked to work from home’

BOX: State govts, cops crack down on racial offenders

Sruthi.Raman@timesgroup, Sandra.Fernandes@timesgroup.com, Sunayana.Suresh@timesgroup.com, Riya.Sharma@timesgroup.com Abhimanyu.Mathur@timesgroup.com, Shamayita.Chakraborty@timesgroup.com; Pathi.Thadhagath@timesgroup.com; Sushmita.Jha@timesgroup.com and Rishabh.Deb@timesgroup.com

last week, a Delhi man was arrested for spitting paan all over a Manipuri girl’s face, hair and T-shirt. “He called me ‘coronavirus’ before fleeing on his scooter,” the girl complained. Meanwhile in Ahmedabad, nine youngsters from Nagaland were forced to spend 24 hours at a quarantine facility, despite testing negative for COVID-19 and having no travel history. On Saturday, two Naga students lodged a police complaint in Mysuru after they were denied entry into a supermarket. “We showed them our proof (Aadhaar card) and told them, ‘we are from Northeast India and are college students’, but still they said, ‘we don’t accept foreigners’. We were arguing to prove ourselves as Indian in our own nation. We went back home without groceries (sic),” one of the students shared on social media, along with a video of the incident, which has subsequently gone viral. The fear of coronavirus has brought out the worst in some of us, and facing the brunt of it are those hailing from Northeast Indian states. ‘It’s like we’re fighting two deadly viruses — covid-19 and racism ,’ they say.Though the COVID-19 outbreak began to get worse in India only during early to mid-March, the discrimination began as early as February. Abem Khwairakpam, a Manipuri who works at a parlour in Coimbatore, says, “I went to Kerala for a vacation in February, and was shocked when a few people heckled me saying ‘corona, corona’. It saddens me to see that people are not even aware that we’re not Chinese. Northeast is an integral part of India. People need to be better informed about our geography, or the discrimination will continue.”A group of students from Kolkata’s Jadavpur University have a similar story to tell. “In the last week of February, my friends and I went to BAPS Shree Swaminarayan Mandir in Thakurpukur, Behala. There was a group of students there along with their teachers. As soon as I entered the temple, one of the teachers, said, ‘It is because of you we have coronavirus’. I was appaled to see teachers behave like that,” says Thinley Bhutia, who hails from Kalimpong.The racism is hard to miss even when there are no words spoken. Ragini Thapa, a Delhi University student who hails from Manipur, experienced that first hand when travelling in metro with a friend, before the lockdown came into effect. “As soon as I stepped in, a woman looked at me and immediately covered her face with a dupatta. Unfortunately, two stations later, I got a seat next to her. She became extremely uncomfortable and left her seat and stood near the exit gate. She did not say anything but sometimes such gestures speak volumes. That is no way to treat a fellow human being.”Kuldeep Bhaswa, a sales engineer from Nagaland, who lives in Hyderabad, “was screamed at by a security guard at a bank for not wearing a mask.” Not stopping at thet, the guard also blamed him for spreading the virus, he says. “When I tried to explain to him that only those who are sick need to wear a mask, he insisted that I should wear one because I belong to ‘that country’. There were many who were not wearing a mask, but I was singled out,” says Kuldeep, adding, “It hurts to be treated like a pariah by your own countrymen.”Wapang Toshi, President, Northeast India Welfare Association, Chennai, says the discrimination is rising at an alarming level. “Most people think we’re Chinese because of the way we look. They shame us by calling us ‘corona’. Some even think we’re carriers of the virus. Many of our people have been denied essential services like groceries and medicines. This discrimination is concerning,” he says, adding, “How many times do we need to prove that we are Indians? All of India is battling the coronavirus today, but the people of Northeast are fighting on two fronts: coronavirus and racial discrimination.”Pranab Jyoti Borah, member of the Assam Association in Bengaluru, says that in the past one week, the association has received over 100 complaints of discrimination from the northeast community. “Many women, who live in PGs were asked to leave by their owners. We had to intervene and request owners. In many cases, when our pleas fell on deaf ears, we had to seek help from the police,” adds Pranab.What’s more disturbing is that people from the medical community, who are working round-the-clock to control the pandemic, are not spared from racism either. Aashna Lemo, a nursing student from Arunachal Pradesh, who lives in Hyderabad, says, “A ward boy in our hospital called me coronavirus and went on to verballu abuse me in Telugu. Miffed, I immediately filed a complaint with the chief doctor. Swift action was taken against the ward boy, but what about the others, who blatantly pass racist slurs at us. Who will punish them? After working in 16-hour-shifts in these circumstances, we have to deal with racism.”Ektha Roy, a Manipuri who studies at medical college in Hyderabad, adds, “We are being treated like untouchables. I overheard a few girls in my hostel point towards me and say, ‘All these viruses spread because of these chinky people’. It’s bad enough that we’re staying by ourselves away from our families during this time of crisis. It hurts when you hear such things and we can’t even share with our families, cause they’re already worried about us and this will make it worse.”A nurse from Nagaland, who works at a Ghaziabad hospital, says she was asked to be replaced by patients, ‘cos they suspected her to be infected with coronavirus. Speaking to us on the condition of anonymity, she says, “There have been quite a few occasions where patients I’ve attended to or their attendants have requested the doctors or other nurses to replace me. They never say anything directly to my face but their discomfort shows. Once a colleague asked an attendant as to why they were asking for me to be changed and they said, ‘Kya pata inko corona ho!’ I understand everyone is worried but this is very insulting and demeaning.”Besides being subjected to cat-calling and racist slurs on the streets, people from the northeast are also being discriminated at workplaces as well. Prakruthi Chakma, a 26-year-old from Manipur who works at a boutique in Hyderabad, says “I was asked by my store manager to go home. When I asked him why, he said it was for my own safety. The store was still open and all the staff went to work till the lockdown was imposed. That was painful.”Taking a firm stand against reports of racism against northeastern people in Hyderabad, Telangana ’s IT Minister KTR instructed the police to take strict action against the offenders. Taking to Twitter, KTR said, “This is indeed repugnant, absolutely unacceptable. Request @TelanaganaDGP to issue Clear instructions to register cases on those who indulge in slander/abuse of fellow citizens. I appeal all citizens to be graceful, compassionate & show your best side at this hour of crisis”(Sic).In Karnataka too, cops were quick to take action and booked cases against the supermarket staff in Mysuru who refused to allow two students from Nagaland to buy groceries, after the video went viral on social media.Bhaskar Rao, commissioner of police, Bengaluru, also took to Twitter on Sunday to offer his support to members of the northeast community. Bhaskar wrote, “Some misguided persons have made unwanted Covid 19 remarks against our brethren from NorthEastern States. These misguided will be dealt with very sternly.Brothers & Sisters from NorthEast, you are secure here, approach nearest Police station or Me directly. Live Fearless (sic).”In Tamil Nadu, the Chennai Police and the Northeast Nodal police officers came together and identified 18 places in Chennai that have a significant northeast population. “Very good security measures have been taken by the Tamil Nadu police, especially in these localities to make sure the racism menace is curbed.”— Inputs by:

Title: Corona deaths in Telangana: 6 who attended Delhi's Nizamuddin dargah die of Covid-19
Content:
#COVID19 has spread among some of those who attended a religious prayer meeting from 13th to 15th March at Markaz i… https://t.co/nnu4qJWLdS — ANI (@ANI) 1585589970000

HYDERABAD: Six people from Telangana who attended a religious congregation in Delhi's Nizamuddin between March 13 and 15 died due to novel coronavirus, the state government said on Monday."Coronavirus has spread among some of those who attended a religious prayer meeting from March 13 to 15 at Markaz in Nizamuddin area in Delhi," according to an official release. "Among those who attended were some persons from Telangana."Two of the six died at the Gandhi Hospital, one each in two private hospitals , and one each in Nizamabad and Gadwal towns, the statement said, without mentioning the time of their deaths.

Title: Nehha Pendse showcases her culinary skills
Content: Nehha Pendse who by her own admission doesn't know how to cook much, entered kitchen recently and tried making various dishes.Interestingly, she didn't pick exotic dishes. Instead prepared some homely baigan ka bharta and gajar halwa. She uploaded videos to share the same with her fans and followers.Apart from this, she also made ghee at home. In a recent with us, she revealed that she wanted to make Shrikhand Puri for her husband on Gudi Padwa.“I wanted to make it just the way my mom makes, to surprise Shardul. But because of the lockdown, I couldn't get learn that from her. Nonetheless, I will surely make it for him next time,” she said. Nehha recently got married with businessman Shardul Bayas.

Title: Katrina Kaif pledges to donate to the PM CARES fund and the CM's Relief Fund Maharashtra
Content: Several Bollywood celebs contributed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi 's PM CARES Fund to combat the Coronavirus crisis in the country. Celebs like Akshay Kumar Guru Randhawa and others did their bit.Now, Katrina Kaif took to her Instagram account to share that she will be donating to PM CARES Fund and Maharashtra's CM Relief Fund which will be used to tackle the current situation. She captioned the post, "I pledge to donate to the PM CARES fund and the Chief Minister's Relief Fund Maharashtra. Heartbreaking to see the hardship and suffering this pandemic has unleashed in the world."Check out the post here:Meanwhile, COVID-19 has brought the whole world to a standstill. As there is no cure for the disease, staying home and avoid getting infected is the only way to stay safe. And for the same, a 21-day lockdown has been imposed in the country recently.On the work front, Katrina will be next seen in Rohit Shetty 's 'Sooryavanshi' co-starring Akshay Kumar. The film was all set to release on March 24, however, due to COVID-19 pandemic, the release has been postponed.

Title: ICMR amplifying coronavirus test sites; more labs being opened across country: PSA
Content: NEW DELHI: Principal Scientific Adviser to the government K Vijay Raghavan on Monday said the ICMR is amplifying coronavirus test sites and more laboratories are being opened across the country.He said the Indian industry is also working on vaccines, re-purposing, critical-care treatment and partnering with academia and start-ups."Many of you have pointed out the need for more diagnostic tests . The @ICMRDELHI is amplifying test sites and you will see many more being done. More laboratories are being opened for testing across states," he said in a series of tweets.He also said efforts to increase test capacity by the 'pooling' of samples are being evaluated.This is not simple and needs the development and testing of optimisation algorithms so that one positive in a large pool is not missed, he added."There are new tests being rolled-out, globally, for the presence, or traces of the virus having visited a person. These can be useful as a first-pass, even if they are cruder than the 'gold-standard' RT-PCR. Indian labs are developing these kinds of tests too," he said.He said the Indian start-ups and incubators have been "astounding' and working on the highest end drug-repurposing, using AI to predict targets, to making equipment and tools for treatment of coronavirus. PTI PR

Title: #Lockdown but not out: City eateries feed the poor, make sanitisers
Content:
Kitchens serving the poor

Protecting, motivating the staff

Microbrewery makes sanitisers

The other side of the spectrum

Even at a time when shuttered city restaurants are staring at an uncertain future, many owners and chefs are coming forward to serve people in this hour of crisis. While some of them are cooking every day to feed the underprivileged, others are using their microbreweries to manufacture chemicals for sanitisers.Piccadilly square, Sanjha Chulha and Khichdi Khichri have joined hands to set up kitchens across city, to distribute food packets to the needy. Three temporary kitchens - at Babughat, Metropolitan and Jodhpur Park - are serving more than 1,000 people as of now. They have even adopted an orphanage and a slum near Ruby Hospital, so that no one goes to bed hungry. Meanwhile, industrialist Harshvardhan Neotia ’s hospitality team at Aafra has come forward to cook meals for those in need. They have started distributing about 500 food packets to the poor and are ready to do more. Pooja Baid , owner of Piccadilly Square, said the need of the hour, for daily wagers, is assured food, like a dal chawal or khichdi. "It is not about providing a sumptuous spread but the basic, so that these people can stay afloat,” she said.Restaurant chains with a large number of employees are trying to keep the moral high. Chowman, Oudh 1590 and Chapter 2 have closed all services for more than a week. The challenge, says Debaditya Chaudhury, co- owner, is taking care of more than 1500 employees from different states, half of whom was unable to go back home. All kitchens of the chain are now working to feed the work force that is stuck in the city.Motivating teams is a concern for many. Harshvardhan Neotia has been sending out motivational videos for his employees. “Instead of complaining, we should engage ourselves in self-improvement activities. I have also asked team leaders in my organisation to engage in conference calls with their respective teams every day,” he said.Spice Kraft, on the other hand, has closed their services much before the nation-wide lockdown was announced. On March 20, before closing down, they distributed all the ingredients and raw material among the staff members. “I hate wasting food. But more than that, we wanted our employees to have basic food items before closing down,” said Sambit.The scarcity of sanitisers inspired the entire team at The Grid, a popular microbrewery, to help make chemicals for sanitisers and disinfectants along with another company. They are currently making around 30,000 bottles of sanitisers per day at their facilities in Salt Lake and Rajarhat. “We are here to make sure that City of Joy does not run out of hand sanitisers. My team is like an army, fighting this war,” said Gaurav Karnani, co-founder.Supriya Mondal, a rickshaw driver, who lives in a slum near Ruby, rued, “I am not being able to drive my auto because of the lockdown. So far, we have been managing from our small savings fund. I am the only earning member in my family of four. I was really worried about the situation. At least now we are getting some food served by the restaurant guys. It is more than enough for us.”Like Supriya, Shikha Panigragi, a domestic help, informed that most of the households have asked her not to work for the time being. Many of them are not even paying the salary. “Now that we are getting food packets, I don’t have to worry about next month,” she said, adding that she has already spent a lot, buying masks and sanitisers for her family.

Title: Devlina stresses on the importance of self-isolation
Content: At a time when corona pandemic is about to reach stage III in India, creating all the more reasons to stay at home, actress Devlina Kumar urged people to maintain the rules and regulation set by the authorities. She also said that since Corona doesn't have a known cure, it is very important to understand the importance of self-isolation. "I love to go out to exercise, shopping and eating. But during this time even I am not going out. It is not the question of my safety alone, if I get infected I will make others life unsafe," she added.

Title: Pujarni enjoys to read and watch classics during lockdown
Content: During the nation-wide lock down, when everything has come to a halt, and it seems impossible to kill time, actress Pujarni Ghosh said she is having a great time at her home. The actress said that she loves to read and watch classics films. So, when she is with her books and films time flies by. "I am reading Tagore and all the books I can find. When I read, I real like an obsessive person. Besides, I am working out everyday," she added.The actress also has a fine taste in cinema and said the European films attracts her the most. "I have a full film library at my place. So spending time doesn't seem to be a problem," she added.

Title: Covid-19 fight: Govt has Rs 60k crore war chest in disaster funds
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The Centre has a war chest of more than Rs 60,000 crore to fight the Covid-19 pandemic — Rs 30,000 crore is already available in state disaster relief funds (SDRF) while allocation of a similar amount has been made for the 2020-21 financial year towards disaster relief and mitigation. This is in addition to contributions received in the PM’s relief fund.According to sources, the balance in SDRF of states is Rs 30,000 crore as on March 30. The kitty is made out of funds allocated every year to states to meet expenditure on relief and rehabilitation. Since the funds under SDRF and the National Disaster Relief Fund (NDRF) are non-lapsable, they get added to the kitty.Since 2016-17, the government has allocated over Rs 80,000 crore for disaster relief and rehabilitation — Rs 50,000 crore towards SDRFs and Rs 30,285 from the NDRF. The home ministry, in an order issued on March 14, had classified Covid-19 as a notified disaster for the purpose of providing assistance under SDRF. It had also provided a list of items and norms of assistance for containment of Covid-19 in India, eligible from SDRF and NDRF.Last year, the Centre had allocated Rs 13,465 crore to states under SDRF to meet disaster-related expenditure. In addition, the Centre had allocated over Rs 14,000 crore from the NDRF to eight states — Maharashtra, Karnataka Madhya Pradesh , Rajasthan, Himachal Pradesh Bihar and Andhra Pradesh — for exigencies arising out of floods. Kerala already had a balance of Rs 2,100 crore in its SDRF.Looking at largescale exodus of migrant workers from Delhi and other parts of the county to their hometowns, the government on Saturday clarified that fund use under SDRF would include relief measures for this class of people in providing them temporary accommodation, food, clothing and medical care. “This would be applicable to homeless people, including migrant labourers, stranded due to lockdown measures and sheltered in relief camps and other places for providing them food etc for containment of Covid-19 in the country,” the order said.While making it clear that no state will face any funds crunch in meeting expenditure towards the battle against Covid-19, the Centre has directed all states and Union Territories to ensure that the lockdown is followed in true spirit and no movement of any citizen is allowed in any part of the country

Title: Ayushmann Khurrana on COVID-19 crisis: Ameer toh yeh sab kuch seh lega lekin gareeb nahi seh payega. Time to ask for forgiveness
Content: Actress Ankita Lokhande, who is quite active on social media, has shared a few pictures with her family after her father returned from the hospital. She also penned a sweet note for her father. He was admitted to the hospital for a while.

Title: Assam doctor’s death raises questions
Content: GUWAHATI: A senior anaesthetist at a private hospital in Guwahati who was on hydroxychloroquine to protect Covid-19 infection — as are many other doctors elsewhere in the country — died of a heart attack here on Sunday afternoon after posting a message to colleagues on a WhatsApp group saying he thought he was having "some problems" after taking the medicine.There was, however, no way of knowing immediately whether his death was a direct consequence of using the drug. "Without a post-mortem one cannot explain Barman’s death," Guwahati-based internal medicine specialist Swarup Jyoti Saikia said, adding that the death did, however, raise "a red flag". Doctors said they would investigate the matter thoroughly.Utpaljit Barman (44), who headed the anaesthetics team at Pratiksha Hospital, had sent a message to colleagues in a WhatsApp group about half an hour after suffering the heart attack at home saying, "HCQS (hydroxychloroquine) is not good as prophylaxis (action taken to prevent disease). Lots of issues. I think I am having some problems after I took it."The anti-malaria drug is commonly used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.Pratiksha Hospital medical superintendent Nirmal Hazarika said, "He took it… not just him, other doctors in our hospital are also taking hydroxychloroquine as a preventive measure. The signs of symptoms at the time of his death were that of a heart attack." He, however, added that hospital authorities are not yet issuing any instructions to doctors to discontinue the drug."He suffered the attack at his home at around 2.30 pm and was taken to the hospital where he died after about one and a half hours," Hazarika said.Two hydroxychloroquine tablets of 200 mg have to be taken every seven days and Dr Barman had taken his last dose on March 22."The attack should not have happened in a person with a healthy heart. This drug is one of the safest among all the drugs used for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and is now also prescribed for some cases of uncontrolled diabetes," Guwahati-based internal medicine specialist Swarup Jyoti Saikia said.He added, "After the ICMR issued an advisory, there has been mass use of this drug among doctors. When there are inadequate number of PPEs, this drug becomes the immediate protection for all frontline healthcare workers. We have to be cautious now."Saikia added, "I have received reports from the US that three patients had sudden cardiac deaths after receiving hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin in California a couple of days ago."The National Task Force for Covid-19, constituted by the ICMR, has recommended the use of hydroxychloroquine for prophylaxis of SARS-CoV-2 infection for high-risk populations. The advisory provides for "placing the following high-risk population under chemoprophylaxis with hydroxychloroquine: Asymptomatic healthcare workers involved in the care of suspected or confirmed cases of Covid-19 and asymptomatic household contacts of laboratory confirmed cases."The protocol recommended by the National Task Force has been approved by the Drug Controller General of India for restricted use in emergency situations.

Title: States taking over star hotels across India
Content:
In their battle against Covid-19 pandemic, state governments have started taking over private hotels, including multi-star facilities, so that they can be converted into special wards for patients in the worst affected cities across the country.

In Indore and Ujjain , the two worst affected cities which account for 70% of Madhya Pradesh ’s total cases, the Shivraj Singh Chouhan government has acquired 28 hotels, resorts and marriage gardens.

Indore Development Authority chief executive officer Vivek Shotriya said that 22 hotels, resorts and marriage gardens have been acquired to set up quarantine centres. “As many as 1,200 patients can be accommodated in these establishments. If needed, we will acquire more buildings,” he said, adding that the target is to make isolation arrangements for at least 2,000 people. In state capital Bhopal, no private hotels have been acquired yet, but district collector Tarun Pithode did not rule out the possibility in the coming days.

In Rajasthan’s Bhilwara town, the worst affected spot in the state, the government has taken over at least 20 hotels and converted them into quarantine centres. "We have taken over 1,500 rooms and currently 600 people are quarantined in these hotels," Bhilwara district collector Rajendra Bhatt told TOI.

In Jaipur, the district administration is arranging for 10,000 emergency isolation beds which will be put up in hotels, private hospitals, university hostels, community halls, dharamshalas and clubs. "We have identified these hotels. We will use them as and when required," said Ashok Kumar, additional DM of Jaipur.

The acquisition of hotels comes days after the governments in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh invoked the British era Epidemic Diseases Act 1897 to acquire private hospitals in these states to combat coronavirus pandemic.

In Kerala, the government has identified private hotels and buildings in several districts. Around 74 buildings, comprising mostly hotels and hostels, have been identified in Ernakulam for setting up isolation wards. In Kasargod, the worst affected district, three hotels have been identified.

In Wayanad, which does not have a major government hospital, 134 hotels with 1,900 rooms have been identified and some of them have already been converted into ‘Covid Care Centres’. As many as 152 people have been placed under observation in nine such resorts.

Similarly, in Thiruvanthapuram, several hotels have been identified, including the iconic Mascot Hotel.

The Yogi Adityanath government in UP has taken over four multi-star hotels in capital Lucknow and one in Agra.

The Goa government has taken over at least one private resort, apart from government-run Goa Tourism Development Corporation residencies for converting them into quarantine facilities.

In Bengaluru, the government has identified 16 hotels, including one frequented by politicians, for housing patients with Covid-19 symptoms. “All primary contacts of Covid-19 positive cases who are asymptomatic, whose immunity level is low and those who are within the quarantine period will be moved to the hotels and kept in individual rooms before being moved to a quarantine facility,” Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) commissioner Anil Kumar said.

Title: Bareilly: Migrant workers returning to UP ‘sanitised’ with bleach, health min blames 'over-zealous' officials, probe on
Content:
A screen grab shows healthcare workers, in protective suits, spray a solution through hose pipe on migrants b... Read More

BAREILLY: Several batches of migrant workers, including women and children, who arrived in UP from Delhi/NCR in government-run buses over the weekend were made to squat on a road in Bareilly district and sprayed with sodium hypochlorite — a bleaching agent which authorities later admitted was “unfit for use on humans” — in a bid to sanitise them.

After the incident on Sunday attracted widespread criticism, joint secretary (health ministry), Lav Agarwal , blamed it on the “over zealousness of officials who acted out of fear”. The secretary clarified that this was not part of any protocol and was not required.

The Bareilly district administration has now set up a team to investigate the matter. District magistrate Nithish Kumar said treatment would be provided to anybody adversely affected by spraying of sodium hypochlorite. The DM also attributed the incident to “over-cautious” personnel. “They should not have done this, but fortunately no one was harmed,” he told TOI.

City mayor Umesh Gautam admitted “negligence on part of the municipal corporation” and said directions have been issued to not repeat this in future.

The incident occurred after a sanitisation team from the municipal corporation and fire personnel were sent to sanitise the locality of a Covid-19 patient. While returning, they reached Satellite Bus Stand in the city and were disinfecting buses when they started spraying the solution on those who were arriving in the vehicles as well.

A video of the incident shows personnel directing people to close their eyes as the bleaching agent gushes out of a hosepipe and cops look on. Senior superintendent of police (Bareilly) Shailesh Pandey has claimed that police was not involved in any way in the exercise.

Municipal commissioner (Bareilly) Abhishek Anand admitted that the chemical solution was only meant for sanitising roads, walls and metallic surfaces and was “not fit for use on humans”. Chief medical officer Vineet Shukla also added that the solution was likely diluted else it could have had adverse effects.

In a press conference later, Awanish Kumar Awasthi , additional chief secretary (home), defended its use, claiming that sanitisers can be sprayed on any person without fear as per international norms.

Later in the day, BJP IT cell chief Amit Malviya tweeted that agencies in Kerala are mass spraying people, “…But all the outrage is only reserved for UP, because a saffron clad monk of the BJP is the chief minister and he is doing a good job.” Kerala officials were quick to clarify. “We have not used any kind of chemical or disinfectant on humans. What was sprayed by our personnel at Wayanad was diluted soap solution,” said director General of fire and rescue force, A Hemachandran.

Priyanka Gandhi shared a video of it on Twitter on Monday, calling it an ‘inhuman act’.

(With inputs from Maria Khan )

Title: Aparshakti Khurana: One should come out as a better version of themselves after lockdown
Content: Actor Aparshakti Khurana believes the coronavirus lockdown will teach people many important lessons about life."I feel now no one will take anything for granted. Once people resume their work... they will value their work for sure. I hope people come out as a better version of themselves after the lockdown, and start building healthy relationships with each other than demeaning others," Aparshakti said.He also shared how is he spending time at home."Sometimes I read scripts or take narrations through video calls. Also, I am learning how to cook. I also spend some time in composing songs. And of course, spending quality time with my wife," Aparshakti added.On the acting front, Aparshakti, who has carved his niche as a fine actor and a comedian with some interesting character roles , was recently seen in the dance drama, 'Street Dancer 3D' . He will next be seen as a solo lead in 'Helmet' , which also stars Pranutan Bahl

Title: Udupi district administration to source protective gear locally
Content: Udupi: The rise in the number of Covid-19 patients in Udupi district has, in addition to triggering panic among the public, resulted in a shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) for those in the medical profession. However, instead of fretting over this scarcity, the Udupi district administration has decided to tackle the problem head-on. The officials have identified units across Udupi that can manufacture PPE kits and have placed an order for as many as 1,000 of them, thereby solving the problem locally.Udupi district deputy commissioner G Jagadeesha told STOI that the kits they would receive from the local manufacturers would comprise goggles, masks , face-shields, gloves and gowns. “The company we have placed the order with has agreed to provide the 1,000 kits in three days,” Jagadeesha said.District medical officer Dr Prashanth Bhat said that both the district administration and the health department had zeroed in on a unit in Byndoor called Dhatri. “The company has assured us that they will prioritise local orders. The use of these kits, however, will depend on the number of Covid-19 patients that Udupi district records,” he added.Dr Bhat said that medical personnel attending to a patient required seven to 10 PPE kits on a daily basis. “Usually, one doctor and three nurses attend to a patient depending on the treatment being administered and the procedure. We use the safety gear when we have to collect samples from patients suspected of Covid-19. Each PPE kit costs around Rs 2,000 to Rs 3,000, and we are using money earmarked under the central government’s disaster management fund,” he said.

Title: Karnataka: Clusterwise lockdown helped Kalaburagi contain spread
Content: KALABURAGI: For as many as 13 consecutive days after its third Covid-19 case was reported, Kalaburagi , the divisional headquarter of Kalayana Karnataka, has not witnessed any positive case. This has set the mood of optimism in the district that hogged the headlines in mid-March when the first death in India due to coronavirus infection was reported from the region.It appears that in the district, which was described as the epicentre of outbreak, the administration is successfully containing the spread of the virus. According to officials, unprecedented measures taken early on, much ahead of the nationwide lockdown , and relatively faster identification of primary and secondary contacts might have helped Kalaburagi tackle the situation effectively.Apart from two active cases and one death, no fresh cases have been reported from the district for 13 days straight. The last positive case reported was on March 17. It was felt that time bomb was ticking in the district with the doctor who treated the first case also testing positive. The situation now seems to be very much under control.Kalaburagi now has its own testing laboratory. Among the 100 samples dispatched for testing, 63 have shown negative, bringing a huge relief to people and the administration under the leadership of deputy commissioner Sharath B that has been fighting a tough battle since the outbreak.Health workers have extensively surveyed 7,827 houses till March 29. This is to be continued with the same rigour, said the officials. The authorities had locked down the cluster, besides sealing the district borders.Two containment zones were created — one where the 76-year-old man, the first positive patient, resided and another where the doctor who treated him lived. These containment zones were locked down, banning the movement of people. Nearly 2,000 people are under observation and 33 are in hospital isolation. Among these 743 with foreign travel history self-reported, highlighting community participation.Srinivas Kakkilaya, a Mangaluru-based medical practitioner, said Kalaburagi is perhaps showing the way by taking appropriate and timely measures to contain the spread of coronavirus. “Rather than nationwide lockdown, cluster or sector-wise quarantine is the need of the hour. This method helped in Kalaburagi,” he opined.

Title: Race against time to map footprint of ‘patient zero’
Content:
PATNA: With Covid-19 positive cases rising steadily in Bihar — 15 in the past eight days, including one death — the health department and other agencies are racing against time to prevent the circle of infection from widening in the state.

The lone Covid-19 fatality in the state so far, a 38-year-old man from Munger who comes closest to being called the “patient zero” of Bihar, is alone responsible for infecting at least 10 people, including his 12-year-old nephew and a 35-year-old woman relative.

This man’s circle of infection is spread across his native Munger, neighbouring Lakhisarai and Bhagalpur as well as Patna where he had come for treatment. The state health department has identified 178 people so far who came in contact with the deceased Munger man, who He had returned from Qatar on March 12.

He tested positive after his death on March 21 at AIIMS- Patna. But by then, he had transmitted the virus to his nephew and the woman relative, who were the next two cases to turn positive. Later, it was found that three employees of a private hospital in Patna also tested positive for Covid-19.

The infection circle expanded to Lakhisarai, when the deceased’s sister-in-law, a 30-year-old woman tested positive for Covid-19 on late Saturday night. The next day on Sunday, four men who worked at a private hospital in Munger where the deceased had initially gone for treatment for kidney ailments tested positive for the virus.

“Swab and other samples of the first lot of 75 people were sent for test to Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI), Patna. While 10 people have tested positive, reports of most others have come negative for Covid-19,” a senior health department official said.

Contact tracing of an infected person often involves scouring footage from CCTV cameras to find people who were infected with the virus by mapping the network of “patient zero” or the first person identified as Covid-19 positive.

“In the case of Munger man, we went through the CCTV footage of the private hospital in Patna and several other places, where he had gone. Many people were identified based on the footage and sent to quarantine,” health department additional secretary Kaushal Kishor told TOI on Monday.

Deliberating on the steps being taken to identify people who have come in contact with Covid-19 positive persons, Kishor said, “Apart from CCTV footage, we go by traditional interview as well, starting from immediate family members to people at the places visited by him. Sometime we are able to identify more people who came in contact with Covid-19 positive case within hours, while in other cases it takes several days.”

Identification apart, measures are also taken to quarantine entire areas where Covid-19 positive cases and contact cases are found. For instance, Khemnichak in Patna, where the private hospital in question is located, and five villages on Saran-Siwan border have been sealed.

“An area of three kilometers around the place, where Covid-19 positive case is found, is required to be quarantined, sanitized and sealed. House to house verification is done in this area for people with symptoms and surveillance officer also keep a strict vigil in the area,” Kishor said.

Title: Bihar: First AES death at SKMCH sets alarm bells ringing
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: The death of a three-and-a half-year-old boy Aditya Kumar, due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome ( AES ) at Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur on Sunday, has put the senior officials of the district administration and the health department on their toes.

Apparently alarmed over the first death this year, the district magistrate held a meeting with the officials of the district administration as well as health department on Saturday and issued necessary directives to check the spread of deadly disease in vulnerable areas.

Aditya’s mother Sonawati Devi had said that the boy was first admitted to a primary health centre at Sakra after he complained of high fever, convulsion and body ache on Thursday. “The boy was put on ventilator for three days but couldn’t survive. In fact, he was brought here by the family members after his condition deteriorated. The doctors tried their level best but couldn’t save him,” said SKMCH superintendent Dr SK Shahi.

Shahi, however, said that another five-year-old girl, who was referred to the SKMCH from Motihari sadar hospital in East Champaran district with similar complications, was released from the hospital on Sunday. “Though her sugar level was also recorded much low, she responded to the treatment well and survived,” he said.

The superintendent, however, admitted that a few suspected AES cases were reported earlier too but there was no casualty.

The DM said that the administrative officials of the blocks, which had earlier witnessed AES cases, have been told to take precautionary measures. Awareness campaigns have also been launched in villages asking people not to allow their children to move in the scorching sun, feed them well at night and prevent them from eating unripe or rotten fruits from orchards.

The most important thing is that children with symptoms of AES should be admitted to either nearby PHC or the SKMCH without any delay. “If the victim is provided treatment within one or two hours, there are 99% chances of survival in such cases. The delay in treatment, however, may prove fatal,” he added.

The DM said that the relatives of the victim reaching the hospital on hiring private vehicles were given Rs.400 immediately and the patients were provided treatment free of cost. He further said that the administration was trying to restart the construction of 100-bed PICU ward at the SKMCH, which has stopped after the outbreak of Covid-19.

He, however, said that the PICU at the SKMCH was fully equipped to deal with AES cases. Even doctors and para-medical staff deputed at the PHCs in the district have been imparted training to deal with such cases. “PICUs have been made operational at all the PHCs in the district,” the DM said.

“As of today, there is no case of AES at the SKMCH Dr Shahi said. Earlier, CM Nitish Kumar assessed the preparedness of the authorities concerned to tackle the AES cases in Muzaffarpur and its adjoining districts at a high level meeting in Patna and issued directives to complete the 100-bed PICU ward at the SKMCH at the earliest.

Title: Several schools start virtual classes
Content: PATNA: In the wake of the coronavirus lockdown, several private schools in the state capital have introduced virtual classes for their students. They will now try to cover a major portion of the syllabi of different subjects before the summer break begins in the third week of May.Taking the lead, Shivam Convent School is conducting online classes six times a week. Principal Neelam Singh told this newspaper, “Our teachers are preparing videos and have even completed the first two chapters of their respective subjects. They are also giving home assignments to the students.”St Karen’s High School, Litera Valley School and Bishop Scott Group of Schools have also begun virtual classes in order to complete the syllabi on time.Bishop Scott Group director Shailesh Kumar said, “We have been conducting online classes in all our four schools since March 28.”Other schools, which have not gone virtual, are making all necessary arrangements for the purpose and training their teachers.Dr D Y Patil Pushpalata Patil International School director C B Singh said, “Students of classes III to XII will attend five-hour long classes for six days a week from April and get home assignments. Their attendance will also be marked.”He added, “Most of our teachers will use the ‘Zoom’ mobile app for conducting online classes. Others will use the ‘Diksha’ portal of the Central Board of Secondary Education.”While St Xavier’s High School is upgrading its in-house software to start online classes, Notre Dame Academy, Loyola High School, Delhi Public School, St Joseph’s Convent High School and St Michael’s High School are busy planning their timetables.Even before the lockdown was announced, St Michael’s Primary School asked its teachers to prepare a list of home assignments and day-to-day activities for the students.Headmistress Vishakha Sinha said, “I had sent a note to all the parents in this connection on March 21. Teachers first give their assignment plans to me and I share them with the parents. They, in turn, make sure that kids complete their work on time. When the school reopens, we will carry out revision work.”Meanwhile, students, most of whom are technophiles, have hailed the online classes. Aarti Kumari, a resident of Rajiv Nagar, said, “I sit with my daughter to make sure that she is attentive. She is enjoying the virtual classes at home.”Lohanipur resident Keshav Ranjan Prasad, whose kids study at St Karen’s High School, said, “Online classes are a great initiative because studies are not being hampered during the lockdown period. My kids are happy, too.”

Title: Kolkata: Mobile vendors fill the gap, sell staple items at doorstep
Content:
With markets getting crowded and people being restricted to their homes, mobile vendors selling anything from ... Read More

KOLKATA: Many people have found an opportunity amidst the crisis presented by the lockdown and their enterprise has become a lifeline for many in several neighbourhoods in the city. With markets getting crowded and people being restricted to their homes, mobile vendors selling anything from veggies to bread and butter, from fruits to even puri and sabzi, have come to the rescue of several households.

Mobile vendors with items loaded on cycle-vans, push-carts or even tempos have become a common sight and several families have taken the vendors’ numbers to find out when they will be servicing their localities every day. Such is the demand that by the time the vendors get done for the day, almost the entire stock is sold.

Many vendors TOI spoke to — who worked in transport or eateries and were left without jobs when the lockdown was announced — said they wasted no time in diversifying to fill the gap.

“I pick up vegetables from Koley Market and do the rounds in areas close to Ganesh Chandra Avenue and Wellesley. Transport options are shut and I am out of work, but I have to feed my family,” said Sanjay Paswan, a vendor.

Mohammad Irshad Sheikh, 62, worked at a restaurant off Central Avenue, which is now shut. Last Thursday, when he found out there was scarcity of bread in central Kolkata, he took his bicycle to a bakery on Rippon Street and picked up loaves to sell there. He said now people call him the night before to place orders. “I reach the bakery by 5am and head to BB Ganguly Street, Eden Hospital Road, Tara Chand Dutta Street, Kaviraj Row and Central Avenue. I sell everything by 9am,” he said.

Central Kolkata has a huge population of migrant labourers who are facing difficulty in getting food. Apart from them, most people who buy from these vendors are the elderly, those who want to avoid crowded markets and those who cannot afford to buy in bulk. “Going to markets will defeat the purpose of social distancing. When fresh vegetables are being sold at our doorstep, why take the risk? asked Jayant Rosario, a resident of Metcalfe Street.

Title: Chaiti Chhath: Many offer ‘arghya’ at home
Content:
PATNA: Patnaites offered ‘arghya’ to the setting Sun on Day 3 of Chaiti Chhath on Wednesday. Most of them stayed indoors in view of the countrywide lockdown due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

The third day of Chaiti Chhath, when ‘sandhya arghya’ is offered, usually witnesses huge gatherings of people. This time, however, many did not celebrate the festival.

Around 300 people used to visit Kankarbagh resident Vishal Singh’s house on the occasion of Chaiti Chhath every year. “We offered ‘sandhya arghya’ with only five people this year. I missed my friends, but am, anyway, happy that I was able to celebrate the festival with my family. There were no fruits and the rituals were performed using dry fruits and coconuts,” he told this newspaper.

He added, “I made my brother and sister-in-law see the rituals through videoconferencing.”

Another devotee, Munni Devi of Nala Road area, celebrated the festival without her children this time.

“No video or phone call can fill the void a mother feels when her kids are not around. I was not even willing to celebrate Chhath, but my family convinced me to. I prayed for the betterment of the world,” she said.

Ghats barricaded: Amid the 21-day lockdown, the district administration has barricaded the Bans Ghat, Mahendru Ghat, Collectorate Ghat, Krishna Ghat, Gandhi Ghat, Law College Ghat, Mahavir Ghat and Sita Ghat to prevent crowding.

In a statement issued by the administration, Patna district magistrate Kumar Ravi says, “A large number of police personnel have been deputed at the ghats and told to prevent crowding. If a ‘vrati’ reaches a ghat, the authorities will ensure that they follow social distancing.”

Title: Sensex down 1,375 pts as growth, labour migration worries weigh
Content: Mumbai: After a brief pause last week, the intensity of selling on Dalal Street that had resumed on Friday continued on Monday with the sensex closing the session 1,375 points, or 4.6%, down at 28,440. Market players said that fears about a sharp decline in economic growth due to issues relating to Covid-19 , including a humanitarian crisis because of the reverse migration of labour force, weighed on investor sentiment. This led to the sharp spike in selling in the new week.On the NSE , the Nifty settled at 8,281 points, down 279 points or 4.4%. On the BSE , investors saw their wealth erode by about Rs 2.5 lakh crore with the stock exchange’s market capitalisation now reduced to Rs 108.7 lakh crore.Religare Broking VP (research) Ajit Mishra said the sell-off in the Indian markets spiked due to the rising risk of community transmission of coronavirus as the total number of cases in the country crossed the 1,100 mark. “Besides, the lockdown in the major cities has also started showing its impact and top think tanks are now vocal about the strong possibility of further contraction in growth numbers if the curfew continues longer than expected,” Mishra said in a note.On the sectoral front, the BFSI sector led the slide, along with auto and real estate, while pharma and FMCG stocks showed some resilience. Among the sensex stocks, HDFC, HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank, Kotak Bank and RIL were top drags on the index, while HUL and Nestle supported it, BSE data showed.During the session, foreign funds were net sellers at Rs 4,364 crore, while domestic institutions recorded a net buying figure of Rs 3,550 crore, BSE data showed. The selling by foreign funds weighed on the Indian rupee, which fell below the 75.5-to-a-dollar mark and ended at 75.59, weaker by 64 paise.

Title: Equitas SFB misses March 31 IPO listing deadline
Content:
Chennai: Equitas Small Finance Bank (ESFB) will miss the March 31 deadline to list its shares on the bourses as mandated by regulators, as coronavirus pandemic and related lockdown spooked listing plans. The promoters are clueless on when the bank’s Initial public offering (IPO) will hit the market.

“We are in a 21-day lockdown and nothing can be done now,” said PN Vasudevan, MD and CEO of ESFB, who has already missed the first deadline to list the bank last September.

Under the RBI’s regulatory requirements, after a small finance bank reaches the net worth of Rs 500 crore, listing will be mandatory within three years of reaching that net worth. For small finance banks having net worth of below Rs 500 crore could also get their shares listed voluntarily, subject to fulfilment of the requirements of the capital markets regulator. In case of Equitas Small Finance Bank, the deadline was on or before September 4, 2019, which was extended to March 31.

“There is no clarity if this 21-day lockdown will extend or not. In such a case, how do we plan to list the bank,” Vasudevan asked.

Title: Police harassing us despite exemption: AIR
Content: Visakhapatnam: Despite exemption from the lockdown as per the Essential Services Maintenance Act (ESMA), an radio jockey (RJ) working for All India Radio (AIR) was detained by III Town police on Friday. He was on his way to work at around 5 pm, when a constable stopped his bike at Siripuram junction. According to the RJ, the cop seized his mobile phone and identity card and took him to the police station. A senior employee with AIR said, “The RJ on contract works for FM Rainbow and special IDs have been issued to those who are commuting to work. Despite being exempted under ESMA, our people are harassed by cops. The RJ was detained for over two hours and was not allowed to seek help. Finally, he narrated his ordeal to the SI and after some phone calls were made from AIR, he was let off.” tnn

Title: No entry of outside vehicles from today: Bihar DGP
Content: PATNA: DGP Gupteshwar Pandey on Monday said vehicles coming from outside the state would not be allowed to enter Bihar from Tuesday. “Those arriving at the state’s borders with Uttar Pradesh, Jharkhand and West Bengal will be stopped there and shifted to quarantine camps for 14 days after screening. Those found to be violating the lockdown will be punished under the law,” the DGP said.Pandey reiterated that the lockdown would be implemented in the state strictly. “Those who arrived earlier have already been sent quarantine centres set up in schools and panchayat buildings in their hometowns after screening. They are being provided food and accommodation free of cost,” the DGP said.He said special relief camps have been set up in all the bordering districts. Doctors and paramedical staff have been deputed there for screening people coming back to Bihar from other states.Meanwhile, the state authorities seem to be in no mood to let off those violating the lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus The tough action against people found to be flouting the lockdown can be gauged from the fact that altogether 195 people have been arrested and 339 FIRs lodged against them since March 24 in the state.Additional director general (headquarters) Jitendra Kumar said on Monday that 5,388 vehicles, including cars, were impounded and a sum of Rs 1.56 crore realised as penalty from respective vehicle owners during the period.The highest 53 arrests were made on March 29 followed by 40 on the very first day. Eight people were arrested on March 25, 36 on March 26 and 22 on March 28. Similarly 15 people were arrested on March 30. The highest 93 FIRs were lodged on March 25.The DGP said frequent violators of the lockdown would be booked under ‘Goonda Act’. “Instructions have been issued to the SPs to enforce the lockdown more effectively,” he said.Pandey clarified that the names of violators would be registered in ‘goonda’ registers at police stations. “Anybody found violating the lockdown willingly and trying to test drive the speed of bike or car will be punished under the Gunda Act,” he said.Meanwhile, the state police headquarters has deployed additional forces in the bordering districts to check influx of migrant workers from outside the state. They have been deployed at check posts along Bihar-UP, Bihar-Jharkhand and Bihar-West Bengal borders.

Title: Many migrant workers gatecrash sealed Nepal border
Content: BETTIAH/MOTIHARI: A near mirror image of crowds of migrant workers heading east from Delhi-NCR to UP, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh unfolded at the Birgunj-Raxaul border on early Monday morning as hundreds of them working in Nepali cities like Pokhara, Narayanghat, Hitauda and Parwanipur trekked to the closed border.Denied entry, the patiently waiting crowd was asked to report to the Indian consulate at Birgunj. “ In view of the total lockdown, we could not allow them to enter,” Raxaul SDM Amit Kumar said over phone, adding that the consulate is making arrangements for their shelter and food at Birgunj.Early last Monday, Nepal had closed its borders, almost coinciding with the lockdown on the Indian side with Bihar having declared its lockdown that day itself. With fears of the Covid-19 pandemic escalating, Indian migrant workers, mostly from East, West Champaran, Gopalganj and Siwan trekked to the Birgunj-Raxaul border. Many hitch-hiked from Pokhara and Mankaamna temple hub on the Muglin-Kathmandu highway.“ We arranged for bread and biscuits for the tired, forlorn working class Indians stuck at the border, but the authorities did not allow the distribution and the food items were returned,” social activist Mahesh Agarwal in Raxaul rued. “Over 2,000 fatigued migrants just squatted on the road,” he said over phone.“Many went for their morning ablutions on the banks of the Sariswa rivulet running through the No-Man’s land between the borders on either side,” Agarwal further said, adding, “About 500 fled wading through the water and successfully made a run to home ground though the porous borderline. Many others, familiar with the borderline topography, moved eastward from the gated border and slipped in through places like Bhelwa, Pantokha, Ahirwa tola, Adapur and Chaura Daano.”Raxaul SDM, meanwhile, said they were no more than a few hundred people who turned up at the border on Nepal side. However, the SDM’s claims were belied by the afternoon when hundreds of such migrants reached and cut through Motihari, the headquarters of East Champaran district.“We hitched rides on tankers but mostly walked,” said Ravi Kant, who worked in a hotel at Pokhara and crossed Motihari on way to his native Hardia village in Kotwa block.Others like Shyama Kant, Girija and Pathalu were part of a 16 strong group from Pokhara who, after breaching the sealed border, had reached Motihari on their way back home. Kamlesh Kumar from Kotwa and Ravi from Areraj were returning from the Mankaamna temple complex where they worked in a hotel nearby.East Champaran DM Shirsat Kapil Ashok said the lockdown has to be maintained at the border. “I have spoken to consul-general Nitesh Kumar, who is setting up a relief and medical camp for Indian citizens stuck at Birgunj. The DM denied that migrants had slipped in through the open border points of Nepal adjoining East Champaran. “I have no such information...will find out,” he said.

Title: Prashant Kishor demands Nitish Kumar to step down as CM
Content:
.#Corona संक्रमण से लोगों को बचाने के सरकारी प्रयासों की एक और भयावह तस्वीर - भारी तकलीफ़ और मुसीबतों को झेलकर दे… https://t.co/HOH8uaQD9x — Prashant Kishor (@PrashantKishor) 1585516243000

PATNA: Three days after lauding him for announcing Rs100 crore relief package for the migrant workers and the destitute in Bihar, poll strategist and former JD(U) national vice-president Prashant Kishor on Monday demanded Bihar CM Nitish Kumar to step down for mismanagement in handling people returning from other states.“Another frightening picture of state government’s efforts for saving people from Covid-19 infection. Such arrangements made by Nitish Kumar for social distancing and quarantine for people returning to the state from all over the country after facing much hardship is heart-rending. Nitish must quit (sic),” Kishor tweeted.Kishor has also tagged a video clip in which many people can be seen locked inside a facility and one of them is crying for going home in Siwan. “We are locked here for past five years. We reached here after lots of hardship and the officials here are saying that they are arranging buses but no vehicle has come so far for taking us,” the man is heard saying while crying.JD(U) functionaries lashed out at Kishor for his statement. “He cannot mislead people. Bihar was the first state to introduce lockdown. Steps were initiated through resident commissioner in Delhi to trace and help migrant workers from Bihar across the country. Various welfare schemes were also taken, including advance disbursement of pension, three months scholarship to students from standard 1 to 12 and setting up disaster relief centres for homeless people in urban areas among others,” JD(U) spokesperson Rajiv Ranjan Prasad said, adding that Kishor should rather question the Arvind Kejriwal government for not being able to handle the migrant labourers in Delhi.Earlier on March 26, Kishor had hailed the Bihar government for helping migrant labours. “After all the public outcry, government of Bihar has announced new measures to help daily wage workers an poor people stranded across India due to the lockdown. This includes additional fund of Rs100 crore from CM Relief Fund. Thank you all for adding your voice to the cause; Nitish Kumar Ji as well,” Kishor had tweeted.

Title: RIL donates Rs 500 crore to PM’s fund, ONGC contributes Rs 300 crore
Content:
MUMBAI: As coronavirus cases rise in the country, more and more companies are coming forward with monetary and other packages to help the government in its preventive and rescue operations against the pandemic. And those that have already announced support are enhancing their commitments.

Reliance Industries ( RIL ), which last week announced the setting up of India’s first 100-bed dedicated Covid-19 hospital in Mumbai, said on Monday that it has donated Rs 500 crore to the Prime Minister’s relief fund. This makes the energy-to-education enterprise the largest corporate contributor to the emergency relief fund launched by PM Narendra Modi last week.

Besides RIL, PSU oil producer ONGC donated Rs 300 crore to the relief fund instituted by the Centre. ONGC’s contribution is the biggest support offered by a PSU in India’s ongoing fight against the virus onslaught.

Engineering giant Larsen & Toubro and government-owned miner NMDC too pledged Rs 150 crore each to the relief fund while Ahmedabad-based Torrent, New Delhi-located Hero and Bengaluru-headquartered Infosys committed Rs 100 crore each to various Covid-19 relief initiatives with half of the sum going to the newly formed PM’s citizen assistance fund.

Coronavirus cases have crossed the 1,200 mark even as the nation is in the midst of a three-week economic and social lockdown. The corporate commitments are increasing while the ongoing lockdown impacts businesses hugely.

TVS Group, which last week announced a Rs 30-crore support for supply of masks and tractors fitted with disinfectant spray, said on Monday that it will donate an additional Rs 25 crore to the PM’s relief fund. Contributions to the PM’s relief fund are exempted from income tax and qualify as CSR expenditure that companies are mandated to make.

Besides donations, these companies are providing ventilators among other medical devices (which are currently in shortage) and offering their hostels, guesthouses, training centres and hospitals as quarantine centres to ease the pressure on government-run medical facilities.

L&T has also set aside Rs 500 crore per month to support 1.60 lakh contract workers by continuing to pay their wages during the ongoing lockdown. The shutdown has dried up jobs in cities for rural migrants, which form a large chunk of the country’s workforce, forcing them to walk miles to head back to their homes. The Shapoorji Pallonji Group also announced that it will take care of its 70,000-plus migrant workers.

Further, Mumbai-based Mankind Pharma has donated Rs 51 crore to Covid-19 relief funds, while Asian Paints has committed Rs 35 crore. Medicine-maker Hetero, textile-to-power group LNJ Bhilwara and financial services firm IIFL too contributed Rs 10 crore, Rs 6 crore and Rs 5 crore to the said schemes, respectively.

Title: 182 coronavirus samples test negative in Bihar
Content: PATNA: Samples of altogether 182 persons who came to Bihar from various countries on or after March 18, were found Covid-19 negative on Monday. Of the total samples, around 46 were collected in Gaya.Director, Rajendra Memorial Research Institute ( RMRI ), Patna, Dr Pradeep Das, said that samples of 182 people, who returned from abroad earlier this month, were tested in the institute. “All the samples that were tested on Monday were of asymptomatic people who returned from foreign countries few days back,” he said.Earlier samples of only those with symptoms similar to Covid-19 were tested. But now samples of all those who entered the state on or after March 18 are being tested. “Most of the samples came from from Gaya, Vaishali, Gopalganj and Darbhanga. All these persons had returned to their native places in Bihar from foreign countries where they worked as daily wage earners, technicians etc. They have been asked to complete the 14-day home quarantine period,” Dr Das said.State nodal officer for Covid-19, Dr Ragini Mishra said, “So far, 869 samples were tested at RMRI, Patna, of which 840 were found negative and 15 were positive. Results of 11 samples are awaited, while three were rejected on several grounds,” she said.

Title: Ludhiana gets 10 shelter homes for the poor
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Ten buildings in Ludhiana have been designated as shelter homes for the homeless and the needy by the district administration. During the curfew, the homeless will be provided shelter, food and medical facilities here.

District magistrate-cum-deputy commissioner Pradeep Kumar Agrawal said the arrangement has been made under the Disaster Management Act 2005. A station house officer level official will be deputed as incharge of each shelter home.

These buildings are located at Partap Singh Wala village (9878903301, 9878903300), Mundian Kalan (9878903302), Gaunsgarh on Rahon Road (9878903303, 9779459933), Lohara (9878903304), Kadian (9878903305, 8146605050), Lalton Kalan (9878903306), Kailash Nagar Bajra Road (9878903307, 9779590353), Tibba Road (9878903308, 9878941815), village Gill (9878903309, 9878903210) and Noorwala Road Phambra (9878903310, 9779590300).

Agrawal said the needy and the homeless can also get in touch with their nearest police station to get lodged in shelter homes. The DC has appealed to the migrants moving towards other states to make use of these shelter homes and follow guidelines related to the lockdown.

Title: FCI to supply 55,000 MT wheat to Bihar: Sushil Kumar Modi
Content: PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi said on Monday that there will be no scarcity of wheat and flour (ata) in the state as the Centre has asked the Food Corporation of India (FCI) to supply 55,000 metric tonne (MT) of wheat to flour mills and foodgrain dealers in Bihar to meet the shortfall, while ITC has also assured the state government to resume and sustain the supply of its Ashirvaad brand of ‘ata’ (flour), soon.“Following the request of the state government, the Centre has directed FCI to supply the aforesaid quantity of wheat to flour mills and foodgrain dealers to meet the need for a month, as the newly-harvested wheat would not be available in the market before the second week of April,” Modi said.He added that the supply of wheat by FCI would help tide over the likely shortage. FCI will be supplying wheat in two phases to 13 flour mills and foodgrain dealers in Patna and also to 98 others in the remaining districts having flour mills.“Apart from Patna, wheat will be also supplied to flour mills and foodgrain dealers in Nalanda, Bhojpur, Buxar, Kaimur, Rohtas, Gaya, Bhagalpur, Jamui, Sitamarhi, Darbhanga and Saharsa districts among others, besides those at Hajipur and other areas of Vaishali district. The FCI will supply 22,800 MT of wheat to Patna and other districts in the first phase,” SuMo said.For meeting the high demand for Ashirvaad brand of ‘ata (flour)’ produced by ITC, the latter has informed the state government that all arrangements for transportation of this brand of flour has been and its Muzaffarpur mill will soon resume production in two shifts to meet the demand.Further, ITC has also streamlined the production and transportation of the flour of its popular brand from its unit located at Asansol in West Bengal, the deputy CM said adding that there would be no scarcity of flour in the state due to its factory production and also for the reason that newly-harvested wheat will also start arriving in the market by the second week of April.

Title: SHRC seeks report on safety of fire force personnel
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The government should ensure safety of fire and rescue personnel involved in sanitising public places in the state following the outbreak of Covid-19 pandemic, the state human rights commission (SHRC) said.Commission member P Mohanadas said the director general of fire and rescue and additional chief secretary, home, should ensure their safety and submit a report within three weeks.The SHRC order came following a complaint that adequate safety precautions were not being provided to the fire and rescue service officials who are currently engaged in sanitising areas like bus stands, vehicles, public places, streets, stores and hospitals where Covid-19 affected patients’ presence were reported.The complaint said there were no guidelines in place that describes the precautionary measures that are to be taken while performing the task.They were also not provided with gloves or face masks. Most of the times, these were being provided by the residents of the respective localities where the clean up was being carried out, the complaint said.It further said the fire service personnel were under immense mental stress and senior officials were not bothered about the officials involved in such activities. The case will be considered by the commission in its sitting to be held in Alappuzha.

Title: No jobs or money: Migrants want to go home, regardless of shelters
Content: MUMBAI/THANE: Days after he walked more than 100km from Vasai to the Maharashtra-Gujarat border only to find it sealed, Naresh Bagora and 700 other migrant workers have been accommodated at a camp in a nearby school at Talasari.Although they are being served poha for breakfast and dal and rice for meals, many want to return to their villages, fearful of contracting the virus in Mumbai. “We will be safer in our village in Rajasthan,” said Bagora.At the PCMC shelter in Panvel, as many as 20 migrants have already disappeared, said official Vinaya Mhatre. Now, security has been tightened. With no jobs or money, many would prefer to wait it out in their villages than at temporary shelters.At the Cidco Exhibition Centre in Vashi, which is accommodating 232 migrant workers, Inder Yadav (21), who worked as a mechanic at a garage in Mumbai, told TOI: “Since eateries were shut, we had no option but to leave for Gorakhpur.”“It will be better if the government sends us home in buses. I used to earn Rs 300 a day. Now, we make nothing,” said Anil Kumar, a construction worker from UP.On Sunday, in a bid to curb the exodus of migrants to villages after the lockdown, the Centre ordered that borders be sealed and that states provide for migrants. By Monday, the Maharashtra government had started 265 camps. The state has sanctioned Rs 45 crore for such relief camps. Of this, Rs 15 crore is for Konkan division, Rs 10 crore for Pune division and Rs 5 crore each for Nagpur, Nashik, Aurangabad and Amravati divisions.Despite the camps, TOI encountered a group of 10 attempting to walk from Mumbai to Gulbarga on Monday. Even though TOI told them they can stay in various shelters, they said they had no faith in the police.At the Cidco camp, migrants complained there were no bathing facilities and they were besieged by mosquitoes. “At the moment, we cannot take a bath here. There are also too many mosquitoes at night. Also, we are getting rice, but not rotis,” said UP migrant Inder Yadav.Deputy municipal commissioner D Chabukswar of Navi Mumbai Municipal Corporation told TOI: “We are constructing makeshift bathrooms for the workers. They are using toilets now.”Some at the camp want to return to their own shanties in Mumbai, “if the government can provide us food,” said construction worker Purya Rathod from Karnataka.Sunil Solanki (45), a migrant from Indore. is desperate to go home. “My family will suffer without financial assistance from me,” he said .(With Vijay Singh, Sandhya Nair, Umesh K Parida, Bhavika Jain & S Ahmed Ali)

Title: Medicos seek safety gear, call for ‘silent boycott’ from today
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana Junior Doctors’ Association (TJUDA) has given a representation to the authorities seeking supply of personal protection equipment (PPE). They also called for a ‘silent boycott’ of duty from March 31, at Niloufer Hospital.

TJUDA took the decision after a three-year-old boy had tested positive with resident doctors exposed to him while attending to him. “We don’t want to end up as Covid-19 carriers. If we are provided PPE, we will be able to attend our duties without any worries,” Mahesh, spokesperson of TJUDA, told TOI.

Members of TJUDA said the authorities should understand that a doctor can act as a carrier of novel coronavirus and spread it to hundreds of patients as happened in Bhilwara, Rajasthan.

Dr Srinivas of resident doctors’ association said they had submitted a representation to health minister Eatala Rajender. “So far, no safety gears have been provided to us,” he added.

Title: Employees use free time to upskill, learn new tech
Content:
Namrata Singh & Aparna Desikan | TNN

Mumbai/Chennai: In these unprecedented Covid-19 times, when India Inc is challenged by factory shutdowns in several sectors, there’s one aspect that’s remained unaffected — learning and development (L&D). With work-from-home (WFH) becoming the norm, professionals are making the most of their extra time indoors by enhancing their skills and capabilities.

Digital learning platforms are witnessing a spike in enrolments. UpGrad has recorded an increase of 30-35% in enrolments in the last couple of weeks for professional and individual learners. “We have also seen 50% higher leads from individuals in this period,” said UpGrad co-founder Mayank Kumar.

Great Learning co-founder Hari Krishnan Nair said, “We are receiving tens of thousands of visitors daily on free learning resources. Content consumption for our learning programmes is seeing a 3x increase week on week.” Most of the surge is coming from metro cities with increased enquiries from cities such as Pune, Noida and Kochi.

At Simplilearn, sales professionals whose job role entailed being in the field are now taking up learning. “There is also a 20% jump in enrolment from individual learners for data science,” said CEO and co-founder Krishna Kumar.

Corporate India, which usually draws up an L&D calendar for the year starting April, is also shifting to virtual modes to ensure there’s continuity in learning. Siemens, for instance, is encouraging its employees to enhance their competencies through a digital platform, which the company has launched. Siemens India MD & CEO Sunil Mathur said, “Continuous learning is an essential ingredient and integral part of every employee’s development in Siemens. With the speed at which technology changes, it is imperative for each one of our employees to ensure, for their own development, that they are continuously updated on the nuances of each new innovation. At this time, when all our employees are working from home, we are encouraging them to further their competencies through the launch of ‘My Growth’, a unique digital platform. It combines the power of two levers — ‘My Learning World’ and ‘Own your Career’ — for holistic individual learning and development.”

There are two kinds of learning. One is instructor-led, which either takes place in person or virtually. This is preferred for leadership and behavioural learning and development. The second is self-placed learning, which — along with virtual instructor-led learning — is preferred for technical, functional and professional learning. Self-placed learning can be taken according to the participant’s schedule.

At Siemens, employees are encouraged to use the multiple offerings of self-paced, virtual instructor-led sessions, and from simulated war rooms to digital immersions on a variety of topics through the digital learning platform.

RPG Group head (organisation & talent development) Syed Azfar Hussain said, “Most of our L&D has moved online. Earlier in the year, after employees created their development action plans, learning programmes and other learning assets were assigned to them. We had drawn up an L&D calendar for the next financial year, beginning in April. Because of the Covid-19 outbreak, all in-person instructor-led programmes have been moved to June-July. Nearly all (85%) technical/functional L&D programmes are progressing through virtual instructor-led and self-paced methodology.”

A combination of both internal as well as external faculty is used to enable L&D. “For behavioural learning, we are trying to replace in-person with self-paced content. However, in leadership learning, it’s difficult to do this without compromising effectiveness. This may get postponed to June-July. Our coaching and mentoring programmes are also going on as scheduled and are not impacted because these can be entirely done virtually,” said Hussain.

Capstone People Consulting’s learning and organisational development round-table is offering ‘webinars’ on reinventing in times of adversity, which are attended by up to 300 professionals. Capstone People Consulting CEO Sujaya Banerjee said, “Keeping the learning curve steep is key in times of adversity. We are working with many of our clients to enable their employees to use this downtime meaningfully for reflection, internalising new insights for thinking differently and arming themselves with the best thought leadership to combat new challenges and difficulties we are likely to encounter on the other side.”

Title: Lack of options to ferry produce leaves veggies to rot in north Bengal fields
Content:
TimesView It is essential to keep this chain moving while conforming to the lock-down guidelines. We have to get used to this new situation and work within the limits it imposes.

KOLKATA: If you find vegetables heavy on the pocket now, don’t just blame it on hoarding by unscrupulous traders during the lockdown. The ground reality is a little different. TOI had earlier reported how potatoes were rotting in fields in North Bengal as farmers were unable to find transport to send the produce to wholesalers.
