Now, fields in West and East Midnapore, Hooghly, and North and South 24 Parganas are suffering the same fate.The farmers there have been forced to harvest only a small part of their produce — only the quantity they know they can sell in local markets where they can ferry it on cycle vans. The remainder has been left to rot in the fields.“Had times been normal, I would have harvested the entire produce and sent it to Kolkata. But now there are no trains or trucks plying. How much can I send on small goods carriers like motor vans?” asked Gobinda Phatik of Shibhati village in Gatbeta, West Midnapore.However, farmers in Hooghly’s Nalikul, Dankuni, Dhaniakhali, Singur and Chanditala say they are earning a good profit on whatever they manage to send to Kolkata.“We have divided ourselves into groups of seven to eight farmers and loading vegetables from each of our fields on small goods carriers. From Hooghly, we head to Tandelbagan, where some of us offload a small quantity for sale in Howrah. Most of the vegetables are then taken to Kolkata. I am getting a very good price for my produce. I was selling ridge gourd for Rs 30 a kg in our local market. But in Kolkata, I got Rs 50,” said Prasanta Khan of Nalikul.Farmers and agriculture department officials in East and West Burdwan said they were keeping fingers crossed and hoping to find labourers to harvest paddy by the end of April. Farmers in Bircham and Murshidabad, however, have been selling their products at local markets.

Title: Lockdown hits transgenders hard in Bihar
Content:
PATNA: Members of transgender community are facing one of the worst crises in their lives due to nationwide lockdown .

The community members depend on daily earnings through ‘badhai’ visits to families on auspicious occasions like child birth, marriage and a few other holy occasions. Nowadays, their source of income has dried up as they can’t move out.

“Our community members have reached on the verge of starvation as they have been earning nothing since ‘janata curfew’ on March 22,” transgender activist Reshma Prasad told TOI on Monday.

According to Reshma, there are around 40,000 transgenders in Bihar. Of them, around 2,500 live in Patna district alone and only 60 to 70 live with their biological families.

“Most of the transgenders reside in groups with their ‘guru’ in different localities of the state capital. Most of them live in rented accommodations. Some of them live in slum areas as they have low income. Their main source of income is through ‘Badhai’ visits or dance performance. Around 800 to 900 members residing in the state capital are solely dependent on the Badhai earnings,” Reshma, who is also the secretary of Dostana Safar, a community based social organization, told TOI.

“As they are following the government’s guidelines during the lockdown, their only source of income has dried up,” said another transgender activist Anupriya Singh. “Those living with ‘gharana’ of their gurus are worst sufferers, as they cannot move out due to the lockdown,” Singh said.

Santosh Guru, who heads a family of around 20 transgender people in Mithapur area, said, “When people are not coming out of their homes, to whom we will seek financial assistance. In the last seven days, we spent whatever little savings we had. With no concrete help coming from the government side, we are now on the verge of starvation,” she said over the phone.

“We live in a rented house at Mithapur and pay Rs5,000 per month. In general days, we cook meals ourselves. Sometimes we take meals at roadside eateries. Due to lockdown, all eateries are now closed. We are running our kitchens by taking grocery items on credit from nearby shops. If the grocery shopowner stops giving us credit, we will die of starvation,” Santosh said.

“With the assistance of Dostana safar, the Bihar Electric Traders’ Association on last Friday distributed packets of grocery items among the community members. But such assistance is not enough. More social organizations should come forward to help out the community members,” said Dimple Jasmine, another transgender activist.

Title: Karnataka: Bootleggers thrive as liquor outlets remain shut
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MYSURU: With the liquor outlets and pubs closing its doors on consumers in the wake of Prime Minister’s call for 21-day lockdown, a parallel grey foreign liquor market is thriving in the state.

Although the state government shut down all kinds of liquor shops, bars and restaurants till March 31 to check the spread of novel corona virus, the closure has encouraged the illegal sale of liquor in many places and paved a way for bootleggers to make fast buck.

“Liquor is being sold in grocery shops illegally in rural areas of the district. In some parts of the city, people had to cough up more than double the standard price for booze being sold illegally,” said a resident of T Narasipura taluk.

However, excise officials has denied the allegation. “Police and the department officials will initiate legal action against illegal sale of liquor. If anyone is seen violating the order, their license will be terminated,” said an excise department official.

This is the first instance in the recent years the liquor stores in the state were closed for more than a week. The closure of liquor outlets had brought cheers among women as well activists after a steep fall in alcohol-induced anti-social activities. Cases of miscreants indulging in random acts of violence had also dropped considerably following the lockdown, claimed police sources.

The district has 558 wholesale and retail liquor shops, including military canteens, pubs, star hotels, clubs, bars attached to restaurants and wine stores. Over 200 of them are retail shops (CL 2 license holders), followed by 17 clubs (CL 4), 3 star hotels, 134 boarding and lodging (CL 70), 138 bar and restaurants(CL 9), 30 MSIL outlets (CL 11), military canteens (CL 8), 32 wine stores and other shops.

Mysuru district is second highest revenue fetching division after Bengaluru to the government in excise sales and orders, said excise department officials.

13 special team formed to check illegal liquor sale

Speaking to TOI, deputy commissioner (excise) K Murali said the department has constituted 13 special team, including five teams in city limits, to check bootlegging in the district.

“If anyone is found selling in grocery store, they will be arrested, cases will be booked and penalised. The department has not yet received any communication from the government regarding the relaxation for liquor shops after March 31 also,” he said.

Title: Tigers roam in the wild unseen, undeterred as lockdown keeps visitors out of reserves
Content: Mysuru: The lockdown may have caused lot of hardships to ordinary people, but it has also brought some good fortune for wildlife, especially the tigers in the reserve forests. The big cats, which were under tremendous pressure due to regular movement of safari vehicles and disturbances caused by tourists, are now freely prowling in their respective territories.The state has five tiger reserves – Nagarahole National Park, Bandipur Tiger Reserve, Male (Malai) Mahadeshwara Wildlife Sanctuary, Biligiri Ranganathaswamy Temple Tiger Reserve (both in Chamarajanagar district), Badra Tiger Reserve (Chikkamagaluru district) and Kali Tiger Reserve (at Dandeli in Shivamogga district).The reserves together house 524 tigers and 6,049 elephants as per the latest census.“Heavy movement of safari vehicles and tourists, especially during weekends in Bandipur and Nagarahole, has caused lot of stress on the tigers. Such stress reduces the life span of wild animals in the reserves,” said Krithika Alanahally, wildlife warden of Mysuru.“The ban on vehicles has also reduced air and noise pollution and brought incidents of road kills to zero. The forest officers and staff can now concentrate more on monitoring the forest to prevent any fire incidents and poaching activities,” she said.While safari has been banned in the reserves, the government has also restricted regular vehicle movements inside the forests, allowing only goods vehicles carrying essential items and other emergency vehicles to pass through the check-posts.Bandipur conservator of forests and field director, project tiger, T Balachandra told TOI that wild animals are very happy after the ban on vehicles.“We see animals, especially elephants, deers, sambars, leopards and others on the roads resting and roaming freely without any disturbance. There is a ban on public carriers and only vehicles carrying essential goods like milk, vegetables and ambulances are allowed to cross the check-posts. Meanwhile, we are vigilant to prevent fire and poaching activities. All the forest ranges have received light rainfall and another one or two showers will ensure that there will be no fire incident this summer,” he said.Male (Malai) Mahadeshwara Wildlife Sanctuary, which houses nearly 20 tigers, is all set to be declared as Male (Malai) Mahadeshwara Hills Tiger Reserve.Speaking to TOI, DCF V Yedukondalu said that all check-posts are closed and only emergency vehicles are allowed.“Animals are happy and sleep on the road. We have received good rainfall and there is greenery everywhere. Since there is no traffic, there are no accidents as well,” he said.

Title: Hunger, not corona, will kill us: Bihar migrant workers
Content:
Passengers who have arrived from different states Migrant workers leave in overloaded buses at near Mithapur b... Read More

PATNA: “Coronavirus hame khak marega. Hum to mar chuke hain, saheb. Char-panch dinon se bhukha pyasa hain. Pair mein chhale par gaye hain. Ab chala nahi ja raha hai. Sanse ukhad rahi hain,” this is how a 45-year-old migrant worker, Md Irshad, narrated his tale at a check post at Bihar-UP border in Gopalganj district on Monday.

Irshad, a resident of Bettiah in West Champaran district, reached from Delhi to go to his native place. He worked at a leather bag manufacturing unit in the national capital. Irshad had departed from Delhi with a group of seven people after the factory was shut following nationwide lockdown.

Irshad said he left for home with Rs 700, which his employer had given him. The story of his journey from Delhi to Kushinagar in UP, close to Gopalganj in Bihar, is heart rendering. “We spent night in the open without food. At some places, we hired autorickshaws and ‘jugad gadi’ to reach Kushinagar. However, we mostly walked on foot,” he said.

Most members of the group led by Irshad had not been able to contact their family for the last two days. “Our cellphones have stopped working. The battery is very low. We are worried about our family members as they are waiting for us at home,” he said.

Irshad is not alone. Around 15,000 migrant workers from Delhi, Punjab, Haryana, Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra have arrived on the Bihar-UP border in Gopalganj, Siwan and Saran districts during the last 24 hours. They are in a hurry to reach their homes as the government has banned the entry of buses and other modes of transportation completely.

In Araria, adequate arrangements are being made to quarantine and provide food to all workers returning from different states. “Around 80 workers have arrived at Narpatganj and 40 at Bhargama. We are making all efforts to manage their stay and keep them in isolation for 14 days before they are allowed to leave for their homes,” Araria DM Prashant Kumar C H said.

Altogether 41 people were kept in isolation cell in Araria district. However, none of them was found positive. A six-page home quarantine diary is being issued to each quarantined person, so that the affected one or the source person – the carrier of Covid-19 – could be detected. The diary holders have to write the names and cellphone numbers of the people they were in contact with in the last 15 days.

In Nawada, despite the district administrations’ ceaseless efforts to tackle the huge influx of migrant workers, arrangements to get them medically examined and provide them with timely food did not go as planned.

Bablu Mandal (23), worker at a pulse mill in West Bengal and a native of Naugachia in Bhagalpur, who was put up at the isolation centre at ITI grounds besides NH-31 three days ago, alleged that the doctors have not examined him yet. DM Yashpal Meena and SP Hari Prasath were seen handling the huge number of migrants who have arrived from Odisha, West Bengal and Jharkhand at Chitrkoli along Jharkhand border.

In Gaya, 43 Jamui-bound workers, who came from Allahabad, have been quarantined at Nigma monastery in Bodh Gaya. DM Abhishek Singh visited the monastery on Monday and inspected the facilities. The DM directed the officials concerned to religiously follow the quarantine protocol.

(With inputs from L P Nayak in Araria, S B Sinha in Nawada and Abdul Qadir in Gaya)

Title: Liquor mafia, boozers having a field day during lockdown
Content:
VARANASI: At a time when people are struggling to arrange even essential commodities during the ongoing nationwide lockdown in view of COVID-19 threat, the liquor mafia in the region as well as boozers are having a field day.

Only in past four days, the cops in Varanasi and surrounding districts have not only witnessed the menace of liquor mafia pumping in huge consignments of liquor in the neighbouring dry state of Bihar, but also cases of black marketing of liquor and even theft in liquor shops have kept them on their toes.

On March 28 late night, a band of thieves breached the rear wall of a country liquor shop in Nandpur area under the limits of Kapsethi police station in Varanasi and fled with 20 boxes full of 180 ml bottles. After the matter came to light on March 30 morning the owner of building in which the shop is located reported the matter to the police.

Before it on March 27 SP Sonbhadra Ashish Srivastava led an operation of district police in which three smuggled liquor-laden truck were stoppd near Khairahi on Sonbhadra-Mirzapur highway. When the containers of trucks were checked secret cavities were detected. The liquor smugglers had hidden bottles containing 72,226.64 litres of branded liquor packed in 825 boxes in the cavities.

Srivastava said, “Following their arrest the drivers of three truck including Rajesh, Jagmendra of Haryana and Shivnath of Bihar divulged that the liquor consignment had been given to them by some Sonu at Sonipat in Haryana to deliver at Muzaffarpur in Bihar.”

He said that apart from liquor three trucks and mobile phones of drivers had been seized.

Again on March 27, the Badagaon cops, who were patrolling Siswa fruit market to ensure proper enforcement of lockdown, in Varanasi caught a person engaged in black marketing of the liquor. A total of 19 bottles of liquor were recovered from his possession.

District excise officer Varanasi Karunendra Singh said, ”With the promulgation of lockdown, a blanket ban is imposed on sale of liquor. The current financial year is ending on Tuesday, but due to lockdown since March 25 no process of counting of old stock could take place so far. We are waiting for the order of state government to initiate this process and also decide the timing for the regularisation of the shops for next financial year.”

He said that his department was also investigating the issue.

Title: Sedate start to doorstep delivery in Dharwad
Content: Dharwad: The promised doorstep delivery of essential commodities in Dharwad began on a sedate note. Over 50 vehicles supplied vegetables and groceries, but were insufficient to meet the demand.The district administration is issuing passes to vendors who are delivering essential commodities on pushcarts, autorickshaws and vans. On Sunday, police cordoned off the APMC yard, the wholesale vegetable market which had seen heavy rush for the past several days, and did not allow retail sellers and buyers.“The only way to make people stay indoors is to ensure doorstep delivery of essentials. Rehabilitation and relief with public and private partnerships should be priority. There is an urgent need for bureaucratic leadership,” said a retired senior IPS officer.

Title: They are delivering goods by keeping trains on tracks
Content:
Nagpur: At a time when the country is completely lockdown owing to the coronavirus pandemic and people are mostly staying indoors, these railwaymen are at the forefront to ensure that freight services remain uninterrupted for essential supplies.

In the last two days, the Indian Railways loaded 71,261 freight wagons — 48,614 had essential commodities while 22,647 contained other important items. The list included foodgrains, sugar, salt, edible oil, coal and petroleum products.

Those keeping the trains on the tracks include running and passing staff, controllers and the ones who still remain on the field for asset management. These lockdown heroes are the loco pilots, their assistants and guards, station masters, pointsman, controllers and trackmen. Their jobs are interlinked.

“Freight trains have no normal timetable and there is no surety when we will return home. Keeping our concentration on the tracks for long hours and then maintaining family responsibilities is the toughest job. Though we are getting rid of human interface, the pandemic is always on our minds and we are delivering the goods by taking all the necessary precautions,” a section of loco pilots told TOI.

“The railways is taking precaution by not using breath analyser at the time of signing in and signing out. Our loco is also sanitized. With passenger trains off the tracks, the workload has gone down but the responsibility is always there. Last week, I drove an oil tanker rake and two coal rakes which were needed to be transported in time,” a loco pilot said.

Talking to TOI, South East Central Railway (SECR) divisional commercial manager (DCM) Anurag Singh, said, “Though loco pilots have a major role to play, the job of controllers, station masters, pointsman, trackmen cannot be seconded in the movement of trains. Those who maintain the OHE lines are equally important. Even if passenger trains are withdrawn, 55-60 freight trains are being operated in the division for which staff is on the field.”

In SECR, 50% of the over 3,000 cadre of civil engineering, operating, signalling, mechanical and electrical departments are at work. Similarly, the cadre of around 800 loco pilots and 400 guards is utilized similarly. The SECR division extends up to Durg while Central Railway reaches Itarsi, Ballarshah and Badnera.

“We are utilizing the services of 1250 loco pilots, 8 controllers, 400 station masters, 200 guards and 350 pointsman. Of the 4,000 trackmen, the services of 1,500 are used on a rotation basis. Unlike a gang of 15-20 earlier, now a group of 7 are maintaining the tracks with complete social distancing. We are not calling women employees,” said Central Railway spokesperson & ACM, SG Rao.

SECR’s Singh said controllers are the brains behind the movement of rail traffic within their section. It includes arranging crossing of trains, efficient utilization of wagons and formation of goods trains at junction stations.

“In the lockdown period, if a coal rake needs precedence to maintain supplies for power generation then other freight trains will get second preference,” said a controller.

“We are working like soldiers to supply essential commodities. There are no fixed duty hours and no specific stations where the train stops. Our brake van cabin has no lights and only a steel chair to sit on. Positioned at the rear, it gives terrible jerks when the train starts and stops,” they said.

“Even as most of the people and those working in the railways are indoors owing to lockdown, the loco pilots, guards, station masters, controllers and trackmen are the real heroes who have been standing tall despite the Covid-19 scare,” says SK Shukla, vice-president of the All India Guards Council (AIGC).

Title: Sebi relaxes rules for FPI registration, rating default
Content: MUMBAI: Through a series of circulars on Monday, Sebi relaxed several compliance provisions for market participants by up to three months due to the unusual situation that has emerged because of the coronavirus pandemic.Among the slew of decisions, the markets regulator allowed credit rating agencies (CRAs) to not qualify a Covid-19 related non-payment of interest and principal as default, and allowed foreign funds to send in scanned copies of documents for renewal of registration. It also extended the deadline for regulatory filing for alternate investment and venture capital funds till April 30 and also extended the second phase of UPI implementation for retail investors till further notice.In its circular on the ratings decision, Sebi said that in view of the three-month moratorium/deferment on payment permitted by the RBI, “a differentiation in treatment of default, on a case-to-case basis, needs to be made as to whether such default occurred solely due to the lockdown or loan moratorium. Accordingly, based on its assessment, if the CRA is of the view that the delay in payment of interest/principal has arisen solely due to the lockdown conditions…CRAs may not consider the same as a default event and/or recognise default.”This has been done to align Sebi’s guidelines along with the relaxations given by the RBI, market players said. For foreign portfolio investors (FPIs), Sebi allowed scanned copies of documents for renewing registration in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. “The relaxation has been given till June 30,” a Sebi circular said.

Title: No new cases in Vadodara in 48 hours
Content:
Three out of the seven admitted at SSG Hospital tested negative

VADODARA: In what comes as a huge relief for the Vadodara doctors and administration, the city did not register any fresh COVID-19 positive case for 48 straight hours.

Also, there is no deterioration in the condition of majority of the nine COVID-19 positive patients who are battling the deadly virus in the isolation ward of two major hospitals in the city.

Two of them, however, remain critical, hospital sources said.

Out of the seven COVID-19 positive cases, which are undergoing treatment at the isolation ward of state-run SSG Hospital, three have already tested negative.

These patients are being monitored in accordance with the isolation protocol.

Out of four other patients, one is on ventilator while another positive case is on bi-level positive airway pressure.

“There are two patients who are critical, but the condition of other patients have not deteriorated so far,” a hospital official said on Monday.

“The good sign for us is that we have tested more than 20 samples in the last two days and all of them have turned out COVID-19 negative,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.

On Sunday and Monday, seven new suspected cases were admitted in the isolation ward, of which six were discharged after their samples tested negative while report of one patient, a 27-year-old youth from Karelibaug, is awaited.

Title: Eight-year-old murdered after failed rape bid
Content:
Bareilly: A man was detained on Monday for allegedly attempting to rape an eight-year-old girl and strangling her to death before dumping her body in Fatehganj West area in Bareilly district.

The girl's autopsy report revealed that she was strangled after an attempt to rape failed.

The autopsy was conducted by a panel of three doctors on Sunday. A person known to the victim was detained. Further investigations are on.

According to police. the girl went missung on Saturday evening. When her family could not find her, they made announcements over the local mosque's PA system.

Other villagers joined the search. Finally, her body was found in the early hours of Sunday morning. Police were summoned.

The body was found in a public toilet.A local woman had seen a man dumping something in the toilet. She raised an alarm. The man fled.

When the toilet was checked, the girl's body was found.

After getting information about the incident, additional SP (rural) Sansaar Singh reached the village and took stock of the situation.

An FIR under IPC sections 376(rape) and 302(murder), besides provisions under POCSO has been registered.

Title: No more queues, all bank branches in West Bengal to remain open
Content:
Customers queue up outside a bank on Monday

KOLKATA: In keeping with the latest directive from the State Level Bankers Committee (SLBC), all bank branches in the state have been asked to resume normal operations — for full banking hours till 4pm — from Monday. However, the circular has put bank employees and officers in a fix as no transport arrangement has been made to ferry them to and from their offices during the 21-day lockdown. Additionally, many bank staffers are worried that regular contact with customers, especially during the first few days of the new-month rush, could prove to be hazardous for them.

The SLBC circular said all bank branches, irrespective of location, will remain open till 4pm on all working days and all ATMs will function 24x7. They will be replenished with cash on a regular basis.

Sikha Das, a savings account holder at United Bank of India (UBI) who waited in queue for three hours on Monday, said this decision will be of huge relief to many like her.

“I have been running from one branch to another since last week just to withdraw Rs 2,000. Most of the time I was told that either the cashier or the manager was absent. I was helpless as my son doesn’t stay here and my husband is paralysed,” Das told TOI outside the Haridevpur branch.

Another customer, S K Ghosh, complained about the serpentine queues in front of branches. “Eventually, cops had to intervene to open a single counter at the branch I visited,” he said.

However, the general secretary of Bengal Provincial Bank Employees’ Association (BPBEA), Rajen Nagar, reasoned that there were 12,000 branches in the state and it was not easy to man them fully at this juncture when public transport was not available. “We have told the banks that employees, except for those who stay near the offices, need to be given transportation facilities. Apart from that, sanitization of branches and social distancing norms have to be followed,” he added.

Avijit Roy, a senior bank employee at the SBI’s Bangur branch, comes to work from Barasat. “I travel on my two-wheeler every day, but many of my colleagues had to skip work in absence of public transport,” he said.

The former deputy chief secretary of SBI Staff Association, Ashok Mukherjee, said that along with customers, safety of the bank staffers was also of great importance.

Nagar pointed out that a lot of customers may come to their branches in the next six-seven days for pension, NREGA payments and other reasons. “We have to ensure social distancing in the offices,” he added.

Sailen Das, a customer at an SBI branch in Howrah, however, lauded the efforts taken in the short-staffed branch. “In the branch that I visit, the employees took adequate care of all customers and ensured that the social distancing rules were followed,” he said.

Title: Stranded migrant workers take long walk back home
Content:
Migrant daily wage earners in the city on their way back home

Visakhapatnam: Migrant daily wage workers in Visakhapatnam city are taking the long way back home. Faced with the closure of commercial establishments amid the 21-day lockdown and fears of a loss of livelihood and the conditions back home, many of them, from Chhattisgarh and Odisha , have decided to walk home.

While authorities at the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) have made arrangements for accommodation and food for stranded daily wage earners, many have instead chosen the risk of crossing interstate borders over the uncertainty of remaining in the city as supply of essential items runs low.

Anil Kumar, part of a team from the Ramakrishna Mission in Visakhapatnam said, “We scouted for some people who might have been stranded on the highway and picked up five people, two of whom were on their way to Vizianagaram towm, another to Odisha and two more to Chattisgarh. We dropped them at the Anandapuram junction, while insisting all along that they return to Vizag, where they would be provided food and shelter.”

The team from Ramakrishna Mission also provided food and water to the workers who insisted on walking home. The GVMC commissioner had also been informed about the situation, they said.

The migrant workers will have to trek across the hilly Andhra-Odisha border in order to avoid border checkposts. They will also be stopped for checks at every major town they pass through and the Konavalasa checkpost in AP and Sunki checkpost in Odisha.

Title: Delhi Corona News: Delhi could use Jawahar Lal Nehru stadium to shelter labourers
Content:
The JLN stadium has 150 beds at its hostel facility located indoors (File photo)

NEW DELHI: With Covid-19 cases in the national capital on the rise, Delhi government has stepped up its fight against the pandemic by turning the city’s biggest sports arena – the Jawahar Lal Nehru (JLN) stadium at Lodhi Road – into a quarantine facility with “immediate effect” to house affected people.

This is the second instance and first in the city where a sports facility is being used to quarantine suspected coronavirus patients. Earlier, Sports Authority of India (SAI) had handed over its boxing training facility in Rohtak to the Haryana government to set up an isolation facility. SAI’s five stadia in the city can provide quarantine facilities for around 900 people.

On Monday evening, the office of the district magistrate (DM) of South East Delhi issued an order to the secretary SAI, directing him to immediately hand over the possession of the stadium to the district administration of the South East. The order – a copy of which is with TOI – signed by DM Harleen Kaur, who is also the chairperson of the District Disaster Management Authority (DDMA, South East), stated: “It has been considered necessary to requisite premises of JLN stadium complex under the provisions of section 34 of DM Act, 2005 for utilising the same for the purpose of creating quarantine facility to house the persons/people.”

The order empowered the SDM (Defence Colony) to take possession of the JLN premises by Tuesday morning.

According to sources, the Delhi government took this urgent step after the city reported a spike in the number of confirmed cases, with Sunday alone witnessing the highest single day increase in the number at 23. As per the latest data available with government agencies, Delhi has 53 confirmed Covid-19 patients with two deaths.

Sources believe the move was necessitated to house thousands of migrant labourers and get them quarantined at a single place after they thronged the capital streets and assembled in large numbers at the Anand Vihar bus terminus over the last few days to reach their home towns in distant parts of India, especially Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.

The Delhi government, as directed by the ministry of home affairs, could possibly use the JLN stadium for sheltering these thousands of workers.

The JLN stadium has 150 beds at its hostel facility located indoors. There are also some beds at its non-operational athletics academy. However, the authorities will face a before they take over the possession of the facility – to get the offices of National Anti-Doping Agency (Nada), MHA (ministry of home affairs) and Income Tax department vacated.

Title: Bihar: Coronavirus samples to be tested at DMCH lab from today
Content: PATNA: The Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital ( DMCH ) will be the third government facility in Bihar for testing of samples for coronavirus.So far, Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) and Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI) in Patna were the two facilities with testing facilities for Covid-19.A trial run was conducted successfully in the microbiology department of DMCH on Monday under the guidance of four doctors and three technicians. The trial report was sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune.DMCH principal Dr Harsh Narayan Jha said the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has certified the institute to carry out the Covid-19 tests. “NIV had recently sent trial kits to the hospital. We have sent the report to Pune laboratory for confirmation,” he said.“The testing facility for Covid-19 samples would begin at our designated laboratory from Tuesday. Now, the sample test results would be known in six to eight hours and treatment of the patients would be started accordingly,” Dr Jha said.The hospital has an isolation ward of 200 beds. There is a plan to increase the number of beds to 400 in the next couple of days. Around 35 suspected cases were getting symptomatic treatment at the hospital while 40 more suspected cases with travel history were reported there on Monday.Dr Jha said they got extraction kits, screening and confirmation kits among other items from the ICMR on Saturday. “We have written to the ICMR about the need of more propyl alcohol, personal protective equipment (PPE) kits and packaging materials,” he said and added that only 25 PPE kits were received so far.“The experts and doctors need protective suits while testing samples and performing duty in the isolation ward. From Tuesday, we will need more PPE kits even for lab technicians who will work for eight hours,” Dr Jha said.DMCH superintendent Dr Raj Ranjan Prasad said all required biomedical materials and extraction kits have been provided to the hospital administration for Covid tests.Meanwhile, Union minister of state for health and family welfare, Ashwini Kumar Choubey, has said the Covid-19 testing facility would begin at All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Patna as well. “Instructions have been given to the AIIMS-P to set up a testing lab,” he said.Choubey said the state government is making arrangements even in the districts where there is no collection centre for Covid- 19 samples. “All officials working to check the spread of Covid-19 have been directed to strengthen the arrangements,” he said.AIIMS-P director Dr PK Singh said on Monday that all the necessary items had already been purchased, except the extraction kit. “We would start within a week the testing facility in the new virology laboratory, which was set up in September last year,” he said.

Title: Virus reprieve: HC stays sale of Biyani’s pledged shares
Content: MUMBAI: In the first judicial order granting relief to a borrower hit by the coronavirus lockdown, the Bombay high court on Monday restrained IDBI Trusteeship and UBS Bank from selling shares of Kishore Biyani ’s Future Retail . The shares were pledged by Future Corporate Resources (FCRPL) to secure the debentures issued by a group company Rural Fairprice.A fall in the market value of Future Retail shares led to the pledge being invoked as the value had dropped to below what was required to provide security for the loan. The Future Group company has an outstanding loan of Rs 610 crore payable to UBS Bank. While the RBI had allowed borrowers to pause repayments for three months, loans against shares contain a clause allowing the lender to sell the pledged stock even if repayment is not due.The HC also directed UBS to withdraw any orders placed with brokers for sale of the pledged shares. Justice K K Tated said, “It is to be noted that when the debenture trust deed was executed, market value of the shares was Rs 350 per share and, because of Covid-19, the share market has collapsed and per share comes below Rs 100.” This is the first such order during the coronavirus lockdown, where the court took a view of commercial problems in an unprecedented market situation.In 2018 and 2019, Rural Fairprice Wholesale (RFWL) had borrowed Rs 670 crore from UBS London branch by pledging shares of Future Retail, which were held by FCRPL, a group company. Both RFWL and FCRPL had approached the HC for urgent orders against March 17-18 notices for the sale of the pledged shares following the market crash in the wake of the Covid-19 shutdown.Counsels Vikram Nankani, Vineet Naik, Somasekhar Sundaresan with Naik Naik Co for the Future Group company argued that Future Retail’s shares fell because of the Covid-19 outbreak and sought a stay from the sale until the markets settled down. Counsel Anirudh Hariani, Varghese Thomas and J Sagar Associates for UBS opposed any relief as the market value of the shares had fallen to Rs 350 crore compared to Rs 610 crore. “Considering the present situation of market and Covid-19, I am of the opinion that plaintiffs are required ad-interim protection till next date,” said the court. The next date falls on May 4.“This is a pragmatic development where the court has kept in mind genuine commercial problems which have affected all businesses and industries in the unprecedented corona crisis, even in cases where force majeure (an act of God) may not be an agreed term,” Future Group solicitor Ameet Naik said later.Nankani and Naik emphasised that the conduct of Future Group should be considered, as till date there was not a single payment default by them with respect to the debentures. Hariani, appearing for UBS, argued that the default on part of the Future Group company cannot be attributable to any force majeure event and that it was entitled to invoke the pledge and sell the shares in terms of the debenture trust deed.

Title: Lockdown in India: Lockdown working, but need to be on our toes
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: India has witnessed a slower rate of progression in Covid-19 cases as compared to several other countries, even developed nations, indicating that the national lockdown and other measures are having a positive effect even though there is no scope for any laxity in enforcing social distancing, the government said on Monday.“Our analysis shows that it took 12 days for cases to rise from 100 to 1,000 in our country, whereas several developed nations, having lesser population than us, have seen a multiple times increase,” health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal said. He added that in some developed nations with far less population, cases surged to 3,500; 5,000; 6,000 and even as high as 8,000 in a comparable time frame.Agarwal, however, underlined that there was no room for complacency and the level of alertness had to be high with full compliance of government guidelines and protocols related to lockdown, social distancing and quarantine. “It is an everyday battle as we are dealing with management of an infectious disease. Globally, we have seen that even if one person fails to comply, we will be back to stage zero. One person not complying with norms will infect hundred others and, in turn, those hundred will infect thousand others. Therefore, 100% alertness is required, ” Agarwal said.The government's strategy in managing the Covid-19 situation with timely interventions such as restrictions on travel from affected countries and concerted efforts by the Centre and states as well as imposition of lockdown has found some support from think tanks like Brookings India.“The escalation of cases has been very rapid in various other parts of the world, especially in countries of European Union, UK and the US. In India, though the cases are rising, the rate of growth is declining. It seems initial proactive measures such as travel ban and closure of schools and colleges around March 12 have bought us some time,” said Shamika Ravi , research director, Brookings India. According to Ravi’s assessment, the growth rate of confirmed cases since March 23 had declined to a doubling of cases every five days, as compared to doubling in every three days earlier.The health ministry reported 1,251 confirmed cases of Covid-19 till Monday. Of this, 1117 were active cases, 101 were cured and one migrant case. Total deaths stood at 29. Agarwal attributed the slower pace of rise in cases in India to people's participation in strictly following social distancing guidelines and the collective preemptive actions taken by the Centre in tandem with state governments.Ravi said the impact of the lockdown would be evident in another week but highlighted that the issue of migrant workers will have to be handled very effectively and efficiently by both the Centre and state governments. “Even if a handful of these migrants are infected, they will have a massive impact and the cases can go up significantly,” she said.

Title: Need of the hour: More high quality PPE kits
Content:
Acute shortage and average quality of personal protective equipment (PPE) kits is increasing worries of officials and health workers battling coronavirus at MGM Medical College and other health facilities of district.

Senior officials are unwilling to reveal exact stock of PPE available with them. “I can’t reveal the exact number (of PPE kits in stock) because it will create panic among medicos,” MGM dean Dr Jyoti Bindal said. Asked if there are just 1,000 PPE kits in stock, she said, “These number of kits remains in stock.”

According to sources, the hospital had ordered 2000 pieces of PPE kits from a supplier. The trucks carrying the supplies however got stuck due to lockdown. The delivery was scheduled on March 23, but now may arrive by Tuesday or Wednesday, sources said.

The low quality of PPE kits supplied by government initially, too are posing a problem. There are three types of kits in use at medical college.

“The highest quality kit prevents any kind of exposure and is provided to medicos in high risk zones like isolation wards in MRTB and Indore chest centre. Second is of mid-level quality provided to those working in OPDs and isolation facilities at MTH and other places but not in direct contact with positive cases. The poorest quality is supplied by state government. It is provided to those working at MYH casualty, cleaning staff at facilities not dealing with Covid-19,” said Bindal.

The scene is dismal at district health department too. At present, the department has just 200 PPE kits left in stock. “The demand is of 6,000 PPE kits,” said Dr Madhav Hasani, in-charge of stocks.

“We have placed order for 1.5 lakh PPE kits with higher authorities in Bhopal. Around 5,000 kits may be delivered within a day or so,” said Hasani.

“The demand is shooting as health teams are screening, isolating primary cases. The demand for providing kits to policemen, IMC workers, district administration officials and private hospitals is also on us,” Hasani said.

Title: Tipplers steal, brew arrack, pay sky-high price
Content:
Vijayawada: Desperate tipplers are now breaking into liquor stores across the state during the lockdown.

In Vizag, Eluru and Guntur, a large number of bottles were recently stolen from liquor stores. Police said these thefts were not for profit but by those who wanted to drink during the lockdown.

According to cops, the miscreants who broke into these stores did not touch cash registers. Excise officials also acknowledged that the illegal sale of arrack is growing in the absence of liquor in the state.

A case-in-point is Ajit Singh Nagar in Vijayawada, where excise sleuths and local police managed to bust an illicit liquor racket and seized 1,200 litres of jaggery used to make arrack.

Speaking to TOI, enforcement director of excise department Vineet Brijlal said they have increased the enforcement drive against illegal liquor sales across the state. “We are looking at this issue externally as well as internally. Internally, we have suspended an excise inspector for illegally selling liquor in East Godavari and even booked a case against him. Apart from that, we have set up special teams to book cases against illegal liquor transportation and sales in the state,” Brijlal told TOI.

Two instances were initially reported in Vizag and Eluru. Later, excise officials caught people trying to sell liquor in Guntur district at exorbitant prices, where 120 bottles were seized. Police sources said that a quarter bottle of a McDowels whiskey which is normally priced at Rs 160 is now being sold for Rs 500.

“Since the lockdown is in place, it isn’t easy for people to get their hands on liquor,” Brijlal added.

Title: Shortage of fresh veggies, but no dearth of fruits
Content:
Locking up of cotton market has affected grocery supplies

Nagpur: Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe’s plan to make farmers sell their produce directly in the city is yet to get streamlined as many parts of Nagpur faced shortage of fresh vegetables on Monday.

The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has made arrangements for farmers to sell their produce on an open ground near Ishwar Deshmukh College of Physical Education, Sakkardara, and near Ashirwad Talkies, Manewada Road. However, many retail vegetable sellers are unaware of the arrangement as newspapers are not being distributed in the city.

Mataprasad Gupta, a vegetable vendor from Ramdaspeth, said he had no stock on Monday. “I had gone to Cotton Market but it was closed. As a result, I had no vegetables to sell. The NMC should start the market immediately,” he said.

Ganesh Meshram, a vegetable vendor from Indora, said he too did not get any new stock on Monday and had to sell the leftover from Sunday. A buyer said that the prices of most vegetables had increased by between 10% and 25%.

NMC officials said that vegetables being sold in bulk in the two places would spread by word to mouth and soon retail sellers would start flocking there.

“We will release the names of farmers and their mobile numbers, who are coming to the city for selling their produce, on Monday evening to all media houses,” said a spokesperson.

Sugar trader Prakash Fulwani said that there was no shortage of sugar in the city. “The rumours in this regard are false,” he said.

A fruit seller from Lokmat Square said that there was no shortage of fruits in the city. “The rates have also not increased,” he said.

Suresh Lalwani, a general provisions store owner from Dhantoli, said that products like milk powder, biscuits, wheat flour, cosmetics, etc were not available. “These products are not being transported to the city. The distribution system has completely collapsed,” he told TOI.

Title: Back from New Delhi, 12 people test negative
Content: COIMBATORE: The public health department has received a list of 57 people in the district who had attended the Tablighi Jamaat meeting in New Delhi between March 22 and 24. Of the 57 people, the department has traced nine people from Anamalai and Pollachi, 31 from Mettupalayam and 10 people from the city corporation limits.The department is in the process of tracing seven another people living within the city limits.Sources say of the swab samples of 40 people lifted on Sunday night and early Monday morning, 12 tested negative and they were sent home. However, test results of 28 people were found to be inconclusive and resamples have been taken and sent to the King Institute in Chennai for confirmation.However, none of them are showing any symptoms now.The meeting that took place at the Nizammudin Basti in New Delhi, also had attendees from other countries including Indonesia and Afghanistan, say sources.The department confirmed that the 21 people whose tests at CMCH were inconclusive were admitted at Mettupalayam general hospital, but the seven patients from Anamalai and the 10 patients from city limits were in ESI Hospital. “If the Mettupalayam patients test positive on Tuesday or Wednesday, they will also be shifted to ESI Hospital,” said a health department official.If the 28 of them and a few patients from city limits test positive, it is likely to become one of the biggest cluster of Covid-19 patients in the country.Besides, these 17 new patients, the ESI hospital already has 21 old patients, including six of them who had tested positive for the virus already. “We are waiting for results of 23 people from both CMCH and King institute,” the official said. The Erode doctor’s older son has tested negative in Chennai. Her younger 10-month-old son, 58-year-old mother and maid have tested positive earlier. “All four of them including the baby are stable and have no complications so far,” said deputy director of public health Dr G Ramesh Kumar.

Title: Six Bijnor sugar mills may stop operations as supply of Rajasthan lime hit due to Covid-19
Content: BIJNOR: Cane lndustry in UP is worried these days over the shortage of lime. It gets lime from Bhilwara in Rajasthan. Lime is a key ingredient for processing cane juice into sugar.Bhilwara is the worst coronavirus-hit district in Rajasthan. Migrant workforce has left the district, resulting in shutting down of quarries there. Hence, supply of lime to UP mills has virtually stopped.DM of Bijnor Ramakant Pandey has sent an SOS to his Rajasthan counterpart to regulate supply.Six sugar mills in Bijnor are on the verge of stopping operations due to the shortage of lime.Besides, 250 lakh tons of ripe cane crop is yet to be harvested. Bijnor district cane officer Yashpal Singh said, "There are nine sugar mills in Bijnor district. Out of these, six mills have little stock of lime, Mills are facing a lot of problems to procure lime from Rajasthan because of the nationwide lockdown."In his letter, Bijnor DM Pandey has also said the government has allowed free movement of vehicles transporting lime during the lockdown.Cane officer Singh said, "Six mills of Bijnor district require around 15,000 quintals of lime from Rajasthan's lime units."We are trying our best to sort out problems of the sugar mills. I hope the mills will procure raw material in time." he added..Sources said if the mills fail to get lime from Rajasthan, they will have to stop operations, which will add to the hardships of cane farmers .

Title: Provide food, shelter, medical aid to poor & migrants: HC
Content: Nagpur: Expressing concern over mass migration of poor migrants and labourers to their native places in other states and hardships faced by them due to the nationwide lockdown, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Monday directed Maharashtra government to make arrangements for them.“The government is directed to make arrangement for stay, food , sanitation clothing and healthcare of the labourers and working class, including migrants, in need of these provisions,” justice Sunil Shukre ordered.While asking the government to examine the aspect of calling charitable institutions registered under the Maharashtra Public Trusts Act and Waqf Act to contribute/surrender funds in its accounts in a certain percentage, the judge further told it to take appropriate decision, consistent with the charitable object espoused by both acts.Warning the government of spread of Covid-19 due to mass migration of these people, the judge told it to take care of all their needs in this crisis. “Under the circumstances, it’s sensible to provide clothing, medicine and healthcare and throwing generally an umbrella of protection around these labourers. They’re going through unfathomable hardships owing to stoppage of their income derived as wages of every day’s hard labour. Unavailability of daily wages on which these people were dependent for survival, has been stopped due to lockdown.”Affirming that funds are required for this huge task, the judge earlier suggested that one of the ways of mobilizing it could be through implementing the provisions and powers conferred upon the charity commissioner and government under the Maharashtra Public Trusts and Waqf Acts.“All charitable institutions registered under both these acts could be called upon to discharge their responsibility to utilize trusts’ and Waqf’s funds for public and charitable purposes in certain percentage to be determined by the government by exercising its rule making power and also issuing appropriate government (GR) resolution consistent with the provisions made under these enactments,” he said.Quoting the suo motu judgment of Orissa high court last week, the judge said it directed the state concerned through its district collector and superintendent of police to make arrangement of stay, food and sanitation, including medical check up of all labourers, working class and continue to do so till lifting of lockdown.“In our state, it’s necessary that similar arrangements are made for such people, who are in need of such assistance. These people are migrating within the state and also to neighbouring ones with family members due to complete lockdown of all activities, except essential services,” the HC said.While hearing a plea by CH Sharma and others regarding inadequate facilities at Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH), where Anup Gilda is appointed as amicus curiae, the HC adjourned hearing till April 8. It was clubbed with another PIL (No10/2020) by businessman Subhash Zanwar through counsel Ram Heda.

Title: Schools, hotels in UP’s Kheri to be transformed into ‘shelter homes’
Content:
Bareilly: Lakhimpur Kheri district administration has acquired schools , panchayat offices and two major hotels near state-national highway and turned them into shelter homes where migrant workers would be kept under quarantine for at least 14 days.

Around 14 private schools and one marriage hall have been acquired where migrant workers who are struck in Kheri district would be given shelter. A similar infrastructure may be used in future if the number of Covid-19 cases rise in the district, sources said.

The medical staff would stay in hotels while the workers will be kept in schools. Some of these workers, who are yet to reach their destination, would be provided with health screening, food and other essential services by the district administration.

SDM of Dhaurahra tehsil in Kheri, Sunandu Sudhakaran, told TOI on Monday, “We have transformed schools into screening camps [also called shelter homes] for migrant workers from other districts or states. They will be kept under quarantine here. All the migrants will be provided with towels, sanitisers, soaps and other essential items. We will ensure that they are served proper food such as puri, sabji, dal and rice. We have also deputed at least two police constables at each screening centre to ensure that these people don’t leave the centre until the lockdown is over. A team of health officials will regularly monitor the health condition of these workers and provide a report to the district administration.”

Kheri CMO Manoj Agarwal said, “All these people have mainly come to Kheri from Delhi, NCR and Maharashtra. They will be staying in schools outside the village and their medical screening will be conducted at community health centres. We are preparing a list of such people with the help of district administration. The workers have been advised not to meet anyone and ensure they are regularly wearing masks and maintaining a two-metre distance from others.”

“The district administration has acquired two hotels where health officials like doctors, pharmacists and other staff looking after the treatment of those infected with Covid-19 would stay,” he added.

Title: 5 coaches to be converted into isolation wards
Content:
Coimbatore: The Salem division of Southern Railway has allocated five train coaches from Coimbatore to be converted into isolation wards.

The five coaches will be sent to carriage workshop in Perambur later this week for renovation and remodelling. The coaches, which are more than 20 years old but still in use, have now been lined up in Coimbatore to be moved to Perambur when Southern Railway gives the go ahead.

Divisional railway manager U Subba Rao said Southern Railway had asked all railway divisions if they could spare a few train coaches for them to be converted into isolation booths in case required for isolation of Covid-19 patients.

“So, we did an inventory and found that we have five or six coaches which are more than 20 years old could be spared. We have now kept them ready for movement to Perambur and informed Southern Railway,” said Rao. They are all second class non-AC coaches.

As for the design, each coach has eight cabins. While one or two cabins would be designed and allocated for storing medical supplies and a changing room for doctors, the remaining five to six cabins in the coach would be allocated for patients, said Rao.TNN

Title: Gandhi market to be closed indefinitely
Content:
Trichy: The district administration has indefinitely suspended operations in Gandhi Market from Tuesday to avoid overcrowding by wholesale and retail vegetable traders in the vicinity. The authorities have identified eight decentralized spots spread across four zones as replacement for consumers to buy vegetables.

Officials said the decision to indefinitely close the market was taken to ensure social distancing and adhere with the nationwide lockdown to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

The locations are Maduram school ground on EB road, Anna stadium, Khajamalai, Cauvery bridge, SIT College ground, Bishop Heber College ground, Chathiram bus stand, Thennue Uzhavar sandhai and Srirangam boys higher secondary school. While the district administration has allotted space for retail sales of vegetables to the public, the locations for the transaction between wholesale and retail vegetable traders are yet to be defined.

“Wholesale vegetable traders supply vegetables to retail traders who in turn sell to the public. With the closure of the Gandhi market, we have not been allotted any particular place for the wholesale operations,” US Karupiah, a trader in Gandhi market said. Traders said that G Corner ground in Ponmalai remains as the frontrunner to serve as an alternative for the wholesale market.

On Monday, with only the makeshift vegetable market on Cauvery bridge functioning, the civic body completed the markings to ensure social distancing among consumers in all makeshift vegetable markets that would function from Tuesday between 6am and 2.30pm. District collector S Sivarasu has ordered the city police not to permit vehicles carrying vegetables to the Gandhi market until further notice.

Meanwhile, early on Monday morning, a minor dispute in allowing retail traders into the Gandhi market who did not have id cards caused chaos in the market.

Title: Liquor being pumped into Bihar from East UP region
Content:
VARANASI: Since the declaration of Bihar as dry state in April 2016, east UP region is witnessing the menace of liquor mafia involved in smuggling the liquor there via districts like Varanasi, Chandauli, Ballia and Azamgarh.

Records of police in Varanasi zone are sufficient to expose how the liquor mafia could not be discouraged despite frequent action of police like seizure of their consignments.

Showing records the recoveries made by police between April 2019 and February 2020 to TOI, ADG Varanasi zone Brij Bhushan said, “In past 11 months, a total of 4,730 cases of liquor smuggling and illicit liquor trade had been lodged by the police in the zone and arrested 5,559 persons. In this period 3.74 lakh litres of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) and 2.16 lakh litres of country liquor were seized from the liquor smugglers.”

Police has destroyed 3.50 lakh kg of raw material used in hooch manufacturing and also 359 bhattis (manufacturing units.) A total of 106 gangs with over 500 members were listed while 63 were booked under Goonda Act.

Maximum cases had been lodged in Bihar bordering Ballia district while Azamgarh, Varanasi and Chandauli also recorded lodging of very high number cases of liquor smuggling in this period.

Title: CI transporting liquor illegally suspended
Content:
Rajahmundry: An excise circle inspector was suspended for illegally transporting liquor from a government liquor shop in East Godavari district. Three others involved have also been arrested. AP excise commissioner Vivek Yadav issued orders suspending Reddy Thrinadh, CI, Rayavaram excise station.

Excise superintendent, Rajahmundry division, KV Naga Prabhu Kumar said Thrinadh allegedly handed out 41 liquor bottles from the shop to two persons.Samson Raj | TNN

Title: BMC sets up community kitchen for destitute, door-step delivery for other residents
Content:
Bareilly: The Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) has set up a community kitchen to provide food to all needy people during the 21-day lockdown due to Covid-19 outbreak. BMC has deputed its vehicles across the city and its outskirts to look for destitute and serve them food, while the Nagar Nigam will distribute food packets among those taking refuge at public places, bus stations, platforms, etc. Officials said citizens willing to contribute for the noble cause can contact BMC.

Speaking to TOI, municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “With nationwide lockdown enforced, the poor and destitute are suffering the most, having lost even their meager daily income. Within Bareilly, a number of people including women and children who have taken refuge on streets, at public places, etc, are starving. They are the target of our relief. Civic body workers have been deputed to conduct ward-wise inspection to identify the destitute and the elderly, who need assistance, and give them food packets.”

BMC workers and officials have made rounds across the city to look for people in need of food or any other help. They distributed food packets among severl migrant labourers near the bus station, truck drivers on city outskirts, and the homeless on streets, shelters and other public places. The drive will continue during daytime till the lockdown is lifted, said officials.

The commissioner added, “Anybody can contribute by either paying some amount for rations, or donating much needed items like rice, flour, spices, cooking oil, salt, etc, at the BMC office premises, which will be used to prepare the food. People who want to contribute financially, can transfer the amount to our Bank of Baroda account: 60570100000507, with IFSC: BARB0NAGNIG.”

Civic authorities have been taking up appropriate measures to help not only the poor, but all city residents, by providing them essential supplies. Door-step delivery of necessary day-to-day items has been initiated, while approximately 300 big and small grocery stores have been identified and roped in by BMC to deliver groceries and other essentials at homes.

Title: Street brawl claims life of 60-year-old man
Content:
Krishnagiri: Police arrested seven people after a street brawl claimed a man’s life near Uthakarai in the district on Monday.

The deceased has been identified as B Munusamy, 60, of Ottampatty near Uthankarai. He was a daily wage labourer.

Around 9.30am on Sunday, one of Munusamy’s neighbours K Nagaraj, 52, was watering plants in his house when the former questioned him for using drinking water for the plants.

On hearing this, Nagaraj, his sons Marimuthu, 23, Ilayaraja, 30, Arun Pandiyan, 29, relatives Murugan, 45, Velu, 39, Prabhakaran, 22, wife Chinnapappa, 48, and Saroja, 44, attacked Munusamy with wooden logs.

Munusamy’s son Govindasamy, 29, who came to rescue his father, was also thrashed.

Both sustained severe injuries and admitted at the government hospital at Uthankarai, a police officer said.

On Monday morning, Munusamy succumbed to his head injuries. Munusamy’s another son Kumar, 29, lodged a complaint with the Uthankarai police station based on which they registered a case. Police arrested Marimuthu, Ilayaraja, Arun Pandiyan, Nagaraj, Murugan, Velu and Prabhakaran.

All the seven accused were lodged at the Salem central prison under judicial custody on Monday evening.

Similarly, Nagaraj’s son Marimuthu lodged a complaint alleging he and his family members sustained injuries after Munusamy’s sons attacked them with wooden logs. Police have registered a case against Munusamy’s son Kumar and his relatives Venkatraman, 30, Sivanesan, 35 and Chakrapani, 29.

Title: After 2-year wait, Sariska tigress gives birth to cub
Content:
The cub playing with its mother in the tiger reserve

JAIPUR: Wildlife lovers have a reason to rejoice. After a two-year wait, a tigress has given birth to a cub at Sariska Tiger Reserve .

The first photo of ST-10 and her cub was captured in Talvriksh range on Monday. With the newborn, number of big cats at STR rose to 16. The park has seven females, three males and six cubs.

Dinesh Verma Durani, founder and general secretary of Sariska Tiger Foundation, said the news has come as a respite for the STR after the death few tigers in park in past two years. “It will give fresh lease of life to the reserve. Sariska has a tremendous potential and I congratulate forest adminstration for their efforts,” he said.

According to sources, the tigers gave birth to three cubs in same range in December 2018, but they disappeared mysteriously. Tigress ST-10 also gave births to two cubs earlier named ST-11 and ST-12 in Sariska. Tiger ST-11 was killed by wire snare.

Title: Delhi: Fruit, veggie prices stabilise as fears of shortage subside
Content: NEW DELHI: To ensure unrestricted transportation of veggies and fruits from mandis to retail markets, the government has issued about 6,000 passes to the transporters for free movement of the trucks and tempos. Enough stocks of vegetables and fruits along with other essential commodities are available in the market and the items are being sold at their usual rates, say officials.Retailers have also confirmed that all seasonal fruits and vegetables are available and the prices have stabilised compared with last week.The country was put under complete lockdown from Tuesday midnight to prevent the novel coronavirus outbreak. Amid rumours that the government might shut the mandis completely, the retailers had earlier hiked the prices of all commodities by 20-25 per cent.Azadpur Agricultural Produce Marketing Committee (APMC) chairman Adil Ahmad Khan accepted that there were issues in the initial days of lockdown that caused artificial scarcity of vegetables and fruits. Not only the tempos failed to reach Azadpur Mandi to pick the stock, the daily wagers engaged in the mandi also failed to report for duty due to the restrictions.“We had meetings with police, district officials and wholesalers and stockists and devised a way to ensure neither vehicles nor staff face any problem in reaching the mandi. The passes were issued to transporters through our central office set up at Azadpur for those engaged in fruits and vegetable business across the city,” Khan told TOI.He added that buffer stocks of vegetables which can be stored for a few days are available, while the supply of green vegetables and fruits from neighbouring states was regular.“We have hired some new workers. We give them meal twice a day apart from the wages. The arrangement has helped us tide over the shortage of workers to some extent,” Khan said.The effect of unrestricted movement of essential commodities reflected in retail prices of most vegetables. The prices of green vegetables as well as potato and onion have dropped by 10-20 per cent, say retailers.“We are selling good quality of potato for Rs 25 per kilo now, which had reached Rs 30-35 last week. Similarly, cabbage is available for anything between Rs15 and 20 per kg, while we sold it for Rs 30 when the lockdown was announced,” said Ved Pal, a retailer in Kalkaji area.The sale of oranges, which improve immunity, has gone up, said Balbir Singh, a retailer in Laxmi Nagar.

Title: ‘Don’t force workers, students to pay rent’
Content:
Dehradun: To keep a check on exploitation of daily wagers and students living in the city, the Dehradun district administration has instructed all shop owners to clear the monthly dues of people working at the shops without any deductions.

In addition to this, the house owners who have given rooms to workers and students on rent have been asked to not force them to pay rent for a month. In case any house owner forces the tenant to vacate the premises, he/she will be booked under sections of Uttarakhand Epidemic Diseases, COVID-19 Regulation, 2020, district officials said, adding that they are also gearing up to crack down on shop keepers selling essential goods in case they are found over charging and hoarding and cases will be registered if found guilty.

District magistrate Ashish Kumar Srivastava said that he has also warned the educational institutions against forcing students to deposit fees in times of crisis. However, the students who do not face any financial crisis should deposit their dues, he added.

With help pouring in to provide food packets and dry ration, the district administration has activated a link on their websites https://dehradun.nic.in and dehradun.gov.in called ‘Happy Meal’ where residents can register to provide food packet and dry ration for people in need.

Every day based on the help provided by individuals, civil society, social organizations, the district administration will also choose corona warriors from each section.

Title: 19 foreigners found illegally staying at 2 mosques quarantined; 4 facilitators booked
Content:
Meerut: The foreigners, hailing from Sudan, Kenya, Indonesia and other nations, were found staying at two mosques in Meerut district without informing the local authorities, who quarantined them along with their contacts and booked four facilitators under relevant sections of the Foreigners Act and Indian Penal Code.

Superintendent of police (rural) Avinash Pandey said, “The local intelligence unit gave the whereabouts of these 19 men and we immediately reached the site. The first mosque is in Mawana tehsil where ten foreigners belonging to African nations – Sudan, Kenya and Djibouti were found. They were at once quarantined along with all those who were in their contact in the mosque. The second mosque is in Sardhana where nine Indonesian nationals were staying. Similar action was taken there as well.”

According to police sources, four persons have been booked who had facilitated their stay in the mosques without informing the local authorities.

“They have been booked under section 14 of the Foreigners Act and IPC’s sections 268 (public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury), 271 (disobedience to quarantine rule) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant).”

After the incident, several teams have been formed to check other areas as well. “We cannot leave anything to chance,” said Pandey.

Title: Political row over spraying disinfectant at Jaripatka slum
Content:
Nagpur: A political row erupted over Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) drive to spray disinfectant at Kasturba Nagar slum, Jaripatka, on Monday. Congress city secretary Rohit Yadav, a resident of Kasturba Nagar slum, was booked by the Jaripatka police for obstructing NMC workers engaged in spraying disinfectant in the area.

A police complaint was lodged by BJP corporators from the ward, Virendra Kukreja and Mahendra Dhanvijay, and NMC health department.

Senior PI of Jaripatka Khushal Tijare told TOI, “Offence has been registered against Yadav under section 186 (obstructing public servant in discharge of public duty, section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and section 3 of The Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act. He came to police station and we served intimation notice to him. He will have to appear in court,” he said.

Yadav told TOI, “There is panic in Kasturba Nagar having around 300 houses after positive patients of Covid-19 were detected in Jaripatka. But disinfectant was being sprayed only in Sindhi Colony, Jaripatka. I started spraying disinfectant on Monday morning with a machine provided by Congress city president Vikas Thakre on my request. I noticed that a few NMC workers were spraying only water in our area. The workers too admitted this. NMC should not cheat people,” he said.

The Congress secretary stated that he didn’t mean to obstruct any NMC work. “I emptied the tank used by the workers only to show people that it had only water. I made a mistake in not informing the police and handing over the workers,” he said.

In a video that became viral on social media, Yadav can be seen spraying some milk coloured liquid from his machine. He is also seen spraying from the NMC worker’s tank. The liquid in this tank appears like normal water in the video.

NMC deputy commissioner Dr Pradeep Dasarwar said, “NMC is spraying sodium hypochlorite across the city. Manual spraying is being done in areas where positive patients were found. Fire tenders are being used for main roads and other parts of the city,” he said.

Kukreja said, “It is unfortunate that some people are trying to play politics despite the serious situation. Mayor Sandip Joshi has ordered spraying of disinfectant after positive patients were found in Jaripatka. The NMC has initiated all measures to control Covid-19,” he said.

The NMC is also spraying disinfectant in the housing society at central Nagpur where one positive case was detected on Sunday.

Title: 57,734 people quarantined in Erode dist, says minister
Content:
Erode/Namakkal: A total of 57 ,734 people from 16,456 families have been quarantined in Erode district following the two-day containment plans implemented on Sunday, school education minister K A Sengottaiyan said on Monday.

Health department officials are checking their condition twice a day, Sengottaiyan, who chaired a meeting conducted by the Erode district administration at the collectorate along with environmental minister K C Karuppannan, told reporters. “The containment plan will be on until we identify all Covid-19 patients in the district. As many as 363 beds have been prepared in government as well as private hospitals to treat them. We are also setting up 75 more beds. The entire district has been closed. Officials including police are monitoring the movement of people round-the-clock.”

Erode collector C Kathiravan explained about the measures being taken to prevent the virus from further spreading. The district administration has set up vegetable markets, mobile ATMs and other basic amenities at Kollampalayam and Sultanpet, where two Thailand nationals infected by coronavirus had spent some time.

Meanwhile, electricity minister P Thangamani and social welfare minister P Saroja chaired a meeting at the Namakkal collectorate. “Of the 1,138 people with travel history, 122 have completed 28 days of house quarantine,” Thangamani told reporters. “Of the 26 people admitted to the Namakkal District Government Head-quarters Hospital with Covid-19 symptoms, 13 tested negative.”

Title: Madurai Covid-19 victim’s elder son, too, tests positive
Content: MADURAI: The 25-year-old elder son of the man from Anna Nagar in Madurai who recently died of Covid-19 has also tested positive for the virus, in addition to the victim’s wife and younger son.He, along with his mother and brother are undergoing treatment at the isolation ward at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) and their condition is stable. The son tested positive for Covid-19 only during his second test. In the initial test, the results were negative, but a re-test was done after his mother and brother tested positive. “The victim’s daughter-in-law and 1.5-year-old grandson tested negative. Two cooks who worked with the family were also tested negative as well,” district collector Dr T G Vinay told TOI.Meanwhile, the Virudhunagar district collector has said that the 60-year-old man from Rajapalayam who tested positive for Covid-19 may have contracted the infection from three foreign guests who attended his son’s wedding in Madurai on March 5. “Among the 1,500 people who attended the wedding were three foreign guests from The Netherlands, United States and Germany. Later, they had returned to their own countries. It could be the source of infection,” he said.In Sivaganga district, at least 26 people were identified to have attended a conference organised by the Thowheed Jamaath, an Islamic organisation, in New Delhi where Thai nationals, who tested positive for Covid-19 were present. Among them, four were admitted to the isolation ward at Sivaganga Medical College Hospital.

Title: One killed, 7 injured as car overturns in Varanasi
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: One woman was killed while seven others including children suffered grave injuries when a car overturned after tyre burst in Aurai area of Bhadohi district on Monday.

The car was coming to Varanasi from Kanpur with eight persons on board. Four seriously injured children were referred to trauma centre of Banaras Hindu University in Varanasi.

According to Bhadohi police, Ujma (32), a native of Varanasi, had left her parents home in Kanpur with her children Uvaid (8), Hasan (6), Yusra (8), Taham (4), sister Rubina (27) and other family member Aliza (18) in a car in morning.

When the car was passing through Aurai the driver lost control on steering following a tyre burst. The car overturned and later jumped the road divider. Rubina died on the spot. Police with the help of locals rushed all injured persons to local hospital where on noticing condition of children as critical doctors referred them to Varanasi.

Title: Dist admin to launch app to track, help those in quarantine
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: After introducing house stickers to identify persons on home quarantine , the Thiruvananthapuram district administration has gone one step ahead to strengthen surveillance as well as to ensure that those cooped up in their houses get necessary supplies.It is planning to release an app in association with volunteers providing IT solutions that would help the authorities track the movement of people in quarantine using geo-fencing and give timely updates about them.Tentatively titled ‘Arike’, the beta version of the app was released on Monday. Deputy collector (disaster management) Anu S Nair said around a dozen IT professionals have been working from various locations to develop the app.“They have been involved in the development of various platforms to co-ordinate activities aimed at curbing the spread of Covid-19 in the district,” he said.Bharat Govind, convener of Inter-Agency Group, a taskforce of young volunteers trained under the district administration, said various IT solutions will be introduced the same way China effectively utilised technology to control the spread of the pandemic.“The app will have two versions. One version is for the people on home quarantine. The other is for ASHA workers. With the support of ASHA workers, people on home quarantine can upload the app on to their phones. The drawback of other apps is that if the people leave the phone at home, their location cannot be identified. People who use this app are asked to send pictures every 30 minutes. It will help the authorities identify their location. If there is a delay in updating pictures, ASHA workers will alert them. It will help them ensure that they stay in their homes,” he said.Moreover, the app’s features allow users to give updates on the progress of the treatment and details of the stock of essentials they have with them, among other things.“Either the person on quarantine can update the information or the ASHA worker can do it for them,” said Govind.In addition to this, a website ‘Sahayahastam’ is being readied to update information on details of provisions and other items available in shops in the district.The deputy collector said the traders agreed with the idea at a meeting recently held with them.
