The website will enable traders to log in and update availability of items.The district administration is also planning to introduce a telemedicine facility for people who suffer from various health issues. “It will help them to consult doctors via Skype so that the they can avoid visiting hospitals,” he said.If the IT-solutions are found to be effective in the pilot implementation in district, it will be extended to other districts too.Geofencing was introduced in Kottayam by the cyber wing under district police chief G Jaidev around 10 days ago. It uses GPS to track the location of people.

Title: 58 foreign returnees reach hospital for screening in Varanasi
Content: VARANASI: Altogether 58 people, who have returned from foreign countries, reached for mandatory COVID-19 test at Deen Dayal Upadhyaya district hospital on Monday. On Sunday, only 21 had turned up for screening.District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said, “Altogether 58 people who returned from foreign trips turned up for screening on Monday. Total figure of people returned from abroad, who reached this hospital since Sunday, has reached to 79. Six of such 58 persons were found symptomatic, and following collection of their sample, they were admitted to isolation ward of the hospital,. One case was admitted on Sunday.”“Others were asked to stay in home quarantine till April 14. Since the creation of COVID-19 OPD and isolation ward at DDU district hospital, a total of 522 persons turned up there till Monday afternoon. Sample of 17 of them had been taken and sent to BHUs microbiology laboratory for test,” he addedFollowing detection of second COVID-19 positive case on March 28 evening, the district administration had made the coronavirus test mandatory for those returning from abroad after March 10. All such persons were asked to reach hospital for screening till March 31. Stating that screening had been mandatory for all of them, the DM said, on failing, FIRs under section 188 will be lodged against them.Persons, who already have been examined at district or BHU hospitals, had been exempted while those who had consulted private hospitals, were also asked to go for this test.

Title: Nizamuddin Coronavirus: Drones, masked men, 30,000 litres of disinfectant
Content: NEW DELHI: The densely-populated narrow lanes of Nizamuddin Basti have been witnessing a flurry of activity of a different kind.Dozens of masked men on mini-tankers have been roaming around the Nizamuddin dargah sprinkling disinfectant to sanitise the area, while screening tents have been set up at the entrance of Alami Markaz , the headquarters of Tablighi Jamaat , which has emerged as a super-spreader of Covid-19 in the country.The spokesperson of South Delhi Municipal Corporation said that a team of 34 sanitation workers and 20 domestic breeding checkers has been stationed in the basti keeping in view the “developing situation”. Till now, 30,000 litres of disinfectants have been used for spraying in the area.A senior municipal health official said for the past two days a mass disinfection drive is being carried out in the entire area using 1% sodium hypochlorite solution. “We are using mini-tankers of the horticulture department for spraying disinfectants as the larger ones cannot enter even the main lanes. For narrower lanes, shoulder-mounted knapsack pumps are being used to sanitise the area,” the official added.“A few houses are so tightly packed that workers are finding it difficult to move around even with their shoulder-mounted pumps. Currently, we are focusing on drains, mosques, pathways, community toilets, shops and lanes. Two rounds have been finished,” another civic official said, adding that contact tracing is going to be difficult as thousands of people from across the country visit the dargah.Tablighi Jamaat, whose headquarters is at the centre of the contact tracing exercise, is an Islamic missionary movement. It focuses on urging people to return to practising the religion as it was during the lifetime of Prophet Muhammad in matters of ritual, dress and personal behaviour. Nizamuddin dargah is located a few hundred metres down the lane.While no official of Tablighi Jamaat could be reached, Syed Kashif Ali Nizami, chief in-charge of the dargah, said, “The entire shrine has been disinfected twice. Though there is some panic in the community, appeals are being made from mosques and the dargah asking people not to come out of their houses. Police are doing their work and we will play our role. I have appealed to people not to sit together and offer prayers at home.”Residents of the gated upscale Nizamuddin West colony are also a worried lot as a few positive cases have been found there. Yasmin Kidwai, the area councillor, has been receiving multiple requests of disinfection drives. “Disinfection need to be scaled up keeping in mind the congested area. Lack of clear communication is leading to panic and stress in the community,” she said.While Delhi Police has deployed drones to enforce the lockdown, former mayor Farhad Suri said they should be used to increase the pace of disinfection. “Apart from the pumping sets of the corporation, I’m procuring four units so that more resources can be stationed in the area. There is an urgent need to calm the nerves and win the confidence of people.”

Title: 24 arrested for overpricing, show cause notice to trade tax officials
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: At least 24 grocery and vegetable traders were caught selling essential commodities at prices high than fixed by the district administration, on Monday.

Nine traders were held during a reality check by district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma and SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary in Chetganj market on Monday morning. Both the officails reached the market posing as a common buyer and caught the traders involved in overpricing. The trade tax officials, who had been assigned the task to check the overpricing, have also come under the scanner.

The action led to chaos in the market as traders started pulling down their shutters. Their union leaders also tried to stage a protest following which two of such leaders were arrested.

SP city Dinesh Kumar Singh said that nine traders have been arrested on the charges of overpricing and black marketing. They were booked under appropriate section of essential commodities Act while their two leaders were booked for breaching peace under section 151 of code of criminal procedure by Chetganj police.

Following frequent complaints of overpricing and black marketing of essential commodities during Covid-19 lockdown, the DM and the SSP reached Chetganj market with carry bags as common buyers and started purchasing essential goods including food grains and vegetables. While purchasing goods they found nine traders selling essential commodities at high prices despite the fact that the revised price list of such goods had already been issued by the administration on Sunday.

The DM ordered the Chetganj police to arrest these traders and lodge FIRs against them.

The action against the traders led to chaos in Chetganj and neighbouring Paan Dariba markets. The traders started pulling down their shutters and the local trader union leaders tried to gather at Chetganj crossing to stage protest against the arrested of the traders. The policemen arrested two of their leaders and made the mob disperse.

Other four teams formed by the DM under magistrates also conducted similar surprise inspections and caught 15 traders in the markets of their areas concerned. They were also sent to jail after lodging FIRs at different police stations.

The DM said that show cause notice is being issued to trade tax officials. The DM had assigned the task of monitoring the markets to 25 trade tax officials and had made it clear that stern action would be taken against the officials if any case of overpricing is detected during the lockdown.

Meanwhile, one Bharat Mishra of Bharthara village under Lohta police station was arrested for attacking a sub-inspector Pankaj Singh aftrer he instructed Bharat to go inside his home.

Title: Women join fight against corona, make masks, PPE kits in Varanasi
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: As the administrative machinery and NGOs are engaged in arranging food and shelters for the needy people and migrant workers, several rural women associated with different self-help groups (SHGs) are making masks and PPE (personal protective equipment) kits as their contribution in the fight against Covid-19. The PPE kit is a specialized clothing worn for protection against infections.

Chief development officer (CDO) Mahusudan Nagaraj Hugli said that fabrics and other facilities for preparing masks and PPE kits are being provided to them. “It is the best way to utilize the lockdown time and earn money too,” Hugli told TOI on Monday.

According to the CDO, about 273 identified SHGs comprising of 629 women have been engaged in this work. So far, they have supplied over 14,649 masks and PPE kits. On an average, they are making 1,500 masks and PPE kits every day.

This initiative has been undertaken to overcome the scarcity of masks and PPE kits by engaging the women under National Rural Livelihood Mission (NRLM). “These women are not only helping the local administration in maintaining the supply of these safety tools, but they have also searched a way of livelihood in such a critical situation,” said Hugli adding that these women have set an example with their social commitment.

Besides, some other women are involved in making masks with their own resources. “With our own available resources we are making masks to distribute among people free of cast,” said Rituja Kushwaha , the team leader of Jagriti SHG at Sajaoi village, supported by an NGO Human Welfare Association (HWA). Many group members including Geeta, Suman Vibha and others could be seen busy in making masks.

“After coming to know about the shortage of masks we decided to utilize the lockdown time in making masks,” said Geeta.

Title: Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath to visit Meerut and Ghaziabad today
Content:
MEERUT: The district administration has made all the necessary arrangements ahead of chief minister Yogi Adityanath’s visit to the city. A panel of doctors, life-saving medicines, two ambulances, packs of CM’s blood group have been arranged to deal with any emergency.

Not just this, a team of doctors along with the FSDA authorities will also keep a check on the food and beverages which will be provided to the CM during his visit here. A team of doctors will also remain on standby at Subharti Medical College in case of any emergency.

“The chief medical superintendent of PL Sharma District Hospital is instructed to provide two ambulances, a team of doctors and life-saving drugs for the VVIP fleet movement. A team of doctors with medicines should be available at the safe house made for the UP chief minister,” read the order issued by SP traffic and protocol, Sanjeev Bajpai.

CM Adityanath will visit Meerut and Ghaziabad on Tuesday to take stock of preparedness for the novel coronavirus.

Title: Meerut: Cops lathicharge mob after incident of stone-pelting, six injured
Content: MEERUT: Police on Monday afternoon resorted to “mild” lathicharge to disperse a mob in Meerut ’s Lisari Gate area, following a clash in which at least six people were injured, after an argument ensued over makeshift barricading at the entry of a colony.The argument soon led to brawl. The clash took an ugly turn after both groups resorted to stone-pelting, at which point, local police lathicharged to disperse the crowd. Those who were injured were rushed to the local hospital for medical aid.Police said they also detained three people and filed an FIR against them under relevant sections, including Disaster Management Act. Efforts are on to trace others who were allegedly involved in the brawl,” said a cop at Lisari Gate police station.The clash took place despite the prevailing nationwide lockdown in the wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak. Chief minister Yogi Aditynath will be arrive at the district today (Tuesday) to take stock of emergency medical preparedness, after number of cases of Covid-19 positive samples reportedly shot up here.

Title: Madurai hospitals take to teleconsultation
Content:
MADURAI: With the outbreak of Covid-19 and the ensuing national lockdown, most hospitals in the city have temporarily halted outpatient consultations and are only attending to emergency cases. To help patients at this juncture, many private hospitals have introduced teleconsultation services.

A multi-speciality private hospital in the city, Meenakshi Mission Hospital and Research Centre (MMHRC), has introduced ‘MMRHC Consult’, a video consultation and advisory service to help patients avail expert medical help within the comfort of their homes. The teleconsultation service can be accessed through the website www.mmhrc.com. It is also available as a mobile app on android and iOS platforms. Experienced doctors will be available between 8 am to 8 pm for consultation and providing medical advice.

This service will be useful for those suffering from common illnesses. The doctors can diagnose the ailments by listening to the symptoms and prescribe medications or suggest different modalities of treatment. Dr Gurushankar, chairman, MMHRC said, “Telemedicine services can help identify serious health issues and provide advice for further treatments. This service also aids patients have a quick consultation with healthcare experts within the convenience of their homes.”

Aravind Eye Hospitals (AEH), a private hospital catering exclusively to eye care, recently stopped all its general consultations and routine eye check-ups for the public andhas introduced e-consultations. E-consultation will facilitate an interactive eye care consultation via computer or smartphone through teleconference with an ophthalmologist. It is available through the website www.aravind.org.

“The teleconsultation is being done for free now but we are a little worried that we might get flooded with calls, to clear even general doubts. So, additionally, we have asked our doctors to follow-up on all patients, who underwent emergency procedures recently, over phone instead of asking them to come in person,” said Dr N Venkatesh Prajna, Chief, Cornea and Refractive Surgery Services, AEH.

Title: In letter to UP CM Yogi Adityanath, Darul Uloom VC offers university building for setting up isolation ward
Content:
MEERUT: Darul Uloom vice-chancellor Abul Qasim Nomani has written to UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath offering a building in the university’s premises in Deoband to be converted into an isolation ward for treating patients found suspected or positive of novel coronavirus. The VC said the gesture was in solidarity with the government’s fight against the pandemic.

“If need be, the local administration – under given difficult circumstances – can contact officials at Darul Uloom to covert the building into an isolation ward,” the VC said.

“The three-storied building is on the highway and has easy accessibility. It has 100 rooms which can be converted into isolation wards,” Darul Uloom spokesperson Ashraf Usmani said.

In Saharanpur range, only one person, a resident of Kairana in Shamli district , has tested positive for novel coronavirus so far. However, neighbouring Meerut has seen a worrying trend after 19 samples were tested positive in the last 72 hours.

Additional resources are being kept at standby by the health officials in almost all districts in case of the outbreak expanding exponentially. As of now, 96 samples have tested positive in the state, out of which 17 have been discharged.

Title: Ex-constable of BSF donates Rs 1 lakh to PM CARES fund
Content:
Roorkee: An 83-year-old former head constable of Border Security Force (BSF) in Roorkee donated Rs 1 lakh to Prime Minister’s Citizen Assistance and Relief in Emergency Situations (CARES) fund. On Monday, city police received the sum from the veteran.

According to circle officer Chandan Singh Bisht, a man Dipak Singh from Delhi called him on Monday and told him that his 83-year-old father Ram Singh Negi wants to donate Rs 1 lakh from his savings to help the country in fighting the deadly epidemic.

"As Negi Ji was unable to go the bank and deposit his contribution to the relief fund account, he sought help from us. I went to his house where he handed me a cheque of Rs 1 lakh. I have deposited the cheque in the bank," said Bisht.

Title: No let-up in containment drive; K K Pudur, Saibaba Colony scanned
Content:
Coimbatore: On Day 2 of the Covid-19 containment plan , 183 nurses and health workers of primary health centres, equipped with masks and gloves , visited homes and checked for cases of fever and breathlessness at Saibaba Colony and K Pudur on Monday.

They plan to cover nearly 9,000 houses and 45,000 people. This is the second circle of houses around the house of 25-year-old Spain returnee who tested positive last week.

On Saturday, the public health department instructed districts to take up a containment plan involving marking a 5km radius around every positive patient’s house and the places they frequented.

In Coimbatore, the one positive patient was in Saibaba Colony and she visited K Pudur, according to the information the patient provided to the health department.

“We drew a 5km radius and a further 2km buffer zone around that radius. We finished the first 1km to 1.5km circle around the patient’s house on Sunday,” said a doctor at the KK Pudur primary health centre.

The first circle included around 900 houses and 4,980 people.

“We took a little longer with every house on Sunday, because they were closer in proximity to the patient’s house. So, we interacted more with families,” said one of the nurses.

The nurses said on Sunday and by 12pm on Monday, they did not come across any patient with fever or breathlessness.

“We did have some mild cold and cough cases, but they had no suspicious contacts or travel history, we advised them to room quarantine themselves. We advised people above 60 and those with heart problem and uncontrolled diabetes, to be extra careful and report even a sore throat lasting more than two days. We gave them phone numbers to call, so we can go check them instead of them coming to our clinic,” another nurse said.

“On Tuesday, we will check the final 1-1.5 km in the outer circle of the patient’s house which includes areas around MM Nursing Home, Nesavalar Colony, GCT college area, Kavundampalayam and Sivanandha Colony,” the doctor said.

The health workers must keep a tab on 57-odd foreign returnees in their circle and check for quarantine violators.

Nurses however say their door to door visits have so far been a smooth process.

“Our area is mostly populated with educated people. The families with foreign returnees are cooperative. Only a few people in slums give us irresponsible answers,” the doctor said.

Many people, especially senior citizens, in Saibaba Colony have begun panicking since they learned that a Covid-19 positive patient was from their area.

“I have moved my mother in her late seventies out of my house to KTVR gardens a little away,” a chartered accountant said.

Sreelatha, 31, who recently gave birth to a baby boy moved out of her mother’s house on Alagesan Road at Saibaba Colony to her husband’s place in Tirupur last week.

“I moved to Tirupur, when I heard the girl is from Saibaba Colony and she went out a few times after returning from Spain,” she said.

Title: Vadodara: Proud baby girl’s cop ‘dad’ feeds the poor
Content:
Constable R S Galsar has started community kitchen to feed poor

VADODARA: He couldn’t experience the joy of welcoming Lakshmi in his native village in Banaskantha. But police constable RS Galsar of Manjalpur police station found his own way to celebrate the birth of his second child .

He shared the joy by treating hundreds of slum dwellers living Atladara checkpost with food by starting a community kitchen near-by.

Galsar has been keeping watch over vehicles coming from and going to Padra at Atladara check post since janata curfew on March 24. On March 28, Galsar’s family members in Banaskantha broke into celebrations as the cop was blessed with a baby girl .

“My friends and I were planning to start a community kitchen for these people many were sleeping hungry. On March 28 when we had just dispatched the first batch of food, I received the news that I have been blessed with a baby girl and all family members were celebrating,” Galsar said.

As holidays of all cops have been cancelled, Galsar regrets that he could not be beside his wife.

“I cannot join the celebrations, so I decided to serve the food to slum dwellers and celebrate in my own way,” he said.

“We have got an opportunity to serve people in times of distress but when people get meals two times in a day it is nothing less than celebration,” said Galsar, who is a cop in Vadodara for 11 years.

Galsar said he plans to take a long holiday to spend time with my daughter, his second child, once the situation normalizes.

Besides serving food in slum dwellers, Galsar and his friends also hand over packets to those are walking back to their hometown on Padra road. The team had started with small meals like ‘khichdi’, but now with donations pouring in they are also making different dishes.

“Eating khichdi daily can be too monotonous so we have started to cook different dishes,” Galsar said. A cook has been offering his services on voluntary basis but during his off-duty hours Galsar too helps with chopping vegetables.“We will continue this community kitchen as long as the lockdown remains so that nobody sleeps hungry,” he told TOI.

Inspector BG Chetariya of Manjalpur police station told TOI: "It’s a proud moment for me as a person working under me is working like this without getting concerned about the risks he is exposed to. Despite such a happy occasion at his home, he is working for the people and I hope it continues to do great work.”

Title: Uttarakhand governor gives one month salary to PMCARES Fund
Content:
DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand governor Baby Rani Maurya has decided to give her one month salary for the PMCARES Fund to help fight the Covid-19 threat, a communique from the Raj Bhawan said on Monday.

Earlier in the day, the governor sought information about the arrangements regarding testing and treatment of Covid-19 in three hospitals of the state by speaking to doctors, nurses and lab superintendents directly.

She also inquired about the health progress and well being of patients. The governor said that contribution of doctors,nurses and para medical staff was very important in the present scenario.

She appealed to the people to co-operate with the state and central government as much as possible in the present situation.

Title: Community kitchens: Corp to source local produce from farmers
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The city corporation will directly collect agricultural produce from farmers within city limits who have been finding it difficult to sell off products owing to lockdown.

The farm produce will be collected at a price which will be fixed by the agriculture officer.

The vegetables sourced from local farmers at a fixed price will be used for cooking in community kitchens run by the city corporation.

The corporation already runs eight community kitchens in the city. Plans are underway to open community kitchens in all the health circles in the city. Purchase committees were also constituted by city corporation for collection of provisions and vegetables for running community kitchens. The civic body also needs to supply provisions and vegetables for camps where guest labourers are being housed.

Mayor K Sreekumar has earlier appealed to city residents to contribute towards the supply of provisions and vegetables which are required for community kitchens on a daily basis. TOI reported on Monday that amaranthus farmers in Vellayani and Punchakkari were forced to cut spinach and dump it as they were finding it hard to sell their produce due to the lockdown.

Owing to the number of food packets being delivered daily and hurdles in smooth supply of goods from across the state border, the corporation is also stretching its resources to get the community kitchens running. The authorities said that if farm produce from local farmers could be sourced, it could help them maintain a decent menu for community kitchens also farmers will also get value for their efforts.

Title: HC direction to govt on patient treatment
Content:
Cuttack: The Orissa high court on Monday directed the state government to make sure that specialist and experienced doctors are available to promptly attend to patients reaching hospitals with serious health issues that need specialized treatment.

The division bench of Acting Chief Justice Sanju Panda and Justice Biswanath Rath further directed the state to provide these doctors with Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) for their safety against Covid-19 infection.

The direction was issued to the health secretary and other government officials, including the DMET, after the court registered a suo motu PIL on the need for adequate medical care in hospitals, both government and private. The court directed the government to ensure that no patient gets turned away without getting medical care.

Title: Meerut man attacks health team surveying coronavirus cases, held
Content: MEERUT: A man was arrested for attacking the health team which was conducting a survey to check Covid-19 cases in Karim Nagar on Monday. The area falls under Nauchandi police station, which has reported the maximum cases.One of the locals allegedly held the team hostage, snatched the survey papers from them and ran away. He was later traced with the help of CCTV footage video and arrested by the police.Dr Vishwas Chaudhary, Meerut district surveillance officer, said, “On Monday, 382 teams had gone for a door-to-door survey to check if anyone has a foreign travel history or is having Covid-19 like symptoms. However, when our teams went to Karim Nagar, some locals misbehaved with them.”“I was conducting the survey in Karimnagar Lane number four, when a man came and started questioning me whether I had permission to do the survey. When I told him that I have the supporting documents to conduct active case findings, he held my hands from behind and told me that he would take me to the counsellor of the area. When I resisted, he snatched my papers and ran from the spot,” said an auxiliary nurse midwife (ANM), on the condition of anonymity, who had gone for the survey.Ashutosh Kumar, station house officer, said, “The accused, who has been identified as Sohail, has been booked under IPC sections 352 (punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 332 (whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty) and 379 (punishment for theft) of the Indian Penal Code and sent to jail.”

Title: Women from northeast face racial slur in Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: While the state struggles to fight the novel coronavirus, people from the Northeast living in Kolkata are battling racism. Several reports of linking people from the Northeast to the virus are pouring in. While most ignored the racist comments, some nurses attached with a hospital said they will lodge a police complaint.

A 24-year-old airline cabin crew member from Sikkim, who has been living in Kolkata for the past four years, was allegedly taunted by healthcare workers of a Tollygunge government hospital where she had to stay for a night on being suspected to have contracted Covid-19 two days ago. “First, the healthcare providers at the fever clinic of the hospital asked if I was Chinese. I was in pain and wasn’t in a condition to retort. Even as I explained I was suffering from UTI, they bundled me into the isolation ward,” said the woman.

“As I entered the so-called isolation ward, which is a dormitory, a woman patient screamed and asked the hospital staffers why a Chinese carrying the novel coronavirus was being admitted to the ward. I was shocked and very hurt,” the woman said. “I was in too much pain to protest. Luckily, the next afternoon they discharged me, advising home quarantine. This was a bitter experience in the city, which is my second home,” she said.

In another incident, a young nurse from Manipur attached with a private hospital was allegedly spat upon by a motorcyclist when she, along with her friend, stepped out of her paying guesthouse in Mukundapur on Sunday night. The duo was going to the hospital in the same area. “Two youths on motorcycle zipped passed them. One of them spat paan on the nurse, while the other shouted that these ‘coronaviruses’ were spreading Covid-19 in the city,” alleged a fellow nurse.

The two are planning to lodge a police complaint.

Title: Call police if you need essentials or food, Hyderabad cops urge residents
Content: HYDERABAD: Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar on Monday said organisers of Sri Ram Navami rally in April first week have cancelled it keeping in view people’s safety due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The top cop also requested people to call police if anyone is in desperate need of food or other essential supplies.After reviewing on the ground situation related to the lockdown in the city, Anjani Kumar issued a media brief saying that most people were adhering to the lockdown rules.“I appeal to people to not believe rumours being circulated through social media. There are no red zones in Hyderabad. If there is any zone in the city, that is safe zone. Entire Hyderabad is Safe Zone,” the commissioner said, warning that stern legal action would be taken against those spreading rumours.So far, over 10,000 passes have been issued for supply of essential commodities and the commissioner said that more such passes would be issued to suppliers as per the necessity. After chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao announced on Sunday that no person, including migrant workers should starve, police of three commissionerates in the city started organising food and supply of essential commodities to migrants in their respective jurisdictions.“If any workers are suffering due to lack of food or essential commodities, please dial 100 or call our Covid-19 control room. One can directly approach any police station or a patrolling vehicle for help,” the commissioner said.

Title: Delhi Corona News: What prompted Delhi cops to cordon off Nizamuddin dargah
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has locked down the entire area surrounding Nizamuddin dargah after several religious preachers, who had attended a yearly Tablighi Jamaat congregation, tested positive for Covid-19 in the past few days.Drones are being used to scan the streets around Alami Markaz, the headquarters of Tablighi Jamaat, to prevent anyone from stepping out of their houses until the entire area is sanitised.“We have isolated the building where the gathering took place. We are assisting the health department in taking people for check-up. In the last two days, around 200 people have been taken for check-ups,” said a senior police officer.Meanwhile, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday ordered the registration of an FIR against a maulana for leading the Tablighi Jamaat congregation, sources said. Delhi government will launch a house-to-house mapping exercise in two nearby colonies on Tuesday to check for novel coronavirus cases.During an inquiry by police, it was found that about 1,500 people, including some foreigners, were residing in the area. Of these, 105 were immediately shifted to Lok Nayak Hospital, while another 34 were shifted on Monday morning. Police were informed about the visitors by the organiser, Moulana Yousuf, on Saturday. The scholars who had attended the programme till March 23 had stayed back as lockdown came into effect that midnight.Asked how the programme was allowed at this time, police said no permission was sought by the organisers. The gathering had taken place within Banglewali Masjid because of which there were no count of the number of participants. “When we came to know about the congregation, we issued a notice to the organisers after which the programme was stopped,” said DCP (Southeast) RP Meena. However, the visitors continued to stay in guesthouses around the mosque without informing anyone.Nearly 300 participants from countries like Bangladesh, Malaysia, Afghanistan, Kyrgystan, Sri Lanka and Maldives had attended the programme, police said. The congregation is also under the scanner of intelligence agencies.A health camp has been set up to scan every resident before evacuating them. Shopkeepers and guesthouse owners are being questioned to find out whether the suspected patients visited other areas.

Title: Six more test positive for Covid-19 in Meerut, take tally in district to 19
Content: MEERUT: As many as six persons tested positive for novel coronovirus in Meerut on Monday, taking the tally in the district to 19. While four of these cases are contacts of the 50-year-old Bulandshahr man who had travelled from Amravati to Meerut and 16 of his contacts have tested positive so far.The man with no foreign travel history, travelled from Maharashtra to Meerut in two trains, stayed in three localities, attended a wedding and prayed at two city mosques before testing positive here. All the areas he visited have been sealed and are being disinfected while his contacts, which are in excess of a hundred, are being screened.Four of his contacts, including his wife and three brothers-in-law, had tested positive on Saturday. Eight other tested positive on Sunday and four others on Monday. Admitted to the isolation ward in Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical (LLRM) College, the 50-year-old man is being treated for the disease.Other than this, two others, who had returned from Philippines and Singapore and are residents of Surya Nagar and Civil Lines area, tested positive for Covid-19.“As many as six cases of novel coronavirus tested positive in Meerut on Monday, taking the tally go up to 19 in the district,” said chief medical officer Dr Raj Kumar.The two foreign return cases were kept under quarantine by the health department on Sunday after the both of them approached the officials. “Before Sunday, both of them were in home quarantine. The samples of their families have been taken and sent for tests. Even then, we will investigate if there were any other people whom they came in contact with,” said Dr Kumar.Meanwhile, tests of all the contacts of the first Covid-19 positive case have been completed, and more of his contacts are being traced.“As many as 382 teams reached a population of 2,65,189 and five suspected cases were sent to Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College. Meanwhile, 310 people were kept in home quarantine. A total of 17 samples were tested on Tuesday, out of which six tested positive. Until now, a total of 109 samples of coronavirus have been tested, out of which 19 have tested positive,” said district surveillance officer Dr Vishwas Chaudhary.

Title: Epilepsy patient dies in Haridwar, eight members of family quarantined
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HARIDWAR: An 18-year-girl, who was a patient of epilepsy but was lately suffering from fever and cough, passed away on Sunday night.

The girl had no travel history. However, as a precautionary measure, eight members of her family were quarantined at home and their samples sent to the lab for Covid-19 testing. Also, a notice is being issued to a private hospital where the deceased girl was allegedly refused to be admitted due to her flu-like symptoms. Haridwar CMO Dr Saroj Naithani told TOI on Monday, “The girl was a patient of epilepsy and suffered from mental disorder. She had complained of fever and cough a week ago. She was taken to a district hospital. Later, she was taken to a private hospital in Kankhal where the hospital authorities reportedly refused to admit her. This is a serious matter and a probe will be conducted. A notice will be issued to the hospital. Those present at her cremation will also be quarantined.”

Title: Police in Meerut scrap FIR against first Covid-19 case
Content: MEERUT: Police in UP’s Meerut have scrapped the FIR registered against the first novel coronavirus patient of the district. The local police said that the case was taken back after it was found that the victim was not aware about him being positive. Earlier, he was being considered as the reason behind the spread of the disease in Meerut as he had come in contact with hundreds within 24 hours.Ashutosh Kumar, station house officer (SHO) of Nauchandi police station, said, “Police have scrapped the FIR against the first coronavirus positive case of Meerut. All of his contacts have tested positive for the disease here. The FIR was cancelled after it was found during investigation that the person in question was not aware about him being positive. In fact, his health deteriorated on March 24 after which he approached the Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College.”TOI had earlier reported that an FIR was filed against the first coronavirus positive case of Meerut under Epidemic Diseases Act, and section 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 270 (Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) and 271 (Disobedience to quarantine rule) of the Indian Penal Code.“We wanted to give out the message that anybody with symptoms of coronavirus should come forward and not hide it from the authorities. This is the only way that we can help in containing the disease,” said Kumar

Title: Travel agency owner arrested for illegally transporting migrant workers to UP
Content:
Representative image

HARIDWAR: A travel agency owner was arrested late on Sunday night for transporting migrant workers of Bareilly district ( Uttar Pradesh ) from Haridwar using a fake permission letter. The arrest was made after two buses going towards Haridwar-Bijnor highway were stopped by Haridwar DM C Ravishankar and city SSP Senthil Avoodai Krishna Raj S at Chandi Bridge during patrolling.

SSP Senthil Avoodai told TOI, “Two buses of a travel agency were stopped for inspection and it was found out that they were carrying migrant workers using fake permission letters prepared by the company. A case has been registered against Tehri resident Ajay Chaudhary, the owner of the company, under sections 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of other), 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will, etc), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using as genuine a forged 1[document or electronic record]) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code . On Monday, Ajay Chaudhary was arrested by our team.”

Meanwhile, Haridwar police also siezed a vehicle ferrying 55 tourists who were on their way to West Bengal.

The vehicle owner had permission for transporting essential commodities but was instead found transporting people. A case has been registered against the accused driver under section 188 of the IPC and further investigation is underway.Notably, several migrant workers from neighbouring Uttar Pradesh, who work in the unorganised sector or in factories at SIDCUL, have become stranded in Haridwar because of the Covid-19 lockdown. As these workers desperately want to return to their homes, some tour operators and travel agents are milking the crisis by trying to ferry them using illegal means in return for money.

It must be also mentioned here that the migrant workers who had marched all the way to UP border were not allowed entry into their home state by UP Police officials in view of the coronavirus pandemic.

Title: 38 camps for outstation workers set up in district
Content:
Jaipur: A day after inter-state and inter-district borders were sealed by the Centre to prevent the reverse migration of workers, Jaipur district administration on Monday set up 38 camps and shelter homes to house the migrant labourers during the remaining days of the nationwide lockdown. These facilities set up in government schools will be a kind of quarantine facility for few thousand workers from outside the state and the districts. As on Monday evening, over 1,500 workers have been accomodated. Food and water will also be provided to them.

TOI on Monday visited the Adarsh Senior Secondary School in Adarsh Nagar where nearly 100 workers mainly from Uttar Pradesh and Delhi have been housed.

Soon after they were brought by police from various parts of the city, they underwent a medical test. Then they were shifted to different classrooms. There were four women in the group who have been provided a separate room.

Four school employees including principal Sandhya Arya and officials from the collectorate — tehsildar Arun Sharma and Patwari Ravi Pratap Singh — were present in the institute to oversee the arrangements. “We have arranged for food and water for the labourers. A team of medical staff has checked on them and none of them is suffering from ailments,” Arya said.

“We will keep them here for at least two weeks and wait for further directions by the government. Most of these people are from Uttar Pradesh,” tehsildar Arun Sharma said.

“I used to work in a book publishing house at Ratlam in Madhya Pradesh . I was on way to my hometown in Hathras. We started from Ratlam yesterday morning (Sunday) and reached Jaipur from Kota this morning (Monday). We were stopped by police and brought here this morning,” said Ashok Kushwaha, who walked half the way apart from riding on trucks, buses and auto-rickshaws to reach Jaipur.

Asked about what his future plans are, Ashok thought for a while and said, “Let’s see what happens. First, I want to go home. My mother, father, wife and children stay there. So, I started from Ratlam hoping to get back home at the earliest. The contractor gave Rs 1,000 to each one of us for travel expenses and food,” he added.

Similar was the plight of a vegetable vendor Pradeep Kumar from Dahod in Gujarat. “I started my journey on Friday. I covered the journey till Jaipur partly on foot and partly in trucks. Now I am stuck. I know I have to stay here for at least 14 days,” he said. Kumar was on his way to his hometown in Jaunpur, Uttar Pradesh.

Title: Mattancherry & Chullickal residents remain indoors
Content:
The number of vehicles on the city road has significantly reduced due to the stringent measures taken by the p... Read More

Kochi: Life was more or less normal in Mattancherry and Chullickal from where the first Covid-19 death in the state was reported on Saturday. However, people have become more vigilant as most of them were seen staying indoors on Sunday.

Meanwhile, health workers and councillors have been taking measures to build confidence among the public, especially those living in the apartment complex where the deceased was residing. “We are providing, those in quarantine, with medicines and other essential commodities,” said Jayanthi Premnath, councillor representing Chullickal division. “There are 42 people in quarantine in the apartment complex where the deceased had been living. We were in constant touch with some of the people residing in the apartment complex updating them regarding the condition of the patient. We had asked them to give others mental support in case the person under treatment dies. So, they managed the situation well,” she added.

At the same time, people have become more dependent as they have been calling up health workers, councillors and other volunteers for fixing even petty issues. There are incidents of homemakers, who are in home quarantine, seeking support for replacing empty gas cylinders with new ones. “A homemaker had sought support from us in this regard. She and her mentally-retarded son are living in a house. Earlier, the delivery boys with gas agencies or some of the neighbours would help them. Now, nobody is ready to help them,” said Antony Francis, councillor.

Premnath too faced a similar experience. “Given the situation, we are unable to send anybody to their houses. We have sought the help from health department. For the time being, we have been giving cooked meals to the family,” she said.

Meanwhile, people’s representatives, who attended a meeting convened by agriculture minister V S Sunil Kumar at Kochi Corporation office on Sunday, raised questions regarding tracking of contacts of housemaid who worked in the apartment complex where the deceased had been living. “The woman would certainly have used the lift and then would have gone to the bus stop and boarded a bus. Then, she would have gone to market before reaching her house at another apartment complex. We asked the district authorities whether her route mapping was done. They just nodded and didn’t explain,” one of the councillors who raised the issue said.

According to health department officials, the death of a person with severe comorbidities underline the need for protecting those belonging to high-risk group. “Youngsters and healthy persons should protect the elderly and those with comorbidities. Proper sanitization as part of break the chain project should be done. This will help reduce the risk,” said Dr Mathew Numbelil, district manager National Health Mission, and one of the persons leading Covid-19 care activities in the district.

Title: Vegetables grown on terraces help residents stay indoors
Content:
Trichy: A section of residents in the city are reaping the benefits of growing vegetables on their terraces even as many are worried about stepping out to purchase vegetables. Plucking around 200 to 500g of vegetables every day, terrace gardening enthusiasts are comparatively having a relaxed lockdown.

Harihara Karthiyen, Thiruverumbur-based terrace gardening expert, has not stepped out of his house in past week to buy vegetables. “A dozen varieties of vegetables are cultivated at our house using the vacant space where sunlight is available. Harvesting 200-500g of various vegetables is enough for us for a day,” Karthikeyan said. People here grow gardens in 350 to 1,000sqft area on their terraces in green bags sheltered with a protective mesh. A few houses even have drip irrigation system. The gardeners claimed that they have stocked vegetables such as onions and potatoes ahead of the lockdown since such vegetables are difficult to grow on the terrace. “While others fear about the quality of vegetable and the way they were transported amidst the Covid-19 scare, we have no doubts in the quality of vegetables grown on our terraces using natural fertilisers,” says Vency John from Crawford. Tomato, spinach, curry leaves, mint, radish, green chilli, brinjal and beans were harvested on the terraces.

If vegetables were harvested in rotation, people can meet the vegetable requirements for a week without stepping outside, said the terrace farmers. Besides the residents, Trichy Corporation’s establishments such as all-weather shelter for the homeless on Bharathiyar Road are also practising terrace farming. Terrace gardening exhibitions conducted by the corporation in the past two years have encouraged around 10,000 residents to pursue terrace farming in the city. Terrace gardening enthusiasts opined that the ongoing lockdown has highlighted to residents the importance of growing vegetables to manage the daily needs.

Title: 7,893 migrant workers reach Varanasi
Content:
VARANASI: So far, a total of 7,893 people from Delhi and NCR region have reached Varanasi in 104 buses since Sunday morning.

DM Kaushal Raj Sharma said, “Of 7,893 people who arrived here, only 828 belonged to Varanasi district . A total of 118 buses were engaged by UPSRTC for sending the remaining 7,065 migrant people to other districts of east UP region and bordering areas of Bihar.

All these buses reaching Varanasi via Kanpur or Lucknow are being stopped at Rajatalb and Pindra area where health teams and NDRF personnel examine each passenger, said officials.

All the migrants were provided food, guidelines for home quarantin. Many schools including private institutions are being utilised to complete all these exercises and also accommodate the migrants. tnn

Title: Red Cross launches blood donation challenge
Content:
Bhubaneswar: After several blood banks in the state went dry owing to the ongoing lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus, the Indian Red Cross Society here has come up with a unique initiative to tide over the shortage through a blood donation challenge.

“Through this initiative, the Red Cross members are encouraging individual volunteers to visit their nearest blood bank and donate blood as congregations are restricted at the moment. Many people, especially thalassemia and critical patients, are in need of blood,” Junior Red Cross officer Laxman Swain said.

He added that mass blood collection drives used to be undertaken in colleges and other educational institutions. But owing to the shutdown, such camps were not being conducted, resulting in a shortage of blood.

“There is a need to bridge the gap between the donors and the receivers. We can’t organise big blood donation drives owing to the social distancing protocol. But we can go in person and donate blood in the blood banks at least. It will not expose one to the virus as some people are fearing,” he explained.

Several blood banks in the city in particular and the state, at large, reported shortage of blood of all compositions soon after the lockdown was imposed. Not only public facilities, but private hospitals too reported acute shortage of blood.

According to the data on availability of blood on Monday, the Capital Hospital has the highest of about 47 units of blood of different groups while BMC Hospital in Old Town area has 14 units of blood. The district headquarters hospital in Khurda has 27 units of blood. The private blood banks also have more or less the same number of blood units.

“We are conducting in-house collection drives to meet the requirement of blood. Patients need regular infusion of blood. We are trying to help them,” Capital Hospital director Ashok Kumar Pattnaik said.

Title: CBSE schools to put off academic fee collection
Content:
Trichy: Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) affiliated private schools in the city have decided to defer fee collection for the ensuing academic year considering the extraordinary situation created over the spread of Covid-19.

Usually, fee collection in these schools go on till mid of April every year beginning from the last week of March. Unlike state board and matriculation schools, for CBSE schools, the academic year begins in April. While Class X and XII are exceptions, other classes conclude their annual examination by mid of March.

“By this time, we would have collected fee and books would have been distributed to students,” said Padma Srinivasan president, of Rockcity Sahodaya School complex. This is an academic forum of CBSE schools around Trichy to discuss academic progress.

Given the extraordinary situation, we have decided not to initiate fee collection for time being, she said.

Respective CBSE schools procure books for their children and the money is collected along with the fees. Most schools have procured NCERT books through CBSE allotted vendors. But, it is also natural on part of the schools to postpone the process until further orders on reopening of the schools come, she said.

On Sunday, a section of parents in the city had raised a complaint against the schools after receiving emails seeking payment of the fee. While the communication also mentioned collection of fine for late payment, parents raised alarm.

Speaking to TOI on the issue, Trichy district chief education officer S Santhi said the communication was old, and the school did not make any fresh attempt to collect the fee. However, schools could not prevent automatically generating emails on fee collection as staffs could not reach school all these days during the lockdown, she said.

Title: Sudden disappearance of bats from urban areas of country intrigues experts
Content: Nagpur: The sudden and concurrent disappearance of bats from different parts of the country has intrigued experts. From onset of summer to felling of trees to pollution and the eeriness due to lockdown, they are speculating different causes behind it.Stressing that the vanishing trend of urban bats is a sign that needs to be looked into, the experts also feel that this mammal does not succumb to viruses and here lies the chance to find vaccines or medicines to fight the corona pandemic.It all started when Deepak Apte, a well-known conservationist and director of the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS), posted on social media about a large colony of around 10,000 bats outside his Thane house having disappeared in the last 15 days. It was the first time in last four years that the roost was not seen.Soon after his post, many people started sharing similar observations from different parts of the country. “After my post, I got similar reports from many parts in Mumbai (Mahim, Prabhadevi), Gujarat (Surat), Karnataka (Mysuru), Rajasthan etc,” says Apte.Reacting to his post, Avinash Hemdev wrote: “Thousands of bats at a location in Chennai have drastically reduced. Something’s up!” Mumbai-based Niranjan Demanna shared similar trend: “We have a fig tree next to our building and every year, we used to see 50-60 bat. This year, we didn’t see a single bat.”While residents of RBI Colony in Prabhadevi in Mumbai reported about a colony of bats vanishing around two weeks back, Kanchan Ankolekar highlighted how the mammals are no longer seen at the trees opposite Kachrali lake in Thane. “I received similar observation from Mysore by Dr Dipak Vyas,” says Apte.The observations have led to various conjectures to unlock the mystery of disappearing bats. According to some, it is quite common for the species to change roosts. “But as a naturalist, for me the question is why is it happening from so many locations at the same time. Is it due to the onset of summer or is it because silence due to lockdown having some effect on these mammals? They are urban bats and generationally used to very high noise, illumination and other disturbances,” says Apte.According to well-known environmentalist D Stalin, who is also the director of NGO Vanashakti, a complete migration of a huge colony like the one reported by Apte is unusual. “I would attribute it to the onset of summer. Generally bats don’t venture out in winters and the activity is less. Having said that, factors like pollution are also responsible,” he says.Highlighting the role played by anthropogenic activities, Stalin adds, “Another reason could be if large trees, abandoned buildings or caves which are home to the bats are disturbed due to excessive human ingress, It can also cause migration of the specie.”Can the trend be related to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic? “It is too early to connect the lockdown with the recent incidents of migration of bats. Only a detailed data analysis will reveal the reasons,” feels Stalin.Experts, however, feel that being carriers of viruses like corona, bats can prove to useful in combating the disease. “Bats do not succumb to the viruses but manage to stay uninfected. This means their immune systems have the ability to fight viruses and in this lies the chance for humans to find the vaccines or medicines needed to fight virus pandemics,” says Stalin.In reply to Apte’s post, Dattaprasad Sawant had shared similar views. “Many other coronaviruses similar to Covid-19 are residing in bats. It seems bats are not affected by Covid 19,” he wrote.Even though bats are known to change their habitats, conservationists feel an in-depth scientific research is needed on the current disappearance. “Any mass migration of fauna is always an indicator of changes in the nearby environment. If there are no known recent modifications in the nearby environment, the disappearance of ecological indicators like bats need attention. So we should wait till the data is received from various parts of the country,” says Stalin.Stressing that having knowledge of roosting sites is important for conserving bats, Apte says, “They roost on large shady trees and in urban areas, felling of trees can also have a negative impact on these animals. They play absolutely valuable role in ecosystem. With rapidly changing climate, these animals are also exposed to climate vagaries.”

Title: Thousands of workers stuck in state have assembled at dist headquarters posing a big challenge for admin
Content:
Nainital/Dehradun: Thousands of migrant labourers are stuck in the interior areas of the state following the nationwide lockdown. Estimates suggest that there are scores of workers hailing from states like Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand as well as Nepal working in construction and mining projects across Uttarakhand on daily wages who are left with no money and help. On Monday, hundreds of such workers gathered at the district headquarters in Bageshwar hoping that the administration will arrange means for them to travel to their homes.

Other districts and block level offices across Kumaon and Garhwal have also reported that thousands of workers are stuck in remote areas of the state and are awaiting the government’s help to get food or to be evacuated. Shakeel Ahmed, a 50-year-old labourer who had come to Bageshwar said that he has been on the road for four days when he was told that the state government is allowing travel on March 31 and he can go to his home in Bareilly. “I work as a daily wager. I left my home in Kapkot four days ago and came here. However, when I went to the district headquarters, we were informed that the ordwer has been withdrawn,” he said.

Ahmed added that the administration didn’t even give them food or any other essential supplies when they asked for it. Some volunteers and activists from Red Cross society finally helped him. “We were turned away saying that we have no documents and therefore they cannot give us food. Finally some local residents helped us and made us stay in a local shelter,” he said.

Speaking to TOI, some locals and activists said that there are hundreds of people like Ahmed who have come to Bageshwar from places such as Kapkot, Garud and Kanda blocks and are in need of food and essential supplies.

“There are thousands of mining and construction daily wagers who are stuck in the interior areas of the state and are now coming to tehsils and district headquarters. These people are in dire need of help. Though the local residents have helped some of them, the administration also needs to get on its toes to provide relief,” said Pramod Mehta, a local activist.

People from Champawat and Tanakpur towns also reported that hundreds of migrants have started their long march from the interior areas to these towns so that they can get help to reach home. “People working on the National Highway project in Pithoragarh have also reached Tanakpur and Champawat town in the hope that they will now be able to travel to their homes. Many of them had the hopes that as the buses will start to run on Tuesday they will go home but that won't be possible now so they are on the mercy of the administration now,” said Amit Kumar a local of Tanakpur.

Kumaon commissioner Rajeev Rautela’s office said that local administrations have been directed to arrange essential items for the migrants and help will be provided without asking for any documents.

Meanwhile, an Uttarakhand Transport Corporation bus ferrying 50 state residents, living in Gujarat, was stopped at Haryana border on Monday. The bus had gone to Gujarat to pick up these people and was coming back to Uttarakhand. A communique from the CM’s office said that a Haryana police team denied permission to passengers to go ahead and added that the driver had to return to Uttarakhand without passengers.

Title: Senior citizens throng banks to collect pension
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: As expected, ignoring the instructions given by government to check the spread of Covid-19 , scores of people, mostly senior citizens , thronged banks on Monday to withdraw welfare pension Considering the safety of senior citizens, who are under high-risk category, and its own employees, several banks had tied up with local administration to arrange facilities like drinking water and sanitizers. “Despite all our efforts, people were not ready to maintain social distancing . So we called police who managed the situation in a sensitive manner. Nearly 200 people were given pension on Monday,” said an employee of a semi urban bank.Welfare pension of two months worth around Rs 2,400 was being distributed for senior citizens and widows. A bank employee said, “Many have a wrong notion that pension will be taken back if they fail to withdraw on time.” However, some had come as they didn’t have money to buy essentials and medicines, he added.DCP R Karuppasamy said situation was under control in city as there were enough banks. Rural SP B Ashok too said police effectively intervened to control the situation.Rajath H C, deputy general secretary of state bank staff union said they were able to manage the situation with the support of local administration and police. “Being senior citizens, most of them were hesitant to use alternate channels provided by the banks to withdraw money,” he said

Title: Tamil Nadu: Covid-19 patient beats loneliness with TikTok
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

TRICHY: A 25-year-old Covid-19 positive woman under treatment in the isolation ward of the Ariyalur government hospital has kicked up a storm on social media by recording and sharing videos on the TikTok platform. Attempts by the hospital management to take away the mobile phone went in vain as the patient held on to it firmly, telling the authorities that recording videos was her only means to overcome loneliness.

Ever since the woman, a native of Ariyalur who worked in a mall in Chennai, tested positive for Covid-19 on March 27, 2020, she has shared at least six videos from the isolation ward. On Monday evening, the woman was seen making videos with and without the facemask and an oxygen mask. The lip-sync videos in Tamil include funny takes on the Covid-19 outbreak. Some of the thousands of social media users who viewed it insisted that she ‘take rest’.

On coming to know about the videos going online, the hospital management advised the patient against recording and sharing them. But she argued that she was engaging in such activities to overcome the loneliness she was experiencing for the past five days. “At the moment, we are concerned about her recovery from Covid-19,” a senior medical professional from the Ariyalur GH said.

Health department officials said they have no instructions to seize mobile phones of patients in the isolation ward. They said counselling will be provided to the patient by a psychologist to ensure her mental health.

Trichy-based clinical psychologist Randeep Rajkumar said such behaviour is common in extroverts subjected to sudden isolation. “The mobile phone should remain with the patient as it will reduce her anxiety level. Snatching away the phone will only stress her further,” he said. Rajkumar also suggested relaying comedies or engaging videos in the isolation wards to prevent patients from feeling lonely. A few days ago, three sanitary workers in the Ariyalur GH were quarantined in the isolation ward for having close contact with the Covid-19 positive woman. One of the three workers reportedly took part in a TikTok video with the woman.

Title: KSUM’s Break Corona platform to spur innovation
Content:
Kochi: Kerala Startup Mission ( KSUM ) has launched ‘ Break Corona ’ initiative, to crowdsource ideas, spur innovations and product solutions that would be crucial in the fight against Covid-19.

Several startups in the state are already engaged in developing solutions and the platform breakcorona.in would bring together all initiatives to a single point for better coordination, officials said.

According to KSUM officials, the platform is looking at ideas and solutions that have been proven or used in some other scenario. These products should already have a Proof of Concept (PoC) and have potential usage in the fight against Covid-19. The mission is currently looking for ideas and products that support Covid-19 patients and those placed on quarantine. It is also looking at ideas to prevent community outbreak, logistics for distributing food, medicine and grocery, support vulnerable people like children and aged.

“If these products are good enough, the state government would adopt them. KSUM will support the startups to implement or manufacture them if the PoC is sound,” said a KSUM official.

KSUM is also looking at ideas that can create job opportunities during lockdown and manufacture of Do It Yourself (DIY) products like masks, gloves and sanitizers.

Students, innovators, individuals, communities and NGOs can also register at the platform to participate in the initiative.

Individual applicants or teams that submits ideas and solutions are expected to have good domain knowledge. The ideas submitted will be evaluated by a panel of experts in the respective domains. The selected ideas will have to be realized by the applicant and they will have to make prototypes on their own.

KSUM has partnered with the GTech group of companies and IMA Trivandrum to vet the ideas and implement them.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Help comes clad in khaki for these hard-hit daily wage earners
Content:
K Suguna, inspector atttached to the Panthanallur police station in Thanjavur district, has been distributing ... Read More

THANJAVUR: Help came clad in khaki for the daily wage earners under the Panthanallur police station limits in Thanjavur who are struggling to make ends meet due to the lockdown to fight Covid-19.

Under the station’s jurisdiction are hamlets Panthanallur, Keela Katur, Mela Kattur, Karuppur and Vellore, whose inhabitants are mostly daily wage earners, engaged in construction, agriculture and conservancy work. The natiowide lockdown has left them without work, and hence no money to put some food on the plate.

To help them, inspector K Suguna of the Panthanallur police station, has been giving out essentials for free, spending money out of her own pocket.

“My team and I have been going to each hamlet to sensitise people on Covid-19 and why it is necessary for them to stay indoors to avoid spread of coronavirus. On one such visit on March 25, I saw some villagers struggle to put together a meal since they had no income,” said Suguna, adding that if the villagers didn’t get any work, they went hungry.

“I wanted to help them out somehow. So, I volunteered to distribute essentials like rice, dal and soap to those struggling,” she added. She now distributes groceries that can help them tide over a few days at least.

“Our higher officers had instructed us to help people in all possible ways, to make them stay at home. As of now, I am doing this using my own money. My colleagues have assured to help too,” she said.

Inspector Suguna’s good deed has earned appreciation from her seniors and villagers alike.

Title: Nepal’s extension of lockdown leaves 600 labourers stranded at border crossing
Content:
Pithoragarh: More than 600 Nepalese labourers, on their way back to their country, have been stranded at Dharchula, as Nepal on Monday extended its lockdown for the next eight days.

Most of the labourers are from districts in Nepal adjoining Pithoragarh.

After India went into lockdown last week, they decided to return home. But with Nepal also imposing lockdown simultaneously, they got stranded at Dharchula.

One of the stranded men, Man Bahadur, said, “I walked 45 km with my wife and two children from Didihat, reaching Dharchula on March 29, in the hope the suspension bridge across the border here would be open. But the Nepal government did not open the gates on Monday, so we are forced to stay here.”

Another Nepalese citizen, Deepak Kumar, said he had walked from Pangla, 35 km away.Although Nepal had closed the border with India between March 23 and 29, it allowed 215 and 160 workers respectively on both dates to cross the suspension bridges at the borders in Dharchula and Jhulaghat on March 27, said Pithoragarh DM Vijay Kumar Jogdande. But on Monday, the Nepal government extended its lockdown till April 7, and did not open the borders, he added, even as more Nepalese arrived, hoping to cross over.The DM said that the district administration will make arrangements for shelter and food for those stranded.

Meanwhile, civil society groups like Rung Museum, Garbyal Mahila Sangh and Pahari Jayaka are also arranging rations for the stranded Nepalese, said Salu Datal, a local resident.

Meanwhile, sources said that four of the stranded labourers decided to swim across the Kali river, which forms the natural border between the two countries , to reach Nepal. Three of them managed to cross over, where they were immediately arrested by Nepal Police. The fourth person turned back from mid-river.

Title: Cook extra meals for needy,politicians appeal to locals
Content:
Many social organisations have come forward to help people by providing food and other needs

Kanpur: The MP, MLAs and MLCs of Kanpur, in a joint appeal, urged residents to prepare an extra meal everyday and inform the police stations of their areas so that the meal could be collected and delivered to the underprivileged in the city.

The joint appeal was made by state ministers Satish Mahana, Neelima Katiyar, Bhagwati Prasad Sagar, Akbarpur, MP Devendra Singh Bhole, city MP Satyadeo Pachauri, MLAs Surendra Maithani, Amitabh Bajpai, Sohail Ansari, Irafan Solanki and MLC Arun Pathak.

State industrial minister Satish Mahana asked the district authorities to identify slums and localities of daily wage labourers so that meals could be delivered regularly to their homes and those areas could be sanitized from time to time. “Several volunteer organizations have also been delivering food. Apart from this, a centre has been made at KDA for volunteers to collect food and distribute to the needy. The administration has so far provided meals to 32,000 persons in the city and to 14,000 in rural areas of the district. Community kitchens will soon be activated,” said Kanpur DM Dr Brahmadeo Tiwari.

In an appeal to the citizens, the district administration called upon the residents to donate funds in DM relief fund to help the needy.

Uttar Pradesh Cricket Associaton (UPCA) has announced to donate a sum of Rs 50 lakh to the state government.

Additional labour commissioner SP Shukla, in a communiqué, informed that a total of Rs 7,21,39,000 had been distributed among 72139 labourers of six districts of Kanpur division.

Meanwhile, the central control room had received around 763 complaints on Saturday, related to health department, police, KMC, civil supply Jalkal, KDA and food security and drug administration.

Title: Trichy: Man, 28, held for abduction, sexual assault of 8-year-old
Content:
Representative image

Trichy: A 28-year-old man was arrested by the Trichy Fort all women police station (AWPS) in for abducting and sexually assaulting an eight-year-old girl on Sunday night.

The accused has been identified as M Rajendran. Police sources said the girl was on her way back home from a shop around 8pm when the the accused intercepted her. He dragged her to a spot behind a ration shop and sexually assaulted her, a police officer said. Some residents of the area noticed him abusing the girl and rescued her. She returned home and told her father who then lodged a complaint with the AWPS.

Police arrested Rajendran and booked him under sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act. He was remanded in judicial custody on Monday. The girl was sent to the Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital for an examination.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: ‘Dial an Auto’ service gets upgrade to meet demand
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Since its launch on March 24, the ‘Dial an Autorickshaw’ initiative has served more than 1,200 people.

With the average number of daily calls going past the 1,500-mark, the authorities have decided to enable WhatsApp on the same number (9859198591) so that more requests can be fielded.

The service was launched to address the emergency travel needs of people. In the week since it started, CityGlide Auto, which provides the service in coordination with the Pune traffic police, has received more than 11,000 phone calls — a daily average of nearly 1,600.

“We are operating 180 autorickshaws, but the number of calls has gone up exponentially, and we are not able to receive many of those calls. With our Twitter handles now receiving requests, people can now also send a message on WhatsApp on the same number to place a request ,” Rahul Shitole, CityGlide CEO, said.

He said only those in need of essential travel, as mentioned in the government’s notification regarding the lockdown, must place a request.

“By Tuesday or Wednesday, a fleet of 100 more autorickshaws will be pressed into service, meaning more customers can be served. All autorickshaw drivers have been provided approval certificates by traffic police,” Shitole said, adding that there was also an advance booking option.

“Close to 70% calls from people are related to medical issues. People have appointments for dialysis or chemotherapy session, and need autorickshaws. Such people can now either WhatsApp or tweet us their details, the emergency, the date of the appointment, etc, preferably a day or two in advance. This apart, we also get requests from people wanting to buy medicines and from those living in hostels,” Shitole said.

The request must contain details like name, contact number, full address, specific purpose of travel, travel date, destination and time of pickup. A tweet with the same details can be sent to @RahulShitole11. Only one person wearing a mask will be allowed in an autorickshaw. Hand sanitizers will be provided by the drivers

Title: Govt distributing free dry ration for poor in curfew belt
Content:
Jaipur: The district administration has already started distributing free dry ration to the poor people living in the curfew-affected areas on a priority basis. A survey is being conducted by the administration to identify poor families in the district outside the coverage of National Food Security Act (NFSA), said authorities.

The state government has released food supplies for one month now, and for the second month it will be released next week. The free dry ration include 5 kg Atta, 1 kg Daal, 1 kg rice, 1 kg salt, 100 gm haldi, 100 gm red chilly, half kg cooking oil and one soap.

District Collector Joga Ram said the government has already paid Rs 1,000 each to every poor family of two categories – non pensioner and daily-wage labourers. The district administration has also started disbursing two months’ pension to the beneficiaries, he said.

To ensure that no family faces a shortage of food supplies, Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot had announced that families registered under NFSA and other poor families will get the two months of free ration in advance. The state government had also announced a package of Rs 310 crore to provide immediate cash relief of Rs 1,000 every poor family in the state.

“Beneficiaries of NFSA are getting ration through public distribution system (PDS). We have started distributing free ration in curfew-affected areas on a priority basis. We are doing a survey to identify those poor families which are outside NFS coverage. We have identified some people and the rest will be identified soon,” said Joga Ram.

The survey is being conducted by a team of civil defence personnel in Jaipur Nagar Nigam area and the same team will distribute dry ration the areas under the corporation.

Title: 8 people admitted to Ooty govt hospital
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Eight people , who returned from New Delhi after attending a religious meeting there, have been shifted from home quarantine to the isolation ward in Ooty Government Headquarters hospital.

They left Ooty on March 20 and returned after four days.

“They are among the 1,500 people who attended a religious meeting in New Delhi. They had left Ooty on March 20 and returned on 24th,” deputy director of public health Dr P Balusamy said. The eight people were under home quarantine till Sunday. “Today, we have shifted them to the isolation ward in Ooty government headquarters hospital,” he said.

“Though they don’t display any symptoms, samples lifted from them have been sent for tests,” he added.

Meanwhile, collector J Innocent Divya said, “Out of 733 people who are under home quarantine in the district, 50 have been released.”

The rest 683 are under the process of daily monitoring, Divya said.

“We are also adopting the containment plan as instructed by the government. However, as far as Nigiris district is concerned, there is no positive case of COVID-19,” she added.

Pointing out that the meat market in Ooty was found too crowded on Sunday, Divya said, “We have decided to decentralize the markets in Ooty and Coonoor towns at ward levels so that people would be contained at their areas.”

Ward level markets of vegetables and fruits will be started from April 1.

“We are also monitoring that the essential commodity supply chain is not broken in the district,” the collector said.

A nodal officer has been appointed to take necessary steps to see that the guest labourers in the district are provided with basic amenities. Quoting the governments clarification in connection with tea manufacturing in the Nilgiris, Divya said, “Manufacture and production of tea can be undertaken subject to general restrictions and other safety measures are adhered to.”

Title: Traders in Delhi's CP offer free meals to guards, workers
Content:
The noble thought of starting a kitchen for poor people struck the traders three days ago when they realised t... Read More

NEW DELHI: Traders of Connaught Place have opened their hearts to support people who can’t find anything to eat because of the lockdown. New Delhi Traders Association (NDTA) has set up a "Good Samaritan kitchen" which offers free lunch and dinner to about 350 people in the time of coronavirus crisis. The beneficiaries include guards deployed at nearby shops and ATMs, sanitation workers, petrol pump employees and other stranded and needy people.

The noble thought of starting a kitchen for poor people struck the traders three days ago when they realised that those guarding their shops were struggling to find food. Due to the lockdown, all the dhabas are closed in the area and the guards can’t even go back to their hometown.

“Most of them stay in the shops only. After the lockdown was announced for 21 days and everything was shut down, these people started facing difficulty in finding food. We discussed the issue with police and New Delhi Municipal Council. After they gave their permission, we managed to get curfew passes for cooks and subsequently started the kitchen for the guards. Later, we started offering food to NDMC sanitation staff and other needy also,” said Vikram Badhwar, secretary of NDTA.
