The "Good Samaritan kitchen" has been set up with the help of QBA restaurant.

“We were initially supplying food packets for 200-250 people daily. However, the demand kept on increasing. Now, we distribute 350 food packets twice a day,” said Aditya Jain, owner of QBA restaurant.

“Safety of staff and people is our priority. While we maintain social distancing during food distribution, local police and NDMC staff are also helping us in distribution of food packets at different locations,” added Jain.

Other members of the association are doing their bit by distributing fruits, sanitisers, masks and even boxes for packaging food material.

Amit Gupta, a NDTA member, said that the trader association is committed to serve humanity and support the administration in every possible manner. “We have other restaurants, including Embassy and Bill Chill, which have agreed to help with food and distribution material,” he said, adding that the service will continue till the lockdown continues.

Title: Virus won’t kill, being jobless will: Migrant workers
Content: JAIPUR: Kamal Singh is jobless and homeless but fearless. Tears roll down his cheeks, but there is still a spark of determination in his eyes. For the moment, he is not worried about coronavirus , the lockdown or even the sealing of inter-state borders. All he wants is to safely take his wife Jyoti Devi and 4-year-old son David to their Etawah home in Uttar Pradesh On a mission to cover a distance of 1,100 km, passing through three states — Gujarat, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh — they are still 400 km away from home.A house painter at Chandoria in Ahmedabad who earned around Rs 12,000 a month, he along with his wife and kid have already covered almost 680 km from his workplace to Jaipur mostly on foot barring a few lifts in trucks and tempos here and there in the last three days.Asked why he is crying, Kamal said, “I am worried about my son. He is just a kid and has to go through all this. I am not worried about myself. All that matters to me is the well-being of my wife and son. I have to get them home without harm. The virus won’t kill us, joblessness will,” said Kamal while talking to TOI at Adarsh Nagar.He is aware that such a reverse migration could bring the pandemic from cities to villages where healthcare facilities are grossly inadequate. “We started from Ahmedabad at 10am yesterday (Saturday). On the way we took rides on tempos, small trucks and buses and walked the rest of the distance. We reached Jaipur this morning. Since 8am, we have been walking. From here, I will go to Agra and head towards Pali Khurd village in Etawah. We ate whatever we got on the way. If we manage to get any vehicle, we will board it…Let’s see…I am not left with a single penny,” he said inconsolably.The only saving grace was that they did not go hungry, thanks to various NGOs who are on the job of feeding thousands of migrant workers to their best of capacity.“The lockdown snatched my job. I took a loan of Rs 1,000 from my contractor but now I am penniless and we are still around 400 km away from home. There were around 20 of us who were working as painters. All have left Ahmedabad,” he said.“My kid has also been walking with us for miles. I want to carry him on my shoulders but I have a heavy bag which I need to carry. That’s our only possession. I just can’t hold my tears seeing my son trudge along with us with his tender feet,” he said.Jyoti Devi is shattered too. She is worried on what the future has in store for them. “It was an okay job. We were happy and satisfied. I don’t know from where this virus hit us leading to this lockdown,” she said.Like Kamal, her only worry is also about their son. “He has been walking without any complaints. Why is God so cruel,” she complained.So what’s next? Kamal doesn ’t have any answers. For the time being, getting back home is his only target. “Let’s see. I can’t tell you what’s in store,” he said.

Title: 94-yr-old murder convict released after Allahabad HC order
Content:
Allahabad high court

PRAYAGRAJ: Amid closure of courts due to lockdown in the state, the Allahabad High Court on Monday, while accepting urgency of the matter, suspended sentence of a 94-year-old convict in a murder case and directed him to be released on bail on furnishing a personal bond of Rs 5,000 only.

Hearing a criminal appeal filed by one Suryavansh of Gorakhpur district , a division bench comprising Chief Justice Govind Mathur and Justice Siddhartha Varma passed the above order and directed the state counsel to ensure compliance of the order at the earliest and file compliance report within a week.

The petitioner had filed a criminal appeal challenging his conviction and sentence passed by sessions court of Gorakhpur on January 24, 2020, in a murder case.

The court while suspending the sentence of the convict considering his old age said, “The crime occurred on March 28, 1978, and at that time, age of Suryavansh was 40 years. It is brought to our notice that Suryavansh is now 94 years old.”

“Having considered this aspect of the matter, we are inclined to allow this application. Accordingly, the bail application is allowed. The sentence awarded to Suryavansh is suspended till the disposal of appeal,” said the bench.

Besides, the court directed additional government advocate, who was representing the state government, to ensure compliance of the order at the earliest and file a compliance report within a week.

Title: He fills fuel, but considers the duty as his ‘seva’
Content:
Ravi Gundela

RAJKOT: When Ravi Gundela leaves home at 6am , his 3-year-old daughter is still fast asleep blissfully ignorant of the hazards that her father daily undertakes in order to keep his small family safe.

A petrol pump attendant, Gundela’s job does not permit him to work from home, an advantage most of his neighbours, friends, and relatives are having under the lockdown.

But thanks to an informed wife, Gundela follows the safety rules to the T — from mask and gloves to washing hands and using sanitizer — he is battle-ready the moment he steps out to work. Fearing that her husband may get infected with Covid-19 virus, and worse still, he may be a carrier of the virus affecting the family, she keeps herself updated on every latest bit of information available on newspapers and television.

Gundela’s duty at the petrol pump near Ramapir Chokdi on 150 feet Ring Road starts at 6:30am and ends at 2:30pm. “I consider it as a seva and my duty at this time of crisis. Petrol falls under essential commodities, so we are required to remain on duty. Even when customers rush in, I use my own judgement to give petrol looking at the genuineness of the customer. We remain on duty to provide petrol to vehicles engaged in providing essential services in the city,” said Gundela, who earns Rs 10,000 every month.

Stating that he comes across a variety of people every day, some who thank him with a smile to those arguing endlessly for change, Gundela said that he takes it all in his stride. “I see appreciation in the eyes of people I serve, thanking us for working for them. Many people come apprehensively fearing we may turn them back, but after getting the fuel they feel extremely grateful,” he added with a smile, happy to be of help to the needy.

Gopal Chudasama, owner of the petrol station where Gundela is employed, said, “Though the demand for fuel has decreased by 80 per cent, we have to keep our petrol station open but as fuel falls under essential commodities. People from nearby areas who are engaged in emergency services like ambulance come to fill fuel in the vehicles.”

Title: Community kitchens rise up to the occasion
Content:
Volunteers feed stray animals in the city on Monday

PRAYAGRAJ: In a bid to offer meals to migrant workers, poor and homeless during the lockdown, volunteers of the Om Namay Shiva – a religious and spiritual organisation which used to serve pilgrims during Kumbh, Ardh Kumbh and Magh Melas – has set up a community kitchen at Gau Ghat to cater to around 20,000 people daily.

Head of the organisation Prabhu Ji told TOI that a team of 30 volunteers has been engaged to prepare food packets for the migrants and homeless people. District and police officers would distribute these packets among the needy, he said adding that “on Monday, we prepared the meal for 4,000 people. They were served food packets in the morning and evening.”

From Tuesday, meal for 20,000 people would be prepared and for that, hi-tech machines have been brought for kneading flour and cutting vegetables, making the volunteers’ job a little easier.

The organisation used to serve around 50,000 pilgrims daily during Kumbh, Ardh Kumbh and at other religious gatherings. The organisation has brought two flour kneading and three vegetable cutting machines from Gujarat. Both the machines have been installed at its Gau ghat kitchen. A volunteer said, “Automatic hi-tech machines would make volunteers’ task a litter easier and we would be able to serve the needy.”

The organisation has also set up community kitchens in Lucknow and Kanpur. While organisation is preparing meal for 50,000 people in Kanpur, meal for 25,000 has been prepared by its volunteers in Lucknow.

Meanwhile, traders associated with Civil Lines Vyapaar Mandal distributed food packets among migrants and homeless people at Thornhill Road, Hanuman Mandir, Civil Lines and adjoining areas. A team of traders led by Sushil Kharbanda , president of the the Civil Lines Vyapaar Mandal distributed food packets in the morning and evening hours.

“We have set up a small kitchen to prepare meals and we are trying to reach out to the poor,” he added.

At the same time, many Samaritans are forgetting about the importance of social distancing while going around streets to distribute relief materials among those stranded because of the lockdown. With a vaccine or cure yet to be discovered for novel coronavirus, doctors have vehemently advocated that people practise social distancing to keep Covid-19 at bay.

At most shelters in the city, inmates can be seen sitting in close groups, right next to each other without maintaining the mandatory distance of at least a metre.

At shops too, residents are failing to stand apart in their hurry to buy essential commodities.

At KP community Centre on MG Road, workers who had come for a medical checkup being conducted by the administration, were seen sitting too close to each other on Monday, ignoring precautionary.

“One has to understand that helping the poor and others is a noble cause and the administration appreciates the Good Samaritans’ efforts, but residents have to ensure that they protect themselves as well as those who are stranded,” said Prayagraj district magistrate Bhanu Chandra Goswami .

Title: CSIR-NCL to soon submit R&D of making raw material for drugs
Content:
Pune: The CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory will help in making raw material (Key Starting Material) to make active pharmaceutical ingredients used to make many bulk drugs in the time of Covid-19.

The Indian pharmaceutical industry is the third-largest by volume, but is critically dependent on imports of raw material. The dependency, in some cases, extent to over 80%, particularly from China.

A senior researcher at National Chemical Laboratory (NCL) said, “If the lockdown continues for a longer duration, there may be a time in future when the pharmaceutical companies may face a shortage of raw material to make drugs. India has one of the largest number of Food and Drug Administration-approved manufacturing sites, outside the US. We supply the final drugs to a lot of countries, including China. But we need self-sufficiency. We at NCL will make the technology that helps create the Key Starting Material.”

CSIR-NCL director Ashwini Kumar Nangia said, “We are hopeful that the CSIR-NCL will be able to soon release the research and development (R&D) reports to the government and chemical and pharmaceutical industry bodies. Each laboratory-scale process will be ready in the next few weeks and months to be taken up for manufacturing by the Indian drug companies. The capability and infrastructure for further synthesis of the final active pharmaceutical ingredients from the intermediate Key Starting Material largely exist in the country.”

Another NCL researcher said, “Projects are already on for manufacturing 3-4 Key Starting Material. For another 4-5 Key Starting Material, the process to manufacture it is already designed. This has been done keeping in mind the cost, safety and other parameters.”

Title: Unsung warriors: Cop leaves ailing father; another postpones marriage to respond to call of duty
Content:
DEHRADUN: While doctors, health staff and sanitary workers are engaged in the frontline fight against Covid-19, the men and women in khaki are also putting their best foot forward in this battle.

Take 26-year-old constable Champa Mehra for instance. Her father Ram Singh is fighting for life in a hospital in Haldwani but Mehra put her duty above her family and foregoing the leave she had taken to take care of her father, rode her motorcycle for 290-km to reach Dehradun to take her place in the police control room where she is handling hundreds of calls daily from people who are affected due to the lockdown. “With lockdown being announced, I decided that I will return to Dehradun at the earliest as the control room plays an important role in an emergency situation. Leaving my father behind with my siblings, I rode my motorycle from Nainital to Dehradun to reach as fast as I could,” Mehra told TOI.

The police control room is receiving around 9,000 to 10,000 calls per day. Of which, Mehra said that she was handling around 300 to 400 calls each day. “Almost all of them are from people, who do not have food or there is an immediate health issue. There is a staff of 54 call operators, who work in eight-hour shifts in the control room. I know that my father is extremely critical but at the same time, it is important to save thousands of people in this mega fight against Covid-19,” said the constable.

It is a similar story for 30-year-old Laeek Ahmed, who is posted at Civil Lines police station at Roorkee. Ahmed postponed his marriage to be on the field during this critical time saying “my conscience was not allowing me to go on leave when my colleagues are in the frontline to tackle this threat.” Ahmed’s wedding was scheduled for April 5 this year.

When asked whether he took the decision of postponing his marriage in consultation with his would-be-wife, Ahmed said, “She totally supported my decision and so did my family. Although her family initially wanted the marriage to take place on time, but later, they also supported my decision.”

During the lockdown, Ahmed is now doing a 12-hour daily shift in different places of Roorkee. “I am doing my bit to enforce the lockdown effectively and convincing people to stay at home, so that we can win this battle against the disease,” he said.

Meanwhile, Dehradun SSP/DIG Arun Mohan Joshi praised the efforts of his team in handling the situation. “Apart from these two instances, there are several other police personnel cooking food for people in need, providing them the required assistance and also distributing water and food packets to needy people.”

Title: Govts lean on Tablighi Jamaat to get its members screened
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre and state governments are leaning on Tablighi Jamaat to get its members to report to the authorities for Covid-19 screening . A source said central and state agencies had asked members of the Islamic evangelical outfit to ensure that all those who came into contact with its foreign members go for virus scan immediately.A home ministry source on Tuesday said while the priority right was to locate/trace, screen, quarantine and, where needed, hospitalise the 824 identified foreign Tablighi Jamaat members who were on religious preaching duties across the country as well as Indian members who came in contact with them, the foreign preachers could subsequently be deported as and when international flights resume, and blacklisted for indulging in missionary activities while on tourist visa. Blacklisting debars a foreigner from future travel to India.TOI had on Tuesday exclusively reported that the foreign Tablighi preachers would face blacklisting for violating their tourist visa conditions.The home ministry on Tuesday said it had shared a list of 824 foreigners engaged in Tablighi Jamaat’s “religious preaching” activities across the country with state police forces as early as March 21 for identifying the individuals, getting them screened for Covid-19 and quarantining them. This was after some Tablighi members, who were on a tour of the country, tested positive in Erode in Tamil Nadu and Hyderabad.Some of the 824 foreign Tablighi preachers have already been located by respective states and are currently under quarantine or hospitalisation. According to the ministry, as on March 21, 1,746 people were staying at Nizamuddin. These included 216 foreigners and 1,530 Indians.In all, some 2,100 Tablighis arrived since January 1. These were largely from Bangladesh (493), Indonesia (472), Malaysia (150) and Thailand (143). Of these, 824 were sent across the country — to UP (132), Tamil Nadu (125), Maharashtra (115), Haryana (115), Telangana (82), West Bengal (70), Karnataka (50), MP (49), Andhra Pradesh (24), Rajasthan (13) and Odisha (11) preaching. “Those who only attended the Tablighi conferences are not facing any violation of tourist visa condition,” said an officer.All Tablighi Jamaat workers staying at Nizamuddin are being medically screened since March 26. “Since March 23, lockdown has been strictly imposed, including in and around Nizamuddin, and Tablighi work came to a halt,” said a release. Two conferences took place at its headquarters, one on March 15-17 and another on March 21-23. Both, a source said, were south India-centric.The Centre had on March 28 advised the state police to also collect names of Indian Tablighi Jamaat workers from local coordinators, locate them, get them screened and quarantined. This was after it learnt that some Indians were at a Tablighi congregation in Kuala Lumpur from February 27 to March 1, and subsequent “open source” reports indicated that many attendees had tested positive for Covid-19.About 2,137 Indian members have been identified in different states and are being medically examined and quarantined.The Bureau of Immigration had been sharing (since February 1) with states, details of all international arrivals from affected countries. Since March 6, it has been sharing details of all international arrivals.

Title: Shirdi temple gives food to migrants
Content:
NASHIK: Shri Saibaba Sansthan Trust, Shirdi, on Sunday distributed food packets to around 2,500 migrants who were on their way to Rajasthan from Karnataka in as many as 66 buses.

The food packets were distributed by members of the trust when these buses stopped at Shirdi. Arun Dongre , CEO of the trust, said, “The district collector had informed us that the travelers will be passing from Shirdi and had requested us to prepare food packets for them. We were ready with the food packets and water bottles before their arrival. The buses halted in Shirdi at 6 pm for 30 minutes.”

The trust had also decided not to open the temple doors for anyone due to the lockdown. “We did not let anyone come on the temple premises as it would have been a violation of the lockdown rule. The buses were stopped near Shirdi police station where we gave 50 food packets and water bottles to every bus,” Dongre said.

“The food packets included chapati , sabji and fried rice . All the necessary precautions were taken while distributing the food,” he added.

Title: Maharashtra: Drones to keep a watch on people’s movement
Content: PUNE: Police have started using drone cameras to monitor the movement of people in the semi-urban belts of the Nanded City area, Baramati, Wagholi, Lonavala and Loni Kalbhor to monitor people’s movement during the lockdown period in the wake of the coronavius outbreak.“The surveillance will continue till April 14 and people violating the lockdown rules will be caught,” superintendent of police (Pune Rural) Sandeep Patil said.The officer said the use of the drones would reduce the burden of police personnel deployed on patrolling duty. “A police team will be immediately sent to the spot in case of any violation recorded on the drone cameras. We will take appropriate action against the violators,” Patil said.Two days ago, the Gujarat police had started keeping an eye on different areas through drones fitted with high-definition cameras. The police monitored citizens roaming in narrow lanes or common plots in residential colonies with the help of the drones and booked the violators.

Title: Pune: Hospitals to get negative ion generators to fight Covid-19
Content: PUNE: The negative ion generator developed by an incubatee firm at the Science and Technology Park in Savitribai Phule Pune University will soon be installed at various hospitals across the state to control viral, bacterial and fungal infections.The Science and Technology Park is an institute promoted by the department of science and technology (DST) of the Indian government and the Savitribai Phule Pune University.Department of science and technology has released Rs1 crore to manufacture and scale up the product, built by JClean Weather Technologies. As many as 1,000 units would soon be ready for installation in various hospitals in Maharashtra, the state government said.The principal innovator behind the technology, DB Jadhav, said, “We built it some 6-7 years ago. A year ago, we incubated a company with STP. We are working on a model with them, which will be effective in 1km radius.”Jadhav, a former employee of the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology, said he used to put aside 20% of his salary every month for research. “These machines cost about Rs 40,000 each. We have received Rs 50 lakh from DST and will receive remaining amount after some time. Our facility in Pashan will be able to manufacture about 200 units in seven days and remaining will be manufactured in a phased manner,” he said.One hour of operation of the negative ion generator machine reduces viral load within a room by 99.7% depending on room size. Four such machines have already been installed at Naidu hospital in Pune.“This machine generates negative ions at 10*8 (10 raised to the power 8) ions per second. This starts a continuous chain reaction in its vicinity. Unlike other micro-organisms, viruses cannot live on their own as they are just a strand of RNA with a protein cover. These negative ions immediately react with the hydrogen in the protein cover, effectively destroying the virus or disinfecting the virus, which means it is no longer able to attack humans,” said Science and Technology Park’s director general Rajendra Jagdale.

Title: In Walled City, cops distribute food packets
Content:
Jaipur: Police on Monday conducted a flag march in the areas which are under curfew in Walled City. During the day, door-to-door delivery of the essential items was done using e-rickshaws. Cops, who have devised a sector-wise plan for home delivery of the essential products, also distributed 1,29,707 packets of food to the needy and the migrants.

After a Covid-19 positive case was found in Ramganj police station area of the state capital, the authorities decided to impose Section 144 from Friday evening. The order came into effect from 7pm on Friday till the next order for Ramganj, Subash Chowk, Manak Chowk , Kotwali and all the areas under Galta Gate, Brahmapuri and Nahargarh police stations. The order prohibits movement of people outside their houses. Barring emergency health services, all commercial establishments will remain closed in the area. Hospitals and medical stores will remain open.All religious places will remain closed till Section 144 remains imposed. However, authorities of religious places have been permitted to depute a minimum staff of five for cleaning the premises.

On Monday, cops seized 224 vehicles for violating the lock down across the city and since the lock down has been imposed, a total of 2851 vehicles have been seized.

Cops also arrested four persons for defying section 144 on Monday and till now 28 people have been taken into custody for the same.

A total of 11 persons have been arrested till now for spreading fake news about the coronavirus. Five cases have also been registered against shopkeepers for black marketing

Title: DM withdraws limited permit to operate market in view of big crowds
Content:
Pilibhit: District magistrate Vaibhav Shrivastav on Monday decided to withdraw the permission granted to purchase food essentials from the market, in view of heavy crowds, with effect from Tuesday. The administration had earlier allowed grocery and fresh fruit and vegetable shops to function everyday between 7 and 10 am. The DM also warned the administration could take more harsh steps to prevent crowds at markets.

It is estimated there are over 700 kirana and daily needs’ shops in Pilibhit city. The administration had permitted operation of the fruit and vegetable market at the agriculture produce marketing committee campus, as well as kirana shops, pharmacies and shops for seeds, fertilisers and insecticides for farmers in the general market.

“We’re bound to close down the market indefinitely as people are not heeding repeated appeals of the administration to follow social distancing norms, and thronging the markets. It is better to withdraw the market schedule instead of imposing a curfew to prevent transmission of novel coronavirus,” Shrivastav said.

He added that door-to-door supply of vegetables would continue. “We will soon make arrangements for supply of food, milk etc at doorsteps in urban areas to keep markets free of crowds. It has already been implemented in rural areas,” he said.

Title: Shop owner, 2 more held for attacking govt officials
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Kazhakootam police on Monday arrested the owner and two employees of a supermarket at Menamkulam for assaulting civil supplies officials.

Two rationing inspectors of taluk supply office here were conducting inspection at a supermarket, when its owner and staff had an altercation with the official. Following this, they assaulted the rationing inspectors, taluk supply officer and his driver inflicting injuries.

“Civil supplies have formed several squads to check hoarding and fleecing at shops and supermarkets. And we are assigned to inspect open markets and shops. For past three days, we have been witnessing crowd at a supermarket. Hence, we asked people to disperse and informed the supermarket owner about that danger of overcrowding. On Monday, rationing staff Simi and Sufeela, who went to speak to the owners, were verbally abused and assaulted. My driver Jayakrishnan also suffered injuries in the ruckus. I informed the police,” said A Shanavas, taluk supply officer, Thiruvananthapuram.

Kazhakootam police arrested supermarket owner Johnson and staff Nikhil K Samuel and Nithin K Samuel. tnn

Title: Eunuchs give back to society, open up their coffers
Content:
A eunuch in Baranpura area of Vadodara distributing food

VADODARA: Eunuchs will be among the first ones to arrive if there is a celebration at your house and may go only after they are paid adequate amount. But in the present situation when people are sitting at home and many from economically humble background are left with no food, these eunuchs have opened their coffers to make sure that nobody sleeps hungry.

Eunuchs in Godhra and Vadodara are going from door-to-door to distribute food or supplying it to the needy ones through NGOs since the lockdown came into effect.

“We do not have any businesses and the money that we have is of the society. So today since the society is in need, we are only giving it back but in different form. Never in my life of 55 years, I have seen such days,” said Kalpana Kunwar of Baranpura in Vadodara.

Eunuchs in Godhra started distributing grains, milk, water and other essential items in slums from Saturday.

Puja said that within two days they have distributed food and grains in 300 houses and are planning to reach out to many more . “For next two days we are making food packets and giving them to NGOs so they can distribute to people walking back to their homes on highways. Monday onwards we will be distributing rice, dried snacks, oil and masalas,” said Kalpana.

“When we go to people’s homes, we ask for money as we consider it as our right and give our blessings but today time is such that we are trying to give people more than our blessings,” Puja added.

Title: Local bodies not to insist on taxes for 3 months: Minister
Content:
Coimbatore: Municipal administration minister S P Velumani said the local bodies would not insist on payment of taxes for three months till June.

Talking to reporters after chairing a Covid-19 review meeting in the city on Monday, Velumani said people need not worry about paying house tax, water tax and other tax heads now. “Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami has given a three-month time for tax payers of city corporations and other local bodies,’’ he said.

On the steps taken to prevent spreading of Covid-19 and treatment of those who tested positive, Velumani said that in addition to ESI hospital which has been turned into an exclusive Covid-19 treatment facility with 400 beds, 240 beds in eight upgraded primary health centres, 150 beds in Pollachi government hospital, 29 beds in Mettupalayam GH and 750 beds in various private hospitals have been kept ready to accommodate people with the symptoms. “In all, 1,569 beds in isolation wards and 387 ventilators are in place,’’ he said.

He said 500 doctors and 400 nurses from Coimbatore Medical College Hospital and ESI Hospital are working round-the-clock.

Title: Camps held to overcome blood dearth
Content:
Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Social organisations in Pimpri Chinchwad city are holding blood donation camps to tide over the likely blood shortage.

The Thergaon Social Foundation (TSF) recently conducted a two-day blood donation camp and collected 150 bottles of blood. Rahul Sarvade, member, TSF, said, "We had shared a link through the social media, appealing to people interested in donating blood to send their details. The camp was held on March 28 and 29."

Another blood camp was held at Golden Care hospital in Hinjewadi on Monday.

Title: Erring officials will face action, warns CM
Content: New Delhi: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday said strict action would be taken against officials who did not act on time against the religious gathering organised by Tablighi Jamaat in Nizamuddin Calling the gathering highly irresponsible and wrong, Kejriwal said, “Till now, 1,548 people have been brought out of Alami Markaz (headquarters of Tablighi Jamaat), and 441 of them were symptomatic. They have been shifted to hospitals... The rest, 1,107 people, who did not show symptoms, have been quarantined.” He later said 24 of the group had tested positive.In the middle of March, people from various countries gathered for the three-day congregation at Markaz, which has now emerged as a super-spreader of the novel coronavirus infection in the country. On March 19, Delhi government issued an order prohibiting gathering of more than 20 people anywhere in the city in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak.After Delhi government on Monday wrote to the lieutenant governor, an FIR was lodged against the Banglewali Masjid administration on Tuesday. “Several reports of how the officials did not act on time are coming up. If the involvement of any official is found, strict action will be taken,” Kejriwal warned.“Lives of many people present in Markaz have been put at risk. Six people have lost their lives after attending the event and reaching Telangana,” the chief minister added. Many people have gone back to other cities.Kejriwal said all religious places had been discouraging gatherings. “Navratri has been going on, but there’s no crowd in temples. Gurdwaras have been shut, people are not going to mosques, Mecca is empty, Vatican City is empty. By holding a congregation at this time, they have committed a serious offence,” he said.Delhi has recorded 97 cases , including five who have recovered and two deaths. “One patient is on ventilator and two are on oxygen support,” said Kejriwal. The rest are stable.He also urged people to contribute to the chief minister’s relief fund and donate personal protective equipment, ventilators, testing kits etc to strengthen the fight.Sharing the government order in a tweet, AAP MLA Atishi demanded action against the police officers who had failed to enforce it.

Title: Central Railway distributes food packets at stations
Content: PUNE: The Central Railway distributed about 1,000 food packets to the needy at various stations in Mumbai, Nagpur, Solapur, Bhusaval and Pune divisions on Saturday, officials said.Teams of railway officers and employees are working round-the-clock in all divisions.“The base kitchens of the IRCTC at Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus in Mumbai and Mumbai Central are preparing dal and khichadi for the poor and needy. Around 2,000 food packets are being prepared in a hygienic way and distributed through the commercial department and Railway Police Force,” an official said.In addition, catering stall owners, commercial department staff and RPF staff are contributing individually and physically in the distribution of food packets. On Sunday, Pune division distributed 150 food packets while Solapur and Nagpur divisions have distributed 140 and 150 food packets, respectively, he said.Mumbai and Bhusawal divisions have distributed around 350 food packets to those stranded near stations. A blood donation camp was organised at Latur station in which 45 persons donated blood.

Title: Kothrud man booked for drive to Deccan for papaya
Content: PUNE: A 40-year-old man from Kothrud drove nearly 6km to the Deccan area to buy a papaya on Sunday evening, only to be booked by the police for flouting the lockdown rules in the time of Covid-19.The Deccan Gymkhana police stopped his car at the Khandojibaba Chowk and booked him under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant) of the Indian Penal Code for wandering without purpose.“The man is educated and employed with a prominent private company. He took the Karve Road from Kothrud to the Deccan area without any valid reason. He was on his way back when we stopped him,” senior inspector Deepak Lagad of the Deccan Gymkhana police station said on Monday.“On being asked why he was out in his car despite the lockdown orders, the man said he wanted to buy a papaya from a vendor in the Deccan area. He had purchased the papaya and was returning home when the police stopped his car,” Lagad told TOI.The police said the man had not taken any permission to take out his car. “A case was filed against him. People can leave their houses only in cases of emergency and to buy essential commodities in the neighbourhood,” Lagad said.The police have, in the meantime, warned fuel stations across the city against providing petrol or diesel to vehicles not involved in essential services.On Monday, the police said they found many motorists at fuel stations requesting pump operators to refill their vehicles. Though many operators denied them fuel, some of them agreed, the police added.“We have filed cases against seven petrol pumps for providing fuel to motorists not involved in essential services. Strict action will be taken against the violators” additional commissioner of police Ashok Morale said.

Title: Homebound daily wagers continue to flock to Prayagraj
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: Teams of medical health professionals screened hundreds of migrant labourers — who had returned to Prayagraj from different parts of the country following the 21-day lockdown announced to check the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) — in various villages on Monday.The labourers flocked in from cities like New Delhi, Ahmedabad, Jaipur and Noida. The daily wagers were taken to community and primary health centres for a medical check-up.Officials are compiling details like name, age, gender, contact details and city \ town of every migrant\passenger coming to Prayagraj during the lockdown.A senior health official said, “We have collected details of around 2,000 migrants across the district and none of them have complained of fever, cough or respiratory distress.”“Migrants continued to return to their native villages and their samples have been sent for testing,” he added. They have been asked to take their care of themselves and stay indoors.Madhur, a migrant who was returning to Holagarh and worked in Greater Noida said, “I have travelled around 300km on foot to reach Kanpur since Friday. From there, I hitched a ride with a truck to reach Prayagraj.”Sudhir Kumar, a native of Malaq, said, “I have been walking from Gurgram and I am too exhausted. I plan to quarantine myself in fields once I reach home.”

Title: Coonoor bakery locked, sealed for flouting social distancing norms
Content:
Udhagamandalam: A bakery near Coonoor main bus stand was sealed by authorities on Monday for not maintaining social distancing norms among customers.

Indian Bakery located near the main bus stand was locked and sealed by Coonoor sub-collector Ranjit Singh as the bakery did not follow the norms while catering to the customers.

Open vegetable market on VP Street was also seen crowded as the street was narrow and the timing for shoppers were limited till 2.30pm.

“It is not a good idea to have the open vegetable market on the narrow VP Street. Area-wise markets will curtail the crowd and safety measures could also be followed in this hour of crisis,” Rajasekar, a resident of Coonoor, said.

Collector J Innocent Divya said ward-wise vegetable markets will be arranged from April 1 in Coonoor and Ooty.

Title: Power consumption sees dip amid coronavirus lockdown in Telanagana
Content: HYDERABAD: The power demand this March has been surprisingly low. Unlike March last year, summer spell this time has not been harsh which could be a factor behind the dip with Hyderabad and Telangana experiencing unseasonal rains this month, temperatures have not zoomed and maintained a steady course. Officials said this had also resulted in power demand usage going down.Residents said with much cooler evenings, their AC usage had come down considerably.It was a different worry for 25-year-old techie Vishesh from Madhapur. “I purchased an AC recently, just before the lockdown was announced. I could not get it installed as the technician cannot come out because of the restrictions on account of the coronavirus lockdown,” Vishesh said.The Kaleshwaram pumphouse demand reached a peak of 13,168 megawatts on February 28 this year. Though the power demand has come down in Hyderabad, the demand in erstwhile Warangal, Khammam and Karimnagar districts where irrigation projects are running to near full capacity, has not come down.

Title: ‘Premature to say Indian strain of virus less virulent’
Content:
Hyderabad: Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB) scientists have said it is “scientifically unsound and premature” to speculate that novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) India strain is less virulent than the ones creating havoc in China, Italy and other countries.

CCMB began sequencing the genome of the virus extracted from Hyderabad samples. The scientists hope to soon sequence Maharasthra and Rajasthan samples too.

Of the 2,077 novel coronavirus genomes that were sequenced across the world, available on Nextstrain, an open-source pathogen genome data, only two were from India, both from samples in Kerala.

CCMB director Dr Rakesh Mishra told TOI that sequencing of at least 50 genomes of the virus should be done from samples from various states to understand the strain better and know the rate of mutation and genetic similarities with the one in , China.

“We have received ICMR kits and samples from Gandhi Hospital. While we do diagnostic tests for confirmation of corona positive patients, we will be sequencing the genome of the virus. So far, only two samples from Kerala were sequenced nationally. The virus is variable, and there is a need for more sequencing to understand the biology of the virus and the rate of mutation,” the CCMB chief said.

“We should have at least 50 to 100 genome sequences to understand the virus better,”he added. Reacting to comments of a few doctors that the Indian strain was less virulent, he said: “It is premature and scientifically unsound to comment on the virulence of the strain based on scanty data. There is too much of speculation.”

Pavitra Roychoudhury, acting instructor at the University of Washington, tweeted on Sunday, “There are only two full SARS-CoV-2 genomes from India, both from Kerala. Unless there are additional data that hasn’t been published. I am not sure how one can say anything about the strains circulating locally (sic).”

Title: Kolkata man stuck in Peru with one meal a day
Content:
Piyush Padgil in Peru

KOLKATA: When Piyush Padgil, 33, embarked on his dream trip to Peru, little did he know that it would turn into his worst nightmare. A young professional from Ballygunge, Padgil had decided to take a trip to Machu Picchu last month. Now, he finds himself stranded in the South American country that is under curfew, with 39 other Indians. The group is currently surviving on one free meal per day.

When Padgil’s trip started on February 28, the Covid-19 threat had spread from China to South Korea. But it was still a long way from India and it didn’t really bother him. Then the disease spread to Iran and Italy, but South America was largely untouched and there were no travel bans. So he got visas to Chile and Peru and started out as planned. Padgil arrived in Chile via Madrid early in March and visited the Atacama Desert, not knowing that the situation was fast changing.

By the time he reached Arequipa in Peru, the disease had spread worldwide. Padgil could not fly back to India from Lima on March 24 as scheduled. He was the lone Indian in Arequipa, surrounded mostly by people who did not speak English. Longing for home and some sort of familiarity, Padgil called the Indian embassy in Lima.

“Though there was total curfew and getting a flight back home was impossible, the embassy put me up with 39 other Indians who had managed to reach Lima,” Padgil said. “I heard of the hardships my mom and sister are facing getting medicines for my father who recently underwent a heart surgery. I feel helpless,” Padgil said.

The condition of others is no better. Most have nearly exhausted all their money and are seeking help from family and friends back home. Sameera Khan and her husband are surviving on just the free breakfast that the hotel is providing. They were scheduled to take the flight back after a visit to Brazil, Chile and Bolivia and had almost exhausted their money when the shutdown was announced. The situation is scarier for Vrishi Reddy (27), a Bengaluru-based child rights activist. She is now stuck in a lodge in remote south-eastern Peru with the nearest village 10km away. She has ration for just five meals.

The group is now awaiting an evacuation as Italy, Ireland, Switzerland and Israel have started to fly their citizens back. They wonder if the embassy will provide them food and shelter for the remainder of their stay there.

Title: Take spl care of pregnant women: CM
Content:
Jaipur: Chief minister has directed the officials to keep a track of pregnant women in various districts and likely delivery date so that proper arrangements, including transportation to be arranged for delivery.

He said special care should be taken of such women put in isolation or quarantine in transit camps.

In a review meeting, Gehlot said that the state government had to discharge its responsibility towards all the needy and deprived sections of the society. In this way, safe delivery, vaccination and other requirements for pregnant women of poor section will be ensured.

He said apart from women doctors and health workers, help of women officers and employees could be used for this task.

Gehlot said that district collectors should also prepare lists of local officials and employees working in various departments of the state government and employ them to play a role as volunteers in various campaigns related to Covid-19 epidemic. These personnel could be used to ensure the availability of food and food items mainly for the homeless, the underprivileged and the needy. These volunteers could help by informing in the ‘war room’ located at the district level in case of any problem and the local administration could use their services when needed, he said.

The CM had directed to employ two senior officers to coordinate with the concerned states to resolve various problems faced by the migrant workers in different states and residents of other states living in the state during this crisis. He said these officers would help in solving the problems of migrants by keeping in constant contact with the chief minister's offices and chief secretary's offices.

He said that many private institutions and undertakings in the state have proposed to use their infrastructure like buildings to deal with Corona . He thanked the concerned institutions and individuals for all such proposals and said that a list of these buildings were being prepared and would be used when needed.

The CMsaid many private institutions and undertakings in the state have proposed to use their infrastructure like buildings to deal with Corona. He thanked the concerned institutions and individuals for all such proposals and said that a list of these buildings were being prepared and would be used when needed.

Title: Lockdown rule violation still keeping cops on toes in Kanpur
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Police on Monday enforced a complete lockdown and did not allow even a single roadways bus to enter the city. Around 22 roadways buses were engaged on Sunday to send migrant workers to their destinations. On Monday the police ensured that nobody was seen loitering in the Civil Lines area as well as the Civil Lines bus station.

SSP, Prayagraj , Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said that adequate police forces were deployed at inter-district borders and not a single bus was allowed to enter the city. He added that policemen deployed on the district borders have been asked not to allow anyone to enter the city and lockdown norms were followed strictly.

On Monday, streets of the city were wearing a deserted look. Additional mobile police pickets were deployed in Khuldabad, Mutthiganj, Ram Bagh, Kareli, Sulemsarai and adjoining areas to enforce the lockdown strictly.

The police allowed movement of vegetable and milk vendors only between 7am and 10am. Police teams were spotted marching in narrow streets directing people to keep themselves indoors. Massive security arrangement was seen at Phaphamau, Jhunsi, Dhoomanganj, Shankargarh, Handia, Saraymamrez and other areas.

Though the movement of migrant workers in small groups was spotted on state and national highways, the police did not allow anybody to enter the city.

Meanwhile, over 130 locals were booked for flouting rules on the sixth day of lockdown on Monday. They were charged under Section 188 (violation of norms) of the Indian Penal Code.

A team of senior police and district officials on Monday inspected temporary shelter homes set for migrants and asked them to stay there till April 14. District magistrate Bhanu Chandra Goswami asked his subordinates to sort out problems of the commonman.

District authorities also visited KP Community Hall where around 100 residents of Prayagraj district are kept in quarantine.

In the past 24 hours, the police claimed to have arrested 48 persons on the charges of violating lockdown norms in the city and trans Ganga and Yamuna areas. A man was also arrested on the charges of blackmarketing of essential commodities. The police also claimed to have checked 5,517 vehicles in 24 hours and seized 13 of them. Besides, 513 vehicles were challaned.

Title: With no farmhands to harvest and no transport, farmers stare at severe loss
Content:
Coimbatore: With no farm labourers available due to the ongoing 21-day lockdown, farmers from the district say they stare at huge losses as they cannot harvest vegetables in time and transport them to markets.

Especially, vegetables such as tomato and ladies finger need to be harvested regularly or they would become overripe and get wasted, they said.

Coconut farmers too said they were facing the same issue with no workers being available to climb trees and harvest coconuts.

Farmers in Thondamuthur, Madukkarai, Kinathukadavu, Annur, Mettupalayam, Sirumugai and Pollachi were all facing the issue, they said.

Also, with no proper logistics available to transport produce to markets due to the lockdown, farmers said there must be an alternative such as a volunteer group which would take produce directly from farms to homes.

Farmers said in many places, farmhands used to come from a radius of 10km to 15km. But due to the lockdown, that is no possible. Now, even with workers from nearby areas not been coming out due to the lockdown, they said harvest and loading work have not been done for the past one week.

P Kandasamy, president of a farmers’ association here, said because of this, crops such as banana, brinjal, chillies, gourds which were ready for harvest, now face a risk of getting wasted.

“There are no machines to harvest these and it has to be done manually. If they are not harvested in the proper time, they will go waste,” he said.

A Karthik Krishnakumar, a farmer from the district and the youth wing president of the farmer’s association, said vegetables such as ladies finger were delicate and had to be harvested once in two days. “If it has to be harvested today, it has to be done. Otherwise, it will get over-mature and can’t be sold in markets. We have to sell them off to hotels for half the price. Now with hotels also not working, they probably would go waste,” he said.

Similarly, in coconut trees, mature nuts must be harvested once in 50 days, or else, they would grow over ripe and hinder the growth of younger bunches, Karthik said.

“It has been more than two months since coconut was harvested in several places due to shortage of farmhands,” he said.

One possible solution for this was to work out a community alternative such as a volunteer group taking produce from the farm to consumers directly, which would save a lot of hassles, Kandasamy said.

“At such a time, we must come together and put in a cooperative effort to tide over our difficulties,” he added.

Title: Migrant workers returning to UP ‘sanitised’ with bleach, health min blames ‘over-zealous’ officials, probe on
Content:
wetfew

Bareilly: Several batches of migrant workers, including women and children, who arrived in UP from Delhi/NCR in government-run buses over the weekend were made to squat on a road in Bareilly district and sprayed with sodium hypochlorite — a bleaching agent which authorities later admitted was “unfit for use on humans” — in a bid to sanitise them.

After the incident on Sunday attracted widespread criticism, joint secretary (health ministry), Lav Agarwal, blamed it on the “over zealousness of officials who acted out of fear”. The secretary clarified that this was not part of any protocol and was not required.

The Bareilly district administration has now set up a team to investigate the matter. District magistrate Nithish Kumar said treatment would be provided to anybody adversely affected by spraying of sodium hypochlorite. The DM also attributed the incident to “over-cautious” personnel. “They should not have done this, but fortunately no one was harmed,” he told TOI.

Mayor Umesh Gautam admitted “negligence on part of the municipal corporation” and said directions have been issued to not repeat this in future.

Ingestion of sodium hypochlorite can cause nausea, vomiting, burns to the mouth and throat. It is corrosive and can irritate the skin or cause inflammation and blisters.

The incident occurred after a sanitisation team from the municipal corporation and fire personnel were sent to sanitise the locality of a Covid-19 patient. While returning, they reached Satellite Bus Stand in the city and were disinfecting buses when they started spraying the solution on those who were arriving in the vehicles as well.

A video of the incident shows personnel directing people to close their eyes as the bleaching agent gushes out of a hosepipe and cops look on. Senior superintendent of police (Bareilly) Shailesh Pandey has claimed that police was not involved in any way in the exercise.

Municipal commissioner (Bareilly) Abhishek Anand admitted that the chemical solution was only meant for sanitising roads, walls and metallic surfaces and was “not fit for use on humans”. Chief medical officer Vineet Shukla also added that the solution was likely diluted else it could have had adverse effects.

In a press conference later, Awanish Kumar Awasthi, additional chief secretary (home), defended its use, claiming that sanitisers can be sprayed on any person without fear as per international norms.

Later in the day, BJP IT cell chief Amit Malviya tweeted that agencies in Kerala are mass spraying people, “…But all the outrage is only reserved for UP, because a saffron clad monk of the BJP is the chief minister and he is doing a good job.” Kerala officials were quick to clarify. “We have not used any kind of chemical or disinfectant on humans. What was sprayed by our personnel at Wayanad was diluted soap solution,” said director General of fire and rescue force, A Hemachandran.

Priyanka Gandhi shared a video of it on Twitter on Monday, calling it an ‘inhuman act’.

(With inputs from Maria Khan)

Title: Less arrival of onion and potato to jack up prices in Pune
Content:
The retail vendors from various local markets pointed out that they had to pay extra money for the transportat... Read More

PUNE: People will have to pay extra for buying onion and potato at least for the next two days because of less quantity of these products reaching the Gultekdi Market Yard on Monday.

“Today (Monday) the market received 3,732 quintals of onion and 2,695 quintals of potato as against the collective arrival of up to 14,000 quintals of these produces during normal days. The less arrival has had an impact on the retail rates,” Babasaheb Bibave, the head of the onion, potato and fruits division in the Gultekdi market told TOI.

A kg of onion was sold for Rs 20-22 in the wholesale market, while potato was sold for Rs22-25 per kg. The price was expected to go up to Rs 35-40 per kg in the retail market, he said.

The Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) officials stated that the commission agents had not opened their shops and the farmers in their contact did not bring their produce to the market on Monday. Hence, the price of these items went up in the auction.

“This won’t continue for long and the prices would come down by Rs2-4 per kg once the usual arrivals begin from April 1,” Bibave said.

The retail vendors from various local markets pointed out that they had to pay extra money for the transportation of vegetables, including onion and potato, and fruits.

Sachin Pingle, a retail vendor from Vishrantwadi, said, “Only licensed vehicles are allowed in the market. These transporters are charging extra and we have to sell every item at a higher price.”

The APMC chief, Balasaheb Deshmukh, said there was adequate vegetables, onions, potatoes and fruits in the market. “As hotels, restaurants and messes are closed, the current arrivals are enough to fulfil the domestic demand. People need not stock vegetables and fruits or rush to the market,” he said.

Title: Jagtial villager fined Rs 500 for violation of lockdown
Content:
Hyderabad:Itikyala gram panchayat in Jagtial district of Telangana has found a novel way to stop villagers from violating the lockdown.

The panchayat secretary imposed a fine of 500 on villager Mittametla Raja Reddy on Monday for coming out of his house. In a receipt that was issued to Reddy, it was said the fine was imposed for roaming around three times in a day. The fine has been listed under ‘others’ in the fines list.

Meanwhile, in Siddipet, local legislator and finance minister T Harish Rao patrolled the local areas and got several two-wheelers seized by police. The minister questioned bikers as to why they were moving around during the lockdown. On receiving unsatisfactory replies, the minister ordered that the vehicles be seized and returned after the lockdown period ends.

Harish distributed provisions worth Rs 1,250 to 700 auto drivers and asked shop owners to provide hand sanitisers and soaps to customers.

Title: Social distancing? Niranjanpur mandi see high footfall
Content:
Dehradun: The office bearers and traders at the Niranjanpur wholesale vegetable market (subzi mandi) say they are trying hard to maintain the norms of social distancing but are facing a tough time as the market sees heavy footfall during the time it is briefly opened during the lockdown.

Traders said that since a lot of individual buyers had also started coming to the market ever since the lockdown was announced, the mandi parishad has changed the timings of opening the market to between 2 am and 6 am.

Talking to TOI, Vijay Thapliyal, secretary of Niranjanpur Mandi Parishad said, “Our aim is to prevent crowds from gathering inside the market. The loaders and other retail traders are being allowed inside only with a valid pass. In addition to that, masks and sanitisers have been made mandatory for protection of all.” The traders say they are also making sure that for general buyers, the vegetables are made available in nearby residential areas to prevent people from coming inside the mandi.

Thapliyal added, “Some traders have also initiated the service for providing vegetables online to comply with the norms of social distancing. The entry passes for loaders are also being issued in a limited manner.”

According to the officials, the market place is being sanitised once the loaders leave the place.

Mandi inspector Ajay Dabral told TOI, “We are prohibiting entry inside the mandi without a mask. Use of sanitisers and hand wash is also being promoted to prevent the spread of the virus.”

Traders also claimed that the decision of keeping away the general buyers has helped in keeping the prices of vegetable under control.

Deepak Arora, a trader at the vegetable market said, “Earlier, with many individual buyers coming to the market, the prices had shot up having ripple effect on buyers purchasing from retailers later. Now the prices are under control, which is also in the interest of the general people in times of crisis when essential goods should be within the reach of everyone.”

Title: Veraval man booked for escaping home quarantine
Content: RAJKOT: A Veraval man , who had tested positive for COVID-19 on March 29, has been booked for escaping and venturing on the streets during the mandatory home quarantine after he had returned from Dubai on March 21.According to an official press release, the 56-year-old man is suspected to have infected nearly 56 people. He was booked on the complaint of Dr Avdheshkumar Chaudhary, Veraval taluka health officer."When I checked on him at his residence, he was not found at home. His family members said as he was into construction business, he had gone to the site. On March 27, Panja's health deteriorated and he was admitted to the isolation ward of the Veraval Civil Hospital. His samples were sent to Bhavnagar Sir T Hospital where he tested positive," said Dr Chaudhary.PK Parmar of Verval City police station told TOI: "We have booked him under Epidemic Diseases Act 1897 for putting the lives of others at risk by coming into contact with them. We have also booked him under sections 269, 270 and 188 of the Indian Penal Code and violation of the prohibitory orders.”

Title: No pay cut for staff on lockdown days, govt tells pvt firms
Content:
Jaipur: With March coming to an end and lakhs of employees and labourers engaged in companies , shops, and commercial establishments wondering about how to get their salary, the state government has announced to issue movement passes to employers so that they can go to their offices and pay their staff.

The order issued by industries department on Monday said that salaries or wages of the employees or workers will not be deducted for the duration of the lockdown and all the payments will be made through online transfers such as Direct Benefit Transfer, NEFT, RTGS, etc.

“In one hand the employers are willing to pay the wages and salaries and on the other, the workers or employees need the money urgently but because of lockdown that was not possible. The movement passes will now allow them to go their offices and make the payment through online modes,” said Subodh Agarwal , additional chief secretary, Department of Industries.

The order also says that in case the online payment modes are not possible with some laborers or employees, movement passes will be allowed to the company person dealing with the payment of salaries so that he can go and make the payment. But the duration of such passes will be for limited period. “For such exceptional cases, time duration and place have to be specified in the passes. This is done to not deprive anybody his or her monthly salary in these difficult times. But we expect the employers to adhere to the objective of the lockdown,” added Agarwal.

Just before the closure of the commercial units, some companies have already paid partial salaries to their laborers or employees but many were left out. Most of the companies did not find time to process the payments as the lockdown was abrupt.

But the payment for the period under the lockdown was not factored in even though the few workers who had been paid by the companies. This will require all the employers to avail the movement passes for the payment.

But some employers said even though they are willing to pay for the lockdown period, it will not be possible for them to do the same for April. “We have now no income and it will be out of question to pay for the month of April, which will be another month of shutdown,” said the employer.

Title: Panchayati Raj bodies to provide masks, sanitizers and gloves at a cost of Rs 60 crores: Pilot
Content:
Jaipur: Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Monday sanctioned Rs 50,000 each to about 11,000 gram panchayats, Rs 1 lakh to 295 panchayat samitis and Rs 1.5 lakh to 33 zilla parishads to distribute masks, sanitisers and gloves in rural areas.

The total expenditure on this head is estimated to Rs 60 crore.

Panchayati Raj Institutions will be able to use the amount for spraying and distributing hygiene materials such as sanitizer, mask, hand gloves etc. and essential disinfectant like sodium hydrochloride to prevent corona infection , said Pilot who is in charge of the departrment.

He said the fund has been allocated to Panchayati Raj Institutions to fight the corona infection. spreading to the villages.

He informed that the Panchayati Raj Institutions have been instructed to provide sanitation materials to the personnel and public representatives who are helping to fight the corona infection in rural areas. tnn

Title: Yachters at Kochi Marina locked up inside their boats
Content: Kochi: The nationwide lockdown is giving a tough time to the yachters too with many of them stuck at the Kochi International Marina. Around nine yachters, who docked at the marina in five boats after reaching from various countries, are under strict quarantine inside their yachts and they cannot even go beyond the marina premises. The Kerala Tourism Development Corporation (KTDC), which runs the marina, directed them to stay inside the boats during the lockdown period. These people are finding it difficult to get food and beverage stock, exchange currency, avail medicines, etc. and are totally dependent on the staff of the marina. They cannot leave Kochi too as all marinas in other countries have been closed down amid Covid-19 fear.Though the rooms at the Marina House adjacent to the docks are meant for the sailors, post lockdown these rooms are not being rented out. Though the sailors are allowed to use the lobby and the lawn of the Marina House, they cannot go to the Bolgatty Palace Resort. The privileges like using the swimming pool and the beer parlour at the resort have been stopped too.“We were supposed to sail to Sri Lanka by March end but the marina there has been shut due to Covid-19 outbreak. We have been asked by the marina officials to stay inside our boats till the lockdown is over. We are used to stay inside boat for 10 or 15 days continuously but only during the voyage. Sitting idle here for 21 days is boring and we don’t know whether it will be extended. Though we have stocked enough provision it may get over anytime. We cannot even go to the banks to exchange the currency or withdraw cash from ATM. Fortunately the marina officials are helping us with all these to smoothen the crisis,” said Helen Sell, a yachter from UK, who reached the marina in December.The closure of bars and beer parlours is another challenge faced by them as drinking beer is part of the diet for most of the sailors to beat the summer heat. “We could not stock the beer before the lockdown. Sitting in the air-conditioned yacht is the only thing we could do to beat the heat now. After all, drinking beer is not the need of the hour amid the Covid-19 outbreak. We can adjust without it, but our freedom of movement has been curtailed,” said a yachter.“ The immigration officials are in touch with the yachters to ensure their well-being,” said a KTDC official.

Title: Kanpur: 88 jailbirds to be released on interim bail today
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Around 88 undertrials in the district jail will be released on interim bail on Tuesday as their bail applications were heard and disposed of in their favour.

In compliance with the directions of UP state legal services authority, the judicial officials had heard the bail applications of undertrials in cases which have a maximum sentence of 7 years.

According to Kanpur jail superintendent Ashish Tiwari , around 303 jailbirds had expressed their desire of interim bail. The jail authorities had obtained their applications and forwarded them with their recommendations.

The judicial officials said that out of the 99 interim bail applications presented before them, they disposed of 91of them.

District judge Ashok Kumar Singh informed that he had passed the administrative orders on Monday morning regarding the same. tnn

Title: Allahabad University to help girls hostel inmates reach home
Content:
Allahabad University

PRAYAGRAJ: As the district administration tries to ensure that migrant labourers arriving in the city get home, scores of inmates in Allahabad University ’s (AU) Women’s Hostel are stranded due to the lockdown enforced to stem the spread of novel coronavirus.

The varsity is trying to ensure that these students reach home safely.

At AU, there are six girls hostels and they are located within the four walls of the Women’s Hostel (WH). Before the lockdown, while many students had left for home. However, many were stranded while they were planning to return once the lockdown was announced.

Although the varsity authorities are providing them with all facilities, but many of them want to return to their homes till the time situation improves.

“The hostel mess is providing us food and the nearby grocery store is open, but now there is no money in the ATM kiosk on WH campus. Also, as the one near the main gate does not have cash, many of us are running out of cash. The lone shop which sold milk and bread on campus is shut these days,” said one of the hostel inmates.

However, the varsity administration has come forward for such girl inmates.

“I have instructed the dean of students welfare (DSW), the warden and the hostel superintendents to prepare a list of inmates who need our help. We are chalking out a plan to send them to their hometowns,” said AU’s officiating vice-chancellor RR Tiwari . There are around 90 such inmates currently stuck in WH, he added.

The VC said that AU would hire additional vehicles and chart out a route plan to ferry the girls. “

He assured that the safety of these inmates will be a priority for the authorities and a woman faculty member and a guard would accompany the inmates. In addition, the inmates would be sent home only after AU gets the consent of the inmates’ parents.

Title: Coimbatore: Fish market closed till April 14
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: After people thronged the fish market on Selvapuram Bypass, the city corporation has directed the shopkeepers to close the market from Tuesday.

On Sunday, when the fish market and farmers’ markets were reopened, people thronged the market throwing social distancing norms to the wind. The crowd was dispersed only with the help of police.

“After seeing the crowd at the fish market, corporation officials held a meeting with the shopkeepers of the market. After officials pointed out the consequences of not following the social distancing at this time, the shopkeepers agreed to close the market from Tuesday,” a corporation source said.

The source said that the market would be reopened on April 15.

Meanwhile, the corporation has given permission to set up markets on the premises of bus stands at Ukkadam and Mettupalayam. It has also requested the public to follow social distancing norms.

Title: Labourers in Jaisalmer set out for home on foot
Content:
Jaisalmer: Hundreds of labourers who came to Jaisalmer from other states for harvesting crops have been stranded here. They want to return home, but after not getting any means of transportation, they have started walking towards their states on foot.

The district administration had issued an order preventing movement of migrant labourers and given directions to provide them food in Jaisalmer.

But in defiance of the order, groups of labourers can be seen walking towards Jodhpur, Bikaner and Barmer with their luggage in tow.

Every year, thousands of labourers from Bihar , Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Punjab come to Jaisalmer for harvesting crops at the canal areas of Mohangarh, Ramgarh and Nachna in February.

The labourers from the canal areas reached Jaisalmer on foot on Sunday afternoon. They are camping with their families at various places and can be seen searching for vehicles to ferry them to their states.

Chandni, a labourer from Ratlam, Madhya Pradesh, said that she wants to go home but wasn’t getting any means of transport. He children are accompanying her.

Another labourer Mohanram Bhil said that he comes from Ratlam every year for harvesting crops at the canal area in Sam. After harvesting crops, the field owner left him. He reached Jaisalmer after walking 60km. He has his family with him. Local people helped by giving food packets.

Collector Namit Mehta said that as per the orders of state government no migrant labourer will be allowed to go out of the district.

Food is being provided to the labourers. Moreover, field owners have been directed not to disengage labourers till the lockdown ends.

Title: SOS callers ask for samosa, pizza, rasgulla, some get goodies, others shamed publicly
Content:
Rampur/Lucknow: The helpline floated by police in UP for the needy has been flooded with strange demands by people seeking home delivery of hot samosas with green chutney, pizza , Banarasi paan and rasgulla . Some are indeed getting it delivered at their door steps while the rest, the mischievous ones, are getting penalised for their "frivolity".

At the control room in Rampur, UP, a man asked for hot samosa and chutney to be delivered home. Another caller was craving for a Banarasi paan.

Perturbed by such calls, Rampur’s district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh decided to “shame” such people in public. All of them were caught and made to clean drains and sweep the road.

“We are receiving several calls on our helpline number in which people are asking for pizza and samosas. So, we have started ‘publicly shaming’ such people to discourage others who are making fun of this pandemic,” the DM said. He also tweeted photos of people who made such calls recently.

But police is also making sure that “genuine” callers are attended to promptly.

“A pregnant government teacher called the helpline and asked for food. She got it immediately,” the Rampur DM added.

Police in Lucknow also responded to a request for rasgulla. A packet eached the caller’s home. On Sunday evening, station house officer of Hazratganj Santosh Singh got the “urgent” call from an elderly citizen. Ramchandra Prasad Keshari, 80, was alone at home and was having a severe bout of hypoglycaemia due to diabetes. The rasgulla, at the moment, was his only medicine.

Without losing time, Singh purchased the sweet and rushed to Keshari's house. “He quickly ate four pieces out of the six, and his pale face turned bright. I realised that he was now safe,” said SHO Singh. Keshari, a widower, lives alone in a flat in Kasmanda House while his entire family-- two sons and a daughter-- lives abroad. A diabetic for 18 years, he had been unwell for four days.

Title: Trichy clinic offers teleconsultation
Content:
Trichy: A city-based hospital on Monday launched round-the-clock helpline (98424-22121) for those having stress and facing anxiety problems in the nation-wide lockdown. The faility will help callers get free mental health consultation from medical professionals.

Athma hospitals authorities, who set up the facility, said that consultation with psychiatrists is a must to overcome various mental issues in times of Covid-19 lockdown. The hospital authorities said that people are worried about their financial situation as the shutdown is affecting mostly their business.

“People are keenly following news breaks and social media for updates on Covid-19. Anxiety and stress are the outcome of this. It is taking its toll on them. Anyone facing the issue may call the number and talk to experts,” said Dr K Ramakrishnan, chief psychiatrists of Athma hospitals.

Within a day of launching the helpline, it received two calls seeking assistance from social workers to cope with the lockdown and the associated stress.

Title: Will derecognise schools demanding next year’s fees: Karnataka minister S Suresh Kumar
Content:
Several parents have complained online about schools insisting that they pay the fees

BENGALURU: Primary and secondary education minister S Suresh Kumar pulled up schools for issuing circulars to parents asking them to pay fees for the next academic year and warned the managements of stringent action.

“The school management will be held accountable under the Education Act and actions will include cancellation of recognition of the school and a criminal case under section 3 of Epidemic Diseases Act of 1897 and also CrPC … Schools that have issued circulars to parents are requested to suspend them until further orders,” he said.

The department of public instruction had issued a circular earlier asking schools to postpone the admission process and fee collection for 2020-2021, including for students continuing in the same institition. The department had acted following parents’ complaints against schools asking them to cough up fees, which they pointed out was not only against the lockdown order but also insensitive.

Meanwhile, the department extended work from home facility for primary and high school teachers till April 11 in view of the lockdown. Summer holidays for schools start on April 11.

Schools say they are in distress

School managements claimed they are facing a crisis with the monthly fee collection having been stopped.

The Associated Managements of Primary and Secondary Schools in Karnataka, which has several budget private schools under its umbrella, requested the government to release the pending RTE reimbursement fees to help them.

General secretary D Sashi Kumar said, “Only Rs 550 crore has been released by the state so far and another Rs 1,300 crore is pending. We request the government to release at least Rs 1,000 crore.”

Title: Jail staff in a fix over release of undertrials
Content:
Jaipur: After the Supreme Court’s order on considering releasing undertrial prisoners from jails, the state is in a fix as this order came before lockdown was imposed in the country. If prisoners are released now, they will have nowhere to go in the present scenario. A meeting is likely to be held soon.

On March 23, the Court had asked states to consider release of undertrials and prisoners charged or convicted for crimes where maximum punishment is less than seven years to decongest jails amid the coronavirus pandemic.

While few states including Maharashtra and UP have already done so, Rajasthan is yet to start deliberating over it with a meeting to be held on in it in the next couple of days. Both Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh released approximately 11,000 undertrial prisoners on bail over coronavirus fear.

R K Reddy , DG Jail, Jaipur said, “The SC’s order came after the entire country was in a lockdown with many states sealing their borders. If we were to release even ten prisoners as of now, where would they go and with what mode of transport? We will have a meeting soon regarding this.” The jail authorities, however, have taken measures to ensure that the jails are less overcrowded with around 2000 inmates shifted to jails which were less crowded.

Title: Police shift over 300 beggars from Panchavati to shelters
Content: Nashik: City police have shifted over 300 beggars from the Panchavati area to three shelters in the city.The three shelters include Islamiya Educational Trust in Ambad, Sant Gadge Maharaj Dharamshala in Godaghat and Nashik Municipal Corporation building in Indukund.The beggars from the Panchavati area are mainly dependent on people visiting the Godavari river.Amol Tambe, the deputy commissioner of police (DCP), Nashik had requested various city-based NGOs to help the police in locating the beggars and shifting them to different shelters.“Various NGOs in the city have come forward and are providing food packets to the beggars. Also, if they remain outside, we will face more problems in combating the spread of Covid-19,” said Tambe. .The senior police inspector of Panchavati police station Ashok Bhagat said that there are nearly 1,300 beggars in the Godaghat area.With the help of the NGOs, the police authorities have provided shelter to over 300 beggars.Abhijeet Kasar Patil, a member of an NGO, said, “A few days back when we went to deliver food packets to the beggars in Panchavati area, they crowded around our van. Hence we could not deliver food and returned our vehicle.
