It is very difficult for them to maintain social distancing in such situations.”Islamiya Educational Trust, which is a private school run by members of the Muslim community, have given 14 rooms of their school to the police authorities for the cause.Nearly, 65 beggars have been shifted to the school which has a facility of filtered drinking water and washrooms.Hafizullah Kitabullah, president of the trust, said “Nearly eight members are always available for them if they need anything any time. We have filtered drinking water for them.” The NGOs are also providing food to the beggars.

Title: Timings announced, wholesale markets to open from 6am to 8pm in Kanpur
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: To ensure availability of essential items at retail shops, district magistrate, Kanpur, has allowed wholesale stores in the city to keep their outlets open between 6 am and 8 pm. This decision will help retailers in procuring essential commodities from wholesalers.

Wholesale markets at Collectorganj , Nayaganj and other areas would remain open from 6am till 8 pm and retailers would have to maintain social distance there. Only those having retail shops would be allowed to purchase essential items from wholesale markets.This has been done to ensure that there is no shortage of essential goods which in turn could cause panic among local people who are not stepping out of homes except when relaxation is given during the lockdown. Retailers will be able to open their shops till 11 am.

A relaxation in the lockdown is being given each day between 4am and 11am.

District Magistrate Brahm Dev Ram Tiwari said that to ensure that there is no shortage of essential items with retailers, they have been allowed to make purchase from the wholesellers who have now been allowed to keep their establishments open. For home delivery of daily need items, till Sunday night, over 800 shop onwers had got themselves registered. Shop keepers who are interested in home delivery can register themselves at kmc.up.nic.in.

Title: Six booked for defying quarantine in Uttarkashi
Content:
Representative image

UTTARKASHI: Uttarkashi district administration on Monday booked half a dozen people for defying quarantine. Five residents of Juguldi village in Dunda had been asked to be in 14-day quarantine at their homes after they returned to Uttarakhand from a different state on March 24.

After local villagers complained of them moving around freely, a team of the health department visited the village only to find them missing from their homes.

Akash Joshi, SDM Dunda block said, “We have booked all five of them under section 188, 269 and 270 of the Indian Penal Code(IPC)for defying home quarantine guidelines and risking the lives of other people. Police arrested and sent all five of them to the district hospital for a 14-day quarantine period on Monday.”

On Monday evening, Uttarkashi Police also booked a resident of Gyanja village for not staying in quarantine as advised.

Title: India Covid 19 news: ‘India still in local transmission stage’
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Covid-19 outbreak in India remains in ‘local transmission’ stage and any evidence of ‘ community transmission’ will be shared with the public so that the level of alertness can be increased, the government said seeking to put at rest speculations about a wider spread of the virus.“It is only local transmission in the country. If there is a community transmission, we will be the first to tell you as we would want to covey it to the community through you (media) to increase the level of alertness and management for Covid-19 at the field level,” health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal said.The clarification comes in the wake of a government document detailing standard operating procedures (SOP) for transporting a suspected case of coronavirus or Covid-19. “This SOP is applicable to the current phase of COVID-19 pandemic in India (local transmission and limited community transmission),” the document said, the words in the bracket sending speculation soaring about government announcing community spread.“We have to get out of these semantics. We have used the word in a very limited context in a way to highlight what we are going to do in terms of action at field. Nowhere we said we have community transmission. It is only local transmission in the country. The document very clearly mentions that we are in a phase of local transmission,” Agarwal said.Government officials said that criticism that India is not testing enough fail to take into account the effort being made to test all serious cases of respiratory distress and ICU patients with SARI (severe acute respiratory infections) and that state governments of all political hues are involved in the exercise. They pointed out that any significant increase in Covid-19 patients cannot go unnoticed as they would turn up at clinics and hospitals. It was unlikely that with so many medical professionals and agencies involved such a development remains a secret.The government has so far maintained that there is no clear evidence of the virus spreading into the community where the links of transmission cannot be traced. This even as there are sporadic cases of severe respiratory infection testing positive for Covid-19 without travel or contact history. Similarly, on Monday, Dr Gangakhedkar, head of epidemiology and communicable diseases at the Indian Council of Medicl Research (ICMR) said some asymptomatic cases have tested positive but are not enough to indicate community transmission.In both the cases – SARI and asymptomatic cases testing positive – ICMR has maintained that the sample size is miniscule to consider them as evidence to community spread. So far, India has tested 38,442 samples for COVID-19. The government and ICMR maintains that there is adequate testing capacity to ramp up testing sample size if required.According to Dr Gangakhedkar, India is currently using only 30% of its testing capacity in public laboratories. There are a total of 115 public laboratories with capability to test over 12,000 samples a day. In addition to this, the Council has also approved 47 private labs which conducted 1,334 tests in last three days.However, some experts are of the view that it is time for India to ramp up testing now to convincingly rule out community transmission based on larger sample size and secondly, to be able to use healthcare and financial resources in a more targeted way.“We need frontload of testing. The testing protocol now has to become more aggressive and stratified. We have the capacity to test and to reserve for a time when we reach the stage of community transmission is pointless,” says Shamika Ravi , director of research at Brookings India.

Title: Flow of migrants continues, traffic crawls on Ganga bridge in Jajmau
Content: KANPUR: A massive traffic jam was witnessed at Jajmau Ganga bridge and also at Kanpur-Unnao border on Monday in view of influx of migrants even as the state government has instructed complete lockdown in view of the rising cases of coronavirus in the country.As per the orders, no public transport will be alowed to operate and district’s borders will remain sealed, however, the essential services related to health, food, water and power supply will continue.Despite the lockdown orders, a huge number of people, crammed inside container trucks, luggage vans and buses and even atop highly inflammable fuel vehicles, were spotted at Jajmau-Ganga bridge on Kanpur-Unnao border on Monday afternoon.Several trucks and containers carrying essential commodities were also stuck in the jam.Team TOI witnessed chaos on the bridge as people jostled with each other in containers and trucks pleaded the authorities to allow the movement of vehicles.The district and police officials rushed to the spot and supervised the situation.SP East Raj Kumar Agarwal told TOI that the traffic jam was caused due to migrant workers returning their homes. “Amid the lockdown orders, we received information regarding a huge number of people travelling in goods carriers to their home towns and villages. Following the reports, the screening facilities were strengthened at Jajmau-Ganga bridge. All the migrants were allowed to move further only after undergoing thermal screening,” said the official.The police went a step further ahead and distributed food packets to the needy amid the chaos. “We have not only distributed food packets but also made the passengers aware of importance of maintaining social distancing. They were provided hand sanitisers and masks before they were allowed to move further,” said a police official further.

Title: Gujarat: 1,526 forest department staff to assist police
Content: AHMEDABAD: Following a request from DGP Shivanand Jha, the forest department has relieved 1,526 of its employees to assist state police in maintaining law and order. They have been asked to report to the district administration. The step has been taken in view of the lockdown because of the novel coronavirus.“The forest department has relieved 1,526 employees that include 75 range forest officer, 408 foresters and 1,043 beat guards,” said principal chief conservator of forest D K Sharma.A senior forest officer said, “The decision to deploy forest officials was taken at a meeting which was chaired by CM Vijay Rupani. “The forest department has 7,000-odd staff that can be deployed alongside the police force. The decision has been taken because the forest department personnel enjoy similar powers as by the police force.”The DCF will ensure minimum staff for wildlife management. The officials said that the majority of the staff to be deployed will be from the social forestry, and will be deployed in control rooms, relieving the police staff.A senior officer said there is shortage of manpower in rural areas and these staffers, who have good hold in villages, will be useful in persuading people to stay indoors during the lockdown period.The officer said that the staff in the vicinity of sanctuary areas will be sent for this duty only in extreme situations. The forest officials have also been asked to keep in touch with their informer network to ensure that there is no harm to the wildlife, especially lions.

Title: Seven Indians airlifted from Iran test positive
Content:
Health workers spray disinfectants in Jodhpur on Monday

JAIPUR: From a multi-storey building in Ramganj of the Walled City area, 10 people have been diagnosed with Covid-19. It is the house of a friend of the person who had returned from Oman recently and later tested positive for the disease. His friend is suspected to have contracted Covid-19 from him and now 10 persons in his buidling, along with him, have been found infected with the virus.

Across the state, twenty cases of Covid-19 were reported on Monday, the highest single-day rise so far. As of now, 79 people have been infected with the virus.

Ramganj area, which is curfew-bound since the first case of Covid-19 was reported on Thursday, has reported ten more cases. The 70-year-old mother and 21-year-old brother of the second 47-year-old positive case have been found infected along with eight other persons. The first case of Ramganj, who had arrived in the city from Oman on March 12, had also tested positive.

Health department officials said the first case of Ramganj was the friend of the second man and was in touch with him. On March 27, his friend was found infected with the virus and now friend’s mother and brother have tested positive and eight other relatives have been diagnosed with Covid-19. They all live in a same multi-storey building in densely populated and congested area of Phhuta Khurra of the Walled City area. Additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh appealed to the people of the area to remain inside the houses. “Those tested positive are all family members of the person who is already positive,” said Singh.

However, one person from Alwar, who travelled from Philippines along with another person who was found positive for Covid-19. He had travelled with a 21-year-old, who belonged to Jhunjhunu and has already been found infected with the virus on Sunday. They landed at Delhi airport on March 18 and hired a taxi to reach Rajasthan.

However, one person has been found infected with the virus in Bhilwara and other in Jodhpur. In Bhilwara, a 40-year-old person has tested positive. “He came for consultation at the out-patient department of the private hospital recently from where 25 other people were infected with the virus, said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).

He is the 26th person to have been diagnosed with Covid-19 in Bhilwara, which is among the top districts of the country reporting the highest number of cases. So far, 18 hospital staff, three patients (who were admitted to the hospital) and an OPD patient and four relatives of admitted patients have been found infected with the virus in Bhilwara.

Besides, seven persons airlifted from Iran have been diagnosed with Covid-19. “One of them is undergoing treatment at MDM hospital while six others are undergoing treatment at AIIMS Jodhpur ,” said a health department official.

Six of the seven evacuees from Iran have been kept at a quarantine facility in Jodhpur and one put in Jaisalmer’s army wellness centre.

Title: ‘Make shelter homes for labourers on road’
Content:
Ajmer: The district administration asked block-level officials to create shelter homes for those labourers who are on road and do not have any transportation to move to their homes.

Divisional commissioner K L Meena on Monday held a video conferencing with block-level officials of Ajmer, Bhilwara , Nagaur and Tonk districts and directed them to arrange food for homeless people. Officials have also been asked to keep record of distribution of food packets and manage the crowd roaming on road.

Hundreds of people along with their luggage and children were seen on Ajmer-Jaipur highway. The Ajmer Municipal Corporation on Monday constituted six teams to identify such people who are on roads. During lockdown, 16 roadways buses from the central bus stand went to different places across the state. AMC is preparing list of such people who wanted to return to their places so that bus services can be provided .

Title: Key doctors across state to be trained
Content: Kochi: In an effort to decentralise the treatment given to the Covid-19-affected by facilitating more hospitals and doctors with adequate equipment and training, experts who handle the treatment at Government Medical College in Ernakulam have started imparting training to key doctors at different hospitals across the state.Once the training is complete,d the doctors will go back to their hospitals and set up a team and facilities to treat Covid-19patients.On Monday, doctors from Ernakulam general hospital, Muvattupuzha general hospital, Aluva district hospital and various other taluk hospitals in the district were imparted training. “We started the training session for doctors so that we can decentralise Covid-19 patients and their treatment. The training will also equip doctors to treat Covid-19 patients at district and taluk hospitals. On Monday, around 25 doctors were given training on combating the disease. Given the contagious nature of the disease, doctors who lead Covid-19 treatment at Ernakulam medical college gave training to the doctors through video-conferencing facilitated through Zoom App,” said Dr Mathews Numbeli, district manager, National Health Mission, and one of the doctors who lead the fight against Covid-19 in the district.“Training was given on how to set up Covid-19 isolation facility, clinical management of the patients and on when and how to refer a patient to the medical college. Training was also given on how to use tele-helpline,” Numbeli said. It is learnt that authorities of major government hospitals in other districts also have evinced interests in getting training from Government Medical College, Ernakulam where many patients with complications are currently undergoing treatment.District administration and officials with the health department in the district have already taken measures to set up Covid-19 treatment and isolation centres in more places in the district. The district administration has already identified around 2,000 rooms for isolating people. Moreover, measures have already been initiated for converting Ernakulam general hospital, Aluva district hospital, taluk hospital at Karuvelippady and other taluk hospitals into Covid-19 treatment facilities.Authorities have also given instructions to the private hospital managements to handle Covid-19 cases. At the same time, many private hospitals have been complaining that they are unable to procure personal protective equipment (PPE). “We don’t require complete PPE kits for all those handling Covid-19 cases. For certain people associated with Covid care, face masks and gloves alone would be sufficient. But, those who have to come in close contact with the patients regularly will require complete PPE kit,” an official with health department said.Officials also said that training regarding the handling of Covid-19 patients have also been given to private hospital doctors and other staff.

Title: A kitchen that caters to north Indian tastes
Content: KOCHI: A community kitchen, in which food is cooked by guest workers exclusively for their community members, will start functioning at Vazhakulam panchayat from Monday. The kitchen will serve North Indian delicacies at free of cost.The special community kitchen is being set up due to widespread complaints that their owners have not been providing food during lockdown. The panchayat will buy grocery and vegetables to the kitchen using own fund. \The kitchen will serve food for around 2,000 guest workers who stay in various houses in the area. “We have asked the owners to give food for the workers. But many could not comply with it. So, we have decided to start a community kitchen after setting up a temporary shed on an open ground in their locality. Health, police, labour and revenue officials will frequent the kitchen to ensure that all parameters are followed,” said Vipin P S, health officer in the panchayat.The 2,000 guest population comprises people from West Bengal, Odisha and Assam. They work in sectors like construction, plywood and other household works. They live in Palakattuthazham ward, situated between the borders of Perumbavoor municipality and Vazhakulam panchayat.A coordination committee comprising ward member, Asha workers and other officials have been formed to run the kitchen. Three or four guest workers, who know North Indian delicacies will be hired. Workers will also be hired for other works including cleaning of utensils. Panchayat officials will collect large utensils, stove and other items on rent to run the kitchen and will rope gas agencies to ensure uninterrupted supply of LPG cylinders.“With no jobs in sight due to lockdown, guest workers from other areas also rushed to Palakattuthazham to be with their community. That’s why number has skyrocketed to 2,000. All of them stay in small buildings in the area. Majority of them stay in four-storyed buildings, crammed into small rooms.“Owners of these buildings do not treat the workers as human beings. They are money-minting instruments for owners. It is true they live in unhygienic conditions,” said Vipin.

Title: Coimbatore: Coronairus wreaks havoc on big, fat weddings
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: S Meenakshi and P Karuppusamy were planning to tie the knot at a marriage hall in Telugupalayam near the city in the presence of more than 1,000 relatives.

But, as the country went under the 21-day lockdown to prevent the spread of Covid-19, the families of the bride and the groom decided to make it a low-key affair. The couple got married on Monday at a temple in Kalampalayam near Perur here in the presence of 15 relatives. Everyone, including the priest who solemnised the wedding, wore a mask.

Though they did not get married in a grand way , they had to accept it as it was for the greater good, the couple said. Thanks to the simple ceremony , the bride’s family was also able to save around Rs 5lakh.

Several marriages scheduled for Monday, an auspicious day, were either held at homes or at temples. D Pushparaj and A Vijayalakshmi got married at a temple in Gandhi Park in the city as did Hari and Nikila, who got hitched at a temple in Chinniyampalayam in the presence of a few close relatives. All of them wore masks.

A Saibaba Colony-based couple, whose families had decided to get them married at a grand event in a marriage hall here, on Monday conducted the simple ceremony at their home in the presence of their parents and grandparents. “We had not anticipated this. But it was a different experience. We have decided to host a reception later for our extended family and friends,” the groom said.

Title: Follow admin advisory, DM asks citizens in Kanpur
Content:
DM takes a dip in Ganga

KANPUR: Faith in god normally boosts one's confidence and district magistrate, Kanpur Nagar, Dr Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari seems to be a strong believer. On Monday he took a holy dip in the Ganga and offered special prayers for the safety of Kanpur citizens.

Later, he made an appeal to the people to follow an advisory issued by the district administration as it would keep them in good health. He asked the people to remain indoors as in the wake of Covid-19 threat the home is safest place. The DM said that the administration was making efforts to streamline the supply chain and soon the door-to-door supply of essential commodities would be ensured.

Meanwhile, Awadhesh Bajpai , president, Kirana Merchant Association , stated that the district administration had not issued passes to their employees. Hence it was quite impossible to keep the market open till 8 pm. Similar situation was witnessed at Naubasta Grain market. tnn

Title: Govt toys with idea of using one ventilator for multiple patients
Content:
The health department has conducted a demonstration in this regard

JAIPUR: Anticipating a situation when the state might require more ventilators for Covid-19 patients, the health department is not only purchasing more ventilators, but it is also contemplating the idea for placing multiple patients on a single mechanical ventilator.

The health department has already conducted a demonstration and also it is examining its feasibility in the state. However, no decision has been taken yet. “Currently, we have enough ventilators. In future, we may require more. For purchasing new ones, we have already issued orders. However, we are taking technical advise on how to use one ventilator for multiple patients,” said health minister Raghu Sharma .

Patients, who have difficulty in breathing due to lung diseases, require ventilator support. In the state, it is estimated that 1,500 ventilators are available in private and government sectors. Reacting on use of one ventilator for multiple patients, experts claimed that it should be done cautiously.

“There are many technical aspects associated with it. If a ventilator is used for multiple users, it should be used cautiously. The distance between patients and ventilators should remain same. Also severity of disease and weight of patients are also important. Patients with equal weight and same severity of disease can use single ventilator. It is must be that if one ventilator is used for multiple patients, it has to be used cautiously,” said Dr Virendra Singh , one of the seven-member advisory committee constituted by the government on Covid-19.

However, one of the private hospitals in the city has started using one ventilator for multiple patients. For placing multiple patients on a single mechanical ventilators, it is required to attach hoses to one ventilator.

Sandeep Bakshi, chancellor of the university to which the hospital is attached said, “This initiative was propelled by the shortage of ventilators everywhere, thereby putting lives at risk. This technique also promises to be much cheaper.” The private hospital advocated that such ventilator is to be used only during crisis conditions like Covid-19 pandemic on similar kind of patients to avoid risk of cross infections.

Title: Trichy: Two held for selling liquor, 104 bottles seized
Content: TRICHY: The city police arrested two people for selling liquor and seized 104 bottles from them near the Gandhi Market on Sunday.Acting on a tip-off, prohibition and enforcement wing (PEW) rounded up S Selvam, 45, of Sooranchery near Gandhi Market and seized 90 bottles of two varieties of brandy of 180ml each.In another incident, PEW caught M Velmurugan, 42, of Mela Chinthamani, for selling liquor illegally in Trichy on Sunday night. He was nabbed near a graveyard in the area. Police seized 14 bottles of 180ml each from him.In another incident, police filed a case of break-in at a Tasmac wine shop at Konakarai in Woraiyur on Monday. tnn

Title: Kulithalai native is 67th Covid-19 patient in Tamil Nadu
Content: TRICHY: A 42-year-old man from Kulithalai in Karur district has tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday. He is the 67th patient to test positive in Tamil Nadu The patient, a native of Kulithalai and with a recent travel history to Delhi, is a resident of Chengalpet district. He came to Kulithalai on March 24 to meet his mother and elder brother. He developed symptoms the very next day and approached the primary health centre and was shifted to Karur medical college hospital on March 26, where he is stable and under observation in the isolation ward.There are currently four patients under observation in the isolation ward of the Karur medical college hospital, who are awaiting test results.Speaking to TOI, Karur collector T Anbalagan said the patient did not travel abroad in recent months. “There is no clear-cut evidence of community transmission so far. We believe that it might be stage 2 transmission during his travel from New Delhi,” he said.“Whether the transmission took place in New Delhi or on the flight is yet to be ascertained. He started from Chennai to Delhi on March 18 and reached on March 20. He stayed there for three days and on March 24 he took an early morning flight to Chennai and came to Kulithalai in the evening,” said the collector.Soon after the patient was tested positive, revenue officials along with department of public health and preventive medicine swung into action in Kulithalai. “The whole area including the specific street where the patient was residing was disinfected along with adjoining areas,” said a senior revenue official from Kulithai.We have started the containment exercise and we are also searching for people who came in close contact with the patient, said the official. “We are trying to trace contacts so that community transmission can be prevented,” added the official.

Title: Migrant workers still moving; volunteers give food and water
Content:
Jaipur: With the suspension of RSRTC and private buses, there were fewer migrant workers on roads across the state on Monday. Many who failed to boarding buses were still walking on the foot. Though they were tired, they were still keen to return to their homes within the state. At Sikar Road which connects Jaipur to districts including Jhunjhunu, Sikar, Churu, Bikaner , Sriganganagar and Hanumangarh, smaller groups were seen moving.

“I prepare food for weddings and functions. April and May are the season where weddings are on full swing and I earn up to Rs 2,000 per day. But after lockdown, my landlord asked me to vacate and villagers are asking to return,” said Ramesh Khatik, a 45-year-old man who was seen at Chomu Pulia while moving with his family including two sons and wife.

He said for the labourers and workers who belong to Rajasthan and its interior districts, the state government should not discontinue the buses. “Gaon main sab milley hain aur hawa bhi shudh hai(Village has everything and air is less polluted),” he said. On the way up to Harmada, there were smaller and bigger groups who were given food by the police teams and other volunteers.

“We have given them a bottle of water, a packet having basic meal including 10 poori, a dry cooked sabzi and some pickle. Also we have given them chips and fruits,” said Shankar Agarwal, a grocery store owner who was seen distributing food packets with his team at Harmada. Similar scenes were witnessed near Beawar (Ajmer), Chopasani (Jodhpur), Rohat (Jodhpur) where the migrant workers who hail from various districts of Rajasthan were moving.

“We are stopping those who are with women and small kids. However, those who are single are allowed to move. The women, children and their family members are kept in the camps,” said a senior officer of district administration in Pali.

Title: Contingency plan in place for supply of essential items
Content: Kochi: A contingency plan will be formulated and put in place in each district in the state to ensure supply of essential commodities during the lockdown period. As the initial step, a plan for one week will be drafted.The decision was taken following a videoconference held between principal secretary K R Jothilal, officials of public distribution system and district collectors. The principal secretary directed the officials to devise and execute contingency plans at district level to ensure supply of essential items if the lockdown continues for a month or gets extended to a period of three months.The conference decided to list out 15 essential items required in each district and ensure that the supply of these items are not disrupted. Special preparations should be made to ensure supply of items that could become scarce. Functioning of parcel and courier services should be streamlined for systematic supply of essential medicines.Measures will have to be put in place to ensure that vegetables and other essential commodities reach procurement and supply markets. If required, instructions should be issued for providing labourers for bringing in goods from other states.The district administration will have to ensure that drivers and labourers who bring essential supplies to the state are provided food. All vehicles leaving the state and coming into the state should be disinfected. The nodal officer should ensure the welfare of labourers. A medical officer should certify that the labourers and drivers heading for other states for collecting goods do not have any symptoms of the disease. Passes should be issued to facilitate transportation of all essential commodities.Ernakulam district collector S Suhas said that sub-committees have been constituted for ensuring supply of essential commodities. He said separate meeting will be held with representatives of various organizations for streamlining supply of essential goods. “Except for vegetables, there is enough stock of all other commodities in the district,” he said.

Title: Mama hai na, don’t worry, Chouhan tells girls’ in hostel
Content:
Chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan distributes ration to those in need

Bhopal: Chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan visited few places in BHEL township and Old Bhopal on Monday and sought information about the facilities being provided to the common man during the lockdown. He first reached the Triveni Woman Hostel in BHEL area and interacted with the working women residing there.

The women informed him that they are receiving the essential commodities. The chief minister told them that they should not have to worry at all; the food items and other essentials items will be made available to them. They must follow social distancing. He assured that we will certainly overcome this crisis.

Chouhan reached another Girls Hostel in Zone II, MP Nagar and spoke to the students residing there. He apprised himself of the facilities being provided there and sought information with regard to the supply of essential commodities. He asked them to keep talking to their mothers and tell them that Mama had come to enquire about their wellbeing. “Call home and tell your parents not to worry, Mama is here who is taking care of us.”

Chief minister also inquired about the availability of masks and sanitizers and directed officials to solve problems being faced by the students.

He also visited Smart City Office and enquired about the public services being provided through the control room and encouraged the team working there. The additional chief secretary ICP Kesari, principal secretary Sanjay Dubey and commissioner Bhopal division Kalpana Shrivastava brief him with the facilities and arrangements. Chouhan asked the youths working in the control room 'Are we ready to win the battle against Corona, everyone said yes we will win'.

The chief minister while inspecting the health division established in the control room, said that they should not let people of the state face any problem. Special attention should be paid on the health of all people. If they come across with the information about the symptoms of infection in any person's health, a team comprising doctor should be sent immediately to examine patient. He urged the officials and staff that ‘Aaiye, Hum Sab Ek Saath Milkar Corona Sankraman ko Haraein and Manva Jeevan ko Bachayein’ (Come, let’s defeat Corona infection together and save human lives).

The chief minister also took stock of the food and ration arrangement, made for the people. He also went through the problems being received at 104/181 and WhatsApp number 9301089967 and inspected the Smart City centre, set up to redress the complaints.

Citizens of the Old City were quite surprised, when the chief minister reached areas traversing through Buddhawara Chouraha and Imami Gate. He interacted with the people and assured them that the government was with them and take care of all issuesand they need not worry about anything. It is important that in these times we stay united and face the calamity bravely and with patience. This tough time will pass.

Chief minister Chouhan visited Maa Asha Darbar and other areas too, met the workers.

Title: Gujarat government releases 500 prisoners, 210 from Ahmedabad
Content:
A committee decided to release undertrials facing imprisonment of up to seven years

AHMEDABAD: As a precaution, about 400 undertrials were released on interim bail and 100 other convicts were released on parole on Monday evening. Senior jail officials said about 210 were released from Ahmedabad central jail.

Additional DGP jails K L N Rao said all released prisoners were properly checked by doctors first. “We gave them masks and also made arrangements to drop them in police vehicles to their native villages or at locations in the city,” he said.

A committee decided to release undertrials facing imprisonment of up to seven years. “Same was the case with convicts who were released on parole,” said a jail official.

Rao said a proposal had been made to the decrease the number of prisoners in jails to contain the spreading of coronavirus.

Title: Kanpur man with coronavirus-like symptoms shifted to hospital
Content: KANPUR: A man having symptoms of Covid-19 was found at Jhakarkati interstate bus terminal on Monday and was sent to UHM hospital after primary treatment.As many as 4,238 people on Monday arrived in the city from other parts of the state, according to a communique from the health department all were examined by a team deputed at the bus terminal.The health department team after examination allowed as many as 3,354 persons to go to their destination from bus terminal. And also allowed 600 persons at Bilhaur bus station to go their homes. The team home quarantined as many as 284 persons belonging to Kanpur.Meanwhile, Kanpur Municipal Corporation on Monday took a unique step towards sanitization . It placed water filled drums each having a capacity of 200 litres and a soap cake at 70 places across the city.According to mayor Pramila Pandey , the step has been taken to encourage people to clean their hands at regular interval for their personal sanitization. KMC’s mobile sanitization units continued their operation in the city and they sanitized and fogged several places and shelter homes at different places.KMC communique informed that tele-medicine facility is proving a popular platform for patients. On Monday, more than 50 persons had contacted for medical aid and benefited.Several social organizations have come forward to provide meals to the needy persons of the city..

Title: Good Samaritans, social organisations come forward to help those hit by lockdown
Content:
Dehradun/Rudrapur: Several non-government organisations (NGOs), social outfits, and good samaritans across the state have come forward to help those who are worst hit due to the ongoing Covid-19 lockdown.

In Dehradun, National Association for Parents and Students’ Rights (NAPSR) is providing free food to more than 500 people in need on a daily basis. The association told TOI that this drive will continue till the timne there is a lockdown in the city.

“We are providing free food at various locations of Dehradun. There is a large section of the population that is struggling to get a daily meal due to the Covid-19 lockdown. We are catering to more than 500 people daily and now, we have started with providing evening tea to police personnel on duty. Since the drive has started, we have covered several areas of Dehradun like Ajabpur Kalan, ISBT, Azad Colony, DL Road, and Sahastradhara Road,” said Arif Khan, NAPSR president.

Many residents have also taken it upon themselves to feed stray animals during the lockdown. A group called ‘Save The Stray During Lockdown’ was created a few days back on Facebook in order to provide a common platform to those who are willing to help the stray animals.

“The stray animals are completely dependent on the leftovers at markets, groceries, restaurants and others. As these establishments have been shut, stray animals are going without food. Thus, ‘Save The Stray During Lockdown’ was created. Fortunately, we have witnessed an overwhelming response as more than 200 people have joined our group in such a short time. Many people are providing us with food supplies for the stray animals. Anyone can join the group by giving us a call at 8920367282. Also, we follow the social distancing norm while feeding the stray animals,” said Anupma Khanna, founder of the group.

In Rudrapur, too, social organisations and residents are helping daily wagers and migrant workers who have gone out of work due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

“We are providing food and milk packets to people in need and are sanitising homes. We focus on providing relief to daily wagers, beggars, domestic helpers, and the likes,” said Karamjeet Singh Channa, president of social organisation ‘Zindagi Jindabad’. Another social organisation Tulsi Foundation has initiated a ‘Sabko Bhojan’ (food to everyone) programme to provide comprehensive kits of essential commodities to those in need. Similarly, locals of Bigbara village have raised funds to provide people with soaps, sanitisers, and masks.

Rudrapur SDM Mukta Mishra told TOI, “The social organisations keep us in loop while reaching out to those in need.” SP (crime) Devendra Peencha added, "Police personnel collect food packets from these social organisations and distribute them to the needy. If we come across any person in need, we are arranging food for them on our own as well.”

Title: Home delivery apps fail to meet demand
Content:
Food delivery boysÊ during lock down at Thiruvananthapuram city on SundayÊ photo by: T K Deepaprasad

Kochi: With lockdown in place, there has been a surge in demand for the e-commerce market. As a result, lots of news applications offering home delivery of groceries and vegetables have come up. Residents, unable to stroll around, turn to these apps to buy essentials. However, most of these apps are either not working or are unserviceable.

When a customer tries to contact the number provided on these apps, it remains on busy mode. Supermarkets, vegetable and fruit sellers and other shoppers promise online delivery asking people to order it at a specific time. However, when one attempts to do so, the app either crashes or remains unresponsive.

Meanwhile, there are certain apps that take orders, but the delivery get delayed to surge in demand. “We have checked almost all apps that promises home delivery but no avail. It consumes a lot of time to add products to the cart. Finally, when we try to place the order, the app crashes. While these has been a surge in demand for vegetables and fruits, ordering them online is, however, not possible. While, some admins clearly say that they have stopped taking orders due to Covid-19, others take orders for selected grocery items only. But it takes minimum four days to deliver them,” says Renjitha, a resident in Kadavanthra.

Meanwhile, Supplyco has started home delivery of groceries with the support of an online platform. “We have launched a home delivery system on trial basis within 8km radius of the city and it’s been huge success. We receive around 150 orders per day,” said Supplyco M D Ali Asgar Pasha.

Horticorp too launched online service with the support of an online platform in Ernakulam, but many customers find it difficult to place orders. “We got 1,800 orders for various products including, egg, milk and vegetables on Sunday and 3,000 orders on Monday. We cannot control the orders due to huge rush of customers. We have been forced to stop receiving orders within one hour of opening the app in the morning,” claimed official of the online platform.

On the issue of transporting essential commodities, transport secretary K R Jyohilal said government has issued 50,000 vehicle passes to district collectors in the state. “Once the vehicles get passes for transporting essential goods, things will pick up,” he said.

Title: Kanpur man stabbed to death by nephew
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A 45-year-old man was stabbed to death in broad daylight allegedly by his nephew over property dispute in Rail Bazar area of the city on Monday.

Rail Bazar inspector Dadhibal Tiwari said, “Around 11 am, police were informed that one Suresh of Kumhar Mandi had been stabbed.” When the team arrived at the spot, Suresh had already been rushed to a nearby hospital .

However, after his condition deteriorated, doctors referred him to Lala Lajpat Rai Hospital, where he died during treatment.

Preliminary investigations revealed that the victim, who was on his way to get some work done with regard to procurement of a ration card, had a scuffle with his nephew Sunil, said police.

“Sunil used to live with his maternal uncle but was forced to leave by the latter about four years ago owing to his drinking habit. This enraged Sunil, who had been picking up fights with Suresh on several occasions since then. He even made claims on his property,” said an investigator.

Sunil tried to escape the scene after stabbing Suresh, but was nabbed by the locals of the area. They thrashed him severely before handing him over to the police.

"Sunil was taken into custody and is being interrogated. Body was sent for postmortem. An FIR has been lodged under relevant sections of IPC. Investigations are on," said police.

Title: MUHS defers PG exams by a month
Content:
Nashik: The Maharashtra University of Health Sciences (MUHS) on Monday announced that the postgraduation (allopathy) examination has been deferred by a month.

The exam, earlier scheduled between May 12 and 18, will now take place between June 15 and 22. Ajit Pathak , the varsity’s controller of examination, in a circular announced the new dates of the summer PG examination for MD/MS/diploma/MSc courses. These are the second-semester exams of the 2020 session.

The university took the decision after the Maharashtra Association of Resident Doctors ( MARD ) petitioned the university, requesting it to defer the exams by at least a month. The PG students are currently assisting senior doctors in medical college hospitals in treating suspected and positive Covid-19 patients.

Kalidas Chavan, the registrar of MUHS, told TOI: “We had received the request from MARD. We have accepted their request and rescheduled the examination.” There are nearly 2,400 students who are to take these examinations in the state. The university has also extended the last date of submission of examination forms to May 5. The students can submit the applications with late fees till May 8 and with very late fees till May 12 (evening 5 pm).

Title: Shelves at many grocery stores bare as stocks fail to arrive; veggie rates stable
Content:
Police ensure social distancing is maintained by citizens queuing up at APMC market in Vashi on Monday

Mumbai: The state’s plan for grocery shops to remain open 24/7 seems a tall order as groceries in the city are failing to work even normal hours due to disruption in supply chains. On the other hand, vegetable supplies have stabilized and consequently prices too. The surfeit of 800 vegetable trucks that arrived in APMC Vashi on Saturday against the daily normal of 550 had a trickle down effect on prices in Mumbai. Rates remained stable at Rs 60-80 per kg in most parts of the city.

By contrast, supermarkets, real and virtual, as well as neighbourhood kirana stores are displaying bare shelves as shop owners have been unable to replenish stocks. Some like Sweet Home Supermarket in Lokhandwala Complex, Andheri, the largest in the locality, closed for business on Monday. Others are operating fewer hours. The owner of Prince Store in the same locality said, “There is no transport, no loaders, no drivers, so the supply chain is broken.”

Even basic salt, dal and rice are in short supply in Pali Market as are biscuits and noodles. Elsewhere, soap and detergent are not available.

In Panchpakhadi, Thane, kirana stores wore a bare look. Resident Anand Viswanathan said, “I visited three stores before I could find salt.”

Mediaperson Naina Roy visited Big Bazaar in Vashi. She said, “Stocks were patchy with fewer fruits and vegetables than the previous Sunday. Also, it was depleted of frozen foods such as sausages, parathas and green peas.”

Vegetable supplies did not pose a grave problem Monday given that 800 vehicles came in Saturday. APMC authorities on Monday restricted entry only to licence or card holders. This decision reduced footfalls by 70%.

As kitchens were shut and procuring food for critical staff in a multinational bank’s offices in Mumbai and Bengaluru became difficult, Vijay R from a corporate cafeteria management firm directly wrote to the CEO of MTR Foods.

“I found the email ID online and was surprised to get an immediate response from the team. Ready-to-eat meals were delivered in just a couple of days as per our requirement,” he said.

Sunay Bhasin, chief marketing officer, MTR Foods, said they have been working relentlessly to supply meals, wherever they can.

Title: Making a song and dance about coronavirus and going viral too
Content:
Ram Miriyala

HYDERABAD: A song writer’s midnight stroke of creativity has turned out to be a chartbuster that is being used to create awareness against the spread of novel coronavirus in Telangana. The song ‘Chethuleththi mokkutha’ is currently a hot favourite on social media to drive home the message against the virus.

“It is not about me feeling happy because the song is doing well. The only reason behind composing the song was that I felt socially responsible,” songwriter Ram Miriyala told TOI.

In addition to the popular song, films stars — Chiranjeevi, Nagarjuna, Sai Dharam Tej and Varun — have also come up with a song ‘We got to fight corona edhemaina.’

Several others like Balu Kampally Swaero have also come up with songs to create an awareness on the coronavirus and the precautions to be taken. Some are also rephrasing old filmi dialogues, as Maruthi Ram has done, urging caution. Siddhala Hussain came out with a folk song. Manasa Acharya reworked the lyrics of the famous Mohammed Rafi song ‘Sepaayi o sepaayi’ to spread awareness about covid.

But, 32-year-old Ram Miriyala’s song has stolen the march over others. Ram, has also written a few popular songs for his band ‘ChowRaasta,’ including the hugely popular ‘Oerelipotha mama,’ which garnered more than four millions views. In just four days, ‘Chethuleththi mokkutha’ got 2.4 millions views on YouTube. “It is fulfilling to know that the song is serving its purpose. The focus should entirely be on the song and not me,” Ram, who worked for a radio channel until recently, said.

Title: Trichy: Police act tough on violators, 100 held
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Despite the crackdown against curfew violators, people continued to venture out unmindful of the risk of being infected by Covid-19 in central region of Tamil Nadu on Monday. In Trichy city, 48 cases were booked and more than 100 people were arrested on Sunday. Instead of booking each individual, the police are booking cases against a group of individuals in order to avoid piling up of cases.

The central region comprising Trichy rural, Ariyalur, Perambalur , Karur, Pudukottai, Thanjavur , Tiruvarur and Nagappattinam - has reported 1,114 cases and 1240 arrests besides the seizure of 749 vehicles including 26 four wheelers in a single day today.

Trichy district was one among the district with most cases registered day. On Monday, Trichy rural police arrested 314 people, seized 156 vehicles and booked 251 cases.

Appealing to people not to venture out from home, Trichy district SP Zia Ul Haq said, “Please cooperate and don’t venture out without strong reason. Otherwise, deterrent legal action would be taken,” SP Haq told TOI. Trichy rural police have deployed four drone cameras for surveillance, he added.

Since then the curfew came into effect on March 24, Trichy district police has arrested 1,136 people and seized 253 cars in 783 cases.

Karuppur village VAO P Pandeeswaran has lodged a complaint against a R Alagappa, 27, of Nallaponnampatti, for spreading false news among residents of Puthanatham in Trichy. TNN

Title: More people seek travel passes to other districts
Content:
Trichy: The collector’s office has seen a flurry of requests for passes mostly for travelling to other districts, after the disaster management department began issuing travel passes for emergency situations.

The department issues passes in extraordinary situations such as prefixed marriages, funerals and medical emergencies. Over the past few days, people began thronging the offices asking for the passes.

People have been frequenting the district collector’s office seeking passes for those not considered as emergency. However, in most cases, they are made to run from pillar to post as even officials do not have the clarity in issuing passes.

The state government had imposed Section 144 under CrPC and prevented gathering of people to prevent community spread of Covid-19. It also closed district borders to prevent travel from one district to another.

This has in a way affected essential travel that cannot be called an emergency. For instance, a professor from city college had sent his 10-year-old daughter to Vellore to his in-laws place for the vacation about two weeks back.

“I had to leave her in Vellore as my wife and I were working till last week. We had plans to bring her back over the last few days but could not do so due to the curfew,” he said.

The professor approached the district administration for a pass to travel to Vellore, but he was denied it after he was made to approach multiple offices.

A senior official from the Trichy district administration said that four passes were issued on Monday. But the office has been receiving many requests that don’t come under the categories mentioned by the state government. “Therefore, we are unable to issue the passes,” the official said.

Passes are being given to pilgrims and devotees stranded in Trichy over the last one week. While these are genuine cases who can make their own arrangement for travel, passes are issued in extraordinary medical emergency.

People suffering from cancer, kidney-related ailments, illness to newborn and funerals are also considered, the official said.

The state has given instructions on Monday that permission can be obtained from respective tahsildar to travel within the district. People need not come to the collectorate for requests. However, inter-district travel needs to be recognised by the collector.

Title: Ahmedabad: On blistered feet, migrants slog on to reach home
Content:
AHMEDABAD: In ordinary days, a road journey between Ahmedabad and Surat takes nearly four hours. But Kallu Yadav and his three friends, all from Etawah in Uttar Pradesh, took 48 hours to reach Ahmedabad from Surat.

Kallu Yadav,32, Ravi Yadav, 25, Ranu Yadav, 23, and Bipin Yadav, had been working at a textile firm in Surat but the lockdown closed their unit and erased their daily earnings, forcing them to leave for their native place.

“We had left Surat on Saturday evening by taking lifts in different vehicles ranging from loading autorickshaws to vegetable containers. We reached up to Nadiad, but from there we did not get any vehicle. So we began walking and finally reached Ahmedabad after a walk of around seven hours,” said Kallu, who was walking on SP Ring Road near Nana Chiloda Circle.

Narrating his tale of migration to Ahmedabad, Kallu said that his father was a marginal farmer with just three bighas of land at their village, and migration was the only choice left to him to earn for his family. Three others too said that they also did not have any option as they did not get education and employment opportunities.

“Stray cows spoiled our crop last year. So we were under great debt and I migrated to Gujarat,” said Ravi.

On the same SP Ring Road, a person was sitting alone tired from walking around 18km from Chanakyapuri to Nana Chiloda Circle. When asked why he was sitting there, Satpal Jatav,40, from Eta district of Uttar Pradesh said that he was a labourer of house painting work but now he desperately wanted to go home to attend his ailing daughter.

“I do not have money to survive here. In my native village, my daughter, 9, has jaundice. I wanted to go home at any cost,” said Jatav before running towards a roadside pit, when he spied a police van.

Near Bhat village, eight men, all aged between 20 and 25, were sharing a packet of glucose biscuits. One of them, Ashok Yadav, told TOI, “We were working at a factory in Kadi town of Mehsana. After the lockdown, we ran out of money so we decided to leave for our village. We did not have food. Seeing our pitiable condition a truck driver gave us a packet of biscuits which we are sharing.”

A police official said that they have instructions from superiors not to allow any migrants to leave where they were. So, the cops are not allowing any labourer to leave for their native place, he said.

Title: Only one Brit at medical college
Content:
Kochi: Of the eight British nationals, only one patient, the person on whom anti-HIV drugs were administered, is under treatment at Government Medical College , Ernakulam . While three of them who were tested negative are accommodated in Bolgatty Palace Hotel, four persons who are still Covid positive have been shifted to a private hospital in Kochi.

Four British nationals, who were complaining about “poor hygiene” at the medical college, had been demanding that they should be shifted to private hospital. But the person who was tested negative after anti-HIV drugs have been administered said he would prefer the treatment at the medical college. Though he is Covid negative now, he is suffering from other diseases like pneumonia.

Three UK citizens, including wife of the British national who is now under treatment at the medical college, are accommodated at Bolgatty Palace Hotel. She has never been tested positive for the disease while two others shifted to the hotel had tested negative following treatment at the medical college. Officials with tourism department said they had been providing all help for the UK citizens ever since they reached Kerala. “Even while they were admitted to the medical college, we had supplied essential commodities like tissue papers, food items, etc.,” an official with tourism department said.

According to the officials with the medical college, even the UK nationals who underwent treatment at the hospital earlier have expressed their satisfaction over the medical care given to them. “Some of them have even send messages to us. An 80-year-old UK woman wrote to us after she came to know that a British couple had complained about the “poor hygiene” and facilities at the hospital. In the message, she briefed about the tests she had underwent here and the efforts that we took for conducting the tests. She thanked us,” sources with the medical college said.

The British national, along with his wife and 17 compatriots, had tried to board a flight to Dubai from Cochin airport while they were undergoing quarantine at Tea Country Hotel in Munnar on March 15, the very day when he was tested positive for Covid-19. Eleven of them were allowed to leave the country on March 21 after they were tested negative.

Title: Trichy: Railway workshop to engage retired doctors to combat Covid-19
Content: TRICHY: Following a communique from the railway board to engage medical practitioners at railway hospitals on a contract basis to handle the situation following the outbreak of Covid-19 , authorities of the Ponmalai railway hospital in Trichy are working on the process of identifying retired medical practitioners and paramedical staff to tie up with them.In order to control and effectively contain the pandemic, health officials from the respective railway divisions have been asked to engage retired doctors at railway hospitals for a period of one month over and above the vacancy as per local requirement. Divisional railway health departments have been asked to follow the engagement process as already laid down by the board. They have also been instructed to give first preference to retired railway doctors who are below 65 years. To meet the shortage of doctors in railway hospitals, engaging contract medical practitioners against regular vacancies has commenced.A senior official from Trichy railway hospital said that seven to 10 vacancies may have to be required to fill including paramedical staff at the Ponmalai Railway workshop hospital. They have begun the process of preparing a list and would soon engage the required number of doctors as well as paramedical staff, the officer said.Meanwhile, the railway board has instructed its divisional health officials to allow all central government servants to avail services from railway hospitals by producing their identity cards at the health units, an official from the Trichy division said.

Title: Unable to get liquor, Telangana man attempts suicide
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Allegedly frustrated at not being able to get liquor due to the lockdown, a 40-year-old tippler in Telangana’s Siddipet attempted to end his life, police said on Monday.

The man, identified as M Yadagiri, a resident of Renuka Nagar in the town, tried to electrocute himself with live electric wires of a transformer. Police rushed to the spot and admitted the man to a hospital after they were alerted about the incident by locals at a funeral nearby. Police said that the victim was addicted to toddy and was suffering from severe withdrawal symptoms.

“At around 6 am, a local informed us about the incident at Bara Imam Chowrasta near Hanuman temple in Siddipet town. Yadagiri entered the enclosed electric transformer’s area by crossing the safety fence. He was behaving aggressively and began punching on the fuse boxes of the transformers. As sparks started emanating from the boxes, people who were in the adjacent graveyard during a funeral quickly disconnected power supply to the transformer using a stick. Power supply to the main line was also stopped with the help of electricity officials,” inspector Saidulu said.

Police took Yadagiri into custody. “Yadagiri is an alcoholic. He used to consume toddy and liquor everyday. As he could not lay his hands on alcohol, he experienced withdrawal symtoms and on Monday morning he attempted suicide by holding electric wires,” the inspector said.

Yadagiri suffered minor burns on his hands and is undergoing treatment at a local hospital in Siddipet. Police made a General Diary entry of the incident. No case was registered.

Title: Pregnant woman walks 200 km, Noida to Jalaun
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A pregnant woman and her husband, working as daily wagers at a construction site in Noida for five years, walked over 200 kms to reach their village Aunta in Rath area of Jalaun district on Sunday. Anju Devi (25), an eight months' pregnant, covered the distance in two days and two nights.

After reaching Rath, Ashok (28), her husband, went to a Community Health Centre where they underwent medical checkup. Doctors, conducted a thermal screening and declared the couple to be normal. However, they were instructed to keep themselves in quarantine for 14 days.

Ashok is a landless farmer and works at a construction site in Noida. They walked for 200km up to Orai and finally reached Rath on a loader. Anju's in-laws heaved a sigh of relief when she reached home along with her husband. They were in constant touch with them through their mobile phone and praying for their safe return.

“I was worried for my child who is yet to come. I am now happy. We couldn’t move out early due to delay in payment by contractor," said Anju.

While leaving Noida on March 25, the couple carried with them `puri' and `sabji', which they consumed the same night. "After that we lived on whatever was served by people on the highway," Ashok added.

Title: Isolation ward staff can’t go home now
Content: Nashik: The Nashik civil hospital administration has instructed the staff working in the isolation ward , where the confirmed Covid-19 patient was admitted on Friday, to not go home until the patient recovers.The decision was taken at meeting between senior officials of the isolation ward before the staff was informed about it.Additional civil surgeon Nikhil Saindane said that the staff will be allowed to go home only seven days after the confirmed Covid-19 patient is discharged.“The hospital has made lodging and boarding arrangement for the staff,” he said.Six nurses, three medical officers and paramedical staff work in shifts in the isolation ward of the hospital.The hospital management has decided to not send the staff home until there is a Covid-19 patient in the isolation ward because of the contagious nature of coronavirus “There is a vehicle to transport the staff from the isolation ward to their lodging facility. They will only travel between their lodging facility and the isolation ward. Laundry arrangement has also been made. If more patients come, further arrangement will be made accordingly,” said Saindane.The doctors said that these arrangements have been made to avoid the spread of the virus among the family members of the staff.The isolation ward has 18 beds for Covid-19 suspects and confirmed patients.The ward is at the rear end of the civil hospital, and it is away from the main building. A separate road leads to the isolation ward from the main entrance of the hospital.

Title: Building fire leads to breaking of lockdown in south Kolkata
Content:
The fire, suspected to have been caused by a short circuit at South City Galaxy on Justice Chandra Madhab Road... Read More

KOLKATA: Residents of an upscale highrise in Bhowanipore had to break the lockdown restrictions and rush out of their homes on Monday morning after a fire broke out on a16th floor flat of the G+20 tower. One flat was completely gutted while another was partially damaged after a gas cylinder went off due to the intensive heat. Around 10 tenders were pressed into service to bring the fire under control. None was reportedly injured or trapped inside the building.

The fire, suspected to have been caused by a short circuit at South City Galaxy on Justice Chandra Madhab Road off Ashutosh Mukherjee Avenue in Bhowanipore, was noticed around 10am. The flat (16A), where the fire broke out, belongs to the businessman Anirduddh Modi, who deals in real estate and tea. Modi, his wife and two children raised an alarm and alerted the building’s security guards. Other residents of the building were alerted about the fire through intercom.

The tenders took over four hours to douse the fire around 2.30pm. The residents of the building stood huddled on the ground car parking lot as the fire had been raging for several hours. Though fire officials brought a hydraulic lift, they could not use it as the fire reached a higher level by then.

The fire videos clicked by locals went viral on social media in a few minutes. Local councillor Ashim Bose said, “The fire brigade had a harrowing time dousing the flames. Lockdown restrictions could not be followed due to the incident. Food was served to the residents of the building in the community centre. They returned to their respective flats only after electricity was restored.” Fire minister Sujit Bose and fire services director general Jag Mohan visited the spot.

Title: Officials to contact NE riot victims for aid, Govt tells HC
Content:
New Delhi: The AAP government assured Delhi high court that its officials would contact the families of 275 victims , who were displaced due to the northeast Delhi riots , to find out if they needed any food or medicines .

A bench of justices Sanjeev Sachdeva and Navin Chawla was also informed by the government that mohalla clinics of the northeast district were functional and the affected people would be provided with the details of nodal officers who could be contacted in case of requirement of medical assistance.

The court, which conducted the proceeding through video -onferencing in view of the restrictions due to the Covid-19 outbreak, was hearing a plea by Shaikh Mujtaba Farooq seeking direction to the authorities to re-open the relief camp at Idgah in Mustafabad and provide proper food supplies, adequate water, sanitation and security to the victims.

The government counsel also stated that the families which were staying at the camp at Idgah had voluntarily left the camp and were not removed by police or the government. Later the camp had been disbanded.

“Without getting into the controversy as to whether the families of the riot victims which were living at the camp at Idgah vacated the camp voluntarily or they were forced to vacate, the fact of the matter is that they were no longer there at the camp,” HC observed, after being informed by the government that its officers would get in touch with the persons whose names and telephone numbers had been provided by the petitioner.

The counsel added that in case any of the families require accommodation, efforts should be made to immediately place them in appropriate accommodation or relief camps. Senior advocate Colin Gonsalves, appearing for the petitioner apprised the court about the issues faced by the riot victims.

The court listed the matter for April 3 for directions or reporting compliance of its order.

Title: No content: Kannada soaps in soup
Content:
BENGALURU: A pall of gloom has enveloped the once-thriving Kannada entertainment TV industry — employing nearly 8,000 people and worth Rs 700 crore in terms of annual business — with all activity grinding to a halt on March 15 following the lockdown .

Lakhs of individual households that feast on Kannada serials and reality shows will be left in the lurch once the current bank of the content ends by April 3. Channels will be forced to repeat old TV serials and other shows, say industry insiders.

“Every serial director will have a bank of about 10-20 episodes. Since the lockdown doesn’t seem to be ending soon, this bank will get exhausted,” said Veerendra Bellichukki , secretary of Kannada Television Association (KTA).

Association sources put the annual size of the industry at Rs 700 crore. According to the association, 65 mega serials, 10 reality shows and several cookery shows are currently being telecast. B Suresha, a former KTA resident and acclaimed director, actor and theatreperson, said re-telecasting serials is not the wisest thing to do but channels don’t have options.

Bellichukki lamented that the biggest impact would be on actors, technicians, and other staff working for serials. “Those working in the TV industry get paid on daily basis and they are largely dependent on it. Due to the lockdown, they won’t be earning,” he added.

Barring the big names, the monthly earning of most people involved in the industry is between Rs 20,000-Rs 25,000, which is very less compared to that in the film industry.

Title: ‘Do it yourself’ is now a lockdown mantra
Content:
KOCHI: Praveen Nair had never tried fixing a leaking faucet before. As the plumber who used to visit his neighbourhood is forced to stay indoors due to the lockdown, he is left with no option but to try doing it himself.

“This is something completely new to me. Water was dripping, and something had to be done urgently. Hardware shops are closed. It is not possible to buy a piece to replace the damaged one. Moreover, there is no one available to do the job. I spoke to the plumber over the phone, and he gave me some quick fix solutions,” said Nair, who works as HR manager in a private firm. Queries were posted on the WhatsApp group of the apartment complex, and he managed to get the tools required for the task from his neighbour. “Another person helped me with O-rings. It took considerable time, and constant contact with the plumber over the phone to get it done,” he added.

As families and individuals remain confined within the walls of their homes, DIY ( Do IT Yourself ) has become the catch phrase. Many homes that were earlier dependent on domestic helps are now left to do everyday chores themselves. Even children are encouraged to do their bit. Housemaids have become a luxury of the past. “Cooking, cleaning, dusting and scrubbing have become shared activities. Everyone has to do their own laundry. We make our kids clean their room and bathrooms,” said Shalini Mohan, a software programmer.

While some people are dependent on families and friends for advice and tips, others manage to get information online. People check websites for easy recipes, and those who want to experiment with their culinary skills search for elaborate recipes. “It’s all about survival during crisis,” said Aswathy A, a student who returned home from a neighbouring state.

Apartment owners associations say that at least some residents have started taking interest in knowing how waste generated in their buildings are being processed. There could be times when sanitation workers would not be able to reach the apartment complex. “Some of the residents also watched the process of treating bio-waste when training was given to temporary labourers. Future is so uncertain, and it might help us,” said a representative of an apartment complex.

However, in the midst all these there is a small section trying to find their feet in the changed situations. “I am in home quarantine since my return from the UK. I do not know how to wash clothes by hand. The washing machine is placed near the kitchen, and I cannot go there. It’s also not possible to handover my clothes to other members in the family. I soak my clothes in soap and antiseptic liquids in a bucket and leave it on the staircase. Someone collects it from there. It never occurred to me that I would have to do all cleaning and moping on a regular basis. I feel sad and guilty about it,” said a student.

Title: 9k from Chandrapur struck at AP, Telangana borders
Content: Nagpur: Worried about the risk of coronavirus spread in Chandrapur , its guardian minister Vijay Wadettiwar refused entry to about 9,000 people from the district stranded on the Andhra Pradesh and Telangana borders.Most of them are poor and are stuck at various places in both states where they went for work. After the nationwide lockdown announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi last Tuesday, they got stuck there as not only Maharashtra but AP and Telangana too sealed their borders. Their plight came to fore after some of them made frenetic calls to their friends and relatives in Chandrapur, who in turn, sought the administration’s help to rescue them.“Since our district is yet to witness even a single case of coronavirus, we don’t want to risk the rest of population due to few of them. I know I will be targeted from both sides after taking this harsh stand, but in larger interest of the society, I need to do it,” Wadettiwar told TOI.The state social justice minister, however, said he had conveyed their plight to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and he had spoken to his counterpart in Telangana K Chandrashekhar Rao. “The latter assured all the help to stranded persons. Even the PM had called on states to seal the borders to prevent the outbreak,” he said.The Chandrapur administration had prepared a detailed list of such citizens who are stuck up in the neighbouring state. About 4,500 are located in Khamam alone, while rest are in Mehboob Nagar, Bhadrachalam and some are at Karnataka border.“Besides CM, our collector has also established contact with their counterparts in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana and they assured all help with food and shelter to our citizens. They have been taken to nearby schools where shelters are arranged for them. Fortunately for us, the collectors there are Maharashtrians and batchmates of our collector. Therefore, it has become easier for us to convince them,” Wadettiwar said.On the minister’s directives, the district administration is also transporting foodgrains and other essential commodities to places where these 9,000 people are stranded. They will be kept there till the lockdown is in place, where they will be checked. “We’ve tried to include all such persons in the list which was prepared with the help of tehsildar. We will take care of all our citizens till the lockdown is in place,” the minister added.Amravati farmers also stranded in MPFarmers from Morshi, Warud, and Ambala are also stuck in Shyamgadh in neighbouring Madhya Pradesh. They had gone there for selling oranges. With no money and means to return to their native place, these aggrieved men made an emotional appeal through social media that went viral. They pleaded to rescue stating that they were starving there since three days and incessant rains made their plight worst. “When we try to go out of the town, the cops thrash us with sticks as curfew is in place. Some of us managed to escape from here after they called minister Bachchu Kadu and MLA Ravi Rana. But, no one came to our help. Our family members are crying there and they too are in dire straits,” they said while requesting to help them.

Title: Pune: Senior citizen cheated of Rs 1.5 lakh in KYC update fraud
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Cyber crooks emptied an 85-year-old retired college principal’s bank account under the pretext of updating his e-wallet.

The fraudsters, between Friday and Sunday, siphoned of Rs 1.5 lakh from his the account. They even got him to share the bank account details of his wife and their married daughter, but these accounts were untouched.

When the man’s son-in-law, a medical practitioner, came to know about the fraud, he blocked the accounts to avoid further loss. He also lodged a complaint with the cyber crime police station later on Sunday.

When contacted, the complainant told TOI that his father-in-law stays in Kothrud . On Friday afternoon, the senior citizen received a text message on his cellphone telling him to update his KYC information for his e-wallet account.

“My father-in-law contacted the given cellphone number. The caller told him that his account will be shut down if he does not update the information immediately,” the complainant said.

Rattled, his father-in-law shared his details including the bank account number and debit card details with the person. A little later, he received an SMS about a Rs 25,000 debit from his bank account.

“My father-in-law immediately contacted the person and told him about the debit. The person told him that something must have gone wrong and assured him that the money would be returned,” the complainant said.

On Saturday, the person again contacted the elderly man seeking other bank account details saying that they would split the amount and return it.

“The fraudsters told my father-in-law that he could give the account details of relatives too,” the medical practitioner said. He gave the bank details of his wife and their daughter.

The same day, the suspects siphoned of Rs 25,000 more and on Sunday they emptied the bank account.

“Altogether, they siphoned Rs 1.5 lakh from the one account. We realized it was a fraud on Sunday. We filed a complaint and on Monday blocked both the accounts,” he said.

Inspector of the cyber crime police station Machhindra Pandit said they will conduct a probe.

The Pimpri Chinchwad police too received five complaints about duping under the pretext of updating the e-wallet

Title: 3 more test positive for Covid-19, Pune case count goes up to 43
Content:
Representative image

PUNE/MUMBAI: Three persons, including two family members of the 40-year-old critically-ill Sahakarnagar man, tested positive for novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection on Monday.

The third case is a 40-year-old resident of Baner who recently returned from Bermuda. He was quarantined at Naidu hospital two days ago. His contacts are being traced. The three fresh cases have pushed up the city’s positive tally to 43.

The Sahakarnagar man suffers from chronic liver disease. He has no history of international travel or any proximity to known infected persons or their close contacts. He has been put on ventilator support at a private hospital in the Deccan area since March 26.

Besides, the civic health officials said a 52-year-old resident of Thane, who succumbed to complications associated with the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection at a private hospital in Pune on Monday, diabetic.

The man developed breathlessness at his in-laws’ residence on March 22 and was admitted to hospital. “He developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). His oxygen saturation was falling rapidly following which we intubated him and put him on ventilator support the next day. His hypertensive and diabetic condition added to the complications in a short span. We could not pull him off ARDS despite putting in our best efforts,” said a doctor from the hospital.

The source of infection in seven people diagnosed with the contagion in Pune between March 20 and March 29 cannot been linked to international travel or a traceable contact to an infected person.

“Presently, the condition of two of them — a 41-year-old woman living on Sinhagad road and a 40-year-old man living in Sahakarnagar — is critical but stable. Both have tested positive for Covid-19. There is no history of international travel or proximity to known infected persons or their close contacts in their case. They are on the ventilator support,” Wavare said.

Mumbai’s tally of cases witnessed a big jump with the civic body announcing 47 new cases. However, state officials said they were still scrutinizing the civic body’s cases, so a majority of them have not yet been added to the state’s list.
