Of the two fatalities from Mumbai, the civic officials chose to report only one -- of an 80-year-old heart patient at Fortis Hospital, Mulund. Sources said the man, who had hypertension and ischemic heart disease, had come to the hospital on March 28 with respiratory distress and died in the next 24 hours. He had no travel history or known contact with a traveller, sources said.

TOI learnt about the second death, which the BMC said was still under scrutiny, of an 86-year-old woman from Ghatkopar. She passed away at L H Hiranandani Hospital, Powai, at 7am on Monday, almost 10 days after her US-returned son and maid tested positive.

Despite two deaths of people having no travel history or contacts, state officials said they still can’t be called cases of community transmission. Dr Anup Yadav of the public health department said 39 patients have recovered and gone home.

A member of a Bollywood star’s family passed away late on Monday evening due to acute respiratory distress syndrome. Though his swab sample was sent for Covid-19 testing, the report is awaited. The family member, who is not into cinema, died at a private hospital in the western suburbs, a hospital source said. Though he did not stay with the star’s family, he is believed to have used the same gym in their building.

(With inputs from Sumita DebRoy)

Title: 7 relatives of district’s first Covid-19 patient admitted to civil hospital
Content: Nashik: Seven family members of the patient who tested positive for Covid-19 in a village near Lasalgaon in Niphad taluka were admitted to quarantine ward of the Nashik civil hospital around 1.30am on Monday and their swabs sent for testing.The 30-year-old man, a bread seller from the village, who had been admitted to the civil hospital on March 27, tested positive on Sunday, following which the district health department swung into action and brought his family members to hospital. The doctor who initially treated him has been home-quarantined and his throat sample sent for testing.The health department also ordered the screening of all the inhabitants of the village as a precautionary measure. A total of 28 teams of Aanganwadi Sevikas, health workers and Asha have been pressed into service to conduct a house-to-house survey. The village has has a population of 6,888 living in 1,400 houses, said officials.District health officer (Zilla Parishad) Dawal Salve said, “We have mapped 3km radius around the village. A medical officer each is leading four teams. If the teams find coronavirus symptoms in any villager, he/she will be sent to the Nashik civil hospital for further investigation.”Salve said that four teams are also working on contact tracing of the patient. “Swabs of people who came in close contact with the patient are also being collected for further investigation.”According to officials, the health workers are also screening people from other villages where the patient sold bread. People who visited the clinic of the doctor who had initially treated the Covid-19 patient are also being screened.The officials said that the bread seller neither has any international travel history nor came into contact with anyone with the history of foreign travel.Meanwhile, superintendent of police Arti Singh said that a team of cops has gone to the village concerned to appeal to the inhabitants over there not to panic as the district administration was making all efforts to ensure that the disease does not spread.

Title: Launch of ration card portability scheme on hold: Tamil Nadu food minister
Content:
TIRUVARUR: The implementation of ration card portability scheme , which was scheduled to be introduced from April 1 across Tamil Nadu , has been put on hold, food minister R Kamaraj said on Monday.

“Considering the Covid-19 situation, it was decided to defer the scheme for now as it may create further confusion in the system,” the minister told reporters after a meeting with revenue and health department.

As part of the “one nation one ration card’ scheme of the central government, Tamil Nadu introduced the scheme in Tirunelveli and Tuticorin districts on a pilot basis. Following its success, the government had announced in the assembly that intra-state portability of ration card would come into operation from April 1.

“Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami had announced distribution of a package including Rs 1,000 in cash, rice and sugar to all cardholders in the state from April 2. In an effort to maintain community distance, the government has introduced token system,” the minister added.

Talking about Covid-19 related works executed by the district administration, Kamaraj said that 304 guest workers have been given accommodation as officials were ensuring they were getting essential food and medical facility.

“We have identified 2,364 people coming from various countries and all of them have been quarantined at their homes. They are being constantly monitored by both health staff and police,” Kamaraj added.

District collector T Anand and SP M Durai were also present during the meeting.

Title: Covid-19 lockdown: Stranded in US, parents of Telugu techies worry about medicine & return journey
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Parents of Telugu techies and other employees, who have gone to the US from both Telangana and Andhra Pradesh to stay with their wards, are stranded there as a result of the lockdown and are facing uncertain times. With no idea as to when they can come back, many of them are worried about running out of medicines and also about medications for which they cannot get local refills.

Venky Duggishetty whose parents had flown New Jersey in November 2019 are among those stuck there. “They had to leave in December, but are stranded here,” he said.

Duggishetty says his parents suffer from diabetes and blood pressure. “The problem is not change of prescription. The problem is the price of medication here. Diabetes medication is very expensive in the US.” He said if the cost of medication in India is Rs 3,600 a month, the same would cost Rs 35,000 in the US. “For now, I will buy the medicines for my parents. But, for how long I will be able to sustain I am not sure,” he said.

R Ravikanth, who lives in Texas, is facing a similar problem. He says his mother, who came to the US to help take care of his new-born daughter last year, is desperately waiting to go back to India. “She has medicines to last for a month. After that, we do not know how we will manage her medical expenses,” he said, add that he is the family’s only earning member.

Mounika Narne whose cousin is going through the same predicament said usually parents get medicines to last for six months. “Most of them may have exhausted their medicine stocks. Some are staying without medication, while others are trying hard to reach out to people to look out for any possibilities of getting them via shipments,” she told TOI.

Title: NIRDPR to help GPs monitor migrants
Content:
Hyderabad: The National Institute of Rural Development and Panchayati Raj (NIRDPR) is launching awareness initiatives to help gram panchayats across India monitor migrants returning from cities.

According to a press release issued by the NIRDPR, the institute is providing information, education and communication (IEC) material and methodical awareness-creation modules through its newly-launched learning management portal ‘Gram Swaraj’. The initiative is aimed at helping migrants and ensuring that they are adequately screened for Covid-19 infection and quarantined where necessary.

The material would not only create awareness about safety measures such as regular washing of hands, maintaining social distancing and other directives but will also prepare gram panchayats towards ensuring that no person goes hungry, irrespective of their socio-economic background.

“There could be a number of households in each panchayat area where the migrant families who returned from urban centers lack resources for sustenance for this long period as their livelihoods may depend on daily earnings. We need to focus on them too,” said WR Reddy, director general of NIRDPR while pointing out that a system has to be created where all needy families will need to be provided with food or ration for their sustenance.

Title: Ahmedabad trend shows least local transmissions
Content: AHMEDABAD: The city tops the chart with 33% of the state’s total positive cases at 23, but when it comes to following the trend, the city has the least number of persons with local transmissions (LT) among the top five districts with highest cases of Covid-19 infection.Analysis of the past four days reveal that the city added six cases to its tally of 18 since March 26. Out of the total, two men had international travel history – a 30-year old returned from UAE whereas another 38-year old returned from the US. Two other men returned after domestic travel – a 70-year-old from Indore and another 34-year-old from Mumbai.Two cases were of local transmission that included a 47-year-old man and a 67-year-old woman. The 47-year-old man succumbed to the infection at Civil Hospital.“In contrast, except Vadodara and Surat – both having local transmission cases consisting of 33% of cases – all districts are now recording a rise in local transmissions. Bhavnagar, that recorded two of the six deaths of the state, has 83% of LT cases whereas in Gandhinagar, the number is 77%,” said a health department official. It’s both a boon and a bane, health officials admitted.

Title: 30 hotels in Nainital to house coronavirus suspects
Content: NAINITAL: As the number of quarantined people continues to rise in Nainital , the district administration on Monday took control of over 30 hotels in Nainital, Bhimtal , and Bhowali towns of the district to use them as quarantine facilities. In a written order, the administration said that these hotels will be developed as quarantine facilities, isolation centres, and shelter homes to house suspected coronavirus patients. "Exercising the powers conferred under the Disaster Management Act 2005, the administration has taken control of some of the hotels in the district and its staff till further orders," read a statement released by the administration.The hotels which have been taken over by the administration include some prominent ones like Shervani Hilltop, Hotel Alka, and Manu Maharani.Local officials told TOI that people who have been quarantined will be marked on their hands and anyone coming to the district from outside will be screened properly before being allowed to enter. "The health officials will continuously monitor the conditions of the quarantined people,” said Nainital’s district magistrate Savin Bansal.

Title: Tiger attack claims fourth victim, a 28-year-old man, in three months
Content:
Pilibhit: A 28-year-old farmer, identified as Krishna Rai of Mala Colony under Gajraula police station, was killed by a tiger that was on the prowl in his field, 300 metres from Mala forest range of Pilibhit tiger reserve, on Monday morning.

This is the fourth death in the tiger attack this year. Earlier, 50-year-old woman Ramoli Sarkar of the same village was killed by a tiger on March 21.

Upon getting information, police rushed to the spot, while no PTR official had visited till 7.15pm.

“The tiger attacked Rai on his neck and trachea, killing him on the spot. We are trying to pacify the agitated villagers,” said Gajraula SHO Jai Veer Singh.

Meanwhile, defying the social distancing norms, villagers thronged the spot in a large number and protested against the “negligence” on the part of the PTR administration in providing them protection from tiger attacks.

Pilibhit sadar tehsildar Vivek Kumar Mishra, who also visited the spot, announced an ex gratia of Rs 4 lakh to the family of the victim.

Title: Railway hospitals face staff crunch amid rush
Content:
Hyderabad: Railway hospitals and health units here are facing staff crunch in the prevailing pandemic situation, that has led to a 21-day nationwide lockdown.

“We are dealing with a huge number of patients everyday. Now that the majority of senior staff is taking care of the patients in mandatory isolation due to Covid-19, there is a lot of pressure on the rest of the staff,” a source told TOI.

Now that the railway hospitals in Mettuguda and Lallaguda will be extending services to central government employees, the staff at thefacilities is expecting heavy rush.“Most of the railway staff including engineers, loco pilots and gatemen are being checked and admitted after returning from work. This has led to a huge division of hospital staff between patients with Covid-19 symptoms and other patients,” he added.

Sources said a number of potential patients with travel histories from different states are being treated regularly. Meanwhile, Indian Railways has notified zonal general managers and production units to gear up to tackle the rush.

Title: Lightning kills 6 farm workers in Yavatmal
Content:
Yavatmal: Six farm workers, including two women, from Kalamb tehsil died on Sunday night after lightning struck the cow shed where they were busy preparing dung cakes. A cow was also killed in the incident.

Resident deputy collector Lalitkumar Warhade of Yavatmal said the six farm workers died at Barad village of Ralegaon tehsil. The incident came to fore when a villager spotted their bodies.

The deceased have been identified as Abhiman Vishvanath Ambadare (60), his wife Mandatai (50), Laxman Bapurao Koyare (50), Subhash Raju Nehare (20), all from village Neemgawhan of Kalamb tehsil, Sahebrao Gulabrao Devnale (45) and his wife Pisabai Devnale (40), both residents of Khodpakhindi village in Kalamb tehsil.

The deceased were engaged by farm owner Ratan Gonde to make cowdung cakes. They were entrusted with cow and other cattle by the owner to graze them in the jungle.

Ralegaon police and tehsildar reached the spot on Monday and sent their bodies for post mortem to Yavatmal GMCH.

Title: Trichy: Delivery boys are working every day to ensure cooking gas at homes
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

TRICHY: Ever since the lockdown , T Alagesh Kumar, 30, has been delivering LPG cylinders to houses by skipping lunch and umindful of the scorching sun. Forgoing his weekly-off, Kumar delivers at least 60 cylinders a day, each weighing around 30kg in various parts of the city.

Kumar, like his fellow LPG cylinder delivery boys starts his day by around 8am. Without public transportation, most delivery personnel who stay on the outskirts have to hitchhike a ride to their workplace. Their uniform helps them gain sympathy from drivers plying with essential commodities to drop them at the required place.

“I have not been taking lunch since Janata Curfew as the demand for LPG cylinders has pushed us to scale up deliveries each day. Once I step out of my house in the morning, I will be back home only at midnight,” Kumar told TOI.

The distance covered by delivery boys has also increased, due to panic booking, as each delivery boy covers at least 80-100km a day against their normal coverage of 40-50km. “There is a marked difference in the reception among our customers anxiously awaiting LPG cylinders during the lockdown. Now, customers value our service and give us tips voluntarily since they are in need of cylinders,” Kumar says.

Though the delivery boys are working all through the week without rest, they said there is a feeling of satisfaction in helping families beat hunger. The lockdown has made people realise the importance of those delivering goods at their doorsteps, from the milkman to delivery boys.

Title: Dehradun hospital staffers donate blood to avoid scarcity during lockdown
Content: DEHRADUN: In a noble gesture, the paramedical staff of Government Doon Medical College and Hospital (GDMCH) donated blood after the administration of the facility urged people to come forward for blood donation in view of the scarcity of blood at the blood bank due to the ongoing lockdown. Interestingly, the staff members who donated blood are contractual workers of the hospital and their service tenure will end on Tuesday (March 31).Govind Prasad, one of the contractual workers at GDMCH told TOI that the hospital administration has suspended the services of 57 contractual workers. “Among the 57 people, services of 31 staffers ended in February while the last working date for others is March 31. We have been told that we won’t be getting any pay after this but we feel it’s our moral duty to help the hospital in the time of crisis. We will continue working, even without pay, until the present pandemic situation passes,” he added.Dr Ashutosh Sayana, principal GDMCH, informed that the blood bank of Doon Hospital is facing a shortage of blood as both voluntary donations and blood donation camps have stopped taking place since Holi. Thereby, the medical college administration has assured to arrange passes for people who would be interested in donating blood.“The major source of blood donation for GDMCH is the camps that are organised by either the hospital itself or private players/NGOs. The hospital needs blood for Thalassemia patients, cesarean deliveries and emergency cases,” said Dr Sayana while adding that people who are interested in donating blood can call on the helpline numbers of the hospital and the administration will get their passes made after which they will not be stopped by the police.Meanwhile, the authorities of Indian Medical Association (IMA) held a meeting with state chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Monday. During the meeting, IMA officials assured the CM that private nursing homes and hospitals will not shut their OPDs so that people get easy access to healthcare services.On the day, the state government also announced to take over 100 beds of state’s two biggest private medical colleges — Shri Guru Ram Rai Institute of Medical & Health Sciences and Himalayan Institute of Medical Sciences.Also, the authorities of All India Institute of Medical Sciences in Rishikesh started Covid-19 tests from Monday. The institute tested 20 samples on Monday and all of them were found negative.

Title: They are our guests, let’s behave like hosts
Content:
Amidst the nationwide lockdown calls of ‘stay home, stay safe’, thousands of homeless casual labourers in Indian cities are among the worst-hit as a result of halted public transport, shuttered shops and uncertainty over the handling of the pandemic that was quickly spreading throughout the country.

Kerala ranked first for having migrant-friendly policies in Interstate Migrant Policy Index 2019 compiled by a Mumbai-based non-profit organization. However, news from Payippad village of Kottayam district, where hundreds of migrants protesting on the street, indicate the lapse in even better functioning systems. Their demand for transportation facilities for their return to native places shows their diffidence in the host society’s efforts of integration and wellbeing. On the other hand, what makes government interventions difficult in such situations is the negligence and non-cooperation of the contractors, who are expected to take care of the welfare and health of the labourers, in officially registering this floating population thus depriving them of their human and labour rights.

To deal with the current situation, the central as well as state governments need to immediately adopt inclusive relief measures to its marginalised communities, including the migrant guest workers. Central government ’s latest directive of closing down of state and district borders will create more panic and insecurity among migrants who are stranded in several Indian cities. To boost their trust and confidence in the host society’s governance mechanisms, on an emergency basis, they should be provided with clean and decent shelters, food, water, medical facilities and other essential supplies. Government facilities like stadiums, colleges and schools can be converted into shelters. Instead of treating them as a burden on the already overstretched system, their safety should be the priority. And, they should be encouraged to stay back wherever they are, taking into consideration the high risk of community spreading of the pandemic.

The central government should also address the welfare of the families of these inter-state migrants back home by announcing targeted relief and medical packages to reassure them that even in their absence their families left behind are taken care of. Provisions for distributing unemployment allowances to these poor and vulnerable workforces in the informal and casual labour sectors for the whole period of the lockdown are crucial. Better coordination of all the relevant ministries and departments, including the labour ministry, health departments as well as state and panchayat raj institutions, has to be ensured in delivering these people-friendly services. Government officials, especially the police, need to act with restraint while dealing with already distressed migrants.

Managing the current situation is not the end of it all. The long-term impact of this pandemic on migrant communities needs to be factored in as next exodus is going to be the return of those who have gone back to their village to the Indian cities in search of work and livelihood options. We, as a community, need to ensure better and safe spaces for these internal migrants when we go back to normalcy.

(The writer teaches migration studies at FLAME University, Pune)

Title: New ready reckoner rates in Maharashtra not before May 31
Content:
PUNE: The Inspector General of Registration and Stamps (IGR) on Monday said the Ready Reckoner rates in Maharashtra would be announced after May 31 because of the Covid-19 outbreak.

This year’s ready reckoner rates were supposed to be announced on April 1. In an order issued on Monday, state IGR Omprakash Deshmukh said the rates would be announced later in accordance with the government’s further instrictions. He added that the existing ready reckoner rates would be applicable in the state till May 31 or the date when the government would issue the instructions.

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat told TOI last week that publication of this year’s ready reckoner (RR) rates had been postponed in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak in the state.

The ready reckoner rates, which are prices of a residential property, land or commercial property for a given area, are published on March 31 every year and implemented from April 1. All calculations related to real estate, such as stamp duty, registration, premiums and tax collection, are based on the ready reckoner rates.

Deshmukh, in his order issued under the Maharashtra Stamp (determination of true market value) Rules, 1995, said it was not possible for the government to publish the rates for 2020-21 in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

“The state government has instructed to continue with the 2019-20 rates till further orders. The government has directed the IGR to continue with the rates till May 31 or further instructions. Necessary orders have been issued to all field officers of the 516 registration offices across the state and they will act accordingly,” the IGR told TOI.

Confederation of Real Estate Developers Associations of India (Credai) representatives have urged the government to not increase the ready reckoner rates on the ground that the Covid-19 lockdown has slowed down the real estate sector that was already passing through a slowdown.

Title: Three cases in Pune’s slums calls for rapid containment measures
Content: PUNE: The detection of three positive cases of Covid-19 from two slum pockets in the city on Sunday sparked concerns of a potential spread within some of the most densely populated zones in Pune.One of the three slum dwellers is a 76-year-old man and a resident of the Laxminagar slum in Yerawada. He has no history of international travel. The other two — a father-daughter duo — are residents of the Meenatai Thackeray slum in Gultekdi. Both had recently returned from a pilgrimage to Dubai.“The 76-year-old patient is undergoing treatment for breathlessness at a private hospital. The 65-year-old man and his 30-year-old daughter are showing minor ailments in the form of cough, sore throat and fever. They are undergoing treatment at Naidu hospital,” said Sanjeev Wavare, the assistant medical officer of health (AMoH), Pune Municipal Corporation.Nearly 30 close contacts of both sets of families have been quarantined at Naidu hospital. “Their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology. Containment measures are underway in both the slum pockets,” Wavare said.The 76-year-old was admitted to a private hospital with cardiac complaints and shortness of breath around 3am on March 28. “His throat swab sample returned as positive from the NIV,” an official from the private hospital said.This official added that the senior citizen had visited another hospital near his home on two occassion: on March 25 and again on March 28.Senior public health expert Subhash Salunkhe, an advisor to the state government on infectious diseases, said stringent cluster containment measures should be set in place through a three- kilometre restriction zone around both slums.“The two cases with travel history to Dubai are reassuring because they picked up the infection outside India. But the case of the 76-year-old, with no travel history, is a matter of concern. Strict cluste r containment measures should be implemented to contain the new virus as it can spread like wildfire within densely populated slums,” Salunke said.Similar containment measures are being suggested by leading expert from across the country. “A spread among the slum population of India will take us very close to the worst-case scenario,” said a doctor from New Delhi who spoke on the condition of anonymity. “In slum areas of many cities, we are still not seeing the level of caution urban households have taken to contain Covid-19. We need to identify hotspots and draw a ring of containment around them.”Social distancing orders as a precautionary measure have also faltered within slum pockets. In a previous interview with TOI, Avinash Sakpal, the deputy commissioner of slum eradication and rehabilitation, highlighted the sheer numbers in these zones. “There are 426 slums in Pune city with 1.40 lakh hutments. Even if we consider that an average of 5 people live in each hut, it means there are about 7 lakh people who live in these slums alone and this is a conservative number as there can be more people living in each of these homes,” he said.

Title: Medicine supply smooth, shops shut over low demand in Pune
Content:
In Baner and NIBM Road areas, some shops were shut

PUNE: Barring some, medical stores across the city have ensured smooth supply of medicines to citizens.

The Chemists’ Association of Pune District has said medicines will be available throughout the lockdown period. The association said the demand is low due to the lockdown hence some medical shops remain open only for few hours.

In Baner and NIBM Road areas, some shops were shut. A security guard at the Baner-based medical shop said the shop did not have stocks and would re-open in three days when they are replenished .

Another chemist in Baner area said they too were out of stocks and did not know about the new stocks.

A representative at Parmar Medicals on Salunke Vihar Road said stocks were available for now. However, some medicines were unavailable and the customers were being told to come back the next day.

He said, “Tablets related to cold, flu, digestive pills were in high demand as according to the representative with the weather changing each day (hot in the day and raining in the afternoon), no one was taking any risks to develop cold and flu.”

Roshni Ajmera from NIBM area said, “Medical shops are closed since this morning. We are depending on the hospital’s pharmacy shops as the local people are complaining about shortage of medicines.”

At Wanowrie circle, Sinhagad Road, Bhusari Colony, Kothrud, Kalyaninagar, Vimannagar and Shivajinagar, a majority of the shops remained open throughout the day.

When contacted, Anil Belkar, secretary of the Chemists’ Association of Pune district, said there were some transport issues initially and the wholesalers could not provide the stock but now it has been sorted.

“There will not be any shortage of medicines and they will be provided abundantly. There is less demand due to the lockdown, clinics are closed and no people are on the roads which has led to decrease in demand. Hence, some pharmacies shut down early after staying open for few hours.”

Title: Cluster containment strategy to be employed in vulnerable districts’
Content:
Ahmedabad:Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health and family welfare), on Monday said that the department had initiated a cluster containment strategy in vulnerable districts.

“We are putting in action the cluster containment strategy, where the district collector or municipal commissioner will oversee its implementation. Areas with a high number of cases will be identified and converted into a containment zone, and these will be isolated with a buffer zone,” said Ravi. “Movement in containment zones will not be allowed. We have sought police help to implement this.”

Gujarat on Monday saw seven new Covid-19 cases – five from Bhavnagar and one each from Ahmedabad and Surat. These included the death of a 45-year-old woman from Jesar in Bhavnagar district. Ravi said that the death follows the co-morbidity pattern as the woman had suffered a stroke a fortnight ago.

Ravi told mediapersons that for the patients under quarantine, the state government has launched a helpline on 1100, which could be accessed for both physical and mental well-being. “The helpline will operate from the EMRI campus in Kathwada and will have a panel of specialists who will provide support to those under quarantine,” she said.

Title: Gujarat: Daily capacity of 700, but only 125 tests done
Content:
So far, the state has conducted only 1,300-odd Covid-19 tests, of which 70 have been found to be positive

GANDHINAGAR: The state government has decided to increase testing for coronavirus and also enhance testing capacity. While the state government claims it has surveyed 3.98 crore persons, only around 125 Covid-19 tests are being conducted on a daily basis, which experts believe, is very less.

A key government source said that the six government colleges in the state where coronavirus tests are being done, have a combined capacity of 700 tests per day. “ In case the spread of the pandemic increases in the state, more testing facilities will be required. The state government is awaiting central government’s direction to add testing capacity.’’

Citing the instance of the Gomtipur coronavirus victim, the source said that the test was done very late. “Similar instances have been observed in Bhavnagar and other places as well, where patients have been tested at a very advanced stage. It is imperative to increase testing to a great extent,” the source said.

Since March 1, about 27,000 persons have returned to the state from various countries and many more From other states. So far, the state has conducted only 1,300-odd Covid-19 tests, of which 70 have been found to be positive.

Title: Second from Rander tests positive, area will be sanitized
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

SURAT: The Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has mounted a Herculean effort to disinfect the entire Rander area after a 67-year-old man tested positive for COVID-19, the second case from the same area.

The patient has no travel history and SMC fears that he may have come in contact with many people in and around Rander. The civic body has shifted 30 people who were in touch with him to government quarantine facility.

Municipal Commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani said that this would be biggest quarantine activity till date as the case of if local transmission. Rander has a population of nearly two lakh. "Since we do not know how this person got infected, we need to isolate maximum number of people. Moreover, we have decided to carry out disinfectant activity in entire Rander area,'' Pani said.

SMC officials suspect that the before testing positive for COVID-19 may have attended religious or social gatherings and there may be many more carries of this deadly virus. "This 67-year-old male owns a laundry shop in Rander. He has been residing within the 500 m radius of the locality from where the 32-year-old had tested positive on March 21. More worryingly, this laundry man was personally visiting his customers for delivering clothes,'' said an SMC official.

Deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), Dr Ashish Naik said, “The second case from same area indicates the spread of local transmission. About four close contacts from his family have been shifted to the government quarantine facility.” According to Dr Naik, the male had visited a private clinic in Rander for treatment of fever and cold. However, the health teams are camping in the Rander town to find out other people including doctors with whom the COVID-19 positive patients had established contact in the last 15 days.

Meanwhile, about 11 new suspected cases of COVID-19 were reported from various parts of the city on Monday. Barring, a 78-year-old male from Ghod Dod Road having travel history to UAE on March 18, none others have travelled out of the city. Also, a 23-year-old woman from Rudarpura having travel history to the US, who was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil Hospital (NCH) on Sunday, has tested negative for COVID-19.

Title: Five including 2 minors arrested in Tankara couple’s murder case
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

RAJKOT: Five persons including two minors were arrested on Monday for allegedly bludgeoning a couple to death in Otada village of Tankara taluka in Morbi district on early Sunday morning. Police said the accused, identified as Vesati Mavi, her husband Patadia Mavi, their two minor sons and Prakash Adivasi had killed Dashrath Vasava (27) and his wife Kari Vasava (25). The couple’s bodies were found from near the farm owned by Dilip Patel. The bodies bore severe injury marks on the heads. The complaint in this regard was lodged by Patel. “Patel alleged that one of the sons of the Mavi couple had an illicit relationship with Kari, due to which Kari and Vesati would fight frequently. Nursing a grudge against Kari, Vesati and the co-accused had allegedly attacked Kari and Dashrath," said L P Bagada, sub-inspector with Tankara police station.

Title: Roads to two Gultekdi slums shut after man, daughter test positive for Covid-19
Content:
A barricade placed in the middle of the road leading to Meenatai Thackeray and Dias Plot slums in Gultekdi

PUNE: The Swargate police on Monday closed the roads leading to Meenatai Thackeray and Dias Plot slums in Gultekdi after a 65-year-old man and his daughter (30) from the area tested positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) on Sunday.

Senior inspector Bramhanand Naikawdi of the Swargate police said, “The father-daughter duo had returned from Dubai on March 9. After they tested positive for Covid-19, they were shifted to Naidu hospital. The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) health officials will conduct medical check-up of people in the slums with whom they came in close contact to prevent the spread of coronavirus.”

He said, “The slums were fumigated as a preventive measure. We have barricaded the slums and closed the roads between Giridhar Bhavan and City International School near Panchami hotel to dissuade the slum dwellers from coming out to roads. All Market Yard-bound goods vehicles will have to ply on alternative routes via Jedhe Chowk, Seven Loves Chowk, Golibar Maidan Chowk or Lullanagar Chowk.”

The city police have also barricaded all entry and exit points within 2km radius of Shri Chhatrapati Shivaji Gultekdi Market Yard for decongesting the wholesale market premises.

Deputy commissioner of police (zone V) Suhas Bawache said, “We have taken a slew of measures for streamlining the movement of vehicles in and around the Gultekdi market yard to maintain the social distancing norm. On an average, around 500 farmers unload produce in the wholesale market, while about 1,500 traders load the goods in their vehicles for taking them to retail markets. We have allowed vehicles to enter through gate number 4 from Bibvewadi Road and exit through gate number 1 outside the Market Yard police station.”

The police and officials from various government departments like the Agriculture Market Produce Committee have prepared a plan” for streamlining the functioning of the market.

Bawache said, “On an average, between 25,000 and 30,000 people visit the city’s main market yard every day. We have barricaded all entry and exit points, including gates of housing societies, and installed a three-tier barricading system. We have issued passes to farmers, agents, businessmen and workers involved in goods loading and unloading.”

He said, “We have given a time slot for entry and exit to all vehicles and allowing entry to only 500 big vehicles at a time. One-hour time has been given to them to complete loading and unloading. Smaller vehicles like tempos will get 15 minutes each for the purpose. Vehicles waiting at designated spots will be released in phases.”

Bawache said, “Farmers can now supply their produce alternatively — for instance, vegetables on Sundays, and onion, potatoes and fruits on Mondays. The grocery market will remain open throughout the week because the sale of vegetables and fruits by small-time vendors outside the market has been stopped.”

He said, “Markets in Mumbai, Navi Mumbai, Kolhapur and Nagpur have been closed down and shifted to open places because of overcrowding. We have been fairly successful in decongesting the Gultekdi Market Yard through these measures,” he said.

Title: Cops champion social distancing, innovate to enforce Sec 144
Content:
CORONA VIRUS AND POLICE CURFEW :Jaripatka Police team stop the people and inquiry during Corona-virus LOCKDOWN... Read More

Nagpur: City and district police are zealously promoting social distancing , and also adopting innovative measures to enforce, without the lathi, the national lockdown to break coronavirus chain. Cops are also now monitoring the bandobast through drone camera systems to keep a vigil on lanes and internal roads.

Commissioner of police BK Upadhyay has extended the validity of police passes issued to citizens to provide essential services from March 31 to April 14.

Koradi police on Monday, under Senior PI Vazeer Shaikh, took action against 40 violators in an innovative way as state government has asked cops to adopt ‘humane approach’. Maintaining the norms of social distancing, Shaikh set up a makeshift detention camp at his police station, and also at Mahadula, where he drew circles at safe distances to make detainees sit in separately. “They had to sit in the sun until we completed the formalities,” he said.

In another example, Zonal DCP Vinita Sahu and Sadar police intercepted three youngsters on a bike riding without helmet at Japanese Garden Square. Apart from penalizing them for violations of Motor Vehicle Act, the three were also made to stand apart following social distancing norms, and their video was made admitting to having breached traffic rules and also section 144 .

City police, under supervision of CP Upadhyay, have pulled up 1,877 violators, including 126 who were detained, for breaching section 144. Around 1,734 traffic violators were also penalized.

Following warning from the top brass, city police have also detained 80 vehicles, including 72 bikes, for violating the ‘stay at home’ policy of the lockdown.

In the four districts, IG Nagpur range KMM Prasanna enforced social distancing norms stringently at three levels apart from preventing breach of section 144. “The personnel have been made aware of the importance of social distancing through educative video,” he said.

“We have ensured social distancing norms are followed at police stations, while checking at nakabandis and also while dealing with the masses. Cops have been told to maintain utmost hygiene and follow safety measures like frequent use of sanitizers, and also wear mask and change it every day,” he said.

“The cops on the roads are also told to avoid communication from close quarters,” said the IG. He said even the ‘lathis’ or sticks are sanitized frequently while they are being used.

On a large scale, Prasanna cited the example of Wardha police, who have shifting a popular market to a ground to maintain social distancing norms. “We have ensured people can still go to a place to buy vegetables but due to the available space they would be spread out,” he said.

Prasanna also informed that police in the districts of Wardha, Bhandara, Chandrapur and Nagpur Rural are following the three basic policies to keep people off the roads. “We are just stopping, convincing and sending people back from nakabandis, and when necessary taking legal actions,” he said.

Citing the example from Chandrapur, Prasanna said two trucks carrying around 50 people from Telangana to Madhya Pradesh were intercepted. “We immediately seized the two trucks and shifted the migrant labourers to safe shelters,” he said. The IG also said that basic needs of the people are also being taken care of.

IG Prasanna also said maximum use is being made of public address system to announce social distancing and also norms for section 144.

Title: Civic activists demand ‘mass sanitization’ drives be controlled
Content:
PUNE: Civic activists want the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s ‘mass sanitization’ drive in the wake of the novel coronavirus spread to be carried out in a controlled manner.

“The government has issued guidelines about mass sanitation, which are being violated in the city. Such misuse of taxpayers’ money should be stopped,” Vivek Velankar, the founder of the Sajag Nagrik Manch, said.

The group has written to the civic administration regarding the same.

“The mass spraying may lead to a false impression about safety among residents of those areas. It will cause more harm than good. Spraying of disinfectants should be done judiciously,” Velankar said.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) officials claimed that corporators from all political parties were demanding that the spraying be carried out in their respective wards. The civic officials stressed most of these areas did not need it as no positive case was reported there.

“We are getting consistent demands from elected members to spray disinfectants in their areas. It is exerting pressure on the limited manpower and resources that PMC has. We find it tough to fulfil the demands of all corporators,” a senior PMC official said, adding that the civic body was using sodium hypochlorite to spray areas that have reported positive cases.

Another PMC official said only 200 people were deployed for sanitizing areas. The civic body has completed fogging areas such as Bavdhan, Kothrud, Peth areas, some parts of Ahmednagar Road, Satara Road and Sinhagad Road.

“Directives have been given to the departments concerned. They have to spray disinfectants only in those areas where positive patients are found,” said PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad .

Title: ‘Police have caught me bro...’, a lockdown message for violators
Content: KOCHI: “Police caught me bro, if you go out unnecessarily, they will catch you too!”A youth can be heard saying in a video that went viral on social media after policemen in Thrikkakara made him call 25 people on his call list to make them aware about the importance of lockdown.The youth, who was roaming around in a street violating the lockdown, was intercepted by police. They were ‘generous’ enough to make him an offer that he could not refuse, call up 25 people and tell them not to come out of their houses unnecessarily and they will let him go home.The incident happened at Kangarappady late on Sunday. The video that went viral shows a group of policemen on duty at Kangarappady in Thrikkkara police station limits suggesting the unconventional punishment to a youth who was out on the streets violating lockdown.According to Thrikkakara police, the video was shot by a personnel on duty at Kangarapady on Sunday night.“People are more or less cooperating with us now. Even if somebody is out, we at first reason with them and most listen to us and return home. On Sunday night, this youth turned up and the personnel on duty made him call his friends, so as to discourage them from going out. It was an impromptu decision by them,” said a senior officer with Thrikkakara police.In the video, one of his friends could be heard laughing and challenging that he would also break the lockdown. However, the cops intervened and said they have got his display picture and would be waiting for him if he did.When the youth told the same to another friend, she broke into laughter and said he deserved it. Police then told the receiver to stop laughing and make the caller understand the situation. The policemen also made him tell his mother that he would be home in a while. They youth was later sent home, police said.

Title: 1-yr diploma in infection control
Content:
Hyderabad: The University of Hyderabad launched a one year post-graduation diploma in infection prevention and control (PGDIPC) distance learning programme on Monday. The programme was launched through the Centre for Distance and Virtual Learning (CDVL).

According to a press release issued by the university, this is a collaborative programme by the School of Medical Sciences, University of Hyderabad and Infection Control Academy of India (IFCAI), Hyderabad. The programme is aimed at building and enhancing the capacity to address prevention and control of healthcare associated infections (HAI). TNN

Title: Gomtipur death: 45 families isolated; 300 homes under scrutiny
Content:
Since Sunday morning the focus of disinfection operations, which is spraying sodium hypochlorite solution with... Read More

AHMEDABAD: After a scrap dealer from a Gomtipur chawl died on Sunday because of Covid-19, a major challenge stares at health authorities in Ahmedabad now: Managing the disease in the crowded slums and chawls of the city.

“It is here that Covid-19 may reach disastrous proportions if we don’t get the community’s help and maintain strict vigil,” explains a senior municipal official. Right now some 45 families of Gajanand ni Chali are under home quarantine, a concept foreign to the people here. Some 300 homes around the scrapdealer’s home will be under scrutiny.

Municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra claimed that since Sunday morning the focus of disinfection operations, which is spraying sodium hypochlorite solution within homes and passages has been on in dense habitations.

“All of the 48 wards have begun disinfection operations,” says Nehra.

Gomtipur councillor Iqbal Shaikh is equally worried. “There are 14 major slums in Gomtipur and tremendous preparations and awareness drives will be required. Slums are a different ballgame to bungalows and apartments.”

A Patel society and a Jain Derasar society are the two middle-class localities around the Covid-19 epicentre here, said officials of the civic body.

A senior AMC official in the estate department told TOI that some major chawls under the lens are Balabhai Jagan Chali, Phoolwadi, Tek Bahadur Society, Ganji Farak Mill EWS Housing Cluster, Badia Kaka ni Chali, Chand Sahib Baba ki Dargah, dwellings along Usha Talkies Road and Swaminarayan School and Noorbhai Dhobi ni Chali.

“People here are mostly daily wagers and are now scared. They are also being told that FIRs will be registered against them if they violate quarantine norms. I feel, though it is late, some awareness activities is a must. Providing packets and ration kits on time will only help in building confidence,” says Shaikh.

Title: Stamp duty relief will boost real estate, say PMC officials
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) officials feel that the 1% reduction in stamp duty for property registration offered by the state government will boost the real estate market with buyers coming forward to avail of the benefit.

The stamp duty concession will be offered for all sale and transfer of properties in PMC and Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) areas. The discount announced in the state budget will be given for the next two years and come into force from April 1, 2020.

According to PMC officials, around 4,500 building permissions are given on an average in the municipal limits every year. “This is a welcome step for the construction industry in the city. Currently, there is a lull in the property market. The concession will help change things for the better. It will encourage people to buy properties,” city engineer Prashant Waghmare told TOI.

According to the PMC data, the revenue generated from building permissions in the last fiscal was Rs650 crore. This year, the PMC has collected Rs750crore from permission, premium fees and development charges.

Title: Police book 20 morning walkers across city
Content:
Nashik: Police on Monday cracked the whip on morning walkers in different parts of the city and booked 20 people.

The morning walkers have been booked under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). “We are continuously taking action against people flouting the instructions issued after the Epidemic Prevention Act was implemented in the city and district,” a police officer said.

“From March 19 to Sunday, we have issued 1,102 notices, 658 people have been booked under section 188 and 168 vehicles have been seized,” he added.

The officer said that they were coming down heavily on erring citizens as a good section of society does not understand the seriousness of the current scenario. “Despite repeated appeals, many of them are coming out of their houses unnecessarily, going on morning walks and moving in their vehicles in different parts of the city,” he said.

“On Monday, Gangapur police took action against 15 morning walkers, while Deolali camp and Upnagar police took action against three and two people, respectively,” he added.

So far, under section 188 of the IPC, Adgaon police took action against 26 people, Mhasrool police took action against 35, Pancahvati (43), Bhadrakali (72), Sarkarwada (38), Gangapur (92), Mumbai Naka (47), Ambad (46), Indiranagar (35), Satpur (62), Upnagar (73), Nashik Road (46) and Deolali Camp (43).

In terms of vehicle seizure, Nashik Road police tops the chart with 35, followed by Indiranagar (32), Ambad (21), Deolali (20), Mhasrool and Upnagar (15 each), Satpur (13), Sarkarwada (7), Bhadrakali (4), Panchavati (3), Gangapur (2) and Mumbai Naka (1).

Title: AI to operate 9 charters to fly back Germans
Content:
NEW DELHI: Germany has mounted a massive exercise to fly out its citizens from India.

Air India will from Tuesday operate nine charter flights from cities like Delhi, Mumbai and Chennai to Frankfurt on its wide-body aircraft to fly Germans back home over next few days. These aircraft will fly back from Germany to India as ferry flights (with no passengers). Last week, Lufthansa had operated two special flights from Delhi — double-decker 500-seater Airbus A380s — to fly Germans back home.

Four flights from Mumbai and one from Delhi will depart on Tuesday. Prior to these international charter flights, Air India will be flying the stranded foreigners from cities like Goa, Trivandrum, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Kolkata to hub Mumbai and Delhi.

Air India has operated a large number of special flights to fly back Indians stranded in corona hotspots like China, Japan and Europe. Thousands have flown back home on these flights.

There is huge demand for similar charters by AI from other countries too, like the US, UK and Canada, to fly back their citizens from India. "The situation is very fluid. Discussions are on but as of now no decision has been taken," sources said.

German ambassador to India Walter J Lindner tweeted on Monday: "After flying 1,000 stranded travellers from Delhi to Frankfurt last week, we are working closely with Indian authorities (especially the ministry of external affairs) to bring home many more. Challenges amidst lockdown not small, but we’re working on it 24/7… We continue to do everything humanly possible to bring the stranded travellers still remaining in India back to Germany."

The US embassy tweeted on Sunday: "We anticipate several flights departing from New Delhi and Mumbai returning to the United States this week… it is likely (these) flights will have stricter than usual limits on the weight of luggage as well as be unable to accommodate pets." US citizens stranded in India would need to fill out a form put up online by the US embassy and enrol in their "Smart Traveler Enrolment Program"’ for critical information about flight opportunities.

Other countries are also keen to operate special flights to fly back their citizens from India. Canada, for instance, wanted to fly out its citizens from India. But for now AI can operate only quick turnaround flights on which the entire operating crew returns on the flight back. Sources said Canada was informed that the possibility of flying its citizens from India to somewhere in Europe, from where it could make arrangements to fly them home, could be discussed. AI has operated special flights to China, Europe and Israel by taking two sets of crew so that one set operates on the way out and the other while flying back home.

At this point, when schedule commercial flights to India are suspended till April 15, AI wants to have its crew back on the same flight to avoid stranding them in foreign lands. "We have to be fully ready with our fleeting personnel to operate special flights to fly out foreigners or fly back Indians from across the world whenever the government asks us to do so. So no chance is being taken," said a source.

Title: BMC’s community kitchen ensures no one goes hungry
Content:
Bhopal: To ensure no one starves amid lockdown, BMC’s community kitchen has come to aid of hundreds of people, here in Bhopal. More than 5,000 people have benefited from the move, said a BMC official.

“I have not been served by the tiffin service since the lockdown. We have been cooking plain rice and to make through the day. The BMC kitchen service is an novel idea for students like us,” said Avinash, a third year engineering student from Nagpur. He along with his roommates stayed back and could not travel after the lockdown was imposed.

“Community kitchens is for everyone in need,” said a BMC public relations officer, Prem Shankar Shukla. Currently two such facilities are being run. BMC plans to expand this service too.

BMC has also sought information from food delivery services, who would be able to deliver food to groups on demand. A central point for dropping the food in various locations has also been demarcated.

There are about five lakh students in Bhopal, about 5% of them stay on rent. With closure of restaurants these students are it tough to cook and get healthy meals.

Title: Medicos seek safety gear, call for ‘silent boycott’ from today
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana Junior Doctors’ Association (TJUDA) has given a representation to the authorities seeking supply of personal protection equipment (PPE). They also called for a ‘silent boycott’ of duty from March 31, at Niloufer Hospital.

TJUDA took the decision after a three-year-old boy had tested positive with resident doctors exposed to him while attending to him. “We don’t want to end up as Covid-19 carriers. If we are provided PPE, we will be able to attend our duties without any worries,” Mahesh, spokesperson of TJUDA, told TOI.

Members of TJUDA said the authorities should understand that a doctor can act as a carrier of novel coronavirus and spread it to hundreds of patients as happened in Bhilwara, Rajasthan.

Dr Srinivas of resident doctors’ association said they had submitted a representation to health minister Eatala Rajender. “So far, no safety gears have been provided to us,” he added.

Title: Gujarat: 1.59 lakh passes issued for essentials supply
Content:
State PSUs donate to CM relief fund

GANDHINAGAR: The state government on Monday said it has made unprecedented arrangements for smooth supply of essential commodities during the lockdown. Moreover, about 9 lakh food packets have been distributed to people across the state so far.Speaking to the media on Monday, Ashwani Kumar, the secretary to the CM, said that in coordination with NGOs, the district level local governing bodies have ensured the supply of two meals a day to senior citizens living in isolation. The homeless the poor, and labourers too have received food packets. And 2.70 lakh packets were distributed to needy individuals and families on Monday.The official further said that to ensure uninterrupted supply of essential commodities, local governing bodies have issued 1.59 lakh passes to vendors, small traders, and workers in the supply chain of essential services.Providing information about the distribution and procurement of essential commodities and day-to-day needs of the citizens, Kumar said that on Monday, 44.82 lakh litres of milk was distributed. Similarly, 1.07 lakh quintals of vegetables, which included 21,895 quintals of potatoes, 25,472 quintals of onions, 10,678 quintals of tomatoes, and 49,176 quintals of other green vegetables arrived in the state, he said. In addition, 15,436 quintals of fruits arrived in state on Monday.Emergency helpline 1070 at state level and 1077 at district level has been started to ensure uninterrupted mecal and essentials supply.Responding to a call by CM Vijay Rupani to donate in the CM’s Relief Fund to fight Covid-19, Rs 27 crore has been donated so far by individuals, religious institutions, and NGOs. Ashwani Kumar said on Monday that state PSU GSPC donated Rs 52.5 crore while the Gujarat Maritime Board donated Rs 25 crore

Title: Bail plea of accused in extortion case rejected
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Additional sessions judge V K Yavalkar on Monday rejected the bail application of Sandesh Wadekar (33), one of the five accused arrested in the case of an alleged Rs50 crore extortion bid on a city-based jeweller, earlier this month.

The city police’s anti-extortion cell arrested the five persons between March 10 and 21 on the charges of extortion and criminal intimidation by using a firearm, after threatening the jeweller that they would make a video clip of his family member viral on social media.

Four of the accused including Wadekar are lodged in the Yerawada jail, while the fifth — former NCP functionary Mangaldas Bandal — is in police custody remand till April 1. On March 26, additional sessions judge AV Rotte had rejected co-accused Rupesh Chaudhari ’s bail plea . The police had recovered a pen camera device, video clip and memory card from Wadekar’s house. Wadekar had worked as the jeweller’s driver.

Yavalkar in his order said, “It is seen from police papers that although role of the present applicant-accused (Wadekar) is not evident from FIR, there is recovery of pen camera used in the commission of the offence for preparing video, from the applicant accused. Therefore, the present applicant-accused appears to be prima facie involved in the commission of offence along with other co-accused.”

The judge said, “Considering the nature and gravity of the offence and stage of investigation, I am not inclined to released the accused on bail.”

Title: Nashik police intercept 750 migrants
Content:
Nashik: More than 750 people, travelling towards Nashik from the Mumbai-side, were stopped by the city police near Vilholi between Sunday evening and Monday morning.

Vijay Kharat, the Zone II DCP, said all these people were handed over the district administration. With the help of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC), shelters have been arranged for them at several places across the city. They will be provided with food, medical help and other essentials.

Kharat said the police also took action against six truck and tempo drivers for carrying people into Nashik from Mumbai.

The city police have had to put up a nakabandi point near Vilholi to keep a check on people who are trying to flout the lockdown rules to get to their home-towns and villages by whatever means available. Between Sunday evening and Monday morning, the police found 750 such people — either discreetly travelling by transport vehicles (like trucks and containers) or walking from Mumbai.

Senior police officers said that since the home-bound migrant workers would only be increasing the chances of the coronavirus spread, they have set up a checkpoint at Vilholi.

Title: Ahmedabad: Isolation rooms booked in 3 hotels
Content:
Hotel Grand Mercure

AHMEDABAD: Federation of Hotels and Restaurants’ Association (FHRA) has confirmed that while there is no official notification from the state health department to keep rooms reserved, if needed, the state government has partially or fully taken over some hotels to set up quarantines.

Industry sources confirmed that Hotel Grand Mercure in the GIFT City Campus along with Gujarat Sports Club have already provided their rooms.

“These are unprecedented circumstances and hotels will comply, if needed, and provide rooms for quarantine facilities. Most hotels are currently vacant because of the lockdown and travel restrictions,” said Narendra Somani, president, FHRA, Gujarat.

“At least 25 rooms from 100+ rooms at our hotel have been provided on request to the state health authorities for setting up a quarantine facility,” said an Ahmedabad-based hotelier, on condition of anonymity. A senior AMC official told TOI that three hotels have agreed to reserve rooms. “People who want to go into quarantine and pay for the services can also opt for such rooms,” the AMC official said.

Title: Cong sets up control room
Content:
Hyderabad: Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee (TPCC) president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy on Monday said that a control room has been set up at Gandhi Bhavan to help people in case of an emergency amid the lockdown. He said that people needing help can dial 040-24601254. The control room will function from 8 am to 8 pm daily during the lockdown period.

Uttam appealed to the Congress workers in the state to help those affected due to lockdown. tnn

Title: Maharashtra: Control rooms set up in each district for hassle-free supply
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The state agriculture department has set up control rooms in each district to monitor the movement of vegetables during the ongoing national lockdown.

The control rooms will ensure that farmers are able to transport and sell their produce without any hassle and supply the commodities as per the demands of the bigger markets.

Over 35 control rooms have been established across the state and most of these units have already started functioning and are monitoring the supply of vegetables and their transport, the department said.

The control rooms’ staff have been told to work in coordination with the respective district administration and Agriculture Produce Market Committees (APMC). The farmers are told to get in touch with control rooms in case of disruptions, an official from the department said. The state government had already clarified that transport and sale of vegetables and fruits is allowed during the ongoing restrictions.

A senior official said farmers faced many problems in the initial days of lockdown while transporting their produce. The sudden cut-off also hampered the supply of commodities in bigger cities. The staff at the control rooms has now started collecting the details of farmers’ groups in their respective districts. These groups will get all the required assistance such as valid passes for transportation of goods, permits and NOCs in supplying commodities to district headquarters without any interruptions.

Title: Techies set up online covid clinic
Content:
Hyderabad: Software professionals industry body Telangana Information Technology Association (TITA) has decided to launch Digithon Covid-19 Online Clinic. Through this platform, it will offer medical assistance to people.

TITA founder and global president Sundeep Kumar Makthala, said, “We have seen how Indians stranded in Italy and France are struggling to get medical attention. We started this platform that allows them to get in touch with doctors .” The initiative, launched on Sunday is free, and doctors are contributing extra time towards the effort. Among those who were helped were Akhil, a student stuck in Italy. TITA also reached out to people in rural areas such as Nandimalla Cross village in Makthal. TNN

Title: 859 homeless persons shifted to shelter homes in Pune
Content:
Migrant workers sheltered

PUNE: The city police have shifted 859 homeless persons/ beggars to 16 shelter homes in the last two days to contain the spread of Covid-19."They were finding it difficult to live on the streets in the absence of alms and with all the eateries closed. Moreover, there is a possibility of the homeless persons being infected by coronavirus since they are mostly unprotected and do not have any support system. Thus, we felt it necessary to shift them," said additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde.The Pune Municipal Corporation had converted some of its schools, empty buildings, community halls, and empty parking lots into shelter homes.Shinde told TOI that the civic body has provided mattresses and cushions at these shelter homes. Food would be provided to those shelted here, said officials.The homeless persons/ beggars were picked up from areas near Sassoon hospital, Shivajinagar railway stations, the riverbed areas of Deccan and Yerawada, footpaths of Laxmi road, Raviwar Peth, Swargate and other parts of the city, Shinde said."Yet there many who are still on the road," he said.Shinde said that there were many families, including children, staying on the road or under flyover bridges."Many people had ventured out on the streets on their scooters and cars to feed the homeless in the last few days. They did not maintain norms of social distancing. With this move, at least they will not step out on the road," a senior police officer said.The police and PMC officials counselled the homeless persons before moving them to shelter homes. However, many of them resisted the move and refused to shift. They said someone else will encroach on their space. The police assured them that no one would occupy their space and then forced them into police vans, a senior police officer said.Shinde said that remaining persons would be shifted to the shelter homes soon.He said the PMC would create more such facilities, if required.The Pune city police officials on Monday shifted 343 migrant workers to different shelter homes in the city.These workers were walking to their native places in Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh and other parts of the state, said police commissioner K Venkatesham.The workers decided to stay back in the city following an intervention by the police.

Title: Telangana will have paddy and rice policy, says CM KCR
Content:
K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Telangana will soon have a comprehensive paddy and rice policy in view of increase in the staple’s yield in the state.

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on Monday held a review meeting at Pragati Bhavan on paddy cultivation, yield, rice, exports and related issues and directed officials to formulate the policy after consulting rice millers and other stake-holders.

“There are 2,200 rice mills across the state and each unit can mill one crore tonnes of rice per year. In the past, these mills could not get paddy to their capacity. Even to mill 20 to 30 lakh tonnes used to be a difficult task. Now, the situation has changed, paddy supply is in abundance,” the CM said during the meeting. While assuring all help to millers, he said there was a need to have more mills in the state.

On the rise in paddy production in the state, he said: “The situation that prevailed in the united AP and now is completely different. Kaleswaram, completion of the on-going projects, revival of tanks under Mission Kakatiya and 24-hour free power, farmers are getting water in abundance, which is resulting in paddy cultivation in the state. Paddy is being cultivated in 40 lakh acres in this rabi season. There is a possibility of getting over a crore tonnes of paddy.”

“In the kharif season, paddy cultivation is likely to touch 55 to 60 lakh acres. Under the Kaleswaram project alone, paddy can be cultivated in over 35 lakh acres. Paddy will be cultivated in at least 70 lakh acres next year. Telangana is becoming the rice bowl of India. Under these circumstances, procuring paddy, sending it to mills and selling the rice will become a tough task. For this, there is a need to implement a comprehensive paddy and rice policy,” KCR said.

The CM also assured millers that there will not be any harassment from officials. Rice millers must have a proper marketing strategy, he added.

Title: Migrants’ march halts long before home is in sight
Content:
PUNE/NASHIK/NAGPUR: A sea of migrants stuck without food and money has little hope of making it home as state governments close borders.

Thousands trudging back to small villages from UP to Tamil Nadu have almost lost hope.

Bhura Jatav and five of his friends, all 19- and 20-year-olds, have walked and hitch hiked on their 1,600km journey from Visakhapatnam to Karauli in Rajasthan, reaching Nagpur on Monday in three days.

“On the Maharashtra-Telangana border, the police allowed our truck to go but we were offloaded. We reached Chandrapur in another vehicle,” he said.

At the Khawasa checkpoint on the Nagpur-Jabalpur highway, nearly 1,000 people were refused entry by Madhya Pradesh.

In Chandrapur, guardian minister Vijay Wadettiwar defended his decision to turn away at least 9,000 people stranded on the Andhra Pradesh and Telangana borders.

“We don’t have a single case of coronavirus. We don’t want to risk the population. My stand is harsh but I need to do it,” Wadettiwar told TOI.

Across the MP border, farmers from Amravati who went to sell oranges pleaded on social media to be rescued as they were starving.

In Pune, those placed in shelter camps by the state government are walking out. In Shirur, 25 masons from Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan had nothing to eat on Monday.

“We are struck with no work and no money. The administration gave us food for two days.” Ramlal Singh from Madhya Pradesh told TOI.

Premshankar Singh from Uttar Pradesh and 50 other migrant workers moved out of Pune but were stopped by the police. “We have little money and no rations and there are families to feed,” he said.

Another group from Nagapattinam was camping in Daund taluka while another 45 people from Cuddalore were in Baramati.

At the shelters, social distancing has fallen by the wayside and cramped accommodation has sent them out of the camps. “With lakhs of such migrants told to stay back, it is very difficult to monitor them and ensure supply of rations,” a district adminstration official told TOI.

Pune divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar said they had provided 214 shelter homes for over 64,926 people. He has assured ration and food for them.

“Each of the six divisional commissioners was making arrangements. More than a lakh are expected. Nearly 50,000 labourers have been given food in Pune, Navi Mumbai, Mumbai, Nagpur and Thane,” said the official. They are from West Bengal, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh.

Despite assurances, many migrants are desperate to go home. A night patrol in Pune stopped 45 people, including 14 children, on their way to Karnataka in a tractor trolley on Sunday. In Nashik, more than 750 people, travelling towards Nashik from Mumbai, were stopped near Vilholi between Sunday and Monday.

Rural areas can turn unmanageable if the government does not act now, said former Shirur MP Shivaji Adhalrao Patil. As many as 30,000 to 50,000 people in Junnar, who came back, are not following the 14-day quarantine, he said. The stamping has discontinued and the monitoring mechanism has buckled, he added.

Another 15,000 have returned from Pune and Mumbai to the talukas in Pune. “They should be in home quarantine, but there is no monitoring and people are moving out freely,” Patil said.

Title: Min: Let poultry vehicles move
Content: Hyderabad: Animal husbandry minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav on Monday directed government officials and cops to allow transportation of sheep, goat, birds (poultry) and fish in the state, particularly those vehicles bringing them to Hyderabad for sale. At a review meeting to discuss prices of mutton, chicken and eggs being jacked up on the pretext of shortage amid lockdown, he said: CM has said people must not be inconvenienced and that all essentials must be made available to them.” TNN

Title: People breaching norms adding to woes of cops on roads
Content:
Nagpur: Police personnel deployed on roads have expressed deep anguish over the state government’s decision to deal with people with a ‘humane approach’. Cops said people repeatedly breach norms of the nationwide lockdown imposed under section 144 in the backdrop of coronavirus scare.

Even state home minister Anil Deshmukh ’s demand before Prime minister Narendra Modi to extend Rs50 lakh insurance cover to police could not bring cheers to the cops at the ground level. Devoid of any prescribed protective gear like N95 masks, cops are checking citizens on the road for around 12 hours, which is another one of their grievances.

A constable, on the condition of anonymity, said the public has already received the message that police will only convince them due to which they not afraid to break norms. “People are misleading cops at checkpoints with various excuses and pointing at the exempted essential services to come on the roads for trivial reasons,” he said.

“We can easliy catch their lies but cannot pull them up heavily. It is taking a toll on our mental health dealing with public for 12 hours as most of them are in no mood to cooperate,” he said, adding that the government has also exposed them to the threat of infection by not providing them proper masks and gloves.

“People are also misusing the passes for moving around and stepping out multiple times instead of sticking to just fetching essential goods,” said another cop. “Some of the pass holders are sharing it with others making it difficult to decongest the road. We have stopped and seized the passes and also told our seniors about the misuse,” he said.

A head constable, posted in north Nagpur, said some of the citizens are using old medical records and papers to step out of homes. “Two persons are stepping out at the same time to purchase grocery or medicines for the same family. We are requesting them to divide the work but still people are moving around on bikes and cars,” said the cop.

Another senior cop said, “Some people are threatening to lodge complaint against us with senior authorities even when we merely point our sticks to them to say or gesture something. People are making baseless allegations against us. We are facing mental harassment from the public,” he said.

Title: Ghats wear funereal look as Covid scare cuts short last rites
Content: Nagpur: Measures to curb coronavirus have struck everyone hard. Not only Chaitra Navratri and forthcoming Ram Navami and Easter celebrations have been affected, even traditional rituals to honour the dead and comfort the bereaved have been cut short or abandoned for fear of spreading the disease.TOI on Monday visited some crematoria across the city and found this. A body was brought to Mankapur ghat with only 10 persons in the attendance. Mourners, who maintained social distance too, left the ghat minutes after the pyre was ignited.Mangal Gorakhnath Raut, in his 10 years as attendant in Mankapur crematorium, has never conducted a funeral with just four persons attending. Since the outbreak in city, Raut has seen a sharp decline in number of mourners coming to the crematorium.On an average, seven to eight bodies are cremated here daily. In almost all of them, the number of mourners has decreased drastically. Earlier, some funerals would have 200-odd people, now it is to 10 to 20, he said.Similar is the situation in other crematoria and burial grounds in the city, said a senior official from the NMC’s health department. “The logistics, too, are changing fast. The dead are quietly being brought directly to cremation grounds from hospital in ambulances, bereft of mourners,” said zonal sanitation officer of Dharampeth zone Deendayal Tembhekar.Tembhekar said after the coronavirus outbreak, many kin are taking bodies directly to crematorium itself. “Earlier, there was a standard practice of first taking body to their house from where they take out procession to nearby crematorium,” he said, adding which is not being followed nowadays.A social activist, who owns a hearse van, claimed he has arranged for the body to be taken directly from the hospital to crematorium as now kin of deceased were wary of risking infection by getting the body home or holding a ceremony involving many people.Priests have not only cut short rituals but also do not hand over flowers and other stuff to family members. The mass no longer takes place in church before burial due to lockdown.Actually, rituals play a vital role to in helping the bereaved overcome their grief, said Vivek Joshi, a priest who performs last rites. “They allow community to come together, share grief, emotion and talk about the person,” said Manoj Sahare, who attended a funeral of his relative at Ambazari ghat.Sajan Turke from Ambazari crematorium said that four to seven bodies were burnt there daily. Now, we see very few people with them. Even priest, who used to take at least an hour to complete the ritual, was now finishing pooja within 10 minutes. There is little time for ceremonies in most of the cases, said Tembhekar.

Title: Nandurbar to purchase ventilators worth Rs 2 crore
Content:
Nashik: Ten ventilators will be purchased for the treatment of Covid-19 patients with the Rs 2 crore fund from the district general plan as part of emergency in view of the Covid-19 outbreak, Nandurbar district collector Rajendra Bharud said on Monday.

Nandurbar district has not recorded any positive cases so far, though 26 institutionally and 18 home quarantined people.

Bharud said that were being made to house the patients in isolation wards and suspects in quarantine facilities across the district.

Another senior district administration official said there are two 20-bed isolation wards while another 100-bed facility will be raised at the nursing college.

The official pointed out that the Rs 80 lakh available as part of the district disaster management has been distributed among various government agencies as part of preparedness.

“The administration would also make available medical equipment to private practitioners at a cost of Rs 1.5 crore through corporate social responsibility (CSR), so that they would continue to operate their OPDs to help patients.”
