The district has 4,500 three-layer masks, 25,000 gloves, 300 N-95 masks and 6,000 litres of sanitisers that could be used during all medical procedures in treating the patients.

Meanwhile, the district borders have been sealed to ensure that there is no movement of people from Gujarat towards Maharashtra or the other way round. The movement of people from Dhule and other areas has also been blocked.

Title: Stranded people, cops get a lease of life at Shindewadi & Hadapsar
Content:
PUNE: Scores of stranded The organization serves stranded labourers and policemen on duty at both the locations through their central kitchens.

According to Pramod Sonawane, the co-owner of the organization, both his kitchens have been serving nearly 150 persons, twice daily.

He said, “We have been serving around 25 to 30 policemen on duty at Shindewadi in Shirval for the past 3-4 days. We started serving at Hadapsar on Saturday, where a lot of labourers are stranded as there is no means of transportation available to go back home. When we approached the police at Hadapsar and Mohammadwadi, they said they all had access to tiffins and that we should serve the stranded labourers as they did not have any money to eat. Even if they did have the money they could not buy food as everything was shut. We distributed food packets among nearly 100 to 125 persons on Saturday.”

Sonawane said they were serving truckers at Shindewadi as well but were stopped by the police. “We were told that if we kept serving truckers, a lot of people would start crowding for food. That is why we have restricted our service only to the police,” he explained.

The catering service was providing rice preparations like pulav or biryani packed in foil boxes to people at Hadapsar while a full-fledged tiffin with sabzi, dal, rice and roti was being served to the policemen at Shindewadi.

Sonawane said, “We have multiple other central kitchens at locations like Ahmednagar Road, Nashik Highway, Hinjewadi and others. We have not started distribution from these locations yet but if the need arises, we will start those kitchens as well. We have been buying potatoes from Market Yard. We already had a large stock of rice grains as we cater to several companies otherwise. We are utilizing all this stock to serve whomever we can.”

Title: Bareilly man who tested Covid-19 +ve was under self-medication for 4 days
Content:
Bareilly: A 34-year-old man, who tested positive for Covid-19, walked into a medical store in Subhash Nagar locality and purchased a cough syrup on March 23. He was under self-medication for four days and went to district hospital on Friday only after learning a day earlier that his colleagues at work in Noida tested positive.

Confirming this on Monday, district epidemiologist Dr Meesam Abbas said, “The man who tested positive for Covid-19 was under self-medication from March 23 to 26. He went on his own to district hospital on March 27 where he was admitted and sample was collected. We have placed the medical store owner and his son under quarantine and their samples have been sent for testing. We are trying to trace if any other individual at the medical store or anywhere else came in contact with the man. Besides, the man was in contact with two of his relatives.”

After testing positive on Sunday, the health department has shifted six members of his family who were all staying with him to a quarantine facility. Notably, the man is working at a Noida-based company and some of his colleagues have tested positive as well. He returned to Bareilly on March 22.

Meanwhile, the health department has asked two private hospitals, situated within one km radius of the man’s house, to provide a daily list of those suffering from acute respiratory illness. “If no individual with this symptom turns up here, the hospitals will again have to notify us. We will collect sample of the people with acute respiratory illness at these two hospitals and test them for Covid-19,” Abbas added, as part of precautionary measure to prevent the spread of Covid-19 in the city.

For conducting active case surveillance, the department has divided the area among nine teams on Monday. The teams will conduct surveillance for the next 14 days. “The teams will visit every house situated within a kilometre radius of the man’s house. They will ask people living here if they have any symptoms, did they come in contact with the patient or any other person who returned home from abroad or other state. If anyone in the area shows symptoms, he or she will be quarantined and sample will be collected,” chief medical officer Dr Vineet Shukla said.

Title: No liquor: Cases of withdrawal effects may rise, says Nimhans
Content: BENGALURU: The lockdown over Covid-19 has thrown up an unexpected challenge, with liquor traders urging the government to allow at least limited sale of alcohol. Reason: “concerns” raised by frustrated customers claiming to have withdrawal symptoms G Honnagiri Gowda, president of Karnataka State Wine Merchants Association, said the shutdown has resulted in social issues like illegal sale of liquor and burglary at retail liquor outlets in Hubballi, Davangere and Chitradurga.However, doctors and psychiatrists say the government should use the lockdown as an opportunity to treat addicts, instead of succumbing to the liquor lobby. In a letter to the state government, Dr BN Gangadhar, director of National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences ( Nimhans ), has warned about a possible upsurge in cases of withdrawal symptoms and urged the government to take precautionary measures and arrange for adequate de-addiction treatment.The wine merchants association’s demand comes in the wake of a similar crisis in neighbouring Kerala, where nine alcoholics allegedly committed suicide. On Monday chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan directed the Kerala excise department to provide liquor to those with a prescription from a doctor.The association claims as per police records, seven people in the state committed suicide due to lack of alcohol.“We urge the government to rope in e-commerce firms and supply liquor online on the lines of Kerala,” said KS Lokesh, MD of Madhuloka, a chain of liquor outlets.The association wants the government to allow liquor sale for limited hours (between 10am and noon).

Title: HEMRL delivers hand sanitiser & disinfectant liquid to civic body
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The High Energy Materials Research Laboratory ( HEMRL ) here on Monday delivered the first consignment of 200 litre of hand sanitiser and 8,000 litre of disinfectant liquid to the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC).

The HEMRL, a laboratory of the Defence Research and Development Organisation, had started the mass production of hand sanitiser and disinfection liquid at its facility since the Covid-19 outbreak in the city. The laboratory has hired a team of four scientists for the production of these items as per the government’s guidelines.

“Our endeavour is to prepare these material as per the World Health Organisation standards. The team of scientists is carrying out the requisite tests for standards,” HEMRL director KPS Murthy told TOI on Monday. PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said, “It is a big help for us. Procuring hand sanitisers and disinfectant liquid at such short notice would not have been possible otherwise.”

The HEMRL has so far provided hand sanitisers and disinfectant liquid to sister laboratories such as Armament Research and Development Establishment, Research and Development Establishment (Engineers) in Dighi and Vehicle Research and Development Establishment in Ahmednagar . “Besides, we have supplied these items to the Armed Forces Medical College and Defence Estates Organisation, among others in the past fortnight,” Murthy said.

The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation has also approached the laboratory for similar supplies. “We will deliver in the coming days,” he added.

Title: AAI told not to invoke food retailer’s bank guarantee
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A district court has restrained the Airports Authority of India (AAI) from invoking a Rs4.2-crore bank guarantee furnished by Lite Bite Food Private Limited, a Gurugram-based food and beverage retail company, till the completion of an ongoing arbitration proceeding over the latter’s move to shut down two of its restaurants in April last year at the Lohegaon airport.

In a recent order, district judge SS Gosavi also restrained the IndusInd Bank Limited in New Delhi from releasing the amounts under bank guarantee in favour of the AAI till the disposal of the arbitration proceeding.

Judge Gosavi ruled, “In the light of the factual and legal position, I hold that the applicant (Lite Bite) has made out a prima facie case. The said bank guarantee will expire on February 7, 2022. The time limit for completion of arbitration proceeding is 12+6 total 18 months. Before expiry of bank guarantee, the arbitration proceeding is going to be completed. Under such circumstances, if injunction as prayed will be granted in favour of application, no prejudice will be caused to the respondents (AAI & IndusInd Bank).”

“On the contrary, if injunction as prayed will not be granted, the applicant would suffer huge irreparable loss. Its security deposit in the form of bank guarantee will be forfeited as well as it will be restrained from taking part in bidding process of AAI in future,” the judge held.

Lawyer Ravi Bharadwaj, representing Lite Bite, told TOI, “On July 9, 2018, our client entered into a 7-year concession agreement with the AAI, with a three-and-a-half-year lock-in period, for operating the restaurants near the Security Hold Area (SHA)-1. Apart from furnishing bank guarantee, it gave Rs2.10 crore security deposit and invested Rs10 crore in the restaurants. However, in October/November 2018, the AAI unilaterally and in breach of the agreement, closed the SHA-1 and shifted the screening area to SHA-2 to the other end of the building, adversely impacting our client’s business and causing losses.”

After an initial exchange of correspondence, Lite Bite intimated to the AAI on April 3, 2019, its intention to terminate the contract and on April 17, 2019, sent a mail to the AAI informing that the earlier intimation be treated as a 180-day notice of termination of contract. In turn, the AAI called upon Lite Bite on April 22, 2019 to furnish Rs12.81 crore licence fees and warned of encashing the bank guarantee.

Title: Farmer shares his produce with out-of-job workers
Content:
Nashik: A farmer in the Kasbe-Sukene village of Niphad taluka has saved quite a few families from going hungry for days by distributing a part of his agricultural produce for free.

With the lockdown firmly in place, daily staples are being sold at a premium — often putting a strain on the budget of the workers.

To add to their woes, many farms and establishments, where these workers are employed, have been shut. Being out of work with no other means of livelihood, many workers are unable to even feed their families.

At such a time, wheat cultivator Datta Ramrao Patil , who has a 3-acre farm in Niphad, gave away a large portion of his wheat stock for free to the workers. Patil’s elder brother, who works for a company, also helped him.

On Friday, when he was working in the field, a woman, along with her daughter, had approached Patil seeking leftover food. She also requested him to save some leftovers each day so that she could collect it for her family. The woman told Patil that since the ration shops were closed, there was no food available in the market. Moreover, she did not have any food at home either.

“The families of the workers living across the street are not beggars. They are all self-respecting people. I thought of giving away 1,000 kg of wheat that I had cultivated in one acre of my farm. I consulted with my elder brother, and he agreed with me,” said Patil.

The grains had been cleaned for sale in the market. “I had not even packed the grains. The amount of wheat we gave to the workers was one-third of our total production,” said Patil.

He requested people to take only what they need.

“We wanted to ensure social distancing. Hence, we carved out boxes to ensure people maintained a safe distance from each other while collecting the grains. Everyone cooperated,” he said.

The video of Patil distributing wheat among the workers was captured by his daughter.

The video went viral on social media, drawing attention from across the globe and applause from chief minister Uddhav Thackeray ’s office.

Title: Cops thrash SCCL worker, staff protests
Content:
Bhupalpally: Employees of Singareni Collieries Company Limited (SCCL) staged a protest and boycotted duties here on Monday after an SCCL worker, Mukkera Ravi, was thrashed by the police while he was returning home after duty late on Saturday night.

“I produced my ID card which clearly states that I am on emergency duty. The police snatched my ID card, threw it away and beat me up,” Ravi alleged.

The employees also demanded action against the police and sought paid leave during the lockdown period.

Bhupalpally DSP A Sampath Rao said that they have initiated a probe into the matter.—Shiva Kumar Pinna

Title: Cinema hall owner booked for allowing labourers to leave
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

RAJKOT: The owner of a private cinema hall was booked for allegedly allowing his labourers to leave from his site in Kalavad in Jamnagar district on Sunday night and thereby breaking the lockdown order.

Police said they caught a group of six labourers walking on the Jamnagar-Rajkot highway near Moti Banugar village.

“When questioned the labourers said they were employed for wall painting work at a cinema hall by one Ilesh Bhadra and that Bhadra had asked them to abandon their work and leave the site. Following this, we booked Bhadra under the Epidemic Diseases Act 1897," said an official from Kalawad police station.

Title: Spl parcel trains by SCR
Content:
Hyderabad: SCR will operate special parcel express trains between Secunderabad and Howrah to ensure uninterrupted supply of essential commodities. “The service, aimed at movement of commodities and goods without distinction of essential and non-essential, is extended to industrial houses, companies, interested groups, NGOs and individuals,” an SCR official said.

The train would start from Secunderabad on April 2 and April 9 and timings would be planned in a way that it reaches destination station in morning for convenience of unloading party. In return direction, train would start on April 4 and April 11. “Minimum composition of parcel vans (VPs) in parcel special trains will be based on demand, however, a customer has to register a minimum of one VP (23 tonnes),” SCR said. TNN

Title: Coimbatore: No major project in corporation budget
Content:
COIMBATORE: With no major projects in its plate, the city corporation has presented the budget with surplus revenue for the financial year 2020-21 on Monday. The civic body is presenting the budget with surplus revenue for the fourth consecutive year.

While the total revenue is estimated to be Rs 2156.18 crore, the expenditure is expected to be Rs 2155.03 crore. The corporation is estimated to have the surplus revenue of Rs 1.14 crore, this year.

Speaking to reporters, corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar said that they had presented the budged earlier that morning. However, he had refused to take further questions about the budget.

The tax revenue is expected to come from property tax, water supply and drainage tax and educational tax. While the corporation has projected revenue of Rs 170.78 crore from property tax, they had expected to earn Rs 84.75 crore from water supply and drainage tax and Rs 28.24 crores from educational tax.

For the financial year 2019-20, the corporation had eyed to earn about a sum of Rs 501.35 crore – Rs 232.61 crore from property tax, Rs 165.29 crore from water supply and drainage tax and Rs 58.71 crore from educational tax. But, according to the revised estimates, the corporation is expected to earn only Rs 270.79 - Rs 163.01 crore from property tax, Rs 80.83 crore from water supply and drainage tax and Rs 26.95 crore from educational tax.

Some of the projects that the corporation has proposed to implement this financial year are construction of community halls at four locations, implementation of biometric system at its schools, expansion of VOC zoo, create ‘my school dairy’ application to connect teachers and parents, construction of an indoor stadium and establishing a smart school per zone.

Also, the corporation has proposed to widen the entrance of Palakad Road to Kulathupalayam Road; junction connecting Selvachintamani lake and Ponnaiyarajapuram road; Thaneerpandal and Vilankurichi road junction; Sowripalayam road, Sathyamangalam road near Textool bridge; and Nallampalayam link road.

Title: Uttarakhand: Gangotri, Yamunotri portals to open on April 26
Content:
UTTARKASHI: The annual Char Dham Yatra will begin on April 26, as the portals of both Gangotri and Yamunotri shrines will open on the day after a six-month-long winter break.

On the occasion of Yamuna Jayanti on Monday officials of Yamunotri temple committee formally announced that opening of the Yamunotri shrine will take place on Akshay Tritiya on April 26. Earlier, the Gangotri temple committee had announced that the portals of the shrine will open on April 26.

Meanwhile, priest community has expressed concern over the possible impact of Covid-19 pandemic on the upcoming Char Dham Yatra. As a preventive measure, they have decided to limit the number of people during the opening ceremony if the situation doesn’t return back to normal by April 26.

Title: Checkpoints along Kasara Ghat moved to curb movement
Content:
Nashik: District administration has changed the position of the checkpoints along Kasara Ghat to prevent entry of vehicles into Nashik.

“Our regular check post was near Ghatan Devi mandir just after the vehicles climb up the ghats. But now the same has been put shifted right in the middle of the ghat where district border starts,” Tejas Chavhan, sub divisional officer, Igatpuri-Trimbakeshwar, said.

The move was to discourage the people from climbing the ghat and then gaining entry in Nashik district . The officer said the Kasara Ghat acts as a psychological barrier for the people coming from Mumbai side.

Bhiwandi ( Thane district ) and Taloja (Raigad district) is home to the large numbers of labourers working in the logistics and the industrial development corporation areas. A very large number of these people are now trying to go home.

“For all these people, the Kasara Ghat is a psychological barrier. Once they come up the ghat, they are confident of moving to their homes. They hardly turn around thereafter,” Chavhan said.

Officials said that when the drivers come up the ghat, they tend to argue and even loiter about creating huge traffic problems. This affects the release of genuine people through the check post.

According to another senior officer from the administration, the team of officials from Nashik had visited Shahapur and other areas asking for check posts to be put up so that people don’tmove towards Nashik.

“Whether that has been put in place or not is not known as the crowd has still not thinned. The shifting of the post in the ghat has helped in many ways. Since there is only space enough for small vehicle to turn around, the vehicles are in queue. So they cannot loiter around and cannot argue as well,” the officer added.

This has thus led to decrease in the traffic coming towards Nashik.

Title: Pune: Dalit industries body & CoEP to set up kitchen for homeless
Content:
The members of a gurdwara in Ganesh Peth prepare nearly 4,500 food packets for students, daily wage earners, m... Read More

PUNE: The Dalit Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (DICCI) and College of Engineering, Pune (CoEP), will start a community kitchen for over 600 homeless people being quarantined in five shelter homes in the city.

The kitchen will start on the CoEP campus.

DICCI, along with Pune Hoteliers Association, is already running a kitchen at three hotels in the city since March 27, providing meals to over 1,000 daily wage workers, including some in Lonavla on the request of the railway police.

“The district administration approved our proposal to set up the kitchen, which will provide two hot meals to the homeless people in quarantine, so we got in touch with CoEP, which agreed to let us use its premises. Other than this, we are also providing a 5kg kit, consisting of wheat flour, rice, dal, masala, oil and salt to about 50 daily wage labourers, who are finding it tough to even eat one square meal a day. This will help them out for about 5-7 days,” Milind Kamble, DICCI’s founder-chairman, said.

CoEP director B B Ahuja said the college’s mess and kitchen were unused as none of the students reside on campus, “All we have done is provide this area. The large mess and kitchen area were fumigated and sanitized today. The area will be used to cook and pack food so that it can be taken to different places. CoEP, being centrally located, will help them cater to people in need across the city,” said Ahuja.

Akshath Shetty, who owns Bamboo house NX on Prabhat Road, said they provided the food to 300 people on Saturday, while Deepak Shetty who runs Sitar restaurant said, that they would be providing dinner for 350 people. “Currently all this is done out of our pocket. My cousin, Yashraj, too provided food from his hotel, but we need more people to join or sponsor this activity,” said Shetty.

Raju Waghmare, also from DICCI, said, “The food will be given at midday and then at 7.30pm at shelter homes. The first two days we will be able to provide food for about 600 people, and once this number increases, we would be able to provide food to about 1,200 people.”

Title: NIMS nod to retirement age extension
Content:
Hyderabad: The Nizams Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) has approved the proposal to extend the retirement age of assistant professors, associate professors and additional professors and professors from 60 to 65 years.

NIMS doctors have been seeking extension of retirement age to 65 years due to shortage of faculty and impending retirements affecting the normal functioning of a few departments. An order issued on Monday by NIMS said that the decision to extend the retirement age came into effect on March 4. “The decision of the executive board will be placed before the governing council for ratification,” it said.

Title: Minister tests negative for Covid-19
Content: Nagpur: Rumors about firebrand leader Bachchu Kadu being home quarantined for 14 days spread across Vidarbha on Monday. Kadu, who is Maharashtra’s minister of state for water resources, school education, and women & child development is suffering from cough, cold, and fever from past five days.Kadu’s office clarified that the minister got himself tested twice for coronavirus and he tested negative on both the occasions.Monday also brought a big relief for Amravati as both sons of a Covid-19 positive couple tested negative. The couple had tested positive in Meerut (UP) on March 22. They left Amravati by train on March 18.The health administration was on toes since the news of city couple found Covid-19 positive in UP came. The Amravati Municipal Corporation (AMC) had started door-to-door surveillance in a locality where the couple resides. The locality was in a shock. Fear was apparent as people had confined themselves to home.While one of the sons tested 100% negative, the other one, despite testing negative, will have to undergo another test on April 1, the administration said. Both sons are in the isolation ward in Amravati.Fear gripped the locality as rumours of one of the sons found positive started getting viral on social media. The administration warned of action against rumour mongers on social media and urged people not to trust such stories.Apart from Nagpur, all other parts in Vidarbha heaved a sigh of relief on Monday as no new positive case was reported from the region.In Yavatmal, where three positive patients recovered and were discharged on Saturday, no new admission was reported in the isolation ward of GMCH. Now, the hospital only has one presumptive patient, whose reports are awaited. Till date, 91 people are in home quarantine in Yavatmal.Gondia, where a 23-year-old youth, a confirmed positive case of Covid-19, is under treatment, also reported no new case on Monday. In fact, 13 close contacts of the positive patients were tested negative, which came as a big relief.In Chandrapur, ten suspects got themselves admitted and swab samples of nine of them were collected. Eight of them were tested negative while one result is pending.

Title: 17 people caught on drone cameras; held
Content: RAJKOT: The eyes of the cops are always watching you during this lockdown period. Drones are the cops' eyes. And with the help from technology, the police in Jamnagar and Devbhoomi Dwarka districts have arrested as many as 17 persons for the alleged violation of the lockdown order in the past 24 hours.“In Bedi locality, we flew a drone and arrested seven persons who were caught breaking the lockdown order on the camera fitted with the drone,” said an official from the Jamnagar police.Meanwhile in Devbhoomi Dwarka district, as many as 10 persons were arrested after they were caught on the drone camera flouting the lockdown order in Salaya and Khambhalia. “We have also detained 18 vehicles flouting the order,” said an official from the Devbhoomi Dwarka police.

Title: Goa government blockade of medicines leaves elders, ailing in lurch
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The state government’s consistent floundering and mismanagement has left thousands of citizens who are sick and with pre-existing conditions without their medication. Senior citizens, especially, have been left in the lurch, as most pharmacies in Goa have run out of stock and wholesalers are unable to operate.

The empty shelves and closed shutters at the state’s pharmacies are due to the fact that trucks carrying medicines have been stuck at the state border, with the Goa government refusing to let them in. The state’s blockage of essential healthcare products is at odds with Centre stating explicitly that pharmaceuticals and medical equipment are exempted from the lockdown. Only on Monday, more than a week after the lockdown began, did supplies start trickling in.

Within the state too, the glacial pace at which the Goa government is issuing travel passes meant that pharmacy and distributor staff can’t get to work, leaving citizens to bear the brunt, and in some cases, put their lives at risk.

Even as the state government boasts of its efforts to combat coronavirus, face masks, hand sanitizers and even vitamic C tablets are out of stock in most pharmacies.

Late on Monday, the district magistrate, North Goa, permitted all pharmacies and pharma firms to operate. Chief minister Pramod Sawant too, on Monday, said that he has directed distributors to continue the supply of medicines to pharmacies to avoid shortage of life-saving drugs.

The impact of the easily-avoidable shortage has hit senior citizens especially hard. Kantilal Mokani’s son travelled over 30 km trying to source hypertension and cardiac medicines for his parents on Sunday. With some pharmacies in Panaji shut, others were out of Apresol (for hypertension).

“I then went to the hospital in Dona Paula which prescribed the medication in the first place. Even the hospital didn’t have the medication. I then had to go to a private pharmacy at GMC, where I picked up what they said was the last stock,” he said.

Arpita Naik, 62 who lives alone, had to do without her regular dose of hypertension tablets for two days, as the pharmacy in Candolim she normally picks them up from didn’t have it. “If not for my friend in another village, I had to go without taking medicines, I don’t know for how many days (this can go on),” she said. Many residents have no option but to travel long distances in search of pharmacies, risking being arrested for defying the curfew.

Sources say that the shortage of medicines could also partly be attributed to people buying in bulk, as the lockdown, abruptly imposed, threw people into a state of panic. This situation, they said, could easily have been avoided if the government had made arrangements to keep the supply chain intact.

“These arrangements ought to have been worked out prior to the lockdown to ensure that the supply chain was not disrupted. But trucks carrying medicines are left stranded at the border,” said Kedar Jirage, proprietor and chief pharmacist at Jeevan Rekha pharmacy. Jirage said that while has been able to stock most medicines, his pharmacies do not have either hand sanitizers or face masks.

The state government’s constant flip-flops have forced some pharmacies to err on the side of caution. Many pharmacists told TOI that, fearing for their safety, they preferred to keep their shutters down, while others opened for only a few hours each day. “These two weeks are crucial, that’s why we have decided to keep the pharmacy open only for a few hours each day as a precautionary measure,” one pharmacist told TOI.

Although Goa has a robust pharma industry, most of the medicines manufactured here are exported. Around 70-80% of the state’s medicine supply comes from other states.

Albert De Sa, president of the Chemist and Druggist Association of Goa, said all pharmacies will become operational in a day or two as their staff have been issued travel passes. Some have already become operational.

“Pharmacists remained shut as their staff were unable to travel due to restrictions. It is difficult for the pharmacist alone to handle all customers. So is the case with wholesalers. Besides the district collector, the FDA director has also been asked to issue travel passes,” he said.

De Sa appealed to people not to stock, as that denies medicines to others. “I fervently ask people not to buy medicines in bulk,” he said.

With pharmacies remaining closed or going out of stock, some people tried alternatives. In Chicalim, when a patient found that Acitrom (blood thinner) 2 mg was out of stock, he bought a 1 mg strip instead, and has been managing the daily dose by taking two tablets instead of one.

Title: CRly to run 3 parcel trains
Content: Nagpur: The Central Railway has decided to run three parcel trains to transport essential commodities. The trains will operate between Kalyan-Sankrail, Kalyan-Changsari and Godhni-New Tinsukia for transporting essential commodities like medical, food, vegetables, fruits etc.All these trains will run with 20 VPU coaches and one guard-cum-luggage van. Frequency may be increased if there is increase in demand for goods supply.The Kalyan-Sankrail parcel train will have 4 services. Parcel train (no. 00101) will leave Kalyan at 8.30pm on April 2 and 9 and will reach Sankrail at 12 hours on the third day.Train no. 00102 train will leave Sankrail at 10pm on April 6 and 13 and will arrive at Kalyan at 6pm on the third day. The train will halt at Igatpuri, Nashik, Manmad, Jalgaon, Bhusaval, Badnera, Nagpur, Durg, Bilaspur, Jharsuguda, Rourkela & Tatanagar.Another parcel train between Kalyan-Changsari will have 2 services. The train no. 00103 will leave Kalyan at 8.30pm on April 7 and arrive at Changsari at 12 hours on April 10. Similarly, train no. 00104 will leave Changsari at 11.30pm on April 10, and arrive at Kalyan at 8pm on April 13. The halts include Igatpuri, Nashik, Manmad, Jalgaon, Bhusaval, Badnera, Nagpur, Durg, Bilaspur, Jharsuguda, Rourkela, Tatanagar, Sankrail, Battanagar, Dankuni, Malda Town and New Bongaigaon.The third train will operate 2 services between Godhani-New Tinsukia. The 00105 train will leave Godhani at 8pm on March 31, and reach New Tinsukia at 2.30pm on April 3. Train no. 00106 will leave New Tinsukia at 12 hours on April 3 and arrive at Godhani at 7pm on April 5.The train will have stoppages at Nagpur, Durg, Bilaspur, Jharsuguda, Rourkela, Tatanagar, Battanagar, Dankuni, Manda Town and New Bongaigaon.

Title: Symptoms after 18-26 days: New case in Lucknow puzzles doctors
Content: LUCKNOW: The curious case of 73-year-old woman, who was tested Covid-19 positive on Monday about 18-26 days after coming in contact with her daughter-in-law, has left medical experts puzzled.According to World Health Organisation (WHO) assessment, the incubation period of coronavirus is 5-14 days, which means symptoms of infection surface in a person within 14 days of coming in touch with a Covid-19 positive patient.The elderly woman is the mother-in-law of a 35-year-old Toronto-based doctor who visited Lucknow on March 8 and tested Covid-19 positive on March 10. The doctor underwent treatment at KGMU and was discharged on March 21 after recovery with the advice of 14 more days of isolation.After the doctor was found positive, her family members, including her mother-in-law were tested and their reports were found to be negative.The elderly woman, the wife of a retired colonel, was admitted to Command Hospital of Central Command in Lucknow on Saturday (March 28) after she complained of urinary tract infection.Since her daughter-in-law had been tested positive earlier, the swab samples of the woman were collected again and sent to NIV Pune for testing in which she was found Covid-19 positive.Lucknow CMO Dr Narendra Agarwal said according to Indian Council of Medical Research and government guidelines, close contact of Covid-19 patient should be tested once within 14 days.“Further, a person has to be tested only when he shows symptoms. In this case, we tested the elderly woman as per guidelines on March 13, two days after her daughter-in-law tested positive,” he said.Prof Amita Jain, head of microbiology department at KGMU said, “As per WHO assessment, the incubation period of novel coronavirus is 5-14 days. Due to this, contacts of Covid-19 patients are advised 14 days self-isolation. However, in this case, the NRI doctor was tested positive on March 10 and her mother-in-law was admitted on March 28, which means symptoms appeared after 18 days. If we count from the date of the doctor’s arrival, the time span is 26 days.”“These facts makes the 73-year-old woman a case study for us. We need to find answers to many questions. Can the incubation period be more than 14 days? Can symptoms take more than two weeks to surface? Can a patient continue to shed virus even after recovery? There can other possibilities too,” Prof Jain added.Virologist Prof TN Dhole, former head of microbiology department at SGPGI, said evidence-based research was required to understand the virus. “There is a possibility that the viral load was very low when the woman was first tested. Due to this, the incubation period could be longer than 14 days,” he added.Some experts said that now when the NRI doctor was being tested again, it would bring to the fore possibilities of recurrence, which so far have been found to be rare.

Title: Man tries to kill self to evade arrest
Content:
Hyderabad: A man attempted suicide by consuming poison allegedly to evade arrest in an attempt to murder case in Shahinayathgunj.

The accused identified as Papalal was shifted to a hospital by the police. The doctors said that his condition is stable. Meanwhile, Papalal’s wife was arrested.

Papalal and his wife had allegedly attacked a neighbour with flower plots and injured the person, following which a case was registered against the couple under Section 307 (attempt to murder) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Police said that Papalal has 12 criminal cases registered against him.

Title: With humans under lockdown, lions camp in Amreli villages
Content:
Lions in Mitiyala, Ambardi, Bhad and Liliya talukas of Amreli

RAJKOT: Unhindered by the movements of vehicles on the roads and unhampered by human beings who have shut themselves behind the doors of their houses due to the coronavirus lockdown order, several prides of lions are seen prowling in different villages of Amreli district .

“Apart from one or two talukas, the sighting of lions is common in the entire district of Amreli. Now, with all most all the roads of the district wearing a deserted look due to the lockdown, the lions are finding the environment conducive to their movements,” said a senior forest officer of Amreli range.

“Several prides of lions are seen on the prowl in Mitiyala, Ambaradi, Dhari, Liliya and Antiyala villages. The lions are seen bathing in the rivers, streams and ponds of various villages of the district. There are 27 checkposts in Amreli district, where instead of vehicles, lions are seen passing by,” narrated the forest officer.

“At present, a pride of 11 lions has been camping on the bank of Dhataradi river near Ambaradi for the past four days,” added the officer.

Other animals too are having a fearless run in the human lockdown period close to the usually populated areas . Deers were seen venturing near Jungadh taleti where lakhs of devotees are come. Hyenas, the nocturnal animals, were seen on Savarkundla-Abhrampara road in the last few days.

Title: Lasalgaon onion market to be shut from today
Content:
Nashik: Hundreds of traders from Lasalgaon, the biggest wholesale onion market in the country, have refused to participate in the daily auction after Nashik district reported its first Covid-19 positive case.

Associations of the Lasalgaon onion traders and head-load workers gave separate letters to the agriculture market produce committee ( APMC ) management on Monday expressing their inability to participate in the auction. The onion traders’ association wanted the auction to be stopped from Tuesday as they were unwilling to take part in it.

Considering their stance, the APMC has decided to close onion auction for next few days. “We are temporarily closing onion auction from Tuesday until further decision following demand from onion traders association and also the loaders due to Covid-19,” said Narendra Wadawane , secretary, Lasalgaon APMC. Though there is a countrywide lockdown since March 22, APMC was exempted as it is an essential service.

On Monday, auction of a record 38,000 quintals of onions took place as most farmers had already brought their produce to the market. A total 1,867 farmers brought their onions in sacks. Onion auction of 76,865 sacks was done on Monday.

Of total arrivals, 75% of the arrivals were of late kharif onions, while remaining were of summer onions.

“The late kharif onions have a shelf life of less than one month and hence farmers have not option, but to sell the produce at the prevailing market rates. Hence, farmers want to sell their produce at the earliest. This is the reason farmers rushed the mandi to sell their produce,” said APMC officials.

On the contrary, summer onions have a shelf life of more than six months. Hence, farmers prefer storing onions with a hope of getting better price.

On Monday too, summer onions fetched more rates as compared to late kharif onions.

While the average wholesale onion price of summer onion was Rs 1,650 per quintal, that of late kharif onions was recorded at Rs 1,200 per quintal.

Title: Lawyers, sports bodies donate funds for C-19
Content: Nagpur: Responding to the call for donating funds for the poor and migrants in view of the Covid-19 crisis lawyers ’ unions and sports bodies have come forward to help the government.Collectively, they’ve assured to raise Rs19 lakh of which Rs14 lakh was collected by lawyers from the High Court Bar Association (HCBA), District Bar Association ( DBA ) and other bar associations. The Maharashtra Badminton Association (MBA) has assured to donate Rs5 lakh towards the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund, according to its president Arun Lakhani.On Monday, the DBA team comprising president Kamal Satuja handed over a cheque of Rs1.5 lakh to collector Ravindra Thakare. Satuja informed that the collection reached Rs4 lakh. He said that after accepting donations for 2-3 days, 40% of the amount will be offered to the district collector, 40% will be donated to the Prime Minister’s Relief Fund and the remaining 20% will be reserved for the aid of needy lawyers.MBA’s executive committee has unanimously decided to contribute Rs5 lakh. “This is a small help from our side as we are facing a huge problem nationwide. It’s an unprecedented situation and we all must strive to keep ourselves safe by helping contain the spread of Coronavirus,” Lakhani told TOI.DRT bar president Atul Pandey collected Rs5 lakh and committed to donate it entirely at the district collector’s office. The union declared that they won’t be accepting any further donations.

Title: Over 68k employees to get Rs 4 lakh life insurance
Content: Dehradun: The state government on Monday announced to provide around 68,457 frontline employees who are directly involved in the fight against coronavirus an insurance cover of Rs 4 lakh each.The life insurance cover would be for a period of a year and will cost the exchequer Rs 17.02 crore. A communique from the CM’s office said that the amount would be made available through the CM Relief Fund.Among the employees that would be insured are 22,523 police personnel, 7,899 health employees, 14,595 anganwadi workers, 14,376 anganwadi assistants, 4,924 mini-anganwadi assistants, 464 supervisors, 78 child development project officers and 3,000 employees of Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam and Kumaon Mandal Vikas Nigam. Provision is also being made for insurance cover for mediapersons reporting on the pandemic.Last week, during the one-day assembly session held to pass the state budget, the CM had announced to provide security cover to all “warriors” involved in the fight against Covid-19.Meanwhile, on Monday, CM Rawat held a meeting with Indian Medical Association (IMA) members. In the meeting, Rawat stressed on the important role of private hospitals in handling the current situation and stressed that the hospitals should keep their OPDs open so that patients having other ailments are not inconvenienced. “The state government will provide all required support to private hospitals,” he said, adding that the health authorities have been directed to ensure that the OPDs of private hospitals function properly and all required co-operation was provided.The chief minister further said that presently, Doon Hospital, Mahant Indiresh Hospital, AIIMS Rishikesh and Himalayan Institute of Medical Sciences have beds reserved for Covid-19 patients.While AIIMS Rishikesh and Doon Hospital have 400 beds each for coronavirus patients, Himalayan Institute and Mahant Indiresh have 200 beds each.The CM also sought assistance from his counterparts in the states of Uttar Pradesh (UP), Telangana and Karnataka in providing help to Uttarakhand residents who have been stranded in these states after the Covid-19 lockdown.A list of stranded people has been provided to the authorities concerned, officials in the CM’s office said. Besides, Uttarakhand government has also kept a fund of Rs 50 lakh for the state residents stranded in New Delhi.On Monday, CM Rawat, through a series of tweets, stated that the evacuation process was not possible at present and thus, he requires assistance from these states. In a tweet marked to UP CM Yogi Adityanath, he wrote, “People from our state are stranded in Prayagraj. Request your assistance in providing necessary relief.”The CM marked similar tweets to the Telangana and Karnataka CMs as well.

Title: With theatres shut, actor takes centre stage on digital platform
Content:
Actors and police recorded a video appeal for the people

PUNE: With theatres shut because of lockdown, stage actor and director Atul Pethe has taken to the digital medium to direct and stage a play based on the deadly virus that has upended lives around the world.

Marking the World Theatre Day on Friday, Pethe released a “three-minute, three-part digital play” on YouTube titled “Theatre in the time of CORONA”.

He said that even though the play has been filmed digitally, he had tried to keep the essence of theatre intact.

The overwhelming theme of the play is agony, across three short “acts”, peppered with an overwhelming sense of desire and clamour for things as basic as the sun outside the home. But it doesn’t end without providing a semblance of hope, of how human beings may reassess the world after the crisis, with a possible end to the greed of humans, and a return to the basics. The last act features Pethe, with his profile lit up dramatically, wiping off layers of dust and msud from his face.

“The mud depicts the layers of greed that human beings in general have put on themselves. We have long abandoned our need and only increased our greed. After this crisis, human beings will hopefully re-assess their basic needs,” Pethe said.

He added, “Everyone is disturbed. Theatres are shut, everyone is confined to their homes and this will have a huge social, economic, and political impact. There is fear and anxiety all around. Even I am wondering as to what is happening to me, with all the fragmentation and polarisation and all the social distancing around me. There was already distancing and discrimination in society based on caste and religion, and this crisis has reduced us to poor and lonely human beings.”

Title: Goa: Expect test results quicker as GMC’s virology lab is up and running
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: A new virology laboratory at Goa Medical College ( GMC ) and hospital, Bambolim, set up in less than a month, became operational on Monday. A trial test at the new lab, which can test samples for coronavirus, was conducted on Sunday.

Director of health services Dr Jose de Sa said that six samples of coronavirus suspects have been sent to the lab and results are awaited.

With the new lab becoming functional, the state is set to get test results faster. Until two days ago, swab samples were sent to virology laboratories outside the state, such as the National Institute of Virology, Pune.

“We received laboratory results within two to three days when sent for testing outside Goa, but we will now know the status of suspects much faster,” said a senior health official.

Goa has five confirmed cases of Covid-19, of which two were detected on Sunday. Efforts were underway to trace the immediate contacts or family members linked to two men. One of the two, a 37-year-old man, had a travel history.

“Some of his contacts have been traced and quarantined, but some of his co-passengers are yet to be tracked when he flew to Goa on March 22. The man came from New York to Mumbai, and then took a Vistara domestic flight to Goa.

The health department has appealed to passengers on that Vistara flight to immediately call 104 or 0832-2421810/2225538, or report to the nearest health centre.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant, speaking to reporters, said that 20 of the man’s co-passengers of the man had been traced. However, it could not be verified how many travellers the health department was yet to trace.

The condition of five Covid-19 patients who are being treated at the ESI Covid-19 hospital was improving, he said. Meanwhile, on Monday, nine passengers were home quarantined, 22 placed under facility quarantine, and six placed in GMC’s isolation facility.

Title: 14.57 lakh working in unorganised sectors in Tamil Nadu to get kits with rice, dal & oil
Content: CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu government has asked the state labour and employment department to procure 14.57 lakh kits with rice, dal and oil to be distributed to workers in the unorganised sectors.Each kit will contain 15kg rice, 1kg dal and 1kg edible oil and it will be distributed to registered members of the welfare boards for workers in the unorganised sectors. The dole will cost the exchequer Rs 93.21 crore. The commodities will be procured through the state civil supplies corporation. The kits will be distributed to 14,57,526 registered members of the welfare boards through the district collectors concerned. The beneficiaries include 24,274 registered and 40,000 non-registered inter-state migrant labourers in the state, additional chief secretary Mohammed Nasimuddin said in the order.As many as 92,445 pensioners and family pensioners in Tamil Nadu construction workers’ welfare board and drivers in unorganised sector are among the beneficiaries.The department has also sought the government’s permission to provide aid to 12.79 lakh registered members of 14 other welfare boards – like handloom and handloom silk weaving workers, footwear and leather goods manufacturing and tannery workers, goldsmiths, pottery workers, domestic workers, power loom workers, street vendors, cooks and washermen — by utilising funds available with the respective boards.Meanwhile, the ministry has also instructed authorities to form five special teams to conduct drives to enrol unregistered workers in unorganised sectors and guest workers on a war-footing. The authorities have been working in coordination with federations of industries and non-governmental organisations to reach out to workers in the unorganised sectors.

Title: Milk consumption in city sees a dip
Content: Hyderabad: Milk consumption in Hyderabad has come down from 30 lakh litres per day to 27 lakh litres per day in the last one week. A large number of milk delivery boys have stopped supplying milk at the doorsteps of consumers owing to coronavirus scare.Also, some of the gated communities have stopped taking milk deliveries due to the virus fear. Another reason for the consumption taking a hit was due to hotels, restaurants, sweet shops closing and pushcart vendors and tea stores not being allowed to function.While Hyderabadis are missing their daily cup of Irani chai in cafes and hotels, milk powder and tetra milk packets with three months of shelf life have flied off the racks in provisional stores and supermarkets with worried consumers purchasing them in bulk due to the lockdown.Managements of government-run dairies and private dairies met animal husbandry minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav and told him how dairies were given time only from 5 am to 9 am to deliver bulk supplies to retailers and distributors in the colonies which is also one of the reasons for milk consumption taking a knock. They urged the minister to extend milk supply timings.As milk has been identified by both the central and state government as an essential commodity, the minister said that he would direct police to allow milk vans to deliver supplies from 5 am to 5 pm daily. The minister also asked officials to speak with Swiggy, BigBasket, among others, and see if they could also deliver milk at the doorsteps of the consumers.

Title: Guest faculty in colleges sans pay since 9 mths
Content:
Hyderabad: The lockdown has added to the woes of guest faculty working at government degree colleges in Telangana who have not been receiving their salaries for the last nine months. The Commissionerate of Collegiate Education had recruited 1,940 guest faculty for 132 government degree colleges across the state.

“We worked for the entire academic year (2019-20), but we have not got salaries since July. We are in trouble, especially during the lockdown period,” Prakash Kammam, a guest faculty, told TOI. Faculty members rue that due to the government’s delay in releasing salaries, many of them had taken personal loans. The nationwide lockdown has now put them in a fix as many are unable to make ends meet.

Several guest faculty members reached out to finance minister T Harish Rao on Twitter seeking help. “I am one of the guest faculty from the 900 faculties who are working in government degree colleges in the Telangana state...We are facing lot of problem. We hope that you will resolve our problem (sic),” tweeted Aamir, a lecturer. Responding to such tweets, Rao tweeted: “Instructed principal finance secretary to sort out the issue and release salaries @navinmittal @HarishRaoOffice pl follow up and follow up with finance (sic).”

Incidentally, this is not the first time that salaries of guest faculty have been pending. In May last, the guest faculty had even approached the State Human Rights Commission seeking regular payment from the government.

“All guest faculty members receive a amount of Rs 300 per hour for the lectures that they take at government degree colleges. Renewal of contracts has been pending with the education department following which their salaries will also be released. We are following up on the issue,” said commissioner of collegiate education department, Navin Mittal.

Title: UP CM helpline gets distress call at 45-second interval
Content: LUCKNOW: In every 45 seconds the UP CM helpline number 1076 starts ringing. The helpline number is inundated with calls made by natives of the state stuck in different parts of the country. They are pleading authorities concerned to make arrangement for their safe return to their homes. In the past 48 hours, the 250-seater call centre of the toll free number has rung up over 2,154 times.Panic-stricken people are making calls from across the country and every distress call highlights problems of not only the caller, but also the people stuck along with him somewhere in the country. Vaibhav Mishra , a professional from Unnao, is stuck in Mumbai. “For over two weeks we are locked up in the two bed-room set. I request you to please rescue us from here,” he told a tele-caller who patiently responded to his call.Data reveals that Maharashtra accounts for the largest number of calls followed by Uttarakhand and Punjab . Also, every single call is linked with four-five persons. This means that the 2,154 calls speak for at least 10,000-12,000 people.The staff on duty lends a patient ear to each one. To the caller from Mumbai, the girl on duty said: “You are aware that the country is under lockdown till April 14. And it is essential to restrict the movement of people to ensure that the pandemic virus does not spread into the community.” Thereafter, she inquired if the person was facing any problem such as shortage of food or medicine and apprised about all precautions that need to be taken to ensure that one doesn’t contract the infection.Secretary to CM, Alok Kumar said: “We are not only recording problems and supporting callers by providing helplines, but we are also counsellng them as many feel home sick, distressed and claustrophobic. A number of poor labourers have been provided food through nodal officers who pursued complaints with officials in the assigned states.”

Title: NMC to set up ICU units with 60 beds in four hospitals
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to set up intensive care units (ICU) at four civic-run hospitals to provide advance treatment to Covid-19 patients.Under this plan, 20 beds each will come up at Zakir Hussain and Bytco hospitals, while India Gandhi and Swami Samarth hospitals will have 10 beds each.The NMC has appealed to donors like charitable trusts, corporate houses and social outfits to offer a helping hand.“We are geared up and working hard to fight against the crisis and deal with the public health situation. Understanding the current scenario and fast increase in number of patients, the NMC is planning to have 60 ICU beds in four civic hospitals,” municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game said.The NMC needs 60 ventilators, 12 defibrillator, 40 monitor multiparty, 120 syringe pumps, 30 infusion pumps, compressors, 18 ECG machines, 60 ICU beds, 60 mattresses, 60 side tables, 60 bed tables, 36 screens, 6 recovery trolleys, 6 dressing trolleys, 18 instrument trolleys, 60 nebulizers, 60 oxygen cylinders, trolley for oxygen cylinders, 18 wheel chairs.According to the civic body, those interested in donating can contact on 9826814167, 9890909300. The NMC has already set up quarantine wards at its Tapovan building and Bytco hospital in the city.Apart from this, the NMC is taking all the preventive measures and has so far disinfected over 1,800-km of city roads with the help of tractors. Regular sweeping of city roads is also being carried out with the help of over 1,500 sanitation employees.The NMC is also creating awareness among the citizens about Covid-19 and has formed 31 teams to sensitise people.

Title: 46 Telangana Annapurna Canteens to come up in two days
Content:
Thank you @TelanganaCMO @KTRTRS for acting on our recommendations & setting up additional Annapurna centres where p… https://t.co/1iQrNRBGpI — Asaduddin Owaisi (@asadowaisi) 1585551006000

HYDERABAD: As many as 46 new Annapurna canteens will come up across the GHMC’s Charminar zone over the next two days.This, after AIMIM chief and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi asked chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao to ensure adequate food arrangements in the seven assembly segments in Old City areas and Rajendranagar circle.Asad took to Twitter to thank the CM and KTR following the approval of the proposal.The canteens, which serve food for Rs 5, will serve free of cost twice a day instead of once. “The food will be served at these places by raising temporary structures and social distancing will also be ensured,” said GHMC commissioner for Charminar zone, Ashok Samrat.The existing canteens which were closed after lockdown orders were reopened following Asad’s request. The lawmaker had tweeted to MA&UD principal secretary Arvind Kumar on March 23 following which the canteens became operational again.

Title: Date for submitting bills to treasury extended till Apr 18
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: In the wake of lockdown announced due to Covid-19 outbreak, the government has extended the date of submission of physical bills of all departments in the treasury till April 18.The decision was taken late evening on Monday, by amending the original decision that all the bills should be submitted before 5pm on Monday. As per the order issued by the finance department on Monday, the electronic copy of the bills should be submitted by Tuesday evening. Under normal circumstances, the physical bills also should have been filed before midnight on the last day of the financial year. In the wake of the lockdown in the country, the functioning of government departments has also been thrown out of gear, with most of them functioning with minimal staff and the mobility of the public has been curtailed.In these circumstances, the government decided to extend the date for submission of physical bills till April 18. While the physical bills that are submitted till March 31 will be moved to the treasury queue and does not need any fresh administrative sanction, the bills submitted after that till April 18 will be released separately, in addition to the Plan allocation for next financial year.“Since both the agencies, viz. banks and treasuries have switched over entirely to a computer based system, the banking transactions on the last working day of the current financial year will have to end at the latest by midnight on the same day,” the circular that was issued by the finance department said. It further said that the treasuries will not be able to pass bills presented after a prescribed time under any circumstances, that was originally set for 5pm on March 28. It was revised later, and the deadline was reset to 5pm on Monday.The government also instructed that since the treasury restrictions are in place, due to financial crunch, all the pending bills in the treasury for clearance should be moved to treasury queue. The government’s financial crunch had led to treasury restrictions and only bills up to Rs 50,000 are immediately passed.Also, government had informally decided to slash the Plan allocation for 2019-20 of various departments by 40% this year in the wake of financial crisis. Under these circumstances, if the bills submitted under various heads under a department is more than 60% of the allocation for that head, the bills are not being passed, treasury department sources said.The government, meanwhile, extended the date for submitting the bills for the availed work advances and temporary advances for various purposes till April 30.

Title: Drug, Vaccine Supply Chain Hit, CM Urged To Intervene
Content: Hyderabad: The Telangana Chemists and Druggists’ Association (TCDA) has appealed to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to intervene and take measures to ensure that the medicine and vaccine supply in the state is not affected further. Hyderabad is known as the pharma capital of India with several pharmaceutical firms having their hubs here.Association president Ch Janardhan Rao said they were facing severe transportation problems for outstation despatches. “Regular local couriers, transport operators and their branches operating in all parts of Telangana have been closed due to which supply chain has been hit badly,” he said.Transporters like Decent Lorry Service, Navata Transport, BMPS Transport, SRMT Transport, VRL Transport, Kranti Roadways, ANL Parcel Service, which ferry medicines and vaccines have ceased their operations ever since the pandemic broke out. Couriers like Professional, DTDC, BlueDart and Safe Express are also not operating.“When we contacted them, the transport operators said that drivers and hamalis are not coming to office due to lockdown and coronavirus fear. Even though passes are provided to the staffers, it is difficult for them to reach offices,” Janardhan said.Janardhan said transporters should be assured about safety of their staff and passes have to be issued for easy movement of vehicles. “Cabs should be permitted to pick up and drop the staffers and each vehicle should be allowed to carry four persons,” he said. “The government should also insist on courier companies airlift the goods from other states, if needed,” the association said.Janardhan said with manufacturing units closed, agents were not getting the stocks and urged the CM to take the necessary steps to open the manufacturing units immediately for uninterrupted supply of medicines and vaccines.

Title: Tipplers find the going tough in dry times
Content: Mangaluru: The fallout of the lockdown has had an effect not only on the economy, but also on many habitual drinkers. The blanket ban on sale of liquor staring March 24 left tipplers in Dakshina Kannada with little time to replenish their cabinet, which has resulted in many reporting to mental health doctors with symptoms of withdrawal On the one hand, surging demand has created a black market for alcohol , with many customers paying as much as thrice the maximum retail price for a sip. Conrad Misquith, a tattoo artist and owner of a studio in Padil, said that people were willing to pay Rs 200 for a 90ml tetra packet of McDowell’s whiskey, the MRP of which was Rs 70. “The problem is that many tipplers are wary of venturing outside their homes. Many senior citizens who are in the habit of taking a sip before retiring for the day too are struggling to cope with the non-availability of liquor,” said Misquith.Psychiatrist and professor at Fr Muller Medical College Hospital Dr Supriya Hegde Aroor said that symptoms of withdrawal could either be severe or mild. “In the latter case, those suffering from alcohol withdrawal report lack of sleep or bitterness in their mouth, which lasts for around a week, after which they adapt themselves to the change, and live comfortably. In those who exhibit severe symptoms can experience seizures and even delirium. In such cases, the first 48 to 72 hours are crucial,” said Dr Supriya, who had to attend to an emergency case a few days ago when a patient tried to commit suicide owing to the non-availability of alcohol and had to be rushed to the hospital.Professor and head of the department of psychiatry at AJ Institute of Medical Sciences and Research Centre Dr Ravish Thunga admitted to a rise in patients who were reporting symptoms of alcohol withdrawal since the lockdown came into force. “Given that alcohol is not going to be available for a long period, such reactions are along expected lines in those with what is called alcohol dependence syndrome. These patients need medical help,” said doctors.Bernard D’Souza, a businessman in Dakshina Kannada district, urged the government to take note of the severity of the problem and introduce a quota system, along the lines of the one followed by the Indian Army.Deputy commissioner of excise in Dakshina Kannada district Shailaja Kote said that the excise department was closely monitoring the unauthorised sale of liquor.Fake news of liquor outlets in Karnataka being open from 2pm to 5.30pm which claim to have originated from police and the DC’s office has added to the confusion. “We have already registered a criminal case, and an investigation is under way. I request people to follow only the official Twitter handles for these updates,” Mangaluru city police commissioner PS Harsha said.

Title: T-Hub, CCMB join hands to launch innovation challenge
Content: Hyderabad: The state government-run T-Hub on Monday said it has joined hands with the Centre for Cellular & Molecular Biology (CCMB) as knowledge partner to launch a COVID-19 Innovation Challenge to empower students to conduct research to develop potential solutions to contain the spread of coronavirus . The Telangana ITE&C department’s emerging technologies wing will help the T-Hub in curating problem statements for the challenge.The programme is open to student innovators across colleges in Telangana. Students will be encouraged to develop a potential solution, idea or an application for reporting, curing or tracing the coronavirus pandemic or any other solution that can help curb the virus’ spread and prevent future outbreaks.The focus areas are easy detection of infected persons, solutions that are low cost and easy to implement, efficient tracking of infected persons and their contact with other persons as well as regular monitoring of the spread of the virus and predict outcomes.As a part of the programme, the two most innovative projects and ideas will be shortlisted for advanced mentoring and support from all stakeholders to transform their ideas into a viable business proposition. Subject matter experts from CCMB, T-Hub, Q City and the emerging technologies wing will work with the students to help them transform their ideas into viable propositions.The students shortlisted will be will get to be part of a curated mentorship programme by the T-Hub for student entrepreneurs and they will gain exposure to industrial experts from Q City, Grace Cancer Foundation, CCMB and other corporate partners.Commenting on the development, T-Hub CEO Ravi Narayan said the COVID-19 Innovation Challenge has been taken up to utilise existing resources and networks to explore possible solutions and innovations to tackle the current global crisis.“Through this programme, we will encourage our student innovators, who are leveraging disruptive technologies, to find unique solutions to improve the management of the pandemic and contain further outbreaks. We hope that the new ideas that emerge will help us and our partners to step back and observe the changes and figure out ways of taking advantage of a horizon of innovative opportunities that are emerging,” Ravi Narayan said.

Title: Online fundraisers to help transgenders in city
Content: Hyderabad: With limited access to government welfare schemes and now a sudden loss of livelihood, the transgender community in the city is scrambling to support its vulnerable members. To overcome the crisis, community members say they are now relying on online fund-raising campaigns to provide economic relief to those at a heightened risk of poverty and ill health.“A majority of transgender persons eke out a living through begging and they buy food and medicines with the money they make each day. None of them have savings to fall back on. Keeping this is mind, we have started an online fund-raising campaign to support them at least for the next couple of months,” said Rachana Mudraboyina, a transgender activist.The Women and Transgender Organizations Joint Action Committee identified 200 transgender persons in the city who are vulnerable and are looking to provide them with a monthly basic income of Rs 5,000 through the online campaign over the next two months.“Although community members were promised a sum of Rs 2,000 from the government, over 75% of them might not receive it as they do not have bank accounts. We are trying to figure out a way to identify those people so that we can at least provide some groceries and economic relief through the online campaign,” said Mudraboyina.The campaign - Help The Hyderabad Transgender Community During Covid-19 Crisis, requests people to donate so that the transgender people in Hyderabad provide for themselves and their families with food, medicine and other essential supplies to stay safe. Meanwhile, the community members with the help and support of few NGOs and individuals have collected groceries and other essentials to distribute among themselves.

Title: Extending a helping hand from behind bars
Content: Hyderabad: The prisons department is doing its bit to help fight coronavirus pandemic. It has started home delivery of hygiene kits, including santisers, handwash, soaps, phenyl and face masks, under its ‘My nation’ brand.With sanitisers going off the shelves and unreasonably priced in some stores, the prisons department has offered a hygiene kit at Rs 900, including delivery charges. The kit contains two sanitisers, two handwash liquids, two soaps, two black phenyl bottles and 12 washable masks.“This is being done without any profit motive but to rise to the occasion and help people during the lockdown,” director general of prisons Rajiv Trivedi told TOI. The products manufactured at the Central Prison, Cherlapally, are being delivered to IT companies and gated communities. Most of the orders have been received from Madhapur area.“The price is far less than what is charged in the market,” Trivedi said.Every day, 100 kits are being made and delivered. Already, orders have been placed for 700 kits. The prisons department is getting calls from Delhi for the products, but the prison authorities are not entertaining requests from outside Hyderabad due to logistic reasons.“Before the lockdown was announced, we were in talks with Amazon and Flipkart for delivery of the products. This will be pursued after the situation normalises,” Trivedi said. Delivery personnel, who belong to the prisons department, have also now being asked to collect payments through digital platforms and not take cash.The prisons department, it may be mentioned here, manufactures many products including school furniture, which is mainly bought by big companies to donate them under the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) activity.

Title: Coimbatore: Five-year-old breaks piggy bank to fight Covid-19
Content:
S Reno Joshua (second from right) donated all the money he had saved in his piggy bank

COIMBATORE: A five-year-old boy from Siddhapudur in the city on Monday donated all his piggy bank savings (Rs 7,000) to the collector’s relief fund as a gesture of fight against the Covid-19 pandemic.

The boy – S Reno Joshua, had saved the amount from the gifts he had received in the past three years. He handed over the entire amount to district collector K Rajamani on Monday.

“A couple of days ago, Reno saw the visuals of how guest workers in the city were struggling during the lockdown. He shot a series of questions towards us after seeing visuals. When we explained about the difficulties that they had been undergoing, he said that he wanted to donate his piggy bank savings,” Reno’s father Suresh said.

“Even though we have been thinking of using the money to admit our three-and-a-half-year-old daughter in school this year, we did not want to set a bad example by stopping him from donating the money,” he said, adding that they have decided to postpone the admission of their daughter by a year.

“We can understand the difficulties of staying away from home especially when the country is locked down completely,” he added.

Similarly, RM Mathivanan, 64, an auto driver, donated a sum of Rs 10,000 to the collector’s relief fund on Monday. He is the president of Jaishanthi auto stand at Singanallur and a member of Labour Progressive Federation (LPF). “Even though the amount is big, I donated the money because I wanted to support the government in its fight against Covid-19,” he said.

Title: 51-year-old serves fellow Surtis by donating, collecting blood
Content:
Yogesh Dhimar

SURAT: While many others were sitting idle at their homes, this 51-year-old resident Jivan Vihar Society on Rander Road in Surat was extremely busy on Saturday. He had a mission — that of collecting as much blood as he can that day.

And so, Yogesh Dhimar called up his friends, relatives, and even foe, if need be, to donate their blood so that not a single patient in the city hospitals have to suffer from a shortage of blood during the lockdown.

"On Saturday, we called Surat Raktadan Kendra and Research Centre's mobile van near my residence for blood donation. I called up my friends who regularly donate blood to come and donate to save lives. Following all protocols for Covid-19, we collected 47 units of blood on Saturday,” said Dhimar, who earlier helped collect 93 units of blood.

Talking to TOI, he said that with the enforcement of the lockdown, it is important that regular blood donors ensure that that they donate so that the blood banks do not run out of its required stock of blood.

In fact, last week Dhimar received an emergency call from Surat Raktdan Kendra at 7am asking him if he could donate blood at the blood bank . Dhimar was there within 20 minutes and donated SDP. “While donating blood , I always pray that the patient who receives my blood should get well soon and should never ever require blood in the future,'' said the man who runs coaching classes, and has donated blood 190 times till now which includes 125 time SDP (single donor platelets).

His blood donation journey began in October 1989 and vows it will continue till it there is blood to be shared in his body. Dhimar is also an active member of blood donation awareness campaigns.

"There are more than 200 people, mostly my friends, whom I convinced to donate blood and have now become regular blood donors,'' he added.

Title: Police must show restraint: High court to DGP
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: The high court on Monday directed the state Director General and Inspector General of Police (DG&IGP) to issue a circular on the lines of the one issued by the Bengaluru police commissioner, asking police to show restraint while implementing the lockdown.

A division bench of chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka and justice BV Nagarathna gave this direction after holding a special sitting via video conferencing to consider various issues related to the outbreak of Covid-19 virus.

During the 160-minute hearing, many petitioners expressed concern over police beating up citizens while enforcing the lockdown. A report was also sought on an incident in Sanjaynagar where police claimed that two persons attacked policemen on duty.

The bench said citizens must also be co-operative with the administration.

When some petitioners expressed concern over the supply of safety equipment to BBMP pourakarmikas who collect waste from houses of quarantined persons, the court asked the government to respond.

On the issue of food security, the court said the state can direct gram panchayats to take care of food security of persons living within their jurisdiction.

The court noted that authorities must look into the aspect of community transmission of coronavirus if cooked food is supplied through Indira Canteens, there will be mass gathering of people.

On April 3, the next date of hearing, the state must inform as to how pregnant women, lactating mothers and malnourished children will be provided with meals in view of closure anganwadis. It must also submit a status report on providing protective equipment to doctors and private hospitals, the number of labs available to test coronavirus.

Title: Classrooms locked down, Lucknow University teachers start ‘OPD’
Content:
Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: A few teachers of the Lucknow University have taken the online way to start ‘Our Pupils’ Day (OPD)’ a programme scheduled from March third week, but which could not be initiated because of the lockdown.

Under the programme, a teacher has to reserve an hour on a designated day every week to counsel students on academic and personal issues. Students can walk-in to the teacher’s chamber for one-to-one session. The twin objectives are to strengthen student-teacher bonding and help students to remain stress-free.

Without waiting for the lockdown to be over, teachers of some departments, including physics, journalism, law and mathematics have started OPDs through video calls. However, instead of one-to-one, most held group sessions. Individual counselling will be held later, they said.

Prof Anurag Srivastava of law department devoted Sunday for counselling. “Students are worried about their future due to academic closure and needed to be assured that teachers would do everything possible to prevent the session from being delayed, he said.

Prof Poonam Tandon of physics department, who ran a group online OPD on Saturday, said “Around 38 students turned up for the session. Since most had concerns about unavailability of books due to the lockdown, we decided to make e-content and e-books available to them.

Title: Karnataka: H1N1 drug speeds up recovery for some
Content: BENGALURU: Karnataka ’s first six Covid-19 patients are all home now, after more than 14 days of hospitalisation and testing negative twice in a gap of 24 hours. And, it’s Tamiflu, an antiviral drug used to treat Influenza A H1N1, that has helped them recover from the infection which has wreaked havoc across the world.Besides Tamiflu, the patients were administered paracetamol and supportive drugs. In fact, two of the six cured patients were hardly given any medicine as they had no symptoms.While there were reports of Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) drugs being used for treating Covid-19 patients in China, Government of India guidelines specified Tamiflu and other supportive drugs. The dosage of Tamiflu suggested was 75mg twice a day for five days.“There is no specific medicine for Covid-19 and we are giving symptomatic treatment only. For some of the patients, bronchodilators in the form of injections were used to clear the congestion in chest. In some cases, nebulisation was also used,” said a doctor who has treated more than five Covid-19 cases so far in a government hospital in Bengaluru.“Though Covid-19 is a virus affecting the respiratory system, because of prolonged hospital stay, there were chances of patients developing bacterial infections as well. Hence in some cases, along with other drugs, antibiotics were given,” he added.One patient was given Tamiflu, crocin and regular steam inhalation.
