Most patients in Karnataka have suffered mild to moderate infection, the authorities said.The doctors noticed that symptoms varied from patient to patient. “While there were some patients who hardly required any medicine, one had very high fever of 102 degree Fahrenheit for more than a week,” a doctor said.A 69-year-old woman who is being treated in a private hospital was on oxygen support when she had breathing issues during the first week. “The woman also had chronic kidney disorder. Her age and pre-existing health condition were a concern. But she has also recovered well with treatment. Her tests have been negative twice in a gap of 24 hours. She will be discharged soon,” said doctors treating the woman.

Title: Betrayed, locals put up posters seeking their ‘missing’ MLAs
Content:
PANAJI: A widely-circulated message on social media called constituents of the Thivim constituency to “gather in large numbers” outside the police station to lodge a missing complaint. It was about their MLA, as everyone said he was nowhere to be seen in “times of need.”

There are posters doing the rounds about Mapusa MLA Joshua D’Souza and Vasco MLA Carlos Almeida. Both are identical and have missing written in bold, all over it. Their constituents had not seen either of them and egged on “whoever has seen them” to drop them back at their constituency’s popular points and take home rewards.

In these times of coronavirus and lockdown when there is shortage of food and essentials, people are looking at their elected representatives for help.

Not just MLAs , but also panchs, councillors and sarpanchs. When they are not seen, they have resorted to innovative ways like posters and messages on social media to get them out of their self-imposed quarantines.

Almost all politicians were active in their constituencies ahead of the zilla panchayat elections, which were first deferred by two days to March 24 and then eventually postponed indefinitely after a public furore against Pramod Sawant-led government for putting people’s lives at risk.

“During festival, ration was sent to respective homes. How beautifully you organised everything. Just inquiring, where are you now? Is all that only to secure the votes for you to get elected? Come on, get out now, go house to house to distribute ration, your constituents are not aware where to find food. Remember, if you don’t show your face now, do you think we will recognise you later?”, states one message that is doing the rounds.

Not every elected representative has gone into a shell. Some MLAs are proactive and have involved their close aides to supply essential commodities to the people. Calangute MLA Michael Lobo and Taleigao MLA Jennifer Monserrate distributed fresh vegetable even before the government started procuring vegetables through the horticulture corporation.

The Corporation of the City of Panaji, controlled by local MLA Atanasio Monserrate, started house to house delivery on the day state government declared lockdown.

In South, deputy chief minister Chandrakant Kavlekar and Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco have both been seen monitoring sale of vegetables and fish, respectively.

With everyone locked at home, social media has become the best outlet to vent out frustrations. Through social media, people have questioned their MLAs, most of whom are active on Twitter and issue statements at every given opportunity. All of them have been told, now is the time to make your presence felt on the ground and ensure essential supplies to the public.

If they don’t show up, more posters and missing complaints are likely to follow.

Title: School mgmts announce relief in fees for students
Content: RAJKOT: In a major relief to the parents amid the coronavirus lockdown, two schools, one each in Bhavnagar and Rajkot , have either waved off the students' fees or brought about reduction in them.In Bor Talav locality of Bhavnagar, Takshashila Vidyalaya waved off Rs 6 lakh fees supposed to be paid by its 800 students.The Sunrise School of Rajkot has decided to reduce its fees by 20%.“The other schools should take a cue from these two schools in Bhavnagar and Rajkot and declare such a relief for their students and parents in this time of crisis,” said an official from Rajkot district administration.Takshshila Vidyalaya trustee Ashok Patel told TOI: “Most of the students of our school come from the lower middle class families. As we are deeply concerned about their parents as to how will they be able to manage to mobilize funds after the lockdown period is over, we have taken this decision.”“Most of the parents are engaged in small time businesses and job works. They are at present incurring financial losses due to the lockdown. In order to mitigate their sufferings, our school trust has taken this decision,” added Patel.Similarly, Wonderland Stem Kindergarten in Hill Drive locality of Bhavnagar has decided to waive off three months fees of its students.“In order not to burden the parents of our students and lessen their sufferings in such trying times, we have taken this decision,” said Sarla Soparia, the owner of the kindergarten.

Title: With no relief in sight for Britishers, common people step out to help in Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: In the weeks to come, when the thousand-odd tourists stranded in Goa reach home, they will think not only about their ordeal in the wake of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, but also of the handful of unsung heroes in Goa who helped them in their plight.

While German, Russian and a few other foreign citizens received prompt response from their government, British tourists felt abandoned by the British Foreign Office. And as India’s lockdown unfolded, common people stepped in to fill the sudden void that they found themselves stuck in.

From faceless locals who provided food to foreigners out of compassion, to the helpline set up by the Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG), and from small hoteliers offering free stays, to a store manager in UK , many people pitched in to provide succour.

When UK supermarket store manager Peter Mendes heard that two of his colleagues were stuck in India, he and one of the colleague created a WhatsApp group and invited other Britons stuck in India to join. As the numbers crossed 70, the former Chinchinim boy began to write to British MPs urging them to organise rescue flights.

“I managed to get some passengers back home thanks to help from the German embassy in New Delhi,” Mendes said. A student of Loyola High School, Margao, Mendes contacted some of his classmates to seek help for British nationals stuck in South Goa.

Up north, the TTAG set up a helpline for foreigners and began frantically calling embassies to explore the possibility of rescue flights. “Many homestays and smaller hotels wanted to get rid of the guests, telling them to vacate. We tried to get all the tourists in one place and one of our members came forward to take them in. We also compiled the list and passport details of all those here in Goa to give to the embassies,” hotelier and former president of TTAG Savio Messias said.

Even as the UK government kept asking its citizens to be patient, another group of Britons, who have been visiting Goa for decades, decided to help out. Cath Hargreaves and David Morphey used their Facebook group and local contacts to keep foreigners updated about flights operated by other nations. Simultaneously, Morphey acted as a liaison with the British High Commission on behalf of over 1,000 British nationals stuck in Goa.

But if one wants to find the true spirit of atithi devo bhava, the small family-run hotels in the Cavelossim-Varca belt are the place to go. In Tamborim at Dona Sa Maria, hotelier Serafino Cota has offered tourists stay at his hotel for free till they get a chance to fly out. “As of now, we are offering tourists a place to stay and food at cost, something like a western thali. The guests said that they can afford to pay till March 31. After that I have told them I shall not charge,” Cota said.

Title: How a Dehradun institute is readying visually & hearing-impaired people for a fight against Covid-19
Content: DEHRADUN: In tune with the government’s efforts to spread information about novel coronavirus and contain its spread, an institute in Dehradun is playing its part to keep the hearing and visually-impaired community fully aware about the contagious disease.National Institute for the Empowerment of Persons with Visual Disabilities (NIEPVD), which comes under the ministry of social justice and empowerment, is producing contents in the form of audio files and in sign-language videos so that those who cannot hear or see are also aware about the disease.According to the World Bank, nearly 1 billion people in the world experience some form of disability and it is extremely important that this large population is not left behind in the fight against Covid-19.The institute which primarily caters to visually impaired people told TOI that all the health advisories and news regarding Covid-19 is being converted into a format which is more convenient for the visually and hearing-impaired people.“Within days of the first advisory came out from health ministry, we converted it into Braille script for the convenience of the visually impaired people. Then those scripts were sent out to 500 organisations which are in some way associated with the NIEPVD. These 500-odd organisations work for the benefit of physically and intellectually disabled people and each organisation caters to more than 700 people with disabilities of different kinds.“Later, we realised that it’s better not to pass on information through some paper since it can act as a carrier for the coronavirus. So, it was better to pass on most of the information through electronic mode, a non-touchable mode,” said Nachiketa Rout, director of NIEPVD.Despite the staff not being able to come to the institute, the audio and video files are being churned out on a daily basis. In order to make sure that there is no shortage of content, the institute is making use of its staff which works in its Composite Regional Centre in Sunder Nagar, Himachal Pradesh “Our staff converted all the advisories into audio formats. In order to access the audio, we placed QR codes on e-pamphlets which can be found on our website and they have been circulated across other organisations too. The e-pamphlets have summarised points but in order to get to know in detail one has to scan the QR code. For instance, the e-pamphlet will have a point to maintain social distancing but in order to know the reason behind, one has to scan the QR code and get the details in audio format. We also have a team in Sunder Nagar which is also contributing to content material,” added Rout.The institute also converted advisories into video formats for hearing-impaired people.Rout further said, “Later, we realised that there is a large community of hearing-impaired people and it is important for them also to be aware of Covid-19. So we decided to convert advisories into video formats too in which they will be explained in sign language.“Our institute generally caters to only visually impaired people. Yet we produced sign language videos for the hearing disabled people so that they don’t feel left behind and know about preventive measures against Covid-19. The communication between a deaf and a blind is next to impossible and we have content which is made for both of them available on our NIEPVDwebsite.”The NIEPVDs efforts were appreciated by the ministry of social justice and empowerment. Recently, one of the videos made by the institute was even shared on the Prime Minister’s Twitter handle. The institute told TOI that the circulation of their content is increasing daily.NIEPVD will soon come up with a 5-minute daily health bulletin in which measures against Covid-19 will be read out. They will also be told in sign language.

Title: IMFL recovered from car, driver arrested
Content:
Representative image

RAJKOT: A car which had a sign board of executive magistrate and Gujarat health department was impounded with a bottle of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) near Digjam Circle in Jamnagar on Sunday evening. Its driver was arrested from the spot.

“We found 500 ML of IMFL in a bottle from the car and arrested its driver Govind Parmar," said an official from Jamnagar C division police station.

“We are yet to probe whether the car indeed belongs to the executive magistrate and the government health department as it is mentioned in the sign board,” added the official.

Title: Over 15,000 enrol in youth defence force
Content:
Kollam: In response to Kerala state youth commission ’s call to join the ‘ youth defence force ’, a first of its kind in the country, a large number of people aged between 18 and 40 years, joined the force to offer voluntary service to people in distress. More than 15,000 people, including film personalities and sportspersons , enrolled themselves as volunteers within a week of its launch.

Speaking to TOI, commission chairperson Chintha Jerome said as the chief minister wanted the youths to volunteer themselves to serve as bystanders, the commission asked those joining the force to indicate whether they are ready to function as bystanders.

“Actually, we never expected such a massive response. But, out of the 15,000 youths who have registered online as volunteers, 1,465 of them have consented to be deployed as bystanders,” she said. She also pointed out that while the “sannadham” volunteer force being constituted by the government is enrolling youth between 22 and 40 years, the youth defence force is enrolling those aged between 18 and 40 years.

“We have film stars Tovino Thomas, Sunny Wayne, director Arun Gopi, footballer C K Vineeth among those registered online. Directors Major Ravi and Sreekumar Menon also have offered to join though they have already crossed the age limit,” she added.

Half of those enrolled are young women. Once the list of the youth defence force is ready, local bodies could conveniently deploy them, Jerome said adding that once the crisis related to Covid-19 spread is over, the commission would consider providing training to the force.

Title: 200ml bottle of sanitizer priced at Rs 100 in Lucknow
Content: LUCKNOW: The Union ministry of consumer affairs, food and public distribution has fixed the price of sanitizer at Rs 100 per 200 ml in the wake of spread of coronavirus infection.According to the gazette notification issued by the ministry on March 21, the prices of other quantities of sanitizer shall be fixed in proportion of these prices. The notification shall remain in force up to June 30.Likewise, retail prices of the melt blown non-woven fabric used in manufacturing of masks shall not be more than the prices prevailing on February 12, the notification said.The prices shall come into force from the date of the publication of the official gazette. This order may be called the fixation of prices of masks and hand sanitizers order, 2020.The notification categorically said: “In exercise of the powers conferred under sub-section 2A and section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act 1955, the Central government hereby makes the following order to regulate the prices of masks and hand sanitizers for preventing infection due to Covid-19 virus.”

Title: Govt cracks whip on black marketing of essentials
Content: JAIPUR: Rajasthan government officials have been cracking the whip on those traders who are indulging in black marketing of essential goods following the lockdown According to officials, in just 24 hours, 1,302 inspections were held by the food and consumer department following which 63 cases were booked for black marketing of food and other items, while in another 1,040 inspections by the department related to overpricing of masks, sanitisers and other medical supplies, 83 cases were registered for charging above maximum retail price. Since March 24, a total of 592 such cases have been registered.There has been a rise in the greedy practice of overpricing as many retailers and distributors of food and medical supplies tend to take advantage of the lockdown imposed to contain Covid-19, claimed officials. The issue has drawn concern of chief minister Ashok Gehlot, who has instructed for a strict crackdown on such malpractices.In compliance of the directives, a large number of inspection drives are being held in addition to those initiated on citizen complaints.It is unfortunate that while most citizens willingly abide to the lockdown in the wake of the pandemic, a few unruly elements have been compromising the efforts and adding to the hardships of citizens.The state government has also been strict against the non-essential business establishments violating the lockdown and has registered 50 such cases in which action has already been initiated in 34 complaints.In addition to the disciplinary action against the violations, efforts are also being made to extend relief to public at large. Supply has been provided by government in 585 cases of food and commodities shortage, while in at least 1,381 locations food has been extended to needy people. Shortage of medical supplies has also been addressed in 63 cases.As the lockdown advances in its second week, the officials are also maintaining a keen vigil on the law and order situation. Due action has been initiated in 99 cases related to illegal activities by anti-social elements, transition of residents and immigrants and other related issues.

Title: UP to rope in private hospitals for corona patients’ treatment
Content: LUCKNOW: After bringing private medical colleges onboard to combat coronavirus , the state government has decided to tie up with private hospitals having more than 100 beds to accommodate patients in case of emergency.Principal secretary, health and family welfare, Amit Mohan Prasad said, “We have started empanelling private hospitals which are willing to collaborate. These hospitals will be converted into Covid hospitals.” Under the plan, the state health department is designing a package to rope in private hospitals. “The package will decide the per month cost of utilization of each facility. This means that for general patients, treatment of coronavirus will be extended in select private facilities free of cost just like government hospitals,” a senior officer, involved in formulating the details of tie-ups, said.Officials said either the government would bear the cost of treatment or would mobilise funds to clear the dues. “Efforts are on to bring corporates on board who can bear the cost of development and maintenance of private Covid-19 hospitals. They are being encouraged to contribute through their corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds which can be a win-win formula for all stakeholders – public, private hospitals, state government and corporates,” a senior officer said.Sources, said the government is in talks with prominent private hospitals in Lucknow and Noida and is likely to reach out to 20 hospitals in a week.

Title: 10 bridges connecting south and north Madurai shut
Content:
Madurai: The city police have closed all the 10 bridges, that connect the southern and northern parts of Madurai, in a stricter measure to control crowd movement in the wake of Covid-19. Earlier, police had only made deployments at important junctions and allowed those who came to purchase essentials.

Meanwhile, corporation officials closed down around 50 shops in various parts of the city including Ellis Nagar, Kamarajar Salai, South Veli Street and South Marret Street for operating the stores by violating restrictions and without streamlining customers with the mandatory social distancing.

A large number of residents came out of their houses and roamed around the city to purchase vegetables, meat, fruits and groceries. Most of the markets represented a normal day as people threw curfew restrictions to the wind. Appalled over the people’s behaviour, police ushered in stricter measures to close down all the bridges.

Except those like the AV Bridge, Yaanaikkal Puthupalam, PTR Bridge and Kamarajar Bridge, where people are let in for essential purposes, others like the Kuruvikkaran Salai Bridge, Temporary Road in Vaigai river next to Kurivikkaran, Obulapadithurai bridge, MGR Bridge, Amma bridge and LIC Bridge were completely shut. Good vehicles carrying essentials, vehicles with pass and ambulances were allowed to pass.

A police officer said, “Monday was better as there were fewer vehicles on the road due to stringent restrictions. People start violating social distancing norms even if we relax the measures a bit.”

A large number of shopkeepers were arrested for opening shops, violating curfew norms. They were released later. Although there is an instruction not to open grocery stories in East Masi Street for retail, many had opened on Sunday morning, causing heavy crowd. Many shopkeepers were booked by the city police. They were strictly warned against open shops only at night for wholesale trading. A total of 43 cases were registered on Sunday, mostly against shopkeepers, for violating the restrictions.

Madurai district police registered 225 cases against people for wandering unnecessarily on roads and arrested 294 people. A total of 196 vehicles were impounded.

Title: He did what the kin denied: Last rites of 1st COVID-19 victim
Content:
Abdul Rehman Malbari, president of Ekta Trust, didn’t think twice

SURAT: He had just finished his routine work of cremating an unclaimed body of a beggar at Jehangirpura crematorium when he received a call from a health officer of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) for disposing of the body of a 67-year-old man, the first COVID-19 fatality in Gujarat on March 22.

Without giving a second thought of getting infected with the deadly virus, he reached Mahavir Hospital in Athwalines where the COVID-19 positive man had breathed his last.

Abdul Rehman Malbari, 51, is president of Ekta Trust, an NGO which has been providing funeral service for abandoned and unclaimed bodies for the last three decades. He performed the last rites of the COVID-19 victim with his three team members at Umara crematorium. The loved ones of the victim were too scared to go near the body out of fear of getting infected.

“I don’t remember putting on masks or gloves in my 32 years of service. But this case was very different. I was made to cover my entire body with four pairs of protective clothes. We lifted the body, kept in our ambulance and drove towards the crematorium at Umara. There we were asked to put our protective clothes at the crematorium too. All four of us and our vehicle were disinfected. After 30 minutes of exercise and standing under the sunlight, we left the crematorium with prayers that there should be no more deaths due to COVID-19,” he said.

As the news spread that he had cremated a COVID-19 dead, people began to keep distance while talking to him. “For a few days, I had to face social distancing from even people close to me. Only my family members were not scared. When the people saw that I was healthy, they started coming closer to me without any fear,” said Malbari, father of four children and a loving husband.

Lockdown or no lockdown, Malbari’s voluntary funeral service never stops. He is single point contact for the administration for the disposal of unclaimed bodies. “Even during lockdown, my work has not stop. Apart from spreading awareness on COVID-19, we dispose of about three unclaimed bodies with dignity at crematoriums and graveyards every day,” says Malbari, who has disposed of more than 70,000 unclaimed bodies in the last three decades.

Malbari’s Ekta Trust has won accolades from the state government and the local administration for rendering its services during natural disasters, be it devastating floods in Uttarkhand in 2013, Tsunami in Chennai, earthquake in Kutch in 2001 and floods in Surat in 2006.

Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner), said, “Malbari is the only contact in the city for disposing of unclaimed bodies. Since Malbari has wide experience in handling decomposed bodies, we asked him to dispose of the body of COVID-19 victim.”

Title: Rajkot: Three arrested for youth’s murder
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

RAJKOT: Three persons were arrested on Monday for allegedly beating a youth to death in Kukaras village of Veraval taluka in Gir Somnath district on the night of March 27.

Police said the accused, identified as Jagmal Bambhania (45), his wife Labhu Bambhania (42) and his brother Balu Bambhania (47), had attacked Jigar Solanki (25) and his brother Prakash Solanki (24) with bats and iron pipes.

While Prakash survived the attack with injuries, Jigar died during treatment at a private hospital in Veraval.

“The accused had attacked the Solanki brothers, harbouring a grudge against Jigar who had a live-in relationship with Jagmal’s daughter Payal. Jagmal was against the relationship and wanted to teach Jigar a lesson,” said G M Rathwa, inspector with Prabhas Patan police station.

Jagmal was particularly angry with Jigar as Payal had divorced her husband at the instance of Jigar in order to enter into relationship with Jigar.

Title: Covid-19: V O Chidambaranar Port allays fears on goods handling
Content: MADURAI: V O Chidambaranar Port in Tuticorin has stated that operations of the seaport are covered under essential services and are exempted from the nationwide lockdown to ensure that essential goods are available to public in a seamless manner. The basic commodities handled by the port include coal for thermal power generation, petroleum products, edible oil and food grains and mission critical medical equipment.They requested people not to believe in rumours spread by uninformed elements with respect to ships and crew calling on the port. The port officials stated that they have also requested the Tuticorin district collector to take appropriate action against those spreading rumours. They said that bulk commodities and container are handled through mechanised means and it requires minimum human intervention or working in large groups.As per the orders issued by DG ( Shipping ), vessels directly arriving from any port in China or transiting through Chinese ports are allowed for berthing only after quarantine period of 14 days from the date of departure of the vessel from the last Chinese port. Vessels arriving from ports of other affected countries as identified by the ministry of health and family welfare will also be permitted after 14 days of departure from those ports.In case of vessels having seafarers who embarked from infected regions, the countdown of 14 days for the entire vessel will begin from the day on which the person embarked the vessel to arrive at the port here. Ship sanitation exemption certificate or the medicine chest certificate and the international health regulations 2005- nCoV 2019 should be sent by the ship agent prior to 72 hours of arrival to the Port Health Officer (PHO).After scrutiny of the documents and screening procedures, clearance is granted by the PHO for carrying out discharge of cargo operations by the port.VOC port has clarified that no crew disembarking is allowed and no shore passes are issued to crew members to prevent them from leaving the ship and to ensure safe operations.The ministry of home affairs and issued orders to keep the supply chain operating at the times of crisis and serve the needs of the public.

Title: Kerala PSC extends validity of rank lists
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala public service commission (PSC) has extended the validity of the rank lists for recruitment to various posts expiring with effect from March 20, 2020, for another three months considering the lockdown . As per an official release issued by the PSC on Monday, the rank lists which was to expire from March 20 to June 18, 2020, will be valid till June 19, 2020.

Later, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, while announcing the PSC decision during his routine press conference, said that that the rank lists will be valid till June 19, 2020, or till a new rank list is published for filling up the particular vacancies. Meanwhile, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala demanded a six-month extension for the ranks lists.tnn

Title: Madurai: Cash, groceries for only 100 people per day in each PDS from April 2
Content:
MADURAI: The Rs 1,000 announced for ration card holders in Madurai district from April 2, will be distributed through the public distribution shops (PDS) at the rate of 50 in the morning and 50 in the evening in each shop, minister for cooperatives Sellur K Raju has said. The minister said that there are 2.40 crore ration cards in the state of which 1.86 crore are white rice cards. As a relief measure for the lockdown period, the TN government has announced Rs 1,000 cash and groceries for the card holders.

He said the district administration and police are taking steps to ensure organised supply of the money and goods to the people. It had been planned to distribute the groceries and money to 50 cards in the morning and 50 more in each shop from April 2. The sales personnel in the shops will get 50 paise incentive for each product in this process.

As many as 2,590 guest workers in Madurai district are now in the care of their employers. Food was being distributed to the homeless people in the district through NGOs. People should extend their full co-operation to the district administration, Raju said.

Title: UP government transfers Rs 611 crore in bank accounts of 27 lakh MNREGA workers
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: The government on Monday cleared dues of workers under Mnrega as chief minister Yogi Adityanath transferred Rs 611 crore into accounts of 27.15 lakh workers.

To facilitate withdrawal of the financial assistance given by the state, banks will remain open till 4 pm. The treasury and bank branches will also work on April 2 which is a public holiday on the occasion of Ram Navami.

The CM also interacted with four workers from Bahraich, Varanasi, Sonbhadra and Deoria through video-conferencing on Monday and spoke to them about the Mnrega scheme. “The rural development department and State Bank of India have come together to ensure the success of this scheme. The importance of this assistance is clear when one sees the condition of workers migrating from one state to another due to the lockdown,” the CM said.

The government also announced that free ration for three months will be given to MNRGA workers, while the Centre has announced 1 kg pulses and free gas cylinders to labourers under the Ujjwala scheme.

Meanwhile, 8.20 lakh construction workers have been given Rs1,000 each by the state as financial assistance for the period of the lockdown. Officials said that Rs 2.02 crore was released on Monday.

The CM announced that women beneficiaries, who have accounts under the Centre’s ‘Jan Dhan Yojana ’, will get an additional Rs 500 per month. The Centre will also provide Rs 1,000 per month to old age, destitute women and divyang jan pension holders for three months.

The state government has already announced that pension for this quarter be issued to beneficiaries in April, two months ahead of the scheduled date.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: 6 more test positive, total count now 76
Content: HYDERABAD: Telangana reported six new positive cases, taking the overall count to 76 so far. According to a health bulletin released by the government, 13 people, who had earlier tested positive to Covid-19 had also recovered and were released from the Gandhi hospital during the day.The bulletin said since the outbreak of the disease, 14 patients have recovered so far, which health authorities said it was a silver lining.Among the six are two family members of a Karimnagar resident, who had earlier tested positive.He had hosted a group of Indonesian preachers who visited Karimnagar on March 14 and one among them was the first to test positive for Covid-19 at Gandhi hospital in Secunderabad.According to Karimnagar district collector Shashanka, the two persons did not show any symptoms of coronavirus but once heath authorities got them tested, the result turned positive.“Since they tested positive, all the seven members of the family, including two children were shifted to Gandhi hospital for observation,” said a senior official.The district authorities have urged the local people in Karimnagar town, where the Indonesian group had visited to cooperate with health staff, who have been asked to continue their house-to-house visits. Karimnagar commissioner of police V B Kamalasan Reddy asked people who are below the age of 35 to register with the police as volunteers, if they wish to assist the police. “Their services will be utilized at market places to see that the public follow social distancing,” he said.There has, however, been a marked number of patients who have been responding well to treatment due to the efforts of healthcare workers in the state. With strict following of social distancing, experts feel that the state will be able to tide over the crisis effectively and quickly.

Title: Govt schools, pvt buildings to shelter migrants
Content: Jaipur: Government schools, hotels and dharamshalas in Jaipur district will be used as temporary shelter homes for the migrant workers or homeless people.Thousands of migrant workers have been travelling back to their home towns after they were left jobless due to the lockdown . These workers risk contracting the coronavirus infection.Hence, Jaipur district collector Jogaram on Monday issued orders to acquire the buildings of seven government schools in Jaipur and other cities in the district including Chomu, Dudu, Sanganer, Bassi, Amber (Delhi Road), Amber (Sikar Road), Chaksu, Phagi and Kotputli. Besides, dharamshalas, hotels, hostels and other buildings will be acquired as well.As per the orders, all the school buildings identified should be ready for acquisition immediately. Officials and principals have been asked to make proper arrangements for electricity, water and toilets in the schools.Medical officials have been asked to make proper arrangements for isolation facilities and testing of suspicious persons at the schools. If there is any violation of the orders, then the owners of the buildings or officers in-charge will be dealt as per law.

Title: Surat woman dies in Bhavnagar, four test positive
Content: RAJKOT: A 45-year-old woman infected with novel Coronavirus died in Bhavnagar on Monday even as four other people tested positive in the same city on Sunday night.Bhavnagaar district development officer (DDO), VJ Baranwal said, “The woman had tested positive on Sunday late night and died during the treatment on Monday morning.”A native of a village in Jesar taluka, the woman had migrated from Surat few days ago and was suffering from lung infection and cerebrovascular accident (CVA). She was taking treatment in a private hospital and was referred to government hospital on Sunday.According to Bhavnagar Municipal Corporation (BMC), four men aged 65 years, 55 years, 50 years and 92 years, also tested positive on Sunday late night.District collector Gaurang Makwana said, “We strongly suspect that three out of these four persons were the contact with a person who died earlier on March 26 . We did cluster containment of whole area the person died four days back.” The 70-year-old victim had travelled to Delhi.Meanwhile, a 28-year-old man in Rajkot is also suspected positive and under treatment at a private hospital. According to official sources, he reportedly came in the contact with a COVID-19 patient in Ahmedabad during his visit.

Title: Amid crisis, Centre hikes MNREGS wages in UP by 10%
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Amid the nationwide lockdown, the cental government has increased wages under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MNREGS) for Uttar Pradesh from Rs 182 to Rs 201, a hike of Rs 19 translating to over 10%, one of the highest in recent times. The new wages will become applicable from April 1.

MNREGS wages for UP had been increased by Re 1 in 2016-17 to Rs 175, remained stagnant in to-18 and 2018-19 and was hiked by Rs 7 to Rs 182 in 2019-20.Additional commissioner, MNREGS, Yogesh Kumar said the wage increase will help in tackling rural distress and raise consumption to boost rural economy. The wages are fixed by the Centre on the basis of inputs given by social research organisations. States with higher economic productivity have been receiving higher wages under MNREGS, he added.

“The states like UP and Uttarakhand had been lagging due to this and hence the increase this year is significant and can help 85 lakh people who have active job cards,” Kumar told TOI. Dadar and Nagar Haveli and Maharashtra have registered highest increase in MNREGS wages of Rs 34 and Rs 32 respectively. Likewise, MNREGS wages in Gujarat and Punjab have been upwardly revised by Rs 25 and Rs 22 respectively.

Title: ‘No demand charge from power bills’
Content:
Nashik: The Maharashtra Chamber of Commerce, Industry & Agriculture (MACCIA) has urged the state government not to levy demand charges and other surcharge on electricity bills to the industries during the lockdown period.

The body has also urged that industries should be charged on the basis of the actual power consumed by them.

MACCIA state president Santosh Mandlecha has written a letter to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray , state energy minister Nitin Raut and chairman & managing director of Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Ltd (MSEDCL) in this regard. “The state government started the lockdown from March 21. Now, the Centre has extended it till April 14. Hence, all industries have shut down and there will be no operation until the lockdown is lifted. Moreover, the industries also have to pay salaries of their employees,” he said.

“We want the government to waive the demand charges in electricity bills for the industries during the lockdown period. Electricity bills should be based on actual use of power. There is also a possibility of MSEDCL sending average bills,”he added.

Title: My stuff was thrown out of rented room: Migrant near Lucknow
Content:
Migrants being scanned at an isolation centre in Lucknow on Monday

LUCKNOW: Thousands of migrant workers from neighbouring states and districts thronged Lucknow on Monday.

The workers had reached Lucknow from Rajasthan, Delhi, Punjab, Haryana, and Maharashtra in the hope of getting means of transportation to reach their native places in eastern Uttar Pradesh .

Most were stopped and taken to Haj house on Kanpur Road for thermal scanning, while others coming from Agra Expressway were taken to Awadh Shilp Gram located on Rae Bareli Road.

In neighbouring districts including Unnao, Sitapur, Hardoi, Bahraich, Kanpur, Sultanpur and Amethi, too, migrant workers were scanned for temperature before being let in.

Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) buses stationed at border areas in Lucknow ferried 3,000 workers to their respective districts in 30 buses on Monday. Majority of the workers had arrived from National Capital Region (NCR).

“We have travelled 500km without proper food. We got no help after our tea stall was closed down in Ghaziabad. It catered to an MNC,” said Murli Vishwakarma of Bahraich district. Murli, with his family of six, had come all the way on foot.

Nagendra Kumar, who repaired watches in Delhi, was forced out of his rented room in Lajpatnagar a day after the lockdown. “My belonging were thrown out and I have been walking on foot since,” said Kumar, a native of Azamgarh.

CMO Sitapur Alok Verma said that his team of 50 workers was on duty to scan each migrant at Khairabad toll plaza. The district administration claims to have tested 5,000 workers.

District magistrate of Hardoi Pulkit Khare said that a team of health officials and police was scanning workers at Numaish crossing before they were sent to their villages. In Sultanpur and Amethi, the administration have scanned 4,000 workers. In Baharich, 2,500 were scanned on Monday.

Title: Village penalizes those sauntering around
Content: RAJKOT: A village in Amreli district took a suo motto decision to penalize people coming out of their homes during the lockdown period.In a bid to discourage people from roaming around and observe total lockdown, Devrajiya village started collecting penalty of Rs100 from the first-time offenders and Rs 500 from repeat offenders. This was the villagers’ own decision and not decided by its panchayat. So far, five people have been fined in the last two days. Kaushik Vekaria, a village leader, said, “People are now not coming out of their houses without any valid reason. The steep fine is discouraging people to break the law. It’s our moral responsibility to follow the rules of lockdown in this critical time.”

Title: GST waiver sought on equipment bought to combat Covid-19 using MPLADS
Content:
Madurai: More than Rs 10 lakh is the GST paid by Rajya Sabha MP A Vijayakumar for the purchase of emergency health care equipment for the Kanyakumari government medical college hospital using his Members of Parliament Local Area Development Scheme (MPLADS) fund. Last week the MP had allotted Rs 1 crore from his fund to strengthen preparedness to combat Covid-19.

The MP circulated a copy of the purchase order on social media to improve transparency. While the people of Kanyakumari have appreciated his contribution, the GST is attracting criticism as the amount is huge. Some said it is the price of three ventilators in the order.

“GST is applicable on all the sanctions using MPLADS. Effectively, around Rs 50 to Rs 75 lakh is deducted as GST from Rs 5 crore allotted annually under MPLADS. I am not against GST, but the government could consider waiving GST on emergency healthcare equipment bought to combat Covid-19. It will ensure that more money is spent on buying equipment,” Vijayakumar told TOI.

Vijayakumar said he will allot a sizeable share of his MPLADS for 2020-21 too for this cause and hopes the government will waive the 12% GST for this cause from April 1.

Madurai MP Su Venkatesan who has made a first instalment allotted Rs 56.17 lakh from MPLADS for lifesaving medical equipment and protective gear for health care professionals at the Madurai medical college hospital. “When the availability of ventilators is hit, why should GST be charged on it? The government should make lifesaving equipment GST free,” he said.

Tirunelveli MP S Gnanathiraviam who has allotted Rs 86 lakh from MPLADS said that the government should consider waiving GST for purchase of lifesaving equipment.

Vijayakumar got the equipment including nine ventilators installed at the Kanyakumari hospital by making multiple calls to people concerned and through highly influential persons in the health ministry as they talked of difficulty in getting the equipment delivered due to political pressure and tough competition from private hospitals pan India on the companies that have limited resources.

“I am planning to share difficulties I faced in getting the equipment in the social media,” Venkatesan said. Tuticorin MP Kanimozhi Karunanidhi has also allotted Rs 1 crore from MPLADS for purchase of testing, screening and personal protection equipment for healthcare professionals and for the purchase of other facilities in connection with combating Covid-19.

Title: Ground Zero milk supply halts, residents scramble for
Content:
Bhopal: Two days after Professors’ Colony was declared a containment area, the supply of milk — though grouped under the essential commodities — has been totally stopped to the locality.

The locality depends on two Sanchi parlours for its milk supply. Both the parlours have been shut from Monday, bringing the supply to a halt. The colony consumes over 600 liter of milk per day. As the people at the ‘ground zero’ have been barred from stepping out of their homes, they are left with no alternative to buy milk.

The entry points to the colony have been totally sealed. On an usual day, the supply chain of government-owned Sanchi milk starts in the midnight. Trucks carrying milk used to reach the colony around 4am.

“They have stopped milk supply saying that it will not be supplied till further orders by the state government,” owners of the parlour agency said.

People in the colony are now left with no option but to search for alternatives like packaged milk powder.

Rajesh Chaturvedi, a resident said, “All the people in the colony are complying against the government’s order that blocked the milk supply to the locality. But the essential commodities should be supplied.”

“Except the public announcement by the police to stay indoors and putting barricades on the entry points, nothing has been done. Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) units are yet to sanitize the area near my house,” said another resident, Lokendra Sharma, who lives near one of the two Sanchi parlours.

After the ‘patient zero’ was detected on March 22, the residents were in shock. Five days later, it was declared containment area (CA). Since then, there has hardly been any movement of the administration in the form of some survey or sanitization operations.

Two most important measures mentioned in the CA order issued by the additional district magistrate of Bhopal on Friday night include screening by the health officers at the exit points of the colony. The other is related to sanitization by the municipal corporation.

Containment area is defined as the first contact area of the reported positive case. The order also talks about no movement of people and vehicles in the defined zone.

Title: Decentralised veg markets, mobile stores big hit among residents
Content:
Madurai: Madurai Corporation’s move to decentralise vegetable markets after shifting them from permanent locations to avoid crowding has evoked good response from the residents. The mobile markets launched by the civic body also become a hit among the residents.

“I was about to buy 1kg of tomatoes for Rs 48 from the retailer in my area, when the corporation’s mobile market arrived at the very spot and I was able to buy the same for half the price,” said Santhanagopal of Karpagam Nagar.

The corporation has moved main markets including the Mattuthavani vegetable market and Thayir market to 14 main roads in the four zones of the corporation, where social distancing was better maintained. “I went to the new market for the first time and was relieved to see that there was good distance between me and the next buyer behind me and we were also able to buy things faster,” said Asokan who went to the market near Aavin junction on Monday.

“The vegetable price at the retail market is very high. I can only buy two items including onions and tomatoes for Rs 100 now, and it is difficult because I have not been working for the past few days,” said Arunkumar, a construction worker. He is forced to buy vegetables and groceries on a daily basis, and has to manage all with Rs 150.

People are now eager to know the locations and timings of the mobile markets at their wards. Residents associations have been receiving eager queries in this regard. Corporation sources said that the response to the decentralised markets is encouraging and that they are also managing to control the crowds.

Title: Govt cancels Rukuna Rath, priests fume
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Rukuna Rath, the annual chariot of Lord Lingaraj here, which was scheduled for April 1, will not be pulled due to the 21-day nationwide lockdown. This is the first cancellation of the Rath in recent memory.

Priests of the temple said no official or separate order announcing the cancellation of the annual festival had been issued by the district authorities or temple administration. “There is nothing more to say except that we are following the lockdown rules. It is clearly mentioned that no religious congregation or function can be observed during the lockdown. More than five persons cannot assemble at one place,” said Khurda collector Sitanshu Rout.

The district administration did not impose any restriction on the construction of the chariot, which was on for the past few days. The cancellation of the rath, thus, has led to resentment among priests and carpenters. “We had been working every day for the past three weeks from 9 am to 10 pm. Nearly a thousand logs had been collected for the construction of the chariot. Only the painting of the chariot was to be done,” said Batakrushna Maharana, the carpenter heading the team of artisans.

“The government is issuing so many orders every day. They could have easily issued another notice. Our effort and money would have been saved,” said Kamalakanta Badu, secretary of Badu Nijog, an association of priests at the 11th century Lingaraj temple.

Title: Life during curfew, first in three decades
Content:
Women distribute food among needy in Kamla Park in Bhopal on Monday

Bhopal: Residents in the state capital are witnessing a ‘curfew’ after almost three decades (since December 1992 (during riots post-Babri mosque demolition), but this is very different from those in the past. It warrants voluntary stay at home without a law and order issue to keep oneself and others safe.

Old time residents – the true Bhopalis— recount curfews in 1982 after dispute over a temple in Somwara, now famously known as Curfew Wali Mata Ka Mandir, in November 1984 after the assassination for former prime minister Indira Gandhi and in December 1984 after the leak of poisonous gas from the Union Carbide factory and in December 1992 in the aftermath of Babri demolition.

But, this curfew is very different from the past ones staying indoors to stay fight and fight an unknown enemy in the form coronavirus and try to flatten its curve before it becomes a community spread.

Many residents have had no experience of curfew till now, have been reasonably prompt in coming to terms with curfew- a word derived from "Curfew Bell", which was rung in the evening in Medieval England as a signal for everyone to go to bed.

"My son Pundarikh is very fond of roaming around with friends. He is a B Com first year student. I also felt that children of his age should engage themselves in outdoor activities more rather than engaging themselves over mobile but it's just the opposite now. We are asking him to restrict himself to home and he is willfully obliging", said B R Sharma, a government servant.

It was during "janata curfew" observed at the call of the Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, on Sunday that the first Coronavirus patient was detected in Bhopal and since the city had responded overwhelmingly to "janata curfew" which saw even milk booths and medical shops remaining closed and eerie silence haunting the busy roads all over the city and district collector thought it fit to put the city under lockdown after the "janata curfew" ended at 9.00 pm and after Shivraj Singh Chouhan took oath as the chief minister, he declared curfew in both the places where Coronavirus patients have been found -Jabalpur (six Coronavirus patients detected so far) and Bhopal (one patient). This quick succession of undeclared and declared "curfew" has indeed caught many families off guard as far as provision of essentials is concerned.

At a super market in Basant Kunj, an upmarket Colony in Gulmophar area, a number of people, who came asking for grocery items (flour, rice or pulses) were returned empty-handed at 9.00 pm since the store was being closed apparently due to exhaustion of stock. This despite the fact that grocery shops have been exempted from curfew.

Petrol pumps are also open but there is no crowd there as people are largely staying indoors and of course staying away from vehicles as well.

It is also a "good" occasion for many families, whose children are out for studies ore in job outside, and not only they are staying indoors due to lock down but their children have also come back from cities like Bengaluru, Delhi or Pune, which are more prone to spread ofcoronavirus than Bhopal.

"Of course, we are all worried over spread of Coronavirus and its socio-economic impact but we are happy, too, because it's for the first time in years that my son, who is an engineer in Bengaluru and daughter, who studies in Pune have come back and we are also a leisure to spend time with them", said RC Rai, a retired government official.

"Having good food, leisurely talk and watching web series or short stories over TV together or laptop separately has been our routine for past few days", he added. But, unlike Rai, there is a sizeable population mainly comprising students or people staying alone from their families, who are having tough time finding food as all the eateries, hotels and restaurants are closed.

"I work in a restaurant. When restaurant is open, we all eat there. But, it is now closed. I have to cook food at home. It's not difficult but I don't have provisions to cook but somehow, with help from my neighbours, I am managing it, said Pappu, a waiter at an MP Nagar restaurant.

Labourers and roadside vendors is another group, which shall find itself in financial crisis, if the curfew remains in force for a longer period.

Title: 134 fleeing labourers found in tempos
Content:
Two tempos ferrying 75 labourers to Uttar Pradesh were intercepted at Charkop in Kandivli on Sunday night. Four people, including drivers and owners of the two vehicles, were arrested and later released on bail.

Meanwhile, Sewri police found 59 labourers employed in industrial units in the docks in two tempos on Monday. tnn

Title: Just 1 attends burial of Telangana's first Covid-19 deceased
Content: HYDERABAD: The body of the first Covid-19 victim in Telangana was laid to rest at a graveyard in the city with only one relative attending the funeral rites.All the close family members of the victim are in quarantine and thus, they could not witness the last rites. The 74-year-old man had attended a religious gathering in Delhi where he developed cold and fever. Though he went to a couple of private hospitals, doctors did not suspect that he was carrying the deadly virus.That he was a victim of Covid-19 became clear only after his death. That the funeral rites were conducted in isolation with only his brother attending it has trigged a debate on how to dispose the body of a Covid-19 victim. Since this is a new disease it is not clear whether the body will continue to harbour the virus after the death, and if so, for how long.The World Health Organisation (WHO) has a clear protocol to deal with the bodies of people, who die due to cholera, Ebola and Marburg. But it has no formal guidelines to deal with Covid-19 bodies. However, the WHO on March 24 came out with interim guidelines on “Infection prevention and control for the safe management of a dead body in the context of Covid-19”.These interim guidelines are valid till a more specific protocol is announced after studying the infection chances etc. “This interim guidance is for all those, including managers of health care facilities and mortuaries, religious and public health authorities, and families, who tend to the bodies of persons who have died of suspected or confirmed Covid-19.These recommendations are subject to revision as new evidence becomes available,” the WHO official statement said. As this is a new virus whose source and disease progression are not yet entirely clear, more precautions may be used until further information becomes available, it added.According to Muslim religious scholars, funeral prayers in absentia can be performed in several cases of infectious diseases like cholera, plague, Ebola and now Covid-19. They also point out that regular religious formalities can be waived of to avoid spread of infection.

Title: Admin starts door-to-door delivery of essentials
Content: JAIPUR: In the wake of Covid-19, the government has announced to start a door-to-door mechanism from Monday to ensure that the common people do not have to leave their homes for food and other essentials during the lockdown period.In Jaipur, the administration has made available two vehicles in each police station which will be used by grocery stores of the respective area to deliver goods. They will have to post the rate list all the items available for delivery on the vehicles.Elaborating further, district collector Joga Ram said, “During the lockdown, people came out of their homes putting themselves at risk because of which it was decided to ensure door-to-door arrangements so that the supply of their necessities is uninterrupted. For this, the administration has made available two vehicles in all the police stations of the city.”The collector added that all the delivery vehicles will have two volunteers each from civil defence force. The catch is that vehicles will be made available only to the grocery store operators who do not have their own home delivery arrangements.In addition, the district administration official said after meeting with the relatively bigger department stores, it was suggested that they can supply the goods in different areas of the city and should soon tell their action plan or route plan to the administration. DeMart, Reliance, Big Bazaar, Easy Day, Metro Mass, etc. attended the meeting of representatives of departmental stores along with those from Oil Mill Association, Grocery Association, Saras Dairy and others. The administration claimed that these stores have already been supplying the goods on bookings through internet as well as telephonically, and keeping the present scenario in mind can supply goods to people without having bookings since they have vehicles of their own to do so.

Title: Madurai Corporation to shift fish sales from Nelpettai, Karimedu markets to avoid crowds
Content:
MADURAI: The Madurai Corporation is shifting the fish market from Nelpettai , which also houses several mutton and chicken stalls, after a large number of people thronged the premises on Sunday violating the restrictions in place to prevent the spread of Covid-19. The decision was taken after district collector T G Vinay and corporation commissioner S Visakan visited the market on Sunday evening.

The corporation also stated that wholesale fish trade in Karimedu market will be shifted to Arappalayam bus terminal from Tuesday onwards. The market will function between 10pm and 6am for wholesale purpose only.

Nelpettai is the second biggest fish market next to Karimedu market, which consists both wholesale and retail sales. The busiest slaughtering unit is also functioning at the market. The corporation is planning to shift retail fish sales both from Nelpettai and Karimedu, where social distancing can be maintained.

“Fish sales will not take place at Nelpettai and Karimedu till the Covid-19 scare comes to an end. A few places are under consideration to shift these markets, where sales can be carried out without causing any threat of the virus spread. One of the places shortly listed is a ground in Kamarajarpuram. Levelling of ground has started by deployed earthmovers,” a corporation official said, adding that an official announcement will be made soon.

Visakan said that meat sales will continue to take place in Nelpettai. “Only fish sales will be shifted to other places, similar to how vegetable markets were decentralized. The shift will help manage the crowds better,” he said.

Meanwhile, Thayir market and South Marret Street market, which witnessed crowds on Sunday were closed by the corporation. Visakan said that a list of places has been released, where vegetable vendors can start selling. So far, vendors have not fully utilized the new facility, he added.

Title: Budget passed under Covid shadow
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Thermal scanning of MLAs wearing masks and use of hand sanitizers at the entrance gate marked the day-long proceedings of the second phase of budget session amid the coronavirus scare here on Monday.

The assembly passed the state’s Rs 1.50 lakh crore budget for the coming fiscal (2020-2021) in the absence of chief minister Naveen Patnaik and attendance of around 80 of the 147 members at the convention centre of Lok Seva Bhawan.

The location was chosen because seven employees of the assembly had come in contact with the state’s third Covid-19 patient, a 60-year-old banker. Speaker SN Patro had directed that the assembly and its premises should be sanitized and had asked the employees to go for home isolation.

The MLAs sat around 1.8 metres away from each other. Replying to the brief debate on the budget, finance minister Niranjan Pujari said, “I am seeking passage of the appropriation bill unanimously amid state’s firm resolve to contain the spread of coronavirus. This will give us more strength to fight the virus and to spend on other public welfare initiatives.”

The finance minister regretted the fact that elaborate debate on various aspects of the budget could not be held because the session had to be curtailed in view of coronavirus scare.

The budget was presented in the assembly on February 18. The speaker had adjourned the proceedings from March 16 to March 29 as part of the efforts to contain the spread of the virus. “The appropriation bill was unanimously passed,” BJD MLA Amar Prasad Satpathy told the media.

Taking part in the debate, leader of opposition Pradipta Naik said the government should take all into confidence to fight the spread of the virus. Congress legislature party leader Narasingha Mishra said the opposition is firmly behind the governments at the Centre and the state in the fight against this health challenge. “However, the government should also take the opposition into confidence and convene an all-party meeting. This will instil more confidence among the public,” he said. The opposition also lauded the role being played by the doctors in treating patients as well as the police in ensuring the lockdown.

Title: 808 teachers to keep tab on those quarantined
Content: SUAT: The SMC has roped in 808 school teachers of Nagar Prathmik Sikshan Samiti to keep a tab on those placed under home quarantine in various areas of the city."These teachers have been saddled with the responsibility to monitor home quarantined people in the city," said an SMC official.SMC school board chairman Hashmukh Patel said: "It is necessary to ensure that home quarantined people don't venture out from their homes and follow the lockdown strictly. The teachers have been roped in to prevent the further spread of COVID-19 in the city.'"The teachers will also guide home quarantined people about dos and don'ts and assist the SMC's health team in its fight against the pandemic,'' Patel added.

Title: Banks, treasuries to open on Ram Navami in Lucknow
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Banks and treasury would remain open on Ram Navami on April 2. Principal secretary, religious affairs, Jitendra Kumar said that UP had declared bank holiday on Ram Navami under the Local Instruments Act. Under this act, the state is empowered to declare a holiday in banks and also in financial institutions which come under control of the Central government .

As Ram Navami is celebrated in a grand way in UP, the state government had decided to declare bank holiday the same day. However, in other states banks function normally on Ram Navami. Now, Yogi government has reversed its earlier decision and declared that banks would function on Ram Navmi day on April 2 along with state treasuries.It would enable the state government to transfer funds to banks through treasuries. The banks would then credit the money in the account of workers, labourers and farmers under various welfare schemes run by the state government.

Title: Pharma workers urged to rejoin work in Goa
Content: MARGAO: South Goa collector Ajit Roy on Monday urged employees of all pharma companies to join their duties willingly. He reassured house owners, society chairmen and villagers that “all pharma companies have taken care of the hygiene of the employees so that they are not infected with any disease.”

Title: Don’t worry about electrical problems, Razak is a call away
Content:
Madurai: Even though are no power cuts during this lockdown period, people still require help for electrical issues. In this hour of need, Abdul Razak, a local electrician, has stepped up to provide his services free-of-cost.

“Whenever there is a crisis, I keep thinking of ways to help people. For instance, I came up with a jacket coated with bee wax for Indian soldiers serving in extremely cold temperatures at the border,” said Razak.

As the lockdown implemented owing to Covid-19 has restricted movements, Razak came up with the gesture as he has no difficulty in moving about being a member of the Red Cross.

People have told Razak that it is difficult to find a TNEB electrician, like when the fuse burns out. “If the problem is something that I can solve, I go to the spot in a few minutes and set it right. The gratitude of the people is my biggest reward,” Razak said.

Since the lockdown was announced last week, he has provided his services free-of-cost to 20 people who contacted him on his phone. Malarvizhi of Bibikulam said she was cooking when her mixer grinder stopped working. “I felt helpless, because I couldn’t take it for repairs and buying a new one was out of the question. My neighbour told me about Razak and I called him. My problem was fixed.”

In another instance, when a ceiling fan stopped working at a house in KK Nagar, J Sugumar’s young child and elderly parents were badly affected because of the summer heat. “I was lucky to get Razak’s number and he set it right in a few minutes. The only cost was for a small part for which i paid Rs 150,” he said.

Razak can be contacted on 9894905268.

Title: Goa Seafarers offer their hospital to fight Covid-19
Content: MARGAO: The Goan Seafarers’ Association of India (GSAI) has written to the National Union of Seafarers of India (NUSI) to hand over the NUSI hospital at Chinchinim to the state government to be used as a quarantine facility.In a letter to NUSI general secretary Abdul Ghani Serang , GSAI pointed out that many Goan seafarers stranded on ships overseas are expected to be back in Goa soon, and thus if a quarantine facility is set up at the NUSI hospital, it could benefit the seafarers as well as public.“A lot of seafarers are stranded in different parts of the world and many are due to be signed off. As the government of Goa has also taken precautionary measures, this will be an additional help. It will be a great help for our community to be isolated in hospital with medical assistance rather than at home,” the letter stated.GSAI president Frank Viegas told TOI that more than 3,000 Goan seafarers working on cruise lines whose jobs have been terminated or have been signed off following end of contract, who are waiting for repatriation to Goa. “A large number of beds will be required for quarantining these seamen. We urge the government of Goa to be prepared in this situation ,” Viegas said.Secretary Michael Beny Da Costa , in a statement, appealed to all the MLAs to urge the government to bring the stranded Goan seafarers back “as soon as possible before the situation goes out of hand.”

Title: Tamil Nadu Corona Update: Tamil Nadu yet to mobilise 1 lakh idle doctors to take on Covid-19 crisis
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: About one lakh doctors engaged in private practice in the state are idle with clinics shut, but Tamil Nadu is yet to ready them to tackle coronavirus cases should there be an outbreak.

Maharashtra and Bihar are preparing to rope in private doctors to handle such an eventuality and experts said it was high time Tamil Nadu trained the doctors by organising online classes on how to handle Covid-19 cases.

Tamil Nadu has 1.4 lakh registered doctors of whom nearly 20,000 work in government-funded hospitals. Many private hospitals, particularly speciality care centres run by ophthalmologists, psychiatrists and ENT specialists, are shut for a week.

Dr Thilak, a dermatologist from Anna Nagar, said, "As we don’t know who could be a carrier of the virus, it is unsafe for both us and patients. We didn’t want hospitals to become the source of infection."

A K Ravikumar, state secretary of Indian Medical Association (IMA), said many private hospitals and clinics are not only ready to send their doctors but also allow government to use their available hospital space and infrastructure. But these doctors should be screened before they are allowed to work to ensure that there is no community spread, said Dr C Ashok, a general physician from Thanjavur.

Government hospital doctors said procuring additional personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and masks for these private doctors will be a challenge as the government has struggled to meet demands of the existing workforce.

To eliminate this, the IMA had proposed a model to director of public health (DPH). According to it, selected hospitals (one in every 3km) in the state can be declared dedicated fever and respiratory clinics. Any fever or respiratory cases will be referred and treated only in these dedicated centres and entry for all other cases should be barred. It would be easier for the government to train doctors for these centres.

"By this, we can also restrict the demand of PPEs and more importantly we will have enough doctors in case of an eventuality," Ravikumar said.

This model will also ensure that other patients can approach hospitals without any fear as currently many were restricting visits to government hospitals in districts which have an isolated ward in one of the blocks, said a house surgeon from Tiruvarur GH.

Title: Mid-day meal ration to be given to needy
Content: Jaipur: The leftover ration for mid-day meal in government schools due to the lockdown will now be distributed to the migrant labourers or daily wagers. The state has issued orders on Monday saying that district collector can use the ration left in the government schools that are closed due to the spread of coronavirus since March 14.Abhishek Bhagotia, commissioner mid-day meal Rajasthan says that it has been issued for the dry ration. “We supply ration to schools on quarterly basis. After the lockdown, rice and wheat is lying in the school premises without any use. So, we sent a proposal to the government which has been approved. Collector with the help of district education officer can utilized this ration for the benefit of the migrant workers or distribution of ration among the people,” said Bhagotia.Due to the lockdown there has been a crisis for daily wagers. Many NGO and government department have started supplying food packets to the people.This is the first time when mid-day meal will be distributed to people. There are, however, cases where it has been shown that students from poor families are now facing problems as the mid-day meal is not available anymore.One district in Kerala has started supplying food to student’s houses due to shut down so that they will not be short of nutrients.Officials in the government have clarified that to prevent the spread of virus and for social distancing government hasn’t decided not to implement this plan in the state.

Title: VSSUT hostel to be converted into Covid-19 hospital
Content:
Sambalpur: In view of the Covid-19 outbreak, the health administration in Sambalpur district is converting a hostel of the Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology (VSSUT), Burla, into a Covid-19 hospital.

The additional district magistrate (Sambalpur), Suryanarayan Dash, said the Pulaha Hall of Residence of VSSUT will be converted into a 500-bed Covid-19 hospital. He said all equipment and facilities required for a Covid-19 hospital, will be available there.

Official sources said the civil work to convert the hostel into a hospital has started. A target has been set to ready the hospital in a month. The work is going on a war-footing. The doctors and para-medical staff of Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research (VIMSAR), Burla, will be engaged at the hospital to take care of the patients.

Dean and principal of VIMSAR Brajamohan Mishra said the district administration is carrying out the work. The hospital will be handed over to us once the work gets over, he said.

Currently, the VIMSAR authorities have opened a Covid-19 counter out patient department (OPD) at VIMSAR. Around 80 to 100 patients are coming to the counter daily. Moreover, there are also two isolation wards with 30 beds at VIMSAR.

The state government has also planned to set up a Biosafety Levels 2 (BSL 2) laboratory at VIMSAR, Burla, where screening test for Covid-19 suspects can be conducted. The VIMSAR authorities have already sent a feasibility report to the state government for setting up of the laboratory.

Title: ‘Patient-zero’ remains in test after seven days
Content:
Bhopal: Recovering from Covid-19 infection, Bhopal’s ‘patient-zero’ tested positive for the deadly contagion in a fresh test conducted on the seventh day of the diagnosis for ascertaining recovery. The patient would now remain hospitalised for another 14 days, according to AIIMS Bhopal officials.

“Both, patient-zero and a journalist’s father are under observation. Another patient was also hospitalised on Sunday. Overall condition of the three is stable,” said institute official.

As per the protocol, a third positive sample is taken after seven days. If the patient is negative, the chances of relapse would have been minimised. The patient had tested positive on March 20.

Overall in Bhopal, 134 people who are under isolation at home or hospitalised have been categorised as under monitoring. Most of these are with a travel history to Covid-19 infected region or those who came in contact with Covid-19 positive patient.

The ground zero of Covid-19 spread has also affected Indore and Ujjain. A number of samples from the two cities would be tested in AIIMS Bhopal. Health department has also provided additional staff to the institute. AIIMS Bhopal would also provide training for initiating Covid-19 testing in Rewa and other locations.

NGOs Jan Swasth Abhiyan stated in a press release that the state government has issued an order to take over private hospitals for handling the coronavirus as needed under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897. So far, two private hospitals in Indore have been requisitioned under this order. In the last 10 days, starting March 19, Madhya Pradesh has been collecting 56 samples per day on an average, with a total of 604 samples collected so far. In comparison to states like Kerala which has identified a large number of positive cases, Kerala so far has tested 6690 samples. Currently in Kerala, everyday 500 tests are being carried out with an outlook of increasing it to 1000 tests per day by next week.

Title: Donate salary: CM to govt staff
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan ’s call to government employees and teachers to contribute a month’s salary to CMDRF has elicited a good response.

Several service organizations has reciprocated positively to the CM’s call and opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala too has expressed support to the drive.

Joint council of state service organizations asked all government employees should to contribute a month’s salary to the CMDRF. The council general secretary S Vijayakumaran Nair said part-time employees, last-grade employees and employees fighting chronic diseases should be exempted from contributing their salary. The government’s attempt to collect salaries without the prior consent of employees had backfired last time. This time, however, the government is keen to strike a consensus with all service organizations so that all would declare their consent voluntarily. The appeal, said service organization leaders who participated in discussions with the chief minister here on Monday, is to contribute a month’s salary in instalments not exceeding 10 months.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said the opposition would cooperate with the call, provided the details of the same is worked out in consultation with all concerned. “We welcome the salary challenge proposed by the government. But whether a full month’s salary should be contributed by all employees demands a second thought. There is nothing wrong in asking employees to decide the volume of their contribution on their own,” he said.

Title: Mhow to shut its borders for 3 days
Content:
xsxsxsxs

Borders of Mhow will be sealed for three days starting Wednesday morning, Mhow SDM Abhilash Mishra said on Monday

The move is to save Mhow from any type of infection from outside cities. It restriction will be from Wednesday morning to Friday night.

Explaining the need for such a move, the official said that it is good that no person has been tested positive in Mhow so far but looking at so many positive cases in Indore, the administration has been decided to seal the borders and make the lockdown effective.

Mishra said that even grocery and vegetable shops will remain closed during the three days. Only milk will be distributed by suppliers at houses. No milk shops or dairies will be allowed to open as people will disobey the advisory on social distancing, when they go to shops.

He added said that even in lockdown, many people were seen moving on their two and four wheelers but if any of them are caught from Wednesday to Friday, the vehicles were seized and riders will be put into jail.

In Dhar, collector Shrikant Banoth took a meeting of all key officials of the district to discuss the situation on Monday. Addressing the officials in video conferencing hall, Banoth said that though no corona positive patient has been found in the district, there will not be any relaxation as far as orders of lockdown are concerned. He emphasized on issues of daily wages workers, who are starving. “Officials should ensure that none of them sleep hungry,” he said. In the meeting, officials briefed that 20 quarantine centres have been made in the district while arrangements have been made for 760 patients. Till now 12000 persons have undergone screening and 76 of them are under isolation either at hospitals or homes.

Title: Covid-19: Longer lockdown can contain virus, research finds
Content: CHENNAI: The 21-day lockdown may slow the spread of coronavirus , but it could bounce back to infect six times the number presently reported, shows a study by The Institute of Mathematical Sciences in Chennai and the University of Cambridge.The researchers warned that the elderly are at greater risk of catching infection from children if physical distancing is not practised at home, as India has a large number of households with three generations under the same roof.The study, yet to be peer-reviewed, forecasts that a single 49-day lockdown or three lockdowns -- for 21 days, 28 days and 18 days -- with a five-day break in between would work effectively to slow the virus spread.The researchers developed a model that studied the population by age and social contacts of people at workplaces, schools and other public spheres to assess the impact of the lockdown. The results indicate that the present lockdown, which will end by April 14, may be insufficient as it may bring down the number of cases by mid-April, but the infection could resurge quickly to infect more than 6,000 by mid-May. Longer periods of lockdown could curtail the infection and bring the numbers below 10."At present, we have no means of controlling the infection other than social distancing.
