Lockdown seems to be the only viable option," said Ronojoy Adhikari who conducted the study with Rajesh Singh.The model has helped the researchers predict the rate of mortality across different age groups. In the absence of social distancing, the study warns that nearly a million people in their sixties, around nine lakh in their fifties and around 3.7 lakh in their forties are at risk.With effective lockdown periods, the study estimates the mortality at eight in the three-lockdowns with five-day break and six for a 49-day lockdown.Along with lockdown and social distancing, extensive testing and mapping affected regions are lso important. "District-level testing should be started. Once infection levels are manageable, we will need to ensure that infected individuals and their contact networks are traced and quarantined," Adhikari said.But even after the lockdown period, the researchers suggest that extensive screening at various points of entry and mandatory self-isolation be continued, as a large population could still be susceptible to the virus and entry of new positive cases from across the borders could start the chain of infections again.

Title: State govt extendsretirement of medical staff by max 6 months
Content:
Jaipur: Following the Covid-19 crisis in the state, the government has approved the extension of medical staff, including doctors, retiring during the period between March 31 and August 31 to September 30 this year.

This was decided at a meeting of the State Disaster Management Authority (SDMA) held at chief minsiter Ashok Gehlot’s residence on Monday to review the situation emerging due to the virus outbreak.

The meeting also decided to accord the highest priority to stop the migration of labourers and provide them with food, shelter and clothing.

“The meeting reviewed the situation and measures taken to contain the spread of coronavirus, feedback about what more needs to be done. Our priority is to also stop the exodus of migrants and to take care of them, provide food, shelter and medicines,” said an official statement. It was decided to intensify screening of all people returning to Rajasthan and to keep them in shelters and quarantine them.

Title: Sikar woman cop sews masks on duty
Content: Udaipur: While everyone carries a tiffin or water bottle to work, constable Sheela Meena carries her sewing machine to the police station where she is posted. She makes 30 to 35 masks per day.Meena (34), who is posted at Thoi police station in Sikar, has stitched over 300 masks which she distributed among her fellow workers as well as the needy.It all began a fortnight ago. Just when the coronavirus was rearing its ugly head in the state, she decided to put her childhood hobby to good use.“I was concerned for the staff at our police station who were vulnerable to infection in case of outbreak of the disease. There are 35 personnel at the station and hence I made 100 masks in the first phase so that each person gets at least two masks to wear during duty,” said Sheela.“My colleagues are cooperative. Our SHO who has granted me relaxation from field duty and asked me to stitch more masks as we have set a target to distribute them among people living in the kachhi basti nearby,” she said.The entire staff extends support to Sheela, who has distributed the masks to sanitation workers, milkmen, vegetable vendors and others at high risk of catching infection.She initially paid for the fabric from her own pocket. Later on, SHO Sangeeta Meena helped her financially.“Sheela is a dedicated worker and takes her duties seriously. I don’t remember any instance when she had failed or stepped back from her responsibilities be it extended working hours or night shift,” the SHO claimed.Sheela makes 30-35 masks per day and it takes about 15 minutes to make one. After the lockdown , it is little difficult for her to buy the cloth, lace and elastic. But she continues to find help as several people provide her with the material.Sheela has made up her mind to continue making the masks until the lockdown is called off.Her husband is a government school teacher. They have two children.“My son Mandeep is six and daughter Tanishka is two-years-old. I have to attend to them as well. But my mother-in-law is very supportive and also encourages me to devote more time to the noble cause. She always insists on safety first,” Sheela said.“For the time being, I don’t go to the field but I do venture out of the house and am on duty. Hence, I take all the precautions. I use sanitizer and frequently wash my hands while on duty particularly because I make these masks and my children are young,” she said.

Title: Chennai: Star hotels hit, open only for long-term guests
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: Star hotels across the city are shut for customers due to the countrywide lockdown. While suspension of flights has led to no new bookings, the industry is staring at heavy losses as maintaining star hotels is expensive.

Several hotels are offering takeaways through food delivery apps and keeping dine-in facilities for guests who checked in before the lockdown came into effect. Such guests include long staying occupants on official assignments and those stranded due to the curbs in movement, accounting for a ratio of two rooms occupied for every 100 rooms.

Sources say a five star hotel with a minimum of 150 rooms spends between Rs 4 lakh and Rs 5.2 lakh towards upkeep, including staff salaries and power, everyday, while it is Rs 3.2 lakh for four star and three star hotels. "Hotel business is like the airline industry which generates revenue only when aircraft are flying," said a general manager at a four star hotel.

The city has 200 star hotels including 150 3 star establishments, most of them on Anna Salai, OMR and GST Road. While some are offering up to 20% discounts for resident guests to remain there until April 14, others are accommodating staff in banquet halls and rooms. Those that are offering takeaways through food delivery apps are coming up with attractive rates.

South India Hotels and Restaurants Association honorary secretary T Nataraajan said such a long closure was unprecedented. "A few hotels were shut for some months due to damage from floods in 2015. Though hotels were covered under insurance, Covid-19 does not come under ambit of insurance," he said.

Title: Banks to extend working hours to clear pension rush
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: State level bankers’ committee rescheduled the arrangement for distribution of welfare pension after banks witnessed heavy rush of beneficiaries, including highly vulnerable senior citizens , on Monday. Earlier, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac asked bankers’ committee to release pension by allotting a day for various groups divided according to the last digit of their account number.

The banks were directed to extend their working hours till they complete distribution for the allotted category. The finance minister has asked banks to complete distribution in five days. Accordingly, the bankers’ committee extended working hours from 10am to 4pm till April 4. After lockdown, banks were functioning from 10am to 2pm.

Though April 1 is a closed holiday, the guidelines is silent on the transactions on March 31, which has created some confusion among bankers and consumers.

tnn

Title: Asha workers track Covid suspects sans masks, gloves
Content: Vijayawada: Accredited Social Health Activist ( Asha ) workers in Krishna district have submitted a representation to district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz requesting him to consider problems at the ground-level in handling suspected Covid-19 patients.The state government is utilising the services of village volunteers, health secretaries and Asha workers to identify foreign returnees and home quarantine them.Stating that the district health department has ignored their needs, Asha workers said they were not provided with masks , sanitizers, gloves and other safety gear. “There are around 3,000 Asha workers in Krishna district. We are going door-to-door and handling the Covid-19 suspect patients. Officials are ignoring our safety. We are buying our own hand sanitizers and other safety gear to prevent the transmission. We have requested the district medical and health officials on this, but there is no response,” said A Kamala, general secretary of Asha workers’ union.Kamala also requested the district collector to provide free transport within the city as Asha workers were facing problems in travelling with the lockdown.Speaking to TOI, the district collector said the administration will be responsive to the demands raised by Asha workers. “Field-level staff are top priority for us. We have come to know that they are facing a problem with the shortage of masks. I have ordered the health wing officials to provide masks and gloves immediately,” Imtiaz said.

Title: 23 booked for violating lockdown order
Content:
Caption

Bhopal:Bhopal police on Monday registered 23 cases against people violating lockdown order. On Sunday, 10 cases were registered against those violating the order. The accused have been booked under sections 188, 269 and 270 of IPC.

Since March 22, after the lockdown order was issued, 142 cases have been registered against the violators.

ASP Sandesh Jain said that since the lockdown order was issued, around 300 people were arrested for violating the order. Around 30 vehicles were seized and more than Rs 15,000 fine was imposed on the violators. Police on Monday booked a grocery store owner and around 25-30 people who were negligently crowding in front of the shop flouting the social distancing norms.

ASP Zone-1 Rajat Saklecha visited the DMart supermarket in Jehangirabad and instructed the store staff to follow social distancing norms at the store. Meanwhile, cops continued to play the role of good Samaritans while enforcing the lockdown.

Nishatpura police on Monday afternoon found an 80-year-old Khandwa based woman roaming in the area and sent her to old age home in Shahjehanabad. The woman was roaming on streets around 3 pm when police spotted her and asked about her family she was not able to give satisfactory answers. She was hungry and depressed. Police provided her with meal and also counselled her. After much efforts, she told police that her daughter and son-in-law, who reside in Laxmi Nagar, had brought her to Bhopal from Khandwa around 10 days back. But they assaulted her and foced her out after taking her ornaments. She told cops that her husband also retired from police department and passed away in the past. When police couldn’t find the address of her relatives, they took her to old age home. The woman told police that her son resided in Khandwa with his family but couldn’t provide proper address. She denied to return to her daughter’s home.

BOX-

Cops cook to feed migrant labourers

Bhopal: City police on Monday continued to distribute food and masks to needy. TT Nagar police are already distributing food packets prepared at the police station itself to needy. Crime branch also started preparing food packets in the police station premises in association with an NGO and distributed them to needy people, who were stopped at outskirts checking posts. Crime branch cops said that many organisations were distributing food items inside the city but at the city outskirts where people coming from outstations on foot including migrant labourers the situation is worse. As such, the crime branch has started preparing food and were distributing around 500 food packets in that area. ASP Crime Branch Nishchal Jharia said that the capacity of the kitchen at crime branch will be extended and more packets will be distributed. Gandhi Nagar police distributed food packets to more than 200 migrants from Rajasthan, who had been residing in tents in the area. TNN

Title: Apollo to set up 5k hotel isolation rooms
Content:
Hyderabad: One One of India’s largest healthcare players, Apollo Hospitals Group, has joined hands with three major hospitality players – OYO Rooms, Tata Group’s Ginger and Lemon Tree to create 5,000 private isolation rooms across the country as part of Project STAY I, a first of its kind initiative in the country. ‘Project STAY I’, part of Apollo Hospitals’ recently launched Project Kavach to battle Covid-19, is expected to take some of the burden off the government healthcare set-up at a time the number of cases has been steadily rising.

The social impact initiative, which also includes food delivery player Zomato, biotech company Biocon, FMCG giant Hindustan Unilever and banks like SBI and Deutsche Bank, will see Apollo Group provide light medical supervision at these isolation facilities through telemedicine and Ask Apollo. A combination of CSR-funded and self-paying customers, STAY I provides an option to those who have reservations about staying in government hospitals for treatment as part of the mandatory isolation.

While 50% of the lower category rooms in OYO Hotels, diagnostics and medicines will be provided free of cost to poor patients, others using the facility will have to pay for the medicines and a daily rent of Rs 1200 for an isolation room in OYO Rooms, Rs 2200 in Ginger and Rs 3,000 in Lemon Tree hotels, Apollo Hospitals Group joint managing director Sangita Reddy told TOI.

The initiative rolled out on Monday with 500 beds initially in Hyderabad, Delhi, Mumbai and Bengaluru and will be ramped up by 50 rooms every three days to eventually reach 5,000 rooms across cities including Chennai, Kolkata, Bhubaneswar, Ahmedabad, Lucknow and Gurugram, she said.

“The working protocols, functioning and monitoring framework have been developed and the project will be launched in phases across cities. Project STAY I is expected to help over 10,000 patients in a month and prevent over 50 lakh infections,” Reddy said on Monday.

Title: Weavers Demand Central Help
Content:
Mangalagiri: Weaver towns across the state are silent as looms have stopped working.

Weavers are pioneers of the concept of working from home but the ongoing lockdown has left them jobless. With retail cloth stores shut across the country, master weavers (employers of the small weavers) have stopped engaging the weavers.

With no other means of livelihood, weavers are among the hardest-hit in the national lockdown.

A majority of handloom workers are low wage earners with a monthly family income below Rs 5,000. A family of three or four members struggle to earn the paltry sums. Although skilled to make the yarn into tiny strings and produce a colourful outfit, they are struggling to make both ends meet.

“There has been no work for the past 10 days. I cannot afford to take my ailing mother to hospital as the situation outside is also worrisome,” said Ganji Anjaneyulu, a handloom weaver.

Summer is business season for handloom weavers as they get their bulk of work decent wage during this period. The demand for handloom fabric goes up in the summer.

Master weavers usually procure orders from across the country during February and March and engage small-time weavers to complete the orders. With Covid-19 slowly impacting one nation after another, the exporters and wholesalers have stopped placing orders with the local master weavers since February.

This has resulted in dip in work at field-level even before the lockdown was announced by the Centre and state governments. “We are surprised by the Centre’s package, which completely ignores the plights of handloom weavers. We request the Centre to grant immediate financial assistance to all the weavers to prevent starvation deaths,” said Macherla Mohan Rao, president, National Federation of Handlooms and handicrafts (NFHH).

Title: ‘Tiff over sealing of borders’ as Taj city turns transit route for migrant workers
Content:
Agra: With the city of Taj turning into a transit route for hundreds of migrant workers from the national capital and neighbouring states in the wake of the Centre’s strict orders to follow the 21-day nationwide lockdown to fight Covid-19, a regulation of traffic between the districts turned into a brief flashpoint between the authorities of Agra and Firozabad districts on Monday.

Tundla SDM KP Singh Tomar said, “An Agra police sub-inspector had blocked the highway with barricades on the border of two districts and didn’t even allow essential services such as ambulance to enter Agra from Firozabad. This also caused traffic jam.” Most of these workers are coming from Bharatpur (Rajasthan), Morena (Madhya Pradesh), Faridabad (Haryana) and Delhi, and using the city as a transit route.

Later, tehsildar and Tundla CO rushed from Firozabad to the spot, while from Agra, under-trainee IPS Somendra Meena reached the spot with his men. A video clip of the argument between the two district officials in the middle of the NH-2 on Firozabad-Agra border went viral. Here, Tundla tehsildar Gajendrapal Singh and IPS under-trainee Somendra Meena were found shouting at each other to stop their side of the traffic from entering into other districts.

Superintendent of police (rural west), Ravi Kumar of Agra said, “Our officers handled the situation professionally. People should understand Agra is a transit route for hundreds of migrant workers coming from Delhi, Haryana, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan. On Sunday, we had arranged over 2,000 public transport services like buses, trucks and even tractor-trollies to move them out. Many of them had walked their way into Agra. Thousands are still stranded in Agra and we have sent them to temporary quarantine facilities with food, water and other necessary items. After the Centre’s strict lockdown order, we have sealed our borders until further notice.”

Moreover, both the districts have decided not to allow any vehicles or pedestrian movement across the border, except for essential services like ambulance, food, grocery and medicine carrying trucks.

According to officials, food, drinking water, temporary shelters and toilet facilities have been arranged for people stuck near the borders. Arrangements were made in coordination with Bharatpur, Dholpur, Firozabad, Etawah, Mathura and Hathras district administrations.

District magistrate Prabhu N Singh said, “We have identified 32 places, mainly near the district borders, where we will cater to around 25,000 people. We are working to further increase the capacity. Duties have been assigned to officials to ensure adequate arrangements at these centres. We will take care of all the requirements of the migrant workers. They will be provided food, drinking water, mattresses and blankets to sleep. Toilet facility will be made available at all shelters.”

Meanwhile, UP CM Yogi Adityanath may visit Agra on Tuesday to “take stock of the situation”. “The chief minister is scheduled to visit Agra on Tuesday. He will be personally reviewing arrangements made for the migrants. He will also check our arrangements to prevent spread of coronavirus. He may conduct spot inspection at a few places,” he added.

Title: 3 suspects flee dist hospital, return after warning
Content:
Agra: Three Covid-19 suspects were found missing from the isolation ward at the Agra district hospital on Monday morning. The incident caused panic among the health department officials. Doctors sought police’s help to find out the three men. Police informed their family members that an FIR will be registered against them if they don’t come back. All three returned by evening.

Surveillance team of the health department had brought two men from Tajganj locality and one from Sadar locality. The men were found having symptoms of Covid-19. They were admitted in the isolation ward at the district hospital on Sunday. In the morning, the ward boy found three men missing and reported it to the hospital administration.

Superintendent in-charge of the district hospital Dr Satish Verma said, “The three men said they had gone to meet their family members. They accepted their mistake and regretted doing so. Their samples have been sent for lab testing.”

Title: State-appointed nodal officer convinces workers to stay put
Content:
Migrant workers who are desperate to return to their respective villages are being requested by a state-appointed nodal officer and his team in the city over phone to stay put, thus highlighting the need for effective communication during a crisis.

The nodal officer was appointed following chief minister Uddhav Thackeray’s assurance that migrant workers need not panic and leave Maharashtra as the state will take care of their food, stay and safety. The officer and his team have been counselling, guiding and offering help to migrant workers over phone.

“They are insisting on going back to their native villages in Uttar Pradesh. However, considering the current situation arising due to Covid-19, my team of five officials has been offering guidance to them and requesting that they stay back wherever they are, instead of trying to leave the state,” said Bimlesh Audichya, nodal officer who is coordinating with local bodies to take care of the workers.

“When we had detailed conversations with the workers, we realized their fear of going hungry was much lower than the longing to meet their near and dear ones. In fact, food figured last on their list of priorities,” Audichya added. “They relaxed after we arranged video calls with the sarpanch of their respective villages or with their relatives. They were convinced that it is advisable to stay back here.”

Title: People who travelled with city’s 1st patient in train asked to get screened
Content: KOLHAPUR: An appeal has been made to all the passengers who had travelled by the Mahalaxmi Express on March 21 to come forward for medical screening. Kolhapur city’s first confirmed Covid-19 patient — who is a resident of the Mangalwar Peth area — had taken the Mahalaxmi Express to travel from Pune to Kolhapur on March 21.So far, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation has traced 86 people who had come in contact with the infected person. Some of the contacts, including his family members, have already been screened, and one relative tested positive.KMC commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti said, “We are tracing the first and second contact persons. We have sought the details of the train passengers. I appeal to all those who had travelled by train to get screened immediately. Those who have developed symptoms should rush to our Covid-19 preventive centres. We will ask all the passengers to quarantine themselves for 14-days.”The man had developed symptoms after four days of his return to Kolhapur city. He was taken to a private hospital and from there to Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Civil Hospital, where his throat samples were collected and sent for testing. After screening his family members, one was found to be infected. Since the infection often develops without showing any symptoms, people remain unaware. Therefore, there is a need for every passenger and person who came in contact with the first patient to get the tests done.“I have asked the Railway officials to provide us with the list of the passengers. If possible, the Railway staff can reach out to the out-of-town passengers who had taken the same train. We are informing other local bodies to make similar appeals in their jurisdictions,” the commissioner said.“The contact persons have to stay away from everyone to stop the spread. We have initiated a house-to-house survey and so far, have covered more than 800 families,” added Kalshetti.Meanwhile, on Monday, the KMC put 208 people in institutional quarantine and 201 persons have been asked to quarantine themselves at home. The persons with travel history must compulsorily be taken to the institutional quarantine centres set up at different places.

Title: 1,000 tourists seek visa extensions, over 400 evacuated from Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The Foreigners Regional Registration Office (FRRO) in Goa has evacuated more than 400 overseas nationals even as 1,000 others applied for extension of visas.

A senior police officer with the FRRO said that out of the 400 evacuated, 300 are from the United Kingdom, 60 from France, 30 from the Czech Republic and the rest from various European nations. There are 1,600 foreign tourists in the state and chief minister Pramod Sawant said that by April 3 charter flights will arrive in the state to evacuate them. The CM, however, said that there is no confirmation yet on how many will actually leave.

On Sunday, TOI had reported that foreign nationals were facing a food and cash crunch due to the lockdown. Many of them were due to fly out of Goa in the last week of March, but were caught when international flights were cancelled.

The officer said that during evacuation police are directed not to stop foreigners travelling towards Dabolim airport.

Every year thousands of overseas tourists visit the state, with most coming from UK, Russia and Europe. Official data has revealed that many citizens from novel coronavirus-hit nations such as China, Italy, France and Spain have been residing in Goa since January. As many as 6,543 C-forms (filled by accommodation owners) have been registered at the FRRO till date.

Foreigners have been stranded in Goa since March 22, the Janata Curfew day as announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi , which chief minister Pramod Sawant immediately extended by three days and on March 24 Modi announced a national lockdown till April 14 midnight.

Foreign nationals applying for visa extensions have been advised against visiting the FFRO office in Panaji and to apply for visa-related services online.

Title: Shortage of PPE & ventilators across MP
Content:
Bhopal: At the time when the country is battling the Covid-19 pandemic, the ‘z-security’ of personal protective equipment (PPE) for doctors and health workers is in short supply across Madhya Pradesh, including the state capital. Number of ventilators required for high-risk patients are low too, claim sources.

Sample this, Ujjain which has reported five cases has only 20 ventilators for Covid-19 treatment. The state capital, which has reported only three positive cases of Covid-19 till now, has 168 dedicated beds and 149 ventilators. Premier medical institute, AIIMS Bhopal, which is at the forefront of dealing with Covid-19 patients, has only 2,000 PPE. One PPE can be used once where average shift is for about eight hours. BMHRC, which is Covid-19 designated hospital, has not yet received its order of 10,000 PPE.

AIIMS to increase testing capacity to 200: Covid-19 testing capacity is being increased from a maximum of 63 samples to 200 that can be run in 3 shifts at AIIMS Regional Virology Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (RVRDL). The facility would complement testing needed for increased tests required after spurt in cases in Indore and Ujjain. ICMR Jabalpur can test 36 samples each day and similar are the numbers at the testing facility of Indore and Gwalior, according to sources.

Title: Kolkata private hospitals fear infection spread
Content:
The isolation ward at AMRI Hospitals

KOLKATA: The rising number of Covid-19 patients and suspects has put private hospitals in Kolkata in a bind. It is a tightrope walk for them, who are serving to these patients on one hand, while keeping the rest of their patients insulated on the other.

With their infrastructural constraints — most have limited isolation facilities with the number of beds ranging between five and 12 — they are anxious about sticking to the prescribed isolation norms that could come under strain, they apprehend. Many are still grappling with a shortage of personal protection equipment (PPE) and fear that if the number of corona patients sees a sudden surge, they will have to stop admission.

AMRI has 16 isolation beds across two of its units. “The number of beds is limited and we can’t have more since isolation protocol wouldn’t permit that. Care must be taken to prevent transmission. While treatment is not an issue, infrastructure is restricted. We can’t take in more than 16,” said AMRI CEO Rupak Barua. He added that shortage of PPEs was a worry. “So far, we have been able to manage with the stocks at our disposal. But we have never had enough PPEs and in case we run out of them, treatment will be hampered,” said Barua.

Peerless Hospital has 8-9 beds at its isolation ward and three at an ITU. “We will reach our limit if the number of patients keep climbing. Eventually, we will have to refuse. We have enough PPEs now but supplies have been erratic. We are worried that if stocks aren’t replenished more regularly, we won’t be in a position to follow treatment protocol,” said Peerless superintendent Sudipto Mitra.

With five isolation beds, RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences (RTIICS) is striving to strike a balance between Covid suspects and other patients. Treating such patients in the absence of PPE puts the doctors and nurses at risk as well as increases the possibility of cross-infection, according to RTIICS zonal director R Venkatesh. He said RTIICS was hoping that the lockdown helps flatten the curve to prevent any major influx of corona patients.

Title: Over 200 visit flu clinic in a day after confirmed covid-19 case reported
Content:
Bareilly: A day after Bareilly reported its first covid-19 positive case, over 200 people, including a few regular patients, suffering from fever and cough visited the flu clinic at the district hospital in the first shift on Monday.

Chief medical superintendent Dr TS Arya said, “More than 200 patients visited the flu clinic on Monday and everyone was treated. A team of four doctors are attending the patients in the first shift, but as the number of patients in the second shift is usually reduces, two doctors are available at the flu clinic.”

Dr Vageesh Vaish, senior consultant and physician at the district hospital, said, “The first case of novel coronavirus has created panic among a section of people, and hence, the number of patients at the flu clinic suddenly increased. Although all patients were given medicines, we did not collect their samples for covid-19 test as they had neither visited a foreign country nor did they come in contact with suspected cases.”

On Sunday, a 34-year-old native of Subhash Nagar locality was tested positive for Covid-19. He works in a Noida-based company where his colleagues were also tested positive with novel coronavirus.

Title: Academic session delay keeps students on tenterhooks
Content:
Bhopal: Ongoing lockdown due to corona virus scare has put the next academic session in trouble. Higher education department officials said it will not be possible for them to start session this year from July 1. Officials said that they are clueless as even board exams are yet to be completed.

Every year higher education announces the admission after the board exam results are declared by the first week of May. As there is uncertainty students are worried that they will not get proper time to complete their course.

"What to say about taking admission in college when even class 12 exams are not finished. I am in high stress about both my board exams and further studies," said Pulkit Sharma, a student.

Another student said, "Colleges and universities have also postponed their exams. I don’t know when my second year classes will start."

Even teaching faculty are also worried as what will happen after the lockdown period is over. "Entire academic has been shut. This is a situation which will have very bad impacts in the long run. Students are really scared about their future," said a teaching faculty of Bhopal-based engineering college.

Engineering colleges which have been facing poor admission scenario are worried that this year they may get even lesser number of students compared to the last few years. "It is possible that admission process in IIT and state engineering colleges may clash. Once the student moves out of the state there are possibilities that they will take admission in other states as the admission process may be delayed in the state. Different states have different academic calendars," said Ankit Soni, another student.

When contacted university officials on the condition of anonymity admitted that academic session will get delayed and it will impact students on a large scale.

Title: Relief as shops in Calangute get produce
Content:
Representative image

CALANGUTE: The supply of essential commodities and vegetables improved in the Calangute-Candolim belt on Monday with a large number of grocery shops and vegetable vendors receiving fresh stock.

However, most grocery shops stayed shut on Monday and are planning to open only after they receive more stock in the next few days.

"I have received good quantity of items like potatoes and onions, but I'm still waiting for things like rice , wheat, flour and dals, among others," a shopkeeper said.

"I will open for 1-2 hours everyday until more stocks come". Some shops were open and seen doing brisk business on Monday.

People have also tapped into the home delivery system arranged by the Candolim and Calangute panchayats, and expressed satisfaction that the delivery was speedy.

Title: Police control rooms buzzing with bizarre complaints
Content: Jaipur: My husband is not cooperating in the lockdown, please send him back home from the bazaar area. These are some of the bizarre complaints the police control rooms in Jaipur and other states are recieving.Many callers are reporting about teenagers and youngsters playing cricket in the colonies and seeking police intervention.“Last night, I got a call from a woman saying that her husband was a chain smoker and walked out of home every now and then. She gave her husband’s number and urged us to ask him to return,” said a head constable working at the Yaadgar police control room in Jaipur.Many women and elderly couples are calling up police stations and control rooms daily.“Some people even ask how long the lockdown will continue,” said Ramesh Chandra, a constable posted at the control room.Elderly couples are urging cops to stop youngsters from playing cricket in the colonies. While women are asking cops to instruct their children not to venture outside home.“We are responding to such calls. The control room intimates the Chetak van in the area from where the complaint is received,” said Ashok Gupta, additional commissioner of police (crime) on Monday.Besides, some callers complain about overcharging by grocery stores, rush at medical stores, etc.Jaipur police commissioner Anand Srivastav said, “We are not baton charging but are strictly taking action against those flouting the lockdown. So far, we have registered almost 300 cases in Jaipur under Section 188 of IPC against people who are not abiding by Section 144 of CrPC issued by public servant. He admitted that many such complaints are received and in many cases strict action was taken. While in some cases people are sent back to their homes.”

Title: Unemployment not virus will kill us, say migrant workers
Content: Determined migrant workers fear for their jobs more than the coronavirus outbreak, lockdown or the sealing of inter-state borders even as they make the backbreaking trek of over 1,000 kilometres, traversing three to four states, with their family and children, find out Siddhartha Dutta and Manasij Bhattacharjee. P 5

Title: Telangana: Techies feed over 2,000 workers, lead by example
Content:
A Good Samaritan hands over food to those in need in the city on Monday

HYDERABAD: Nine techies along with 20 members of Society for Cyberabad Security Council (SCSC) and several activists donned the role of saviours for the needy migrant labourers. The good samaritans have been serving food to about 2000 labourers.

For the week up to March 28, the team distributed about 200 packets per day. However, once their good work got a mention on twitter, a number of requests poured in and the food distribution touched 2,000 packets per day in the last 48 hours. Several like-minded individuals and organisations decided to fund them too. Food was distributed in Siddiq Nagar (Hitech City), Nanakramguda, Neknampur, Gopanpally and Kukatpally. The locations were rolled out to the volunteers by officials of Cyberabad Covid control room and twitteratis.

“We received ample support form Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) officials. We want to bridge the gap between authorities and the needy. I request people to help the migrant workers till the lockdown ends,” said Sai Teja an activist from the city.

A techie said that traffic police helped them by providing vehicles.“Cyberabad Traffic DCP Vijay Kumar arranged vehicles to transport food,” said Ramanjeet Singh, a techie. After videos of migrant workers were posted on twitter in Yousufguda, one techie reached out to them and provided food. The team is also co-ordinating with GHMC and police to ensure that the needy people are not starved. “After serving food to a group of 15 workers on Monday at Kukatpally Housing Board(KPHB), I reached out to police, who promised me that the migrant workers will be provided with food,” said U Surender, a techie.

In another incident 400 people working in a private firm in Jeedimetla were provided with food after an activist co-ordinated with officials. “After members of All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) members approached us, we informed GHMC officials who provided food to them,” said Srinivas B, an activist.

Title: Govt to issue passes to pvt sector workers
Content:
Vijayawada: In a bid to regulate public movement, the state government on Monday said it would issue passes to individuals involved in essential commodities ’ supply chain.

Government officials said the passes are meant for private sector employees who work in private-run factories, offices or establishments which are engaged in the production or supply of essential goods or services as listed by the government.

Explaining the procedure, officials said the entire process to acquire a pass has been put up on the Spandana portal and the applicant need not visit any office.

The owner or employer is the person eligible to apply for the pass on behalf of his employees. The government has also made it clear that employers dealing with essential commodities can run their operations with maximum of 20% of its organisational staff (minimum five). Employees working for the government offices, general public who move out to buy essential supplies during the stipulated time need not avail these passes.

Once approved, the passes will be sent to the employees’ mobile numbers through an SMS, which will have an encrypted QR code. The SMS will have a web-link, which when clicked opens up a printable format with the encrypted QR Code. The police personnel at the check posts are provided with QR code reader. In case of rejected category, a message will be sent to the applicants.

Title: No shampoo, man and his son shave their heads
Content:
Agra: In a bizarre incident, a family which has imposed a strict lockdown regime on itself following the novel coronavirus outbreak, on Monday, decided to tonsure heads of male members and give the rest haircuts themselves, ostensibly after they ran out of shampoo. The family is also gaining fame in the area for using loudspeakers to exhort neighbours to stay indoors.

The residents of Nagla Kishanlal in Foundary Nagar, Agra, the family — comprising of Ravi Kumar, his wife Lalita Devi and three children Tanya (10), Soumya (8) and Yashank (6) — has become talk of the town.

Speaking to TOI over the phone, Ravi Kumar said, “Since PM Modi’s lockdown announcement, we are strictly following protocol. However, a couple of days ago, we ran out of shampoo and didn’t want to go out to buy more. So my son and I decided to shave off our heads, while one of my daughters asked me to cut her hair short.”

He added, “We also motivate our neighbours to follow lockdown protocol by using our public address system.”

Title: Rs 52 crore from mining fund to be used for Covid facilities: CM Pramod Sawant
Content: PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Monday that the decision to transfer food security allowance under the midday meal scheme to the child’s parents has been kept on hold.The Union government allowed the state to utilise Rs 52 crore from the district mineral fund — collected from mining companies to be spent on the welfare of mining dependent people — to set up facilities in view of Covid-19, the CM said.Sawant also said that the Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) has not been withdrawn from the streets of Goa, and that they would continue to bring “discipline”. Speaking to reporters, Sawant said that he has spoken to the director of education and issued a direction to keep on hold the transfer of food security allowance. Sawant said that the amount to be transferred to the parent’s account is Rs 200, and the government has to spend Rs 400 to transfer it.Last week, with schools closed due to the lockdown and students unable to receive their midday meals, the state government had decided to transfer the food security allowance into their parents’ bank accounts.Schools have been closed in the state with effect from March 16, and students have been unable to receive their midday meals. In a letter dated March 20, the ministry of human resource development advised states to provide either midday meal or food security allowance if the midday meal itself can’t be provided for any reason.Sawant also urged flour mills to operate so that people can consume whole wheat flour. He also said the government is taking all steps to maintain the food chain in the state. He said that 268 tonne of vegetables was brought to Goa by the horticulture corporation, and supplied to 1,200 outlets across the state.

Title: Kolkata: Doctors fret over three patients without travel history
Content:
A sanitization drive under way at Eastern Command Hospital

KOLKATA/HOOGHLY: Health experts are concerned about the fact that the three Covid-19 cases reported from Kolkata and the suburbs on Sunday had neither travelled abroad in the recent past nor had come into contact with people who have tested positive till now.

After the three tested positive, the administration made efforts to sanitize their homes and places of work, but panic continues to prevail among family and friends. In fact, the positive report for the Hooghly resident has sent panic waves sweeping across localities in Durgapur, Bankura and Mathurapur in South 24 Parganas. Between March 13 and March 14, the 59-year-old resident of Gangulybagan in Sheoraphuli had travelled to Durgapur and Barjora in Bankura, stayed at a hotel and returned home by the Black Diamond Express.

“The next day, he visited his mother in Mathurapur with his wife. On March 16, he started feeling unwell and got admitted to a private clinic in Uttarpara. The next day, he shifted to a private hospital in Chandernagore’s Bagbazar. During his stay there, he also got his chest examined at a diagnostic centre. He later shifted to the hospital in Salt Lake, Kolkata, where he tested positive to Covid-19. The locality in Gangulybagan has been sanitized and the chest clinic at Chandernagore has been asked to close down for the time being. The private clinic at Shibtala in Uttarpara has also been sanitized. His wife, son, his brother and his family and driver are under observation,” a health official said.

The Baranagar resident suffered a lung infection in 2016 and hasn’t left home since. His brother, along with his wife and son travelled to Madhya Pradesh in March. On Wednesday, the former employee of another engineering firm developed serious respiratory trouble and got admitted to a nursing home in Lake Town where he tested Covid-19 positive. All remaining 20 members of his family from Niyogipara have been sent to quarantine and the locality sanitized.

The Army has also taken measures to find out details of people who may have come in contact with the colonel, an anaesthesiologist, from the Eastern Command Hospital. The officer travelled to Delhi between March 12 and March 17. “Army teams have isolated the facility and identified direct contacts of the doctor in Kolkata. These people have been relocated to a separate facility with full administrative and medical support for mandatory quarantine,” an Army spokesperson said.

Title: Family of man who died in an abandoned house quarantined
Content: LUDHIANA: The family of the man who was found dead in an abandoned house in a village in Machhiwara has been put under quarantine. His last rites were held up for over five hours as the villagers and his relatives insisted on a coronavirus test.After the body of the 42-year-old mentally-ill man, who allegedly had fever, breathing problem and cough, was found, his relatives resisted the cremation and demanded the health department take his samples for the novel coronavirus. After the health department officials convinced the villagers and relatives that he had not died of the disease, they cremated him around 3pm Sunday.Dr Jaspreet Kaur, who is posted at Community Health Centre in Machhiwara, said the family of the deceased has been put under quarantine as a precautionary measure and a sanitary officer has pasted a poster outside his house, even though he didn’t die there. His family comprises his wife, a 22-year-old son and a daughter. His brother and his wife also lived in the joint family.The health officer said the deceased was not a Covid-19 case and there were various facts to support the argument, one being he didn’t have a foreign travel history and there was no evidence of him having visited the Hola Mohalla festival in Anandpur Sahib Health officials said the deceased was a smoker and had respiratory issues. They added that as of now none of his family members has shown any symptoms.Former sarpanch of the village Gurpreet Singh said at present, there were no health issues in the village.‘Health team didn’t even touch body’Former sarpanch Gurpreet Singh had first spotted the body. After the health team had left, the body was kept in front of the deceased’s house. People said the deceased used to wander for days and had returned a week ago and was being treated for fever and cough for the past few days. Some villagers had voiced the apprehension that he may have visited Anandpur Sahib, where the state’s second corona-positive case had gone. Some women, who had spotted him near the village gurdwara recently, said he appeared to be breathing with difficulty. Cautious, family and villagers were wary of touching the body and insisted for a corona test before the funeral. They said the health department team told them “no report of corona test is issued for the dead”. The former sarpanch said the health department team didn’t even touch the body. About 20 persons were there at the cremation ground, where they maintained social distancing and wore gloves and covered their faces.

Title: Ludhiana: CMCH, DMCH OPDs to start from April 1
Content:
LUDHIANA: Christian Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) and Dayanand Medical College and Hospital (DMCH) will start OPDs from April 1 while taking all precautionary measures.

The government of Punjab , ministry of home affairs and justice, had issued a circular on March 29 that stated that chemist shops, hospitals, including OPDs, drug de-addiction centres, rehabilitation centres, nursing homes and diagnostic laboratories must be kept open.

CMCH director William Bhatti said, “We will see patients coming to the hospital from April 1, else their condition may worsen. We will take precautionary measures while diagnosing them.”

DMCH will hold a meeting with a team of doctors on Tuesday morning as thousands of patients throng the hospital.

Chief cardiologist at Hero DMCH Dr GS Wander said, “We will remain open from April 1, but we don’t want crowding as it will defeat the purpose. So far, over 1,500 patients have contacted the hospital doctors through phone calls. Some of them were called to the hospital this week.”

DMCH secretary Prem Gupta said, “We have reduced the number of attendants with a patient. After a meeting, we will take a call on starting OPDs from April 1.”

A city doctor on Monday tweeted to the CM that OPDs be started so that patients were not hassled.

Title: From April 3, Bhilwara to go under extreme confinement
Content: JAIPUR: No one will be allowed to step out of their houses from April 3 to April 13 in Bhilwara , where 26 people tested positive for Covid-19 , and supply of essentials will be regulated during the period.Boundaries encircling 74,000 houses in Bhilwara will be strictly blocked, even mediapersons will not be allowed to enter the area. Amid fear that Covid-19 will enter community transmission level, the 10 days from April 3 will be crucial for health authorities and district adminitration in containing the spread of the virus.Curfew was imposed in Bhilwara on March 20 after six healthcare staff of a private hospital were found infected with the disease.

Title: Prices of vegetables, grocery surge
Content: Jaipur: Prices of vegetables and grocery items continue to surge due to short supply at many localities in the city.Though many grocery stores have given their orders by calling up wholesalers, they are yet to get supply of things like wheat flour, pulses and other FMCG products, including soaps, shampoos, conditioners, chips and noodles. The retail stores are expecting a good supply during the first week of April.On the other hand, the wholesale traders of fruits and vegetables complained that police and administration are not allowing retail buyers to enter into Mohana Mandi, which is also the reason for increase in prices.TOI on Monday visited grocery stores in various localities, including Sodala, Jhotwara, Murilpura, Khatipura and Vaishali Nagar and found many daily use items were out of shelves. “Police are making limited passes for vehicles bringing our items. Thus wholesalers are asking us to arrange for vehicles and passes on our own. Due to this problem for the past three days, we have not received any supply of wheat flour, pulses, refined oil and mustard oil,” said Suraj Goyal, a wholesale dealer at Sodala.Other retailers said there is also a shortage of things like noodles, poha, biscuits, soaps and shampoo. “We were left with sachets of shampoo and smaller biscuit packets. Hopefully, we will get things by first week of April,” said Mahesh Bagra, a retail grocery store owner at Jhotwara.Meanwhile, prices of vegetables at Mohana Mandi continue to increase. “On Monday, many of our regular retailers were not allowed to enter with their vehicles. We urge police and district administration to allow our vehicles and issue more passes,” said Naieem Qureshi, a wholesale dealer at Mohana Mandi.A few localities were, however, benefited with arrival of vehicles carrying vegetables and fruits.

Title: No point in opening units without raw material, open markets: Businessmen
Content:
LUDHIANA: The Punjab government’s decision to allow factories making non-essential goods to operate during lockdown has industrialists questioning the intentions behind the move.

Businessmen are not criticising the government’s decision. They are asking without supply of raw material and with complete closure of shops and establishments in other states, which are their biggest markets, how can they start manufacturing and where will they sell their finished good? Some businessmen claim the decision was taken so that the government could justify levying of minimum charges for power connections.

They say the conditions laid for opening the factories are way too harsh and ever since chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh announced the decision aimed at curbing the mass exodus of migrant workers, a large number of business associations have instructed their members not to apply for the permissions and they have been openly opposing the move on social media. They say it is not viable to go through the lengthy process and incur extra costs in operating the factories by fulfilling the conditions fixed by the government. Sources say members of business associations are peeved at not being consulted before taking the decision.

According to Jaswinder Thukral , president of Janta Nagar Small-Scale Manufacturers’ Association, “The decision is not going to help any micro or small unit. The small units require raw material and tools on a daily basis and when the shops are closed how will we procure these and start production? This is practically impossible and therefore the government must take its decision back immediately and keep the factories closed till April 14.”

Speaking to the TOI, Inderjit Singh Navyug , former president of United Cycle and Parts Manufacturers’ Association (UCPMA), says, “This is an impractical decision. Even if we meet the harsh conditions fixed for operating the factories and even source raw material and produce goods, it will be of no use because the entire market for cycle and cycle parts is in UP, Bihar, MP and Jharkhand. When these states are totally under lockdown, whom are we going to supply the goods to? This decision would have benefitted us only if the shops, commercial establishments in other states too were fully open and there was no restriction on movement of buyers in the markets.”

According to Varinder Rakheja, former president of Sewing Machine Dealers ’ and Assemblers’ Association, “How can the risk of opening factories amid this situation be taken? On one hand, the Central and the Punjab governments are pleading to comply with social distancing and on the other the state is asking us to open the factories. How will government ensure that the factories that resume work after obtaining the permissions are complying with all the norms?”

A large number of factories making essential goods like bread, buns, masks, among others, are already running in the city as they were accorded permission to run their operations subject to certain restrictions like number of labourers.

Applications for resuming work at units

A few applications for opening factories have reached the district industries centre (DIC), but sanctions may take time as the department is not ready to take any chances. It is likely that the government officials will inspect the factories to check if they fulfil the conditions laid down by the government, which include arrangement for boarding and food for workers, health check-up and social distancing during machinery operation.

Title: Rlys seek NGOs’ help to provide masks, sanitisers to staffers
Content:
Bhopal: West Central Railway, Bhopal division, on Monday issued an statement that according to the instructions given by the health department, the railways is providing its personnel with the necessary material as masks, sanitisers, liquid soaps, gloves and others to fight coronavirus infection. The division has also appealed to all concerned that if such material is available with any NGO or vendor, they should provide it with the information for purchase.

DRM Uday Borwanker is constantly in touch with employees and supervisors in the division, so that they do not face any kind of deficiency.

Higher amounts of these items may be required by the Bhopal division till the period of lockdown, stated an official release.

Notably, masks and sanitizers are being made for their employees by diesel workers and their families in the diesel shed and electrical loco shed in Itarsi.

“This is a very serious matter in the situation arising out of Covid-19, and in this difficult time, Indian Railways is working day and night to transport essential materials. Our employees are very bravely and diligently contributing to it,” stated the release.

Title: Goa: Horticulture outlets restart ops, stocks being received
Content:
Goa State Horticulture Corporation Limited

PANAJI: After suspending operations for a week in light of the nationwide lockdown, the horticulture outlets run by the Goa State Horticulture Corporation Limited(GSHCL) resumed operations on Monday. The GSHCL has supplied around 268 metric tonnes of vegetables through its outlets.

While the corporation insisted on starting with home delivery of the greens, some store operators refused to resume the activity due to logistical issues with the delivery services. Approximately 1,000 of the 1,200-odd stores had operations running across the state.

“The vegetables have reached in all constituencies . Things will settle down in the next few days,” said GSHCL chairman Pravin Zantye .

GSHCL has sourced most of its vegetables – onions, tomatoes, potatoes, cabbage, cauliflower and French beans – from suppliers in Belagavi while green chillies, lady-finger and cluster beans have been sourced from local farmers in Goa.

Sources at the corporation said that the horticulture operators were maintaining social distance with shoppers at their outlets. However, most outlets managed to do home delivery through volunteers who were appointed by the local panchayat.

“People are not supposed to come to the outlets. We want the outlets to undertake home deliveries,” GSHCL managing director, Sandeep Faldesai said.

Meanwhile, of the three outlets on Divar island, only the single outlet near the Divar junction was selling vegetables on Monday. As residents lined up outside the outlet, sources said that the queue started extending till the fish market, almost a mile long.

Title: DD Kerala benches its 400-strong workforce
Content: Kollam: The employees of Doordarshan Kendra , Thiruvananthapuram, is wondering whether it is the Mandi House mandarins’ ‘love for English in the time of Corona’ behind the decision to replace DD4 ’s Malayalam programmes with DD India’s English content.Since March 24, DD4 has stopped telecasting its Malayalam programmes and is filling the time slot of nearly 22 hours a day with English programmes. Except for the three half-an-hour news bulletins and over a dozen five-minute news highlights, the DD4, the regional channel dedicated to Malayalam, is broadcasting English programmes only. Reason: the management does not want to risk its workforce by working during Covid-19 pandemic.However, a section of the DDK staff are complaining that by the time normalcy returns whatever little loyal viewership the public service broadcaster has these days will switch over to other popular satellite channels.DDK employees said that the management should have utilized its 400 strong manpower and resources to render support to people to tide over the challenge posed by Covid-19, by telecasting novel programmes. “While the entire world is fighting Covid-19 pandemic, we were ready to work and produce Malayalam content But the public service broadcaster is refraining from its duty,” said an anonymous source at DDK.Deputy director general Doordarshan and chief of DDK, Thiruvananthapuram, Sanjeev Sugathan said that he was only complying with his headquarters’ guidelines to avoid risking its employees’ lives. “Initially, 50% of the employees were asked to work from home. As the situation worsened, I decided to function with a skeletal staff and asked the majority of them to stay at home,” he said.

Title: Mathura admin sanitizing all vehicles, roads barricades
Content:
Agra: The administration in Mathura has adopted the practice of sanitizing all its on duty vehicles and barricades on the roads, twice a day. The precautionary measure was taken even as no case of Covid-19 has surfaced in the district famous for religious tourism.

Also, 50 buses which were used to transport migrants to different districts and neighbouring states from Mathura were also sanitised after return.

Mathura’s chief fire officer Pramod Sharma said that police personnel have been deployed on 24*7 duty and they are at the risk of contracting the disease. So the administration has decided to sanitise all vehicles and barricades which have been used on roads. He said, “We have two machines and they are being used for fogging purpose”. He told TOI that vehicles are being disinfected with Sodium Hypochlorite.

Title: Man posing as doc nabbed for violating lockdown rules
Content:
Agra: Wearing a lab coat and posing as a doctor, a man was caught by Agra police for violating lockdown on Monday. After sustained questioning, the man broke down and revealed that he was returning home after dropping his wife, a nurse in a private hospital.

Identified as Bhupinder a resident under Madan Mohan Gate police jurisdiction, the man was caught from Naubasta intersection by Lohamandi police.

Narendra Sharma, station house officer of Lohamandi, said, “Bhupinder was driving a motorcycle when he was caught by our men. When he was asked why he was roaming on city streets amid the lockdown, he claimed he was a doctor and was heading home. However, something was not adding up to his narrative. When asked to show his ID card, he failed to present one.”

Under sustained questioning, he revealed that he was not a doctor and had worn the lab coat to avoid policeman depioyed near the barricades.

Since he impersonated a doctpr, he was booked under IPC sections 171 (wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and presented in the district court, where he was granted bail, added the SHO.

Meanwhile, district jail of Agra released 426 undertrials on a eight-week interim bail amid coronavirus scare.

Title: AAP asks ration shops to have stock
Content:
Aurangabad: The Aam Aadmi Party ( AAP )‘s state wing has asked the government to ensure that state-run public distribution system (PDS) outlets are open and have sufficient stock amid the ongoing lockdown in the country.

The central government has announced that poor families will be provided with three months of ration for sustenance. The AAP said that this move of the government is a much-needed relief for the people. “We found that a vast majority of the ration shops are closed, and even those that were open were short on supply,” said AAP state secretary Dhananjay Shinde.

Maharashtra’s key cities like Mumbai, Pune, Nashik, Aurangabad, Nagpur and Pimpri Chinchwad have a substantial population of migrant labourers and daily labourers, who are worst hit due to the lockdown and PDS through ration shops must work so as to ensure that their abject conditions are immediately alleviated, he said.

The members of the party conducted inspections at Kothe Galli, Panchavati in Nashik, Akurdi and Pimpri in Pimpri Chinchwad, Appar Pune, Hadapsar, Bhekrai Nagar- Phursungi in Pune, Gulmohar Colony, Bhadkal Gate, Jyoti Nagar, Satara Parisar, TV Center, Garkheda, Shivaji Nagar in Aurangabad, Manjri village, Tandulja in Latur, Reshim Bag, Medical Chowk, Mahal and Itavari in Nagpur.

The AAP said that its government in Delhi is providing food proactively for 4 lakh people who are in distress through Delhi Urban Shelter Board and 525 Food and relief centres including night shelters and requisitioned schools.

Title: 700 hotel rooms for medics near hospitals in West Bengal
Content:
Nine medics of ID Hospital have started staying here

KOLKATA: The state government has booked 700-odd rooms in various hotels and guest houses to put up doctors and nurses.

The rooms, being booked by KMC, are mostly near ID Hospital, SSKM Hospital and Calcutta Medical College & Hospital (MCH). While ID Hospital is the state’s only referral hospital for treating infectious diseases, SSKM Hospital or IPGMER on March 10 got approval for conducting Covid-19 tests and MCH has now been designated as the go-to facility for suspected patients.

The first batch of nine medics from ID Hospital handling Covid-19 cases have started staying in a Beliaghata guest house (Siliguri Atithi Nivas) on Beliaghata Main Road. A doctor said, “The list will grow longer because we are encouraging more and more nurses and doctors to live in the vicinity.” A senior official in KMC said, “Our priority was to look for stay-over options near ID Hospital because coronavirus tests are being done at NICED situated within the hospital.” The government will pay for the double- and triple-bedded rooms.

Arindam Biswas, consultant (general medicince), R N Tagore Hospital, welcomed the state preparedness.

“The doctors, nurses and other health caregivers are working round the clock. The authorities can’t have them covering long distances to reach their workplaces. That itself would be in violation of the lockdown, legally and clinically. An arrangement for 700 hotel rooms near the key hospitals look adequate at this point of time.”

An official in the state health department said, “ICMR has hinted that the disease may have infected patients outside the limited criterion of overseas travel history. The number is small but that’s an indicated that India is likely in Stage 3. Bengal must also be prepared for this.”

Title: Ambulance topples over man fleeing Bengaluru after shutdown
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: A speeding ambulance hit five bikes before toppling on the motorcycle of a security official, killing him at Gangapura Gate, near Hoskote, on NH-75 in the early hours of Saturday.

The official, Ramesh Kumar Reddy, 37, a resident of Thanisandra and from Chittoor district in Andhra Pradesh, and his wife, Nandini Reddy, were fleeing to their village owing to the Covid-19 scare and lockdown in Bengaluru. Nandini survived the accident with minor injuries.

According to police, Reddy had stopped his bike on the road and was enquiring with other motorists about a Covid-19 checkpost ahead. The checkpost has been set up near Gangapura Gate to prevent people from entering Kolar district. A few motorists had stopped their bikes on the roadside and were talking to those who were sent back from the checkpost when the serial accident took place at 3.20am.

The ambulance driver moving towards Kolar lost control of the vehicle and hit six bikes, including Reddy’s. The ambulance toppled and landed on Reddy, killing him instantly.

“We were worried about Covid-19 and decided to head back to our village. We left home at Thanisandra around 1.30am. Some motorists informed us that police were not allowing vehicles to cross the checkpost. So, we stopped our bike and were waiting there along with other motorists when the incident took place,” police quoted Nandini as saying in her complaint.

Nandagudi police said four others were injured in the accident. The ambulance driver is in police custody.

Title: Veggie prices dip as vendors hit the streets for survival
Content:
The number of vegetable vendors has increased to such an extent that in the stretch of one-and-a half km of Ch... Read More

Bhopal: There was a slump in the price of vegetables on Monday as more vendors and daily wage earners are taking to selling vegetables by the roadside, the only “option” left with them till the lockdown is lifted.

Dheeraj Singh, who has office in M P Nagar, was surprised when he randomly asked a vegetable vendor on a handcart the price of tomatoes and was informed, “Rs 10 per kg.” Last Thursday, Singh had bought tomatoes for Rs 50 a kg.

When Singh asked the vendor why he was selling them for so cheap, he replied: “Bechna to hai na saheb. Harek jagah to sabziwale baithe hain (we have to sell our stuff, after all. There are vegetable vendors in every nook and corner of the city nowadays”.

Green vegetables, onion and potatoes are also also available for the ‘before lockdown’ prices. Drumsticks, selling for Rs 60 per kg, was the costliest of all vegetables. The number of vegetable vendors has swelled to such an extent that in the stretch of one-and-a half km of Chuna Bhatti, there were as many as 15 vendors.

“I work with a welding shop. The shop has been shut since the day of janata curfew. I have no job now, so I need to earn some money to sustain my family,” said Jauhar, who was selling vegetables from outside a closed shop in Shahpura.

In addition, the ‘vegetable at your doorstep’ scheme initiated by the district administration to keep the prices of vegetables under check may also have helped restoring the prices of vegetables to normal.

“Supply of vegetables in the wholesale market was normal, but it was the vendors who were selling them at inflated prices. Now, it has been checked,” said an official of the Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC).

Title: Each GVMC ward will get a bazaar to meet buyers’ needs
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The district administration will set up bazaars in each GVMC ward . The city currently has 13 bazaars and another 21 bazaars were set up after the lockdown. “We will set up another 27 mobile bazaars,” said joint collector Siva Sankar.

The district administration has set up four additional bazaars, two mobile bazaars, two additional bazaars in Anakapalli, one each at Payakaraopet, Natavaram, Makavarapalem and Yalamanchili. The district administration has asked marketing officials, tahsildars and bazaars estate officers to set up one bazaar in each ward within GVMC limits. After delimitation, GVMC has 98 wards.

The joint collector said that the administration was encouraging farmers to bring their produce to markets. “We are displaying the prices of vegetables. We are taking stock report every day to assess the situation. More than 200 farmers have permission to sell their produce in the bazaars,” he said.

The joint collector requested the public to maintain social distance and said the district authorities would provide essential commodities. He said the district officials were taking measures to see that all essential commodities would be available in markets.

Title: Heavy police deployment on roads to check motorists
Content:
Kolhapur: The city police are coming up with a host of measures — from seizing people’s vehicles and registering cases against them to blocking major roads by putting up barricades — to ensure that people do not unnecessarily venture out of their homes as long as the lockdown is in force.

Police have even started initiating action against those illegally transporting people in vehicles such as trucks and ambulances from other districts to Kolhapur.

On the very first day of the lockdown, police took action against 100 people for violating rules and even seized their vehicles. Police did not arrest anyone but registered cases and accordingly will take action against them once the lockdown period is over.

On the second day, police booked more than 400 people for coming out on the roads and seized their vehicles. However, realising that the exercise of seizing vehicles was not bearing desired result, police started blocking a part of the major roads with barricades. So far, barricades have been put up at 200 spots in roads and chowks.

Heavy police force has been deployed at all the roads connecting to Kolhapur district to ensure people entering the district do not have an international travel history or any connection with foreign nationals. The Kini and Kognoli toll plazas on national highway 4 connecting Pune and Bengaluru are being monitored to keep a check on people coming in. The rush on NH 4 reduced after superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmuhk warned that all those entering Kolhapur district from Pune and Mumbai would be put in institutional quarantine.

Continuing their action against violators, police registered cases against 70 people in the district for reasons like roaming on road without purpose, keeping shops open and selling liquor when it is completely banned.

Title: Innovating to fight corona: 1 cylinder to supply six patients with oxygen
Content:
The portable MOM designed by the Naval Dockyard

Visakhapatnam: To cater to the requirement of oxygen supply for multiple patients during the ongoing pandemic , personnel from the Naval Dockyard, Visakhapatnam have designed an innovative ‘Portable Multi-feed Oxygen Manifold (MOM)’ using a six-way radial header fitted to a single cylinder .

This innovation will enable one cylinder to supply six patients with oxygen simultaneously, enabling critical care management to a larger number of Covid-19 patients with limited resources.

A typical oxygen providing facility at hospitals comprises an oxygen cylinder feeding only one patient through a ventimask arrangement. During the ongoing pandemic, ventilator support is required for five-eight per cent of patients, while a large number require oxygen support.

Existing facilities are not adequate to cater to such a large requirement. A need was felt to design a portable arrangement that could provide oxygen through masks to a number of patients using a single-cylinder.

After successful trials, the Naval Dockyard commenced the manufacture of 10 portable MOM with two six-way radial headers catering to 120 patients at makeshift locations.

Title: Four rob Joshi Nagar man of his car at gunpoint
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Amid the curfew, four men robbed a resident of Joshi Nagar of his car at gunpoint in Haibowal on Saturday night.

While two of the accused have been identified as Aman Tidh and his brother Kanu, sons of liquor smuggler Lucky Tidh, of Durgapuri, Haibowal, police are yet to establish the identities of their two accomplices.

Dinesh Khanna, a make-up artist, said in his police complaint, “Around 11.45pm Saturday, I was going to drop my friend, Suresh Kumar , to his house in Tarsem Colony . When we reached near a dera in Haibowal Kalan , a sedan (a silver Hyundai Elantra) intercepted my car, a Hyundai i20 (PB913232). A turbaned man alighted from the sedan and walked towards us. As soon as I rolled down the window, he took out the car keys. Then Kanu came out of the sedan.”

Soon thereafter, Kanu’s brother Aman along with his accomplice reached there on a scooter. “At gunpoint, Kanu asked me and my friend to step out. After abusing us, Aman got into my car and drove off. The turbaned man sped away in his sedan and Kanu along with his accomplice escaped on the scooter,” Khanna added.

Khanna then called up the police. “I know Aman and Kanu as they live in my locality and are notorious criminals. But I do not have any rivalry with them. When police reached the spot, I along with them went to the brothers’ house and found my car parked there.”

The complaint was lodged on Sunday night.

On how the car was snatched amid curfew, Haibowal police station additional SHO sub-inspector Kuldeep Singh said, “As checkposts have been established in all areas, the accused could not escape with the car. We are on their lookout.”

Both Aman and Kanu were earlier booked for smuggling liquor. Aman also has an attempt to murder case against him as he had opened fire at a dhaba in Dadu Majra in February 2019, the cop added.

A case has been registered against the four under sections 392 (robbery), 506 (criminal intimidation), 34 (act done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) of the IPC.

Title: Congress sets up ‘control room’ to help migrants
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The Congress party has set up three control rooms each in Panjim, Margao and Mapusa to give any assistance and to provide relief to migrant workers and those still struggling for essential groceries in the state. The party also demanded that “all food stocked up by BJP MLAs should be immediately released” to avoid creating an artificial shortage.

Pointing out that BJP was trying to gain political mileage from the supply crisis in Goa, state Congress president Girish Chodankar demanded that the government should use the public distribution system to supply essential commodities to people instead of using BJP karyakartas.

“We demand that the chief minister and all BJP MLAs release the stock hoarded so that the artificially-created absence of essential commodities is relaxed,” said Girish Chodankar, adding that videos of the stock hoarded have gone viral on social media. On Saturday, the party held a video conference meeting with desk-in-charge of Goa, A Chellakumar, and other senior functionaries to take stock of Goa’s situation.

Title: No plan to extend 21-day lockdown: Govt
Content: Cabinet secretary Rajiv Gauba on Monday denied speculation that the government may extend the 21-day lockdown after April 14. Expressing surprise at some reports to this effect, Gauba confirmed there were no such plans. “There are rumours & media reports, claiming that the Government will extend the #Lockdown21 when it expires. The Cabinet Secretary has denied these reports, and stated that they are baseless,” the PIB tweet said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: What leaders are doing while working from home
Content:
DMK chief M K Stalin

CHENNAI: Even during lockdown, politicians are making their presence felt by issuing statements, as usual, to media. The only difference is that they are confined themselves to their comfort zones in their houses. Most leaders said they were spending much of the time over phone, checking WhattsApp messages and making calls.

Some leaders like TNCC chief K S Alagiri had moved to their homes in their native villages to get some leeway to move around, before the lockdown started.

DMK chief M K Stalin starts his day with a walk inside his compound. Much of the time he spends talking to party functionaries, MPs and MLAs over phone to keep himself abreast of the ground reality across the state. He asks party leaders about availability of essential commodities, sanitizers and masks, said a DMK leader. He spends some time with the family members too.

On Monday, Stalin announced that the DMK would donate Rs 1 crore to the chief minister relief fund. A video in which Stalin speaks to party MPs, MLAs and district secretaries was released by the party.

TNCC chief K S Alagiri spends much of his time reading books. He has picked up one on Adi Shankaracharya for now. “As part of public life, I release videos about Covid-19 and ask each party cadre to keep calling at least 50 people to explain need for social distancing and keeping their area clean,” said Alagiri, who is staying in a small village near Chidambaram. He said he was enjoying the greenery and fresh air as his house is surrounded by large tracts of agricultural land.

Alagiri said he was re-discovering himself while reading a book on Adi Shankaracharya. “Shankaracharya’s philosophy brought people together. But I feel it is difficult to control mind,” said Alagiri.

CPM state secretary K Balakrishnan is busy speaking to party functionaries in Bihar, Jharkhand and West Bengal. “My day starts with receiving calls from party cadres from across India. They want help for people from their states stuck in Tamil Nadu on account of lockdown. Though migrant workers want to go back to their states, it is not possible now as borders are sealed. I contact our cadres across the state and organise food and place for stay for the migrant workers wherever they are. Many Tamils stuck in Kerala seek help to return to Tamil Nadu. I explain the situation to them,” said Balakrishnan, who is staying in his residence in Chennai.

CPI state secretary R Mutharsan reads books and watches TV to while away time at his home in Chennai. “My routine has changed and the time spent on phone has increased. Confined to our homes, we are unable to provide help to those in need. Many suffer without accommodation and food,” he said. The government should increase the number of tests to identify new cases before there is an exponential growth in the number of patients, he said.

Title: Four Kolkata cops extort money from truckers ferrying essential goods, suspended
Content:
The extortions reportedly took place at the Howrah-end of Vidyasagar Setu
