KOLKATA: Kolkata Police has suspended four cops —an assistant sub-inspector and three constables—for allegedly stopping trucks ferrying provisions and other essential goods and extorting money from them. A departmental inquiry has been initiated against the four, who belong to the Vidyasagar traffic guard and the Hastings police station’s Vidyasagar Setu outpost.

The incident took place on the Howrah-end of Vidyasagar Setu near Nabanna on Friday night. A businessman lodged a complaint with a senior officer on Saturday night, following which, DC (south) Meeraj Khalid and DC (traffic) Rupesh Kumar were asked to probe the incident. The two officers checked images of CCTV cameras on the bridge as well as its approach roads and made their recommendations. “We found suo motu evidence that raises suspicion. The accused cops were suspended in less than 36 hours of receiving the complaint. The probe will continue,” a senior officer said.

This is the first case of cops being suspended during the lockdown, imposed to minimise the spread of novel coronavirus, and the first time the force came under scrutiny. The swift action, said sources, was taken to send out two messages: one, that such unscrupulous act won’t be tolerated and two, to ensure that suppliers can have faith in police and run their business without facing harassment during lockdown. “While we hail the police good work, such dereliction of duty will not be accepted, especially when we are doing everything to ensure supply lines to markets are not hampered,” said an officer.

Cops on duty at places bordering Kolkata have also been sent strict instructions through their OCs not to break the law. Among various initiatives that police have been taking to help out traders, suppliers and retailers carry on business during the shutdown is the introduction of e-passes for food and medicine supply workers and setting up of helplines for those stranded on road. “We are sending our police teams across all major markets and grocery stores to collect reports on the functioning. We are ensuring that people do not have to pay through their nose. The supply of vegetables has increased and prices of vegetables have stabilized,” said an enforcement branch (EB) officer. “We received certain calls from traders in Koley Market that some trucks carrying essentials from districts were stopped at Burdwan and Dankuni. We called up the district police concerned and ensured the vehicles reached Kolkata,” said DC (EB) Biswajit Ghosh.

Title: NGO, locals & students join hands with police & admin to feed poor and migrants
Content:
Agra: Various social organisations, students, businessmen, police personnel, administrative officials in Agra, Mathura and Aligarh have come forward to provide food to the daily wagers, homeless and others affected by 21-day lockdown across the nation due to Covid-19 outbreak.

While Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) students have been distributing raw material to the needy people every day, district administration with the help of an NGO are distributing 20,000 food packets twice, in afternoon and in evening every day.

Talking to TOI, district magistrate CB Singh said that apart from providing cooked food to the needy and homeless people, the administration is also providing help to local residents by engaging “easy day”, on which people can book food items for home delivery.

AMU coordination committee members are providing pulses, flour and potato to people, who have lost work due to lockdown. “It is our responsibility to help the most vulnerable amongst us in their time of need,” said a member of the committee, Aamir Mintoe.

In Mathura, NGO Annamitra foundation with the help of police has distributed raw material to 600 families so far. They are distributing two packets including flour, rice, oil, pulses and spices along with vegetables to people after verifying their credentials from their local network with the help of police.

Founder of the NGO, Yogesh Sharma, said that apart from distributing raw material, cooked food that include “vegetable rice”, biscuits and milk were being distributed to migrant workers, who were travelling from Delhi to their home district on foot on NH-2.

In Agra, several volunteers including shoe exporters, lawyers and educationists have joined hands to help people, who are facing problems due to sudden lockdown. They are distributing at least 15,000 cooked food packets every day along with fruits and biscuits for children.

“We have been taking necessary hygiene precautions by wearing gloves and face masks and using hand sanitisers during food distribution,” said Vivek Sarbhoy, who is city coordinator for the program.

Title: Student who returned from UK tests positive for Covid-19
Content:
Agra: A 17-year-old student, who had returned from the United Kingdom on March 18, has tested positive for novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in Agra. The latest report has taken the total number of Covid-19 positive cases in the Taj city to 11.

The UK returnee’s father is the owner of a group of private colleges. And the boy is a Class 11 student studying in Newcastle, UK. He along with his father visited the Agra district hospital on Saturday for tests. The samples were sent to King George’s Medical University (KGMU) and reports came out late on Sunday. His father has tested negative, so far.

After his return from the UK, the student was asked to maintain self-quarantine for a few days, sources said. The health department has now placed the entire house under lockdown and sanitised the area. Contact mapping and screening of people in the neighbourhood has begun.

Since March 2, as many as 11 Covid-19 cases have surfaced in Agra. Out of these, seven, including five members of a shoe exporter’s family, manager of the exporter’s factory and his wife, have been ‘cured’ and are currently quarantined at home. Three patients are being treated at the quarantine facility in SN Medical College.

On Monday, district magistrate (DM) Prabhu N Singh said, “Seven patients have been cured. Samples of railways employee’s daughter, who had returned from Europe and had initially tested positive, following treatment at SN Medical College, has now tested negative, twice. She will be released soon.”

“The health department is screening everyone who was in contact with the student. The neighbourhood is being sanitised. People are advised not to step out of their houses without any valid reason. They have been asked to call the helpline numbers ‘108’ and ‘102’ in case of any health issues,” the DM added.

Title: MMRDA to bear cost of 11,000 labourers
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: MMRDA will bear the additional cost incurred for around 11,000 of its labourers in relief camps, besides ensuring their sanitation and health checkup.

Metropolitan commissioner R A Rajeev held a review meeting with heads of various departments via video-conference on Monday to discuss the well-being of labourers. MMRDA said since the force majeure clause is in place, labourers’ expenses will be reimbursed to the concerned contractors.

MMRDA will continue to give monthly salaries to the staff, appointed through an outsourcing agency, as the facility to work from home is being provided to them. Rajeev said there were 5,444 labourers for various Metro projects, 5,042 for MTHL and 576 for other projects in Mumbai Metropolitan Region . tnn

Title: At your doorstep: Community groups deliver daily essentials
Content: Kolhapur: As roads across the city wore a deserted look owing to the lockdown, the community groups formed to provide doorstep delivery of essentials have made the process less painful for the citizens.On Sunday, people in many areas had stepped out of their homes to buy groceries. However, on Monday, there were less number of people outside grocery stores and medical shops.“I received around 15 orders from my locality and nearby Kasba Bawda area. I am yet to get the movement pass, but after showing the order details to the police, I was allowed to deliver the goods. Most of the orders were for grain, spices, bread, jam, tea and cooking oil. We have been asked to pack the orders and sanitise them before delivering them to the people as there is a possibility of transmission of coronavirus through parcels. The community groups also need to be informed before and after the delivery with details of the order,” an owner of a retail shop in Line Bazaar area saidMeanwhile, after district collector Daulat Desai ordered the doctors to open their clinics, many clinics were opened on Monday. The collector has ordered the civic body to seal or cancel the licences of the clinics if they remained shut.Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti held discussion with the doctors and requested them to open their clinics as people suffering from other ailments were having a tough time.“I have asked our staff to get details of the clinics that are still closed. The doctors can use the gloves and masks which they already have. Many are demanding personal protective kits that are currently being provided only to the doctors handling coronavirus cases. If needed, we will provide them with the kits. We expect all clinics to open from Tuesday,” Kalshetti said.Police have also started making announcement that children and senior citizens should remain indoors as they have less immunity and may easily get infected by the coronavirus.Also, district guardian minister Satej Patil held live sessions with the citizens on Monday. During the session, citizens made several demands starting from relaxing the restriction on movement and opening of essential service outlets in their locality.

Title: Developers take care of workers, tell them to stay: Credai
Content:
Aurangabad: Developers and builders in the city said most of the workers employed with them are from Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh and a majority of them had left before the lockdown was announced. Those who had stayed back, however, are being taken care of.

Sunil Bedmutha, the Aurangabad Credai secretary, said the workers were not willing to stay back without any work. About 15,000-17,000 workers were engaged in the city before the lockdown,” he said.

“The situation was already grim for the construction industry. The Covid-19 outbreak has delivered another blow. However, the workers are our responsibility, so we are taking care of them,” he added.

Credai officials said at least 300 sites were functioning earlier this month. Now, though all the work has come to a standstill, they had not allowed the workers at the sites to leave.

Developers said they had paid the workers enough to meet their daily expenses. Ramesh Nagpal, a senior architect and developer, said he had not allowed the workers to leave the sites and is taking care to provide them food and wages.

Nagpal, who runs two construction companies in Pune and Aurangabad, rued the exodus seen in Delhi. Also a former national chairman of the urban development committee of Indian Institute of Architects, he urged PM Narendra Modi to issue suitable orders to companies to look after the workers.

Credai Aurangabad president Narendra Singh Jabinda told TOI, “We told the workers that if they want to go, they could do so at their own risk. Otherwise, we will provide them enough to meet their expenses,” he said.

Jabinda and Bedmutha pointed out that on municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey’s request, the Credai has started a well-equipped quarantine ward at Kalagram. At least 10 people, who had come from Jordan, were quarantined there.

Title: Govt: Won’t hide community spread
Content: The Union government said on Monday lockdown and other steps were having a positive effect on the infection rate of Covid-19 with India going from 100 to 1,000 cases in 12 days as compared to other countries struggling to control the disease. The government said it would inform the public of a community spread if it happens as stronger steps may be needed. P 6

Title: Villagers in Goa fall back on local farm produce amid lockdown
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI/QUEPEM: With lack of essential commodities and poor access to groceries in the face of the ongoing nationwide lockdown to tackle the spread of Covid-19, villagers are turning to locally produced food for survival.

Most villagers continue to fetch items like onions, tomatoes and potatoes from grocery stores. Since vegetables like ladies’ fingers, cabbage and brinjal easily grow in Goa, their distribution is making small farmers unsung heroes for hungry Goans.

In some far-flung villages, small farmers move house to house selling their personal produce while those closer to towns are taking orders via WhatsApp , sources said.

“This lockdown hardly affects villagers as they are the main suppliers of agricultural produce,” John Fernandes , a lawyer from Ambaulim and an organic farmer, said.

As most villagers in the Quepem taluka are agriculturists, they have enough food grains to last them for over a year. They also use raw mango as a pickle and use raw jackfruit in dishes.

In Aldona, vegetables like cluster beans, brinjal, spinach and ivy gourd are available. “This is all freshly picked produce procured directly from the farmers. They’re even priced within the normal range,” said villager Nirmala Fernandes .

After state horticulture outlets downed shutters, Taleigao-based Vito Gomes had about 1,000kg of brinjals from his farm . These were distributed among buyers.

A resident of Dona Paula said he and his neighbours have been able to source sweet potatoes and brinjals from a neighbour.

Nestor Rangel, who has an organic farm in St Estevam, has about 4,000kg of brown rice. He is awaiting his travel and distribution permit to start selling from his farm. “For now, I’m selling the rice from my home in St Cruz to whoever can travel till here. The prices have not been hiked. I don’t take cash and insist on an online transaction to ensure minimal interaction,” he said.

Title: District civil hospital transformed into exclusive Covid-19 facility
Content: Aurangabad: The Chikalthana district civil hospital has now been transformed to exclusively deal with Covid-19 cases after getting directive from district collector Uday Choudhari to shut down all other health services at the facility The entire building of the state-run hospital situated on Jalna Road will now work as Covid-19 management centre. Though no positive case has been reported in Aurangabad district as of Monday, the hospital is being equipped to be ready for any unforeseen situation.Santosh Naikwade, pediatrician at the hospital on behalf of district civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni, said the ground floor of the hospital is reserved for screening and swab collection of the patients.“The first floor of the building has the isolation ward with 100 beds. The symptomatic and asymptomatic patients with travel history or those who have come in contact with a confirmed coronavirus patient will be placed in isolation ward. Currently, 6 persons are under observation in the hospital,” he said.“On the second floor, the hospital has 43 beds reserved for the confirmed cases of Covid-19. The work on installing compartments between every bed is underway. We have 8 ventilators available, 5 more are being procured from Government Medical College and Hospital and 5 are being repaired. The district collector will provide another 11 or 12 ventilators,” Naikwade said.Divisional commissioner Sunil Kendrekar and Choudhari visited the hospital and reviewed the availability of equipment and supplies.“The hospital has currently 300 sets of personal protective equipment (PPE) which is used by the doctors for swab collection. More sets will be procured if the positive cases are found,” the hospital said.Meanwhile, 5 physicians, 5 anaesthetists and 5 specialists at the hospital will be undergoing Covid-19 management trainingDoctor’s swab sample sent for testingA doctor at the district civil hospital, who had been to Pune, has developed fever. Subsequently, the hospital has collected his swab sample and has sent it to the Government Medical College and Hospital for Covid-19 testing.

Title: ‘No need for card-holders’ thumbprints on ePoS devices’
Content:
PANAJI: In view of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19), fair price shops (FPS) owners will now have to self-authenticate distribution of foodgrains on the electronic point of sale (ePoS) device for ration card-holders.

The department of civil supplies and consumer affairs directed FPS operators on Monday to exempt ration card-holders from authenticating thumbprint on ePoS devices at the shops, in a precautionary measure against the potential spread of the virus.

“The distribution of ration quota for April commenced from March 30.

Similarly, under the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana scheme, all the NFSA (AAY and PHH) ration card holders will be given double of their current entitlement and the essential food supplies will be distributed free of cost from April 07,” a statement from the department read. The government constituted a team of the inspector of civil supplies commercial tax and legal metrology to verify the stock.

Title: Delhi schools become temporary homes
Content: NEW DELHI: Many of the migrant workers who swarmed Anand Vihar on Saturday to find transport home in defiance of the anti-Covid-19 lockdown have found lodgings in Delhi government schools and night shelters. As many, however, have left Delhi. The 140 migrants or so accommodated in a government school in east Delhi’s Patparganj chafed to return to their villages, worried as they are not only about their own prospects but also relatives fending for themselves in the villages during the national closure.Alarmed by the surging crowd’s potential to spread infection, Delhi government wants to ensure they don’t migrate in such numbers and is, therefore, providing them food and shelter in around 800 centres, including 569 schools and 244 night shelters. Around 12,000 migrant workers and homeless people are staying in these camps. Most are content with the arrangements, but express a wish to reach their hometowns and villages as soon as possible.Social distancing is a way of life at these camps, with the beds placed at appropriate distances and food distribution likewise following a space pattern. Each person has been given a mattress and blanket. Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia said that the state government had converted 11 more schools into temporary shelters on Monday. “The numbers in the night shelters doubled in the last two days, so we shifted many from the night shelters to government schools,” said Bipin Rai, a DUSIB member.At the school in Patparganj, volunteer Baban Ghosh, an area resident, told TOI, “Thirty-six classrooms are occupied by the migrants, who are not allowed to leave the premises. We were able to provide milk to women who asked for some for their kids.” Inside one classroom, a couple and their two children, aged five and 13, were resting having walked from Nangloi to Anand Vihar. It was a tough walk and Laxmi, 26, even fainted leaving her husband, Aleen Kumar, a construction labour, to resuscitate her. “My head was spinning and I couldn’t walk,” revealed Laxmi. “We were picked up by an ambulance and brought here. We are from Kanpur and we want to go back.”The two kids have made friends with Raja, 23, who shares the classroom with them. Raja hiked from Rajouri Garden and reached the Anand Vihar bus stand by noon and got a bus too, but it was stopped from leaving. “I have three children, wife and parents back in the village. They made a video call on Sunday and were crying to see me walking like this,” Raja said. “Now that I have meals and shelter, I have recorded a video for them. They are happy, but once this is over, home is where I want to be.”Under the railway flyover at east Delhi’s Shakarpur, women and children keep coming towards the road and returning to their temporary halt. “We are seeing if food is being distributed,” explained Geeta Devi. “Daily-wage workers do not have savings. We have been here since morning waiting for food. The problem is it arrives only two times, so we all take turns to check if it has come.”At a night shelter a short distance away are 10 labourers, who share the two bathrooms there. Ashok Chakraborty, 60, who hails from Ballygunge in West Bengal and has been living at the shelter for some days now, told TOI, “I wanted to go home, but the shelter caretaker informed me I might get stuck on the way if I left this place. Here at least, food is not a problem and we get meals twice a day.”

Title: State borders face space crunch to quarantine incoming migrants
Content:
Unaware of the fresh orders to seal state borders, the labourers continued to walk or proceed towards their de... Read More

Bhopal: A day after the Centre decided to stop the massive migration of labourers, the bordering districts of Madhya Pradesh faced a practical problem of identifying space to quarantine thousands of migrants who have already reached the entry points to the state.

Unaware of the fresh orders, the labourers continued to walk or proceed towards their destination in trucks or even atop empty petrol tankers. Many of them who already travelled hundreds of kilometers from Dahod in Gujarat to Morena in Madhya Pradesh on way to Mathura in UP are stuck midway after the MP government order.

Now look at the plight of Jagdish Kumar of Mathura. Heading a group of 17 people of the same family including 15 children, Jagdish had started his journey from Dahod in Gujarat last week.

After he left Dahod, he reached Western MP to take AB road and reach Morena in about 3 days. By the time he reached Morena, he had already covered about 1000 kms and was unaware of the new government order.

“I am a resident of Mathura, but now police have stopped me at this border check post in Morena. They have promised to let me go after two hours. My home is just 140 kms from here”, he said pleading the local journalists to talk to police so that he can proceed further.

Meanwhile, ill-equipped and overworked doctors brave the adverse circumstances. In the absence of mask, many of them wrapped a piece of white cloth around their face to cover nose and face as they screen the migrants.

A top government bureaucrat in Bhopal said, “It’s a huge task. It’s difficult to seal the borders. It’s not a building gate that can be closed down. The number of people reaching from Gujarat in Jhabua and Alirajpur is huge. So is the case in the district of Morena.”

He said that the administration was asked to identify “nearest buildings” to quarantine the migrating population and provide them food.

On Monday morning, arrival of large number of people continued in Morena district. Sarai Chola, a village bordering Rajasthan is the centre of activities.

The district collector Priyanka Das said, “We have identified places to quarantine those who wanted to proceed further from Morena to the districts of UP and MP.”

In the neighbouring Sheopur, district collector Pratibha Pal told TOI, “We have identified tribal hostels which were vacated after the students left for home. We have about 90 people who wanted to go to Jharkhand. But they are lodged at the hostel and we will provide them food and water.”

In the afternoon, a large number of people arrived at Harpalpur , a bordering town of Chhatarpur district. They were travelling from Delhi to Banda and Jhansi districts of Uttar Pradesh. Over 1000 people stuck near Harpalpur before the district authorities talked to their UP counter parts. After the and after their nod, the buses carrying the migrants were allowed to move further.

Title: 38-year-old man admitted to isolation ward in Satara
Content:
Kolhapur: Satara district civil surgeon Amod Gadikar on Monday said a 38-year-old man has been admitted to the district hospital after he complained of dry cough and breathlessness.

“The throat swab sample of the patient has been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune and he has been admitted in the isolation ward. His condition is currently stable,” Gadikar said.

He added that a 35-year-old Paris-returned man and a 57-year-old woman from Satara district, who were admitted to the Satara district hospital on Saturday as suspected Covid-19 patients, have tested negative.

According to Gadikar, the two positive patients, who are admitted to the isolation ward in Satara, are also responding well to the treatment and are stable. “As a precautionary measure, we have started contacting and collecting swab samples of senior citizens having travel history after March 15,” he said.

Meanwhile, medical education minister Amit Deshmukh, during a press briefing, said the Miraj medical hospital will be turned into a full-fledged coronavirus treatment centre for the district.

“A three-member committee has been formed under the chairmanship of the Mumbai-based JJ Hospital dean Pallavi Saple. She has turned the Miraj hospital into a 300-bed Covid-19 isolation facility. It has 15 intensive care units and other medical facilities. A testing centre for coronavirus infection too will be set up at the hospital in the coming days,” he said.

“The training of the hospital staff is underway and will be completed within a week,” Deshmukh added.

Title: Eight booked for hunting hog deer
Content:
Plibhiti Field force of Pilibhit Tiger Reserve on Monday seized 18 kilos of hog deer meat from a banana orchard at Naujalaha Nakta village under Mathotanda police station. The meat was wrapped in banana leaves. Eight people have been booked by the PTR authorities.

The hog deer had been killed at Mahrajpur village, about 6 km from Barahi forest range of PTR.

Deputy director of PTR Naveen Khandelwal said three

of the eight accused were identified as Manoj Sarkar, Roman Sarkar and Panchu Mandal. All hail from Mahrajpur. They were nabbed by the forest force from their homes. The other five would be arrested soon, he added.

Khandelwal said all were booked under provisions of the Wildlife

Protection Act.

Title: Halfway through 1,600km journey, labourers stuck in city shelter home
Content:
Nagpur: Driven by the chaos that followed the lockdown, daily wager Bhura Jatav and his five friends began their 1,602km journey from Visakhapatnam city of Andhra Pradesh to Karauli district of Rajasthan. Hitch hiking, and walking till they got the next ride, the group reached Nagpur, covering 800km in three days, with a similar distance still to go.

When they were first stopped at RBI Square in the afternoon, they refused to go along with Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) officials to a shelter home. However, by evening they had forced to stay at a shelter home.

Aged around 19 and 20, the boys worked for Metrochem company at Vishakapatanam as contract workers. They showed their duty attendance sheets with the address of a book centre at Lekipattanam locality of the city.

A search on the internet shows there is not even a direct train to Karauli, close to the Chambal region in Madhya Pradesh. A road journey from Vizag to Karauli leads through four states before reaching Rajasthan. “The contractor, who is also from our village, left us and is not traceable. When it difficult to sustain any more, we all left,” said Rakam Jatav.

They first boarded an empty truck headed towards Delhi from Vizag but had to get down at the Maharashtra-Telangana border. “At some place called Rajura on the Maharashtra-Telangana border, the police intercepted us. The truck was allowed to go but we were asked to get down. We started our journey again and reached Chandrapur, getting another ride,” he said.

The group said people had been kind to them on the route, with locals giving food and political workers helping them to get a ride. They had walked into the city after being dropped on the outskirts. Like the many other migrant workers, they narrated the same story of running out of money and food.

“We have spent 3 months to a year in Vizag. There are no opportunities back home, and we don’t have any landed property either. Now, we have to rush back as there are aged parents at home,” said 19-year-old Saurabh Gunavat. “We earned Rs12,000 a month and were able to save Rs3,000 to 4,000,” said one of them.

Meanwhile, on almost all the highways, the numbers thinned on Monday though migration continued. TOI again drove on Nagpur-Jabalpur highway to find groups of workers continuing their journey. From groups of 10 to those boarding mini trucks, TOI spotted over 400 workers from Nagpur till around 20km before Mansar.

In the middle of the highway, 15km from Mansar, a group of 20 men were resting under a shade by the side of the road. They were hotel employees at Hyderabad, with one of them employed as a guard in Care Group of hospitals. The group was heading towards Sidhi district of Madhya Pradesh, over 1,091km from Hyderabad.

After facing a crisis, they had called friends in their village, who came to pick them up in three passenger jeeps. On the way back, one of the vehicles rammed into another, leaving it damaged. No one was hurt but the vehicle could not go further. The group is stranded again, as they wait for help.

MP SEALS BORDERS, 1,000 SENT BACK

On Tuesday, the Madhya Pradesh government sealed entry points into the state. Sources at the Khawasa checkpoint on the Nagpur-Jabalpur Highway confirmed the development. They said nearly 1,000 people have been refused entry. Some of them insisted on camping at the border itself. A majority of those at the border only want further passage to UP, said the source.

Title: Government fish vans to reach out to more Kolkata markets
Content:
Locals queue up at Jadubabur Bazar to buy fish

KOLKATA: The State Fisheries Development Corporation (SFDC) that retails fish from mobile vans in some markets, will reach out to more localities in north and south Kolkata. The decision to augment its retail initiative was taken following complaints of a steep rise in fish price across city markets.

While Rohu and Katla are being sold at Rs 300-Rs 350 per kg in the retail market, SDFC sells these two varities at Rs 160 and Rs 190 per kg, respectively. Though the agency also sells other varieties of fish like bata and mrigel, it is rohu and katla that are in demand now.

SFDC managing director Subrata Mukherjee said around 20 vending vans had been deployed to sell fish in Ballygunge, Tollygunge, Jadavpur, Jodhpur Park, Bhowanipore, Kalighat, Shyambazar and Salt Lake at prices that were much lower than the market price. “Sometimes, we are sending the vans twice, once in the morning and again in the afternoon-evening with replenished stocks,” said Mukherjee.

Since the crisis is also affecting markets beyond Kolkata, SFDC authorities are working on a proposal to extend the retailing of fish to fringe areas as well. Mukherjee also said that the agency’s mobile app was in operation for bulk order of raw fish in specific locations.

The West Bengal Comprehensive Area Development Corporation (WBCADC), which is under the state rural and panchayat department, is also reaching out to senior citizens in Salt Lake and New Town to sell fish, meat, vegetable, pulses and other essential grocery items at competitive rates.

“We are reaching to senior citizens in Salt Lake and New Town. They can place orders through phone or online. We will have the order delivered to the doorsteps,” said WBCADC administrative secretary Soumyajit Das.

Title: ‘Ensure every house gets essentials’
Content:
POINGUINIM: Door-to-door delivery of essential provisions began in Canacona from Sunday. Councillors of the Canacona Municipal Council and panchas of various panchayat bodies distributed groceries and other essential items to the people of their respective wards.

At a meeting held on Sunday, Canacona MLA Isidore Fernandes urged the elected representative to ensure that every household gets proper supply of essentials and that supply of medicines is unhindered. He also stressed on the importance of this to ensure that people do not come out of their houses, thus exposing themselves to the risk of contracting coronavirus.

All panchas and councillors have been issued volunteer passes and Fernandes said he has requested the CM to consider Canacona as a special case for passes.

Meanwhile, villagers came to the aid of some migrant families living in Borkoifond in Poinguinim .

Title: In line since 4am, Sanguem locals return with no vegetable
Content: QUEPEM: The battle for groceries and vegetables continued on Day 6 of the lockdown , with local authorities botching up the distribution process at Sanguem, leaving residents frustrated.The ward councillors on Sunday evening had distributed only 10 coupons in each ward for residents to buy vegetables, and to their surprise, they received a very small quantity of vegetables for Rs 150. In each packet, there were only five onions, three tomatoes, two cucumbers, one cauliflower, two bitter gourds, one piece of sponge gourd and a small amount of green chilies.Taitrist and resident Justiniano Fernandes said that more than 400 persons stood in line to purchase groceries, from around 4am on Sunday morning, but all were sent home at 8.30 am empty handedA video released by Sharmila Suraj Arolkar, resident of Sanguem town, in which she is seen criticising politicians across party lines for not providing basic provisionswent viral on social media.Later in the evening, Sanguem deputy collector called her to his office and questioned her as to why she released the video. Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar and mamlatdar Manoj Khorgaonkar were present during the questioning.Arolkar told TOI that she had only stated facts, and brought to the notice of the deputy collector that one councillor allegedly took away large quantities of vegetables to celebrate his daughters birthday.

Title: Good samaritans help the needy
Content:
NSTL employees distributing food packets on Monday

Visakhapatnam: Philanthropic organisations and a few locals have come forward to help the poor in the city and its outskirts during the lockdown. While some are supplying protective gear to health workers, others are providing food and essential commodities to the poor.

Santosh Pulletykurty, founder-president of Ken Foundation Society, supplied 2,000 masks, 2,000 pairs of gloves and 20 litres of sanitiser to the Government Hospital for Chest and Communicable Diseases. “We also received a letter of appreciation from the hospital superintendent for providing protective material to personnel who are testing and treating Covid-19 cases,” he said.

“My friends from the business community and I have made arrangements at a kitchen in MVP Colony to supply food for free, which includes breakfast and lunch, for around 400 people per day. We have also identified a few institutes housing physically-disabled students and old age homes in Tagarapuvalasa, Yendada and Madhurawada and will supply food from March 31.”

Members of Rotary Club Vizag Couples, Richard Borthwick and his wife Supraja, with some team members served food to about 200 stranded passengers and the homeless at Vizag Railway Station. “We also distributed 200 masks made by our son Aaron,” said Supraja.

Adnan Sabuwala, a member of Lion’s Club said they met the deputy collector and handed over 1,000 cloth masks and 60 N95 masks for health and sanitation workers.

Title: Migrants happy to get shelter, but want to go home
Content:
Nagpur: A steady stream of migrants kept flowing into the NMC’s shelter homes on Monday as the government clamped down on inter-state travel and ordered officials to move them into the designated camps.

Using its own night shelters and premises of private institutions, the NMC has scaled up its accommodation capacity to 1,262 spread over 15 shelters. While migrants, majority of them being labourers from neighbouring states, were happy to have a roof over their heads and all three square meals a day, the homesickness was evident.

Dinesh Hirbulkar is from Amravati who rues the fact that he’s so close, and yet so far. “I worked at a private firm here but after the lockdown, there was no work. I had to collect some money due to which I stayed back. I received the money but when I reached station, it was announced that trains have been shut down. At this shelter, people are from MP and other states, whereas my home is literally next door and yet I can’t go,” said Hirbulkar, who has been put up at the shelter home in Indora.

Sheshrao Umbre from Mandla said he lies to his mother about everything being normal here. “I called and told her that I am still at the construction site, and though work has stopped, they are allowing us to stay there and are also feeding us,” said Umbre.

He is happy with the facilities but says is eagerly waiting for the lockdown to end so that he can go home. “I rue the fact that we started for home so late due to financial issues. Two more weeks is a very long time to stay in one location. I want the government to do medical tests on us and then allow us to travel to MP,” he added.

Prashant Uikey, supervisor of a shelter home at Indora, said, “We have have almost 40 people here in two separate buildings. Enough distance is being maintained and they all are being provided all meals and medical attention.”

At the NMC school near Raj Bhavan at Sadar, Pravesh Sharma begs to be released. Sharma worked in a granite factory in Bengaluru. Twelve of them and a child started off on six motorcycles from Bangalore to Gwalior. At Nagpur, they were apprehended by the police. The bikes were taken to Dhantoli police station and the group was sent to the school which now is a shelter room for migrant labourers and footpath dwellers.

“Can something be done,” asks Nawal Singh from the same group. He also admits that their condition was not like many other daily wagers. “They have been living in Bangalore since 12 years and were not migratory workers exactly. We could have easily pulled on during the lockdown, but then there was panic everywhere, so we left too. As the children’s schools were closed, we took it as an opportunity to visit our home town as well, but now are held up here,” said Singh.

At the school that had 55 occupants, the migratory workers felt like caged birds and wanted to be allowed to continue their journey further.

“I have developed cramps in the legs walking all the way, but it was all in vain after I was caught by the police and put up here,” says Shyam Maraskole, a construction worker. Maraskole said he walked down from Nashik with three others. “My children are anxiously waiting. I could have easily reached home in Seoni district,” he says. Seoni is around 100km form Nagpur.

“They can carry out our check up and let us go. We will again get ourselves examined in our villages,” said Suksen, also from Seoni. “We are all put up in a single room. This will only increase the changes of infection,” said Tamsingh in his twenties as leftover food could be seen lying in dustbin right in front of the rooms.

Title: Corona lockdown: Rescue flights to take 1,600 stranded foreigners out of Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Efforts to repatriate tourists stranded in Goa have picked up pace as authorities have lined up at least six rescue flights to evacuate approximately 1,600 foreign nationals by April 4.

The German government with support from the Union ministry of external affairs has organised three rescue flights out of Goa International Airport from Tuesday. The flights, operated by Air India, will include not just German nationals, but citizens of other EU nations too, said sources.

The first flight will depart from Dabolim at 5.15am on Tuesday for Mumbai and then head directly to Frankfurt. On April 1 and 2, similar flights will depart at 11am to Mumbai and then Frankfurt.

“The document verification process has already begun, the passengers have been provided food. Most passengers are German, but the flight is loading a lot of EU passengers,” a source in the German embassy said.

Officials with Airports Authority of India also confirmed that the Finnish airline, Finnair, will be operating a relief flight on April 1 and that an aircraft from Poland could also be deployed to pick up stranded EU citizens on April 4.

Airport officials said Israel operated a special rescue flight to take its citizens stranded in the state through Arkia on Monday night.

“Our efforts are on to ensure that stranded foreign nationals return to their homes. We are working with all foreign embassies. Already three relief flights have taken off from Goa. In the coming days there will be three Air India flights in which at least 900 Germans will be leaving. One Finnair flight will fly to Helsinki after that,” Goa airport director Gagan Malik said.

Officials estimate that there are around 2,000 foreign nationals stuck due to the lockdown in Goa. “Social distancing will be maintained all through the process and we will also ensure that they are seated apart while sitting at the airport. We are trying to give as much relief,” Malik said.

The relief flights for German nationals sparked envy among the British tourists who remain stranded in Goa. “Germans putting UK to shame,” said Derbyshire resident Hazel Holiday.

“At the end of our lane in Colomb Bay we have just seen a group of German citizens being picked up by mini bus to take them to a coach in Palolem for airport transfer. They received individual emails from their government with everything planned for them. Well done Germany- UK still nothing!” she said in a public post on Facebook .

Title: Lockdown makes procuring goods difficult for store owners
Content: Aurangabad: A host of issues is plaguing the owners and operators of stores selling essential commodities like groceries and medicines. Since they have to deal with many customers in a day, they stand a higher chance of getting infected by coronavirus . Moreover, the nationwide lockdown has made commodity procurement difficult.Procuring the products from wholesale markets and ensuring that people get access to essential commodities amid lockdown is not easy. However, the traders are doing their bit to ensure residents get what they need at the local stores and sometimes even at their doorstep.Sangita Shirse and Pratik Shirse of Sandeep Provisions in Cidco N-3 said that they were trying to ensure that they have all the essential commodities so that citizens could get whatever they need under one roof. They are even facilitating doorstep delivery of groceries but are facing issues in procuring the essentials.“Due to difficulty in movement of goods, there is a shortage of supply at Old Mondha. We need to procure essential household products to keep up with the demand,” said Sangita.Owner of Dhiraj Provisions in Cidco N-5 is worried about infection spread. “We come in contact with hundreds of people everyday. You can’t tell who is infected,” said the owner.Some shopkeepers have placed a table infront of the counter to ensure 1 metre gap from the customers. Boards put up in shops asking people to cover their faces and stand on the markings to ensure social distancing is of little help, especially during sudden rush in the evening.According to Jadhav of Savji Bhaji market, the rush at the vegetable wholesale market in Jadhavwadi is concerning. “We follow the norms to avoid infection but there is no alternative to procurement of fresh produce for vendors like me. If the fruit and vegetable markets can be separated or different days are designated for their sale, the rush of customers can be reduced,” said Jadhav.Jagannath Kale, president of Aurangabad Jilla Vyapari Mahasangh, said that traders have held meetings with district supply officer (DSO) Mahadeo Kirwale ensuring that there would no shortage in supply of essential commodities. “We are seeing to it that commodities like oil, rice, wheat and sugar which are procured from other cities have a smooth supply.”“We are coordinating with the local suppliers . Even the Aurangabad DSO is coordinating with his contemporaries in other districts to ensure that the trucks carrying these commodities are not stopped,” said Kale.Suggestions were also being made to use the extra space available at Jadhavwadi market for vendors to sit away from one another to avoid rush, he said.Meanwhile, with the salary day of most citizens drawing nearer, the district-level trader association has appealed to people not to engage in panic buying. “They can buy the essentials needed for a month. There is not going to be any shortage of essential commodities. This would avoid the gap in supply and demand,” Kale said.

Title: Pandemic lockdown leads to cleaner air
Content:
Aurangabad: Due to a country-wide lockdown from past one week, there has been a considerable drop in the air pollution levels of the city.

Over the last one-week vehicle movement is next to negligible which saw the environmental sensors installed under the smart city project showing a drop in numbers.

Aurangabad Smart City Development Corporation Ltd. (ASCDCL), the special purpose vehicle formed for the implementation of the Smart City project in Aurangabad, has hired KEC International Ltd. for the master system integrator (MSI) project.

The dashboard available with the MSI showed a notable change at Kranti Chowk and Mahanubhav Ashram Chowk. The data recorded from March 20 to 28 showed between 111 to 29 with the average being 75 which is well within the limits of CPCB standards.

Title: One has to conquer fear first to defeat Covid-19, say survivors
Content: JAIPUR: There is more fear about the disease than what it is in reality, says the first cured Covid-19 patient, who belongs to Rajasthan.While the virus is affecting the lives of people, 85-year-old Madhusudan (name changed) is lucky and has survived despite having co-morbidities like chronic kidney disease and diabetes.He has just recovered from the disease. His family was also fortunate as no one got infecteed. “We were in disbelief when this happened to us,” Madhusudan’s son told TOI, while recalling the day when doctors asked the family to distance themselves from him for some days. The 10-odd days in isolation will always remain etched on Madhusudan’s mind. Even while he was suffering painfully, he could not hug and embrace his children.His family knew that it was a tough time as the entire country had started facing the highly contagious epidemic. “We were aware that if we got worried or lost hope, we would be heading nowhere. Family members gave strength to each other and we defeated fear from our minds. From the entire episode, I can say that as long as you are taking all medicines, precautions and following guidelines issued by the Centre and the state government , there is no need to worry,” said Madhusudan’s son.

Title: Goa businessmen shield corona-hit clients with refund cover
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Some businesses are leaving legalities aside and offering full refunds to clients should the need arise, in wake of the pandemic. Professional wedding photography service Aether Storytelling has assured couples that it will stand by any decision they take in these times of uncertainty.

“We believe that in these times, anything that can be done to reduce stress must be done,” it stated publicly urging other wedding service providers to follow suit. Founder Gasper D’Souza told TOI that he is already receiving calls from anxious clients about destination weddings scheduled for the last three months of this year.

“We haven’t got any cancellations yet, but we have been receiving calls from concerned clients especially from Australia who will have to travel in through the Far East,” D’Souza said.

With bookings done way in advance and entire families being flown down for weddings, couples are nervous about their plans even though the events are scheduled for the latter part of the year.

“Legally we have a contract signed and it is made very clear that the booking deposit amount is not refundable. But, these are not normal circumstances. We decided that in a situation like this, we must do our part for the clients,” he said..

Title: Metro construction workers getting free food, shelter
Content:
CORONA VIRUS AND METRO ISOLATION WARD: Nagpur on Monday March 30th,2020

Nagpur: Even as lakhs of construction workers in the country are desperately trying to go back to their villages as they are unable to buy food items, MahaMetro ’s construction workers are getting free food and shelter . Not only this, the workers are being regularly checked for coronavirus by doctors engaged by its contractors.

A MahaMetro spokesperson said that about 2,900 workers, who were unable to go back to their homes, are being taken care of in their labour camps. TOI visited one such camp at Nagalwadi (near Hingna) and talked to the workers. They said that they were getting sufficient food.

The Nagalwadi camp, housing 300 labourers, belongs to MahaMetro contractor Afcons. Gaurav Tripathi, an Afcons employee, said that a doctor from Lata Mangeshkar Hospital comes to the camp office near the camp and checks the workers for coronavirus symptoms. An ambulance is also available for ready use.

“We have set up two isolation rooms so that if somebody has cough and cold, he is kept there away from others. As soon as it is possible, we will shift the patient to government hospitals,” said Tripathi.

Lav Kush Kumar, a labourer from Uttar Pradesh, said that while he was getting food, he would prefer to go home. “There is nothing to do the whole day. Boredom is a big problem,” he told TOI. Naresh Mandal, a worker from West Bengal, said the same thing. Both the workers said that they were tested by the doctor every three to four days. Most of the workers in Nagalwadi camp are from UP, WB, Bihar, Jharkhand and Odisha.

A MahaMetro spokesperson said that about 5,500 construction workers were employed in Nagpur Metro project in the first week of March. “Hundreds went to their native villages for Holi and did not return till the lockdown was announced. Some 600 workers were from nearby districts and went home before the lockdown. Now, there are 2,871 workers in 40 camps,” he said.

He further said that all the camps and offices were fumigated and disinfected frequently. “The workmen are being educated about the importance of social distancing. Masks , gloves etc., have been distributed and are available in adequate stock. Twelve thermal scanners are available and workmen are randomly tested for high temperatures,” he said.

“A safety team comprising 20 professionals and their team are on emergency duty. Senior officials visit worksites regularly and ensure that the actions are effective. Detailed emergency preparedness and response guidelines have been prepared and implemented. Psychological counselling is being offered to workers to ensure that they stay in proper frame of mind,” said the spokesperson.

He added that eight doctors were taking care of the workers full time or part time. The number of male nurses employed by MahaMetro is eleven.

Title: After their release, inmates’ return home worries officials
Content:
Bhopal: In a bid to contain the spread of Covid-19, around 1,000 inmates at Bhopal Central Jail and 12,000 across state have got either interim bail or parole. However, for the administration a major challenge awaits as due to the total lockdown, these inmates would have to be dropped home by police.

The decision to release these inmates was taken by a state-level committee comprising the Madhya Pradesh high court Chief Justice, principal secretary and director general (jails). The panel had decided that undertrials and convicts who are lodged in jails for crimes having conviction of less than five years were to be released. These measures came following a Supreme Court order on March 23 that directed all states and Union Territories to set up high-level committees which would look into the release of convicts on parole who have been in jail for up to seven years, in order to decongest jails amid the threat of Covid-19.

DG (prisons) Madhya Pradesh Sanjay Chawdhary said, “We have already taken several measures such as setting up of isolation barracks to contain the spread of Covid-19 in jails. Releasing these inmates will be of great help as it will reduce crowding in jails. As far as sending them home is concerned, it has been decided that the inmates would sent to their respective districts by police in their vehicles. They would first report at the jail of their respective district and would then be dropped home”.

Sources said that when the decision to release inmates was made, their transport was the biggest concern as the entire state is in lockdown. Subsequently, it was decided that police would drop these inmates home. However, given the emergency duties bestowed upon police during lockdown, this would also be difficult, and is likely to take time as well, added sources.

Superintendent Bhopal central jail, Dinesh Nargawe said, “Around 147 inmates who were under trials were already released, others would also be released on interim bail soon. Even convicts are being released on parole of 60 days. Between 1,000 and 1,200 inmates would be released from Bhopal central jail”. Sources said that some of the inmates at Bhopal jail who are eligible for release are from far away districts like Balaghat; transporting them to their homes would be a herculean task for police.

Title: SUK’s move to defer summer semester exam affects more than 3 lakh students
Content:
Kolhapur: The summer semester examinations of the Shivaji University, Kolhapur ( SUK ), which was supposed to commence in the last week of March, has been deferred until April 14 by the varsity in a move that will affect more than 3 lakh students from over 290 affiliated colleges in Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur districts.

In a circular issued on March 27, G R Palase, SUK’s acting director of the board of examinations and evaluation, said as per the instructions from the Union and state governments, a lockdown has been imposed and all the varsity’s verbal, practical and written examinations have been deferred until April 14.

When contacted, D T Shirke, the pro-VC of SUK, told TOI: “We are working on several options. Even if the lockdown ends on April 14, we have to give a breathing period to the students before starting the exams. Quite possibly, the exams could commence in the first week of May.”

In case there is another extension to the lockdown, Shirke said the university will work on other plans for first and second-year undergraduate course exams. It will be put the plan before the academic council members and only after the council’s nod, it could be worked out. Shirke, however, refrained from giving more details.

Due to the changes in the current schedule, entrance exams for various courses will also be affected.

Shirke said unless the final-year undergraduate semester exams conclude, the entrance exams will not be conducted.

Due to the lockdown and suspension of all academic activities on the campus, most students have left their hostels, but there are a few students who are still living on the campus. Shirke said they are taking every precaution.

Title: Imtiaz Jaleel takes to road, appeal citizens to remain indoors
Content:
Aurangabad: Amid reports of citizens constantly violating the lockdown orders, Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel on Monday took to roads and appealed citizens to stay indoors .

“It is unfortunate that the youths from different parts of the district are stepping out of their homes just to have the feel of things in violation of lockdown,” Jaleel told TOI.

He visited several areas and appealed the masses to stay indoors from the public announcement system installed in the civic body car. He even appealed the head of families as well as elderly people to take responsibility of not letting the youths out of their homes without any valid reason.

Sources in the civic body informed that the MP has been asked to continue with his appeal by stepping on the streets for the next few days.

The idea to rope in Jaleel to convince the masses was considered by district collector Uday Choudhary and civic body chief Astik Kumar Pandey. The police brought it to their notice that using force and registration of offences against offenders has failed to put a check on people venturing out. Instead, it has added to friction between the masses and the police.

A senior police officer said, “The police, administration, government and masses need to be on the same page for fighting the pandemic. However, some mischievous elements from different parts of the city continued to venture out and create a problem for law enforcement agencies.”

The city police have already started registering offences against those stepping out even without face masks, as well as those violating social distancing norms while buying groceries in the markets.

Title: Safety of medical staff ensured: Goa Government to Bombay HC
Content: PANAJI: The state government on Monday informed the high court of Bombay at Goa that all doctors and staff have been provided with 17,000 tablets as per Indian Council of Medical Research guidelines to protect them against any Covid-19 complication. Steps are also being taken to provide them with full personal protective equipment, the government said.While submitting a detailed reply to the court in response to a letter petition filed by two law students regarding safety of doctors and staff, hospital isolation and facilities for quarantine, ventilators and testing, the government stated that it has placed orders to procure almost 200 additional ventilators and has 400 testing kits.Apart from this, it is expected to start actual testing of samples of Covid-19 within two days. Standard operating procedures have been evolved and sent to the Indian Council of Medical Research for approval, the government said.Advocate general D Pangam placed on record the reply signed by secretary (health). Two law graduates Jay Mathew and Gauravvardhan Nadkarni had approached the high court. Their letter was converted into a public interest litigation petition by court.While disposing the petition, Justice M S Sonak observed that it is apparent that the state authorities are effectively exercising their responsibilities and making efforts to combat this pandemic.The government said that samples for Covid-19, which are being sent to Pune and Mumbai, will be tested at the newly established laboratory at Goa Medical College and Hospital. A team of doctors from Goa has already been sent to the National Institute of Virology in Pune for training and trial tests have already commenced where actual testing and reporting is expected to start within a day or two, the government stated.Five quarantine centres have been set up in North Goa and five in South Goa besides isolation facilities available at several government and private listed hospitals.The state government also made reference to setting up of a task force and war room. A State Control Room has also been established to deal with the aspect of interstate travel, medical assistance and essential supply of medicines, the government stated.Information helplines for coronavirus and mobile apps have been made available for the public.

Title: I want to be home, says pregnant woman stuck in camp with ailing daughter
Content:
Nagpur: Vishakha Praful Tambore, 24, and a resident of Boda village in Tiroda tehsil of Gondia district, had come to Government Medical College and Hospital here for treatment of her two year old daughter Alia when the lockdown was announced by the government. She and her daughter are since stuck in Nagpur.

Vishakha said Alia was suffering from a heart ailment since birth. A local doctor advised her to take Alia to GMCH Nagpur. They were in Nagpur when suddenly a complete lockdown was announced and all transport services were shut. “We got stuck at the hospital. Yesterday, we were brought by the authorities to the shelter camp at Tuli College of Hotel Management on Bokhara Road near Koradi octroi post Nagpur,” Vishakha said.

Vishakha is also five months pregnant for the second time. Her Husband who works in Hyderabad is stuck there due to the lockdown, said Neerja Pathania, an event management professional who along with her friend Neha Patel, an entrepreneur, and a few others are managing this shelter camp as a social responsibility.

Neerja said that it was a risk for people like Vishakha to stay in such camps without a doctor. She said they were trying for a doctor as a daily check up is must of people staying in the camp, specially of someone like Vishakha.

Vishakha said if she had known things were going to take such a turn she wouldn’t have come to Nagpur.

“Though those running the camp are counseling us and taking good care of me and my daughter by providing us with mask, food and stay at this camp but I still want to go back to my home as my in-laws are waiting for us,” Vishakha said.

Title: Bhopal, Gwalior, Jabalpur collectors could be shifted
Content:
Bhopal: After Indore, the state government is planning to change the collectors of Bhopal, Jabalpur and Gwalior districts. Avinash Lavania, who is the son-in-law of senior BJP leader Narottam Mishra, could replace Tarun Pithode as Bhopal collector.

Besides, the government would also change the Gwalior collector after the erstwhile Nath government had replaced Anurag Choudhary with Kaushlendra Vikram Singh as the new Gwalior collector earlier this month. According to sources, Choudhary would be given charge of a big district and may be even send back to Gwalior.

Jabalpur collector Bharat Yadav, who had ordered the closure of an iron ore mine owned by BJP MLA Sanjay Pathak earlier this month, is also expected to be removed. Officials had said the Jabalpur district administration, where the mine is located, ordered the closure of the mine for allegedly violating a Supreme Court ruling.

On Saturday, the state government transferred Indore collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav and made DIG Manish Singh the new collector. Harinarayanchari Mishra was appointed as DIG.

Earlier, Rajgarh collector, Nidhi Nivedita who had allegedly assaulted a BJP leader during a pro-Citizenship Amendment Act rally on January 20, was transferred on March 24, a day after Shivraj Singh Chouhan took oath as CM for the fourth time.

Soon after taking over as CM, Chouhan changed chief secretary and appointed Iqbal Singh Bains as CS. Kamal Nath government on March 17 had appointed M Gopal Reddy as chief secretary, but was removed within a week after BJP came to power in state.

Title: Paippad protest: Cops to probe conspiracy angle
Content:
Guest worker arrested

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state police have ruled out interference of any extremist forces in the sudden mobilization and protest by guest labourers at Paippad near Changanassery But, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan smelt a conspiracy behind the agitation. While speaking to reporters here on Monday, Vijayan said the police have started to probe the conspiracy and already three persons have been arrested.“This is an attempt to jeopardise the good works the state has done in controlling the spreading of the virus. As per the directives issued by the prime minister, the state government has done everything to take care of the needs of the migrant labourers,” said Vijayan.Police and intelligence agencies have reached a conclusion that the main reason behind the sudden grouping of labourers from northern states was mainly triggered by the video clippings of thousands of labourers thronging the interstate bus terminal at Anand Vihar in New Delhi, where the Uttar Pradesh government had arranged buses to ferry them to their hometowns.“These clippings and the news was widely circulated in the social media groups containing labourers from Bihar, Odisha, West Bengal, etc. in the state. This triggered a hope that they will be provided with some kind of transport facility to return to their native states,” sources said.Also, in a discussion held by the local tahsildar with the representatives of labourers, contractors and the house owners, all kinds of basic facilities were assured to them, but the contractors were willing to send them back as they are also running into crisis with their work being stalled, sources added. At the same time, many of the house owners were willing to accommodate them without rent.“Most of the labourers were hardly left with any money as they send them to their homes on a daily or weekly basis. Also, with the beverage outlets and other pan shops shut down and the regulations in the state being tough in these matters, the labourers who are used to such habits suddenly found it hard to adjust,” sources added.State police chief Loknath Behera had said an assistant nodal officer will be appointed by the police, and all the details relating to the migrant labourers- including their activities, health and comfort- should be sent by district police chiefs to ADGP (law and order) and ADGP (intelligence) on a day-to-day basis.A man from West Bengal was taken into custody in connection with the public protest held by guest workers at Paippad in Kottayam district on Sunday. Police have examined the call list of the guest worker, Mohammad Rinju. They found that he had contacted several workers as well as some media persons through this phone ahead of the protest. Police are probing whether some other forces are behind him.A special investigation team was formed to probe the conspiracy angle.Food minister P Thilothaman convened a meeting at Paippad on Monday to ensure the welfare of the guest workers. The minister directed not to impose rent on the workers during the lockdown and they should not be ousted from the place. A special medical team will be assigned in the region.

Title: 75-year-old’s death not related to Covid-19
Content:
Kolhapur: A 75-year-old man admitted in the city-based Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Rugnalaya (CPR) on Sunday night for breathlessness and other diabetic conditions, who died during treatment on Monday morning, has been tested negative for Covid-19.

Kolhapur district civil surgeon B C Kempi Patil, said, “The deceased was from Top village in Hatkanangale taluka. He was diagnosed with pneumonia along with his existing ailments of diabetes and breathlessness.” He added that the deceased had no previous history of foreign travel, neither had he come in contact with any known Covid-19 patient. “His throat swab sample was sent to the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) as a precautionary measure.

Last week, samples of another deceased person, who was admitted to a private hospital with symptoms akin to coronavirus infection, had tested negative for the virus.

Kolhapur city has two positive patients who are admitted in CPR’s isolation ward, while another positive patient from Pethwadgaon (in the district) is being treated at the Miraj Medical Hospital.

According to the district information office, around 1,025-bed facility has been arranged at 11 venues across the district for institutional quarantine. Private hostels and residential schools have been used for the purpose. Across these facilities, 308 suspects have been quarantined.

It added that as on March 30, the Kolhapur health department had sent 181 swab samples to the testing lab, of which, 137 tested negative. Two patients’ swab samples were positive and they are getting treatment at CPR. As many as 23 sample reports are still awaited, while 18 were rejected due to the asymptomatic nature of the individuals.

Title: Scribe, cop accuse each other of assault after lathi charge
Content:
Aurangabad: There have been allegations and counter-allegations of assault against the Hingoli police as well as a journalist and his associates following a lathi-charge incident in the town’s Gandhi Chowk area on Sunday afternoon. Both the journalist and an assistant police inspector were admitted to a hospital in Hingoli.

While one group claims the Hingoli traffic police personnel had assaulted a TV journalist who was filming them while they were lathi charging people roaming around the city, the police counter it by saying that the journalist and his associates had instead attacked and injured a police officer and had stopped a public servant from performing his duty.

A couple of days ago, the same journalist had reported on the unhygienic way the traffic policemen were distributing masks, which allegedly angered the policemen. However, the police said that the journalist picked up a quarrel with the cops and assaulted a police officer.

Based on API Omkant Chincholkar statement, journalist Krushna Khandelwal and five others have been booked on the charges of using criminal force to deter a public servant from performing his duty, unlawful assembly, rioting, disobeying orders duly promulgated by the authorities. Relevant sections of the National Disaster Management Act have also been slapped.

Hingoli SP Yogesh Kumar told TOI, “Based on the complaint lodged by the police officer, we have registered a case against the scribe and five people who accompanied him. Yesterday, we had sent a team to record the journalist, but could not do so. Today (Monday) we are sending our team to record his statement again. After that appropriate action would be taken.”

Chincholkar too released a video and claimed that the journalist was upset after the police had caught some youths from his locality while moving around in violation of the lockdown. This led to heated arguments, following which Khandelwal, and five others, allegedly attacked the cops and Chincholkar suffered a head injury.

Following the incident, especially after the police gave priority to registering an offence against Khandelwal, local journalists expressed their concerns over the possibility of an impartial probe. Several journalists’ associations, including those in Mumbai, condemned the incident and demanded action against the alleged police high-handedness.

Earlier this week, the Hingoli police faced criticism after a woman assistant police inspector allegedly assaulted a health assistant on duty for Covid-19 survey and her father, a serving head constable. The incident left the health assistant with five stitches on her head.

Title: Aurangabad SP comes to the rescue of madrassa students
Content:
Aurangabad: Mokshada Patil, the Aurangabad superintendent of police, came to the rescue of about 50 madrassa students hailing from Araria in Bihar, who were stranded at the Laygaon-based Jamia Islamia Abul Hasan Madarssa location in the limits of the Chikalthana police station.

Apart from arranging the essentials needed by the students, Patil also sent a police team and ensured that calls were made to the students’ families. The family members were assured of the students’ safety.

To ensure that the students, all of them teenagers, do not get bored during the lockdown, cricket kits and footballs were gifted to them with instructions to the madrassa management to let the students play within the compound.

Patil told TOI: “The students hail from a far-off state and it is obvious for the children and their parents to worry about each other. We have not only assured the families of the students’ safety but have also shared our direct contact numbers — so that they can contact us for any help or assistance.”

It all started after a nation-wide lockdown was announced. The students wanted to return home. Their parents too were worried and were making calls to the madrassa management. When API Mahesh Andhale got to know of this, he informed the superintendent of police, who took a personal interest in addressing the issue.

A police team led API Andhale reached out to the madrassa and even briefed the students on the precautions, including social distancing, to be taken during the coronavirus outbreak.

In addition, 60 migrant families, including several children, who had left Bhalgaon to return to their home-towns in other states, got stuck in the city. On learning about it, the Chikalthana police not only arranged for dry ration for them but also gifted the kids with cricket kits and footballs.

Title: Rumour-monger from Behala lands in cop net
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: A 29-year-old homemaker in Behala was arrested on Monday for sending a false message on a kindergarten school guardians’ group about multiple Covid-19 cases being detected in New Alipore area.

This is the second such arrest in the city during the lockdown, the first being that of a woman who had spread rumours that a Beliaghata ID Hospital doctor had been detected with Covid-19. The CID and Bengal police also arrested two persons—one in Siliguri and another at Memari in Burdwan—for spreading fake novel coronavirus news over the past 48 hours, taking the total arrests in Bengal to 15 so far.

“No one can spread rumours. In her post, the woman claimed New Alipore has 15 novel coronavirus cases in New Alipore’s Block P. It raised alarm among locals,” said an officer. Police has slapped IPC section 505 (1) (b) on the accused, Pallavi Shivani, a resident of Jyotish Roy Road in Behala. Shivani’s husband is a businessman.

“We learnt on Sunday that a woman had posted rumours that New Alipore area had at least 15 Covid-19 cases and the state was trying to suppress it (though the messages shared by police with media makes no mention of the government). The woman’s user name has the name of a playschool chain. We contacted the authorities but we found no one called ‘Pallavi’ worked there. We contacted some of the parents and one of them identified the sender. We arrested her from her home. She could not show ant explanation in support of her information,” said an officer. “She was produced in court on Monday.” After her arrest, the woman broke down.

“I have made a big mistake, please let me go,” she pleaded before the cops. She promised to send a mass apology and later, her mobile was taken away.

Kolkata Police is set to question 100 people under CrPC 41 for sharing and sending fake messages, most of which turned out to be that of incidents from outside the state. “If we find ulterior motives, we will make arrests,” said a cyber cell officer.

Title: Private hospital, 2 test centres sealed; about 40 people quarantined
Content:
Nagpur: Continuing the containment drive to prevent further spread of Covid-19, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Monday sealed the Janata Hospital at Jaripatka, Dhande’s Panorama MRI Centre at Shankar Nagar and Rainbow Medinova Diagnostic Centre at Ramdaspeth. The civic body has also directed Government Medical College and Hospital to disinfect and seal ward no. 36.

One of the five positive patients of Covid-19 from the same family at Jaripatka had a paralytic attack and was admitted to the ICU at Janata Hospital. Then, he was taken for a medical test at Panorama Centre. Later, he was admitted in ward no. 36 of GMCH. The 14th positive patient, a resident of a housing society near Gandhisagar Lake, too had a test at Rainbow Medinova Centre. These developments resulted in the closure of all these places.

Swab samples of around 26, which include doctors, nurses, a pathologist and others from Janata, eight GMCH doctors and four paramedical staff and a couple of staff members from the MRI centres, were taken before they were quarantined. Most of the suspects were isolated at the GMCH wards where shortage of rooms for suspects too was reported on Monday.

NMC’s additional medical officer (health) Dr Praveen Gantawar said there was no patient admitted at the Janata Hospital before it was sealed.

The patient who had a paralytic attack belongs to the Jaripatka family where four more members have tested positive. His 33-year-old younger brother was the first to test positive on March 28, becoming the 10th Covid-19 patient of city. On March 29, the paralysed man and the 10th patient’s 12-year-old daughter tested positive. On Monday, the ailing patient’s 44-year-old wife and 14-year-old son also tested positive.

On March 30, TOI was the only paper to report about large-scale exposure at Janata Hospital and GMCH as the family had not disclosed the 33-year-old man who worked at the shop of Khamla businessman was a Covid-19 suspect at the time. He was reportedly handled without safety kits.

Dr Gantawar said an ambulance was deployed outside Janata hospital for needy patients. “I will inspect GMCH general ward where the patient was initially admitted. After we informed them that his brother tested positive, the patient was shifted to GMCH’s Covid-19 ward on Saturday,” he said.

The medical officer said the man was admitted at Janata from March 26 evening to 4pm on March 27. “On March 26 night, he was taken for MRI at Panorama in Shankar Nagar where it was confirmed he had brain haemeorrage. Then, he was shifted to GMCH,” said Dr Gantawar.

At Janata Hospital, the man had reported to the casualty section. “After the ECG, he was shifted to ICU. The corridor too was contaminated. The nurse who attended him may have touched others,” said Dr Gantawar.

On Rainbow Medinova Centre being sealed, Dr Gantawar said, “The 14th patient had visited it. We don't want to leave a single area open from where the virus can spread,” he said.

NMC chief medical officer Dr Yogendra Savai and Gantawar led the NMC team in the sealing action.

Before sealing, an NMC team led by deputy commissioner Dr Pradeep Dasarwar disinfected the entire Janata Hospital and the two centres.

The NMC is also checking how many patients came for diagnosis at these two centres from the date when the two positive patients were brought for tests.

Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar confirmed that the GMCH doctors and paramedical staff were quarantined.

In the morning, NMC health officials informed that eight suspects were diverted from GMCH to IGGMCH. Officials said the suspects have to stay back due to which rooms were occupied. “Once the results come, the suspects would be shifted to MLA hostel and others brought in,” they said.

Title: Navy, Defence Security Corporations pitch in to supply food to needy in Vasco
Content: PANAJI: With several people struggling to feed themselves amidst a supply crisis, the Indian Navy and the Defence Security Corps (DSC) reached out to residents and migrant workers in Vasco by supplying food and groceries on Monday.The DSC and Indian Naval personnel from INS Hansa distributed cooked food to around 320 people in the vicinity of Vasco railway station and Mangor.“Joining the fight to contain the Covid-19 pandemic and as a measure of goodwill towards the citizens in distress during the nationwide lockdown , jawans of DSC and Indian Naval personnel from INS Hansa distributed food at several locations,” said an official statement.Simultaneously, from 7:15am, the Indian Navy operated a grocery stall at Varunapuri for civilian workers and employees of the Military Engineering Services (MES). Vegetables and fruits procured from Belgaum on Sunday were sold to several residents who had no access to fresh supplies.Chief minister Pramod Sawant threw Goa into an unprepared lockdown, which is in its eighth day, leaving most citizens without essentials “The food distribution was a great relief for stranded migrant labourers, rag pickers and low income families, struggling to feed themselves in the prevailing lockdown conditions. Around 320 people were provided cooked food at Vasco railway station, Bogda and Ram Mandir,” said a naval officer.The Indian Navy procured vegetables and fruits from produce chain Taazi Tokri. While Taazi Tokri sold the items, naval personnel helped enforce social distancing.
