Title: Eerie silence descends on Delhi's Anand Vihar again
Content:
A strict clampdown was imposed not only on all roads leading to Anand Vihar but also at all border areas of De... Read More

NEW DELHI: The Anand Vihar area, which saw scores of migrant workers descending on the interstate bus terminus and the Kaushambi bus depot on the other side of the road on Saturday and Sunday, was eerily desolate on Monday. A strict clampdown was imposed not only on all roads leading to Anand Vihar but also at all border areas of Delhi.

From Saturday night to Sunday, more than 30,000 migrant workers who reached the area despite fervent appeals from chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to stay back in Delhi were transported to nearby areas in Uttar Pradesh, from where they could get buses to their villages.

On Monday, only security personnel and multiple layers of barricades could be seen in the area with both the ISBT and the Kaushambi depot sealed. “It will be ensured that no crowding takes place at Delhi’s borders with UP and Haryana,” a Delhi government official said.

From Monday, the government has ensured stringent checking of those boarding Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and Cluster scheme buses and only those involved in essential services and carrying curfew passes are being allowed to board. “Drivers and conductors have been told that they will face action if there’s any violation,” he said.

Just 50% of Delhi’s bus fleet has been deployed to ferry those involved in essential services. Routes have been rationalised keeping in mind the workplaces of essential service providers and their residential areas. Many hospitals have also hired DTC buses to ferry their staff.

Title: Amid lockdown, Rs 2 lakh liquor stolen in Lanjhi
Content:
Aurangabad: Amid Covid-19 lockdown, few unidentified individuals burgled a liquor godown in Lanjhi and decamped with Rs 2 lakh worth liquor bottles during the wee hours on Monday

Police suspect that the burglary is a result of serious constraint in the supply of liquor, and the possibility of liquor addicts committing the crime cannot be ruled out. The central government declared a country-wide shutdown till April 14 in wake of the coronavirus outbreak. Those being caught with liquor are being booked under various sections.

About 22 liquor boxes have been stolen and authorities suspect that at least a pickup van must have been used for carrying the liquor. On learning about the incident, the Waluj police followed by the crime branch team rushed to the spot. The spot panchanama revealed that the suspects walked away only with the boxes containing different kinds of liquor, and did not touch the boxes containing beer bottles.

Police have found that the suspects took extra precautions to not to leave behind any clue as they even walked away with the DVR as well as the inverter.

Based on the complaint lodged by Manjusha Jaiswal, a resident of Waluj area, an offence against unidentified suspects was registered. It said the incident came to light at around 6 am on Monday, when complainant’s husband Manoj, along with his employees reached the godown to inspect the liquor stalk being maintained at the godown to find the shutter locks to be broken and liquor missing.

Title: ‘Cuban wonder drug to be tried only in extreme cases’
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Government, which is awaiting permission from ICMR and drugs controller general of India for the trial of Cuban drug Interferon alpha , only intends to try it in extreme cases and it may not be a ready-to-go drug for Covid-19 in other categories.State planning board member Dr B Ekbal, who pitched the idea of using this drug in emergency cases, said that it is not a wonder drug and had been in use.“We plan to conduct a trial for which permission is awaited. This drug was used for treating Hepatitis C. We can do a trial and find if it is useful in severe cases. Even then we need to formulate a trial protocol and finalize when it can be used,” he said.Dr R R Gangakhedkar, who heads epidemiology and communicable diseases at ICMR, said the drug is mainly used to control cytokine storm, which is caused by an overreaction of the immune system to an infection. “It has been used in multiple diseases when it comes to development of acute respiratory distress syndrome. China used it widely. It doesn’t mean that it works alone, this is just a symptomatic treatment. If you have cytokine storm we use interferon alpha,” he said.Covid-19 can be fatal when it triggers an overreaction of body’s immune system which is called cytokine storm. Cytokines are meant to regulate body's response against an infection, however in some cases it results in an overdrive. When coronavirus enters the lungs, it drives immune cells to combat the virus. However, excessive production of cytokines results in hyper-inflammation which could be potentially fatal to the patient. Cytokine storm is a common complication of respiratory diseases caused by coronaviruses.A study by Chinese researchers on clinical predictors of mortality due to Covid-19 by analysing data of 150 patients from Wuhan, published in Springer journal in March, said the predictors of a fatal outcome included age, presence of underlying diseases, secondary infection and elevated inflammatory indicators in blood. It also suggests that the mortality might be due to virus-activated ‘cytokine storm syndrome’ or fulminant myocarditis.Kerala plans to try this drug on patients under clinical category C, which includes breathlessness, chest pain, drowsiness, fall in blood pressure and conditions denoted as red flag signs along with worsening of underlying chronic conditions. “A major concern for us is that 21% of state’s population have co-morbidities and they are vulnerable and in extreme cases we could try this drug,” said Ekbal.The disease management guideline prepared by Kerala for Covid-19 said the treatment includes general supportive measures under full infection control protocols and it will conform to management of respiratory involvement according to severity, other bacterial co-infection etc and other multi-organ support (as and when indicated).

Title: Dargah plea to PM, CMs to rescue stranded pilgrims
Content:
Jaipur: Ajmer Dargah Committee has written to PM Narendra Modi and CMs of Telangana, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Karnataka and West Bengal urging them to either airlift or provide other transport facilities for around 3,000 pilgrims stranded in Dargah area.

These pilgrims are putting additional pressure on the Dargah committee and locals who are feeding them two meals a day and accommodating them in their houses.

“The Dargah is committed to providing food and shelter to the devotees stranded here. But, nobody knows how long the lockdown will continue. It will be great if the respective governments make arrangements for their residents who is anxiously waiting for their return,” said Shakil Ahmed, Nazim (CEO), Ajmer Dargah .

The move came after the Dargah committee’s repeated attempts to convince the local administration and state government failed.

Leaving no air of confusion, Ajmer SP Kunwar Rastradeep said, “Nobody can move anywhere according to home ministry’s order.”

Since curfew has been slapped in the area following a Covid-19 positive case, those who are helping them with food and water are finding it difficult to feed them. Rafiq Qadri, a volunteer who is providing food to over 1,400 pilgrims, said it has been a week since they are providing food due to generous donations from people. “It will be really difficult to run the programme for long. After some days, we have to focus on the local poor families and with limited resources, we won’t be able to feed both the sections,” said Qadri.

These pilgrims came a few days before the lockdown and got stuck due to cancellation of trains and bus services.

Most of these pilgrims have vacated the hotels and are staying at the free space provided by locals. They are living in small rooms with 8-10 members in a room.

“I have come with 40 members, including children and women. Without proper arrangements, we cannot travel. I have appealed to our CM K Chandrashekar Rao to help us return to our home state,” said Hafiz Ur Rehman , a devotee from Hyderabad.

Title: JMC plays good samaritan, feeds dogs & birds in city
Content:
A JMC employee feeds pigeons in city on Monday

JAIPUR: To provide food for the animals and birds amid lockdown , the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) has started an initiative along with the Akshay Patra Foundation.

Everyday JMC is serving 8,000 chapatis to dogs all over the city. Recently, JMC bought 50 new hoopers in which a helper has been provided with the duty to distribute chapatis to dogs in the city.

An official at JMC said, “We have been receiving calls at call centres regarding street dogs not getting food due to lockdown. Hence, JMC has decided to spend money to feed the animals. Similarly, there are many spots in city where pigeons are being fed by the passers-by daily. We have purchased about eight quintals of seeds to be fed to the pigeons.”

People used to feed pigeons at various spots like Ramniwas Bagh, Albert Hall , Hawa Mahal, etc. however, with the lockdown the entire state machinery has come to a standstill which has affected not just human beings but also animals.

Commissioner V P Singh has ordered a cement tank to be kept in every park to provide water to animals and birds. “I request the public to make two extra chapatis at home for the dogs and feed birds on their terraces. This is a time of crisis so we want people to co-operate with each other,” said Singh.

The lockdown had an adverse effect on the migrants and daily wagers the most. People have been out of jobs and are not able to arrange two meals. With Akshay Patra, JMC has started distributing more than one lakh food packets in the city. Special vans of Akshay Patra are distributing these packets.

Title: Now, district administration stresses on room quarantine
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The district administration is mulling stressing on room quarantine instead of home quarantine with the latest instance of home quarantine norms being compromised in the district.

The seven-year-old daughter of a person who has been tested positive has been hospitalized after she developed symptoms. The person arrived from Dubai and was advised to go on home quarantine. He stayed at home for five days and according to authorities the norms were compromised which may have exposed his family members.

This is the second case in the district when home quarantine was reported to be compromised. The person who came from Britain to the city and was tested positive had compromised on home quarantine which made district collector K Gopalakrishnan to repeatedly insist on the need to stick with the norms.

The district administration is also making the families choose a single member to take care of the person under home quarantine rather than random family members interacting with the person. The ministry of health and family welfare has recently brought out guidelines on home quarantine in which instructions for the family members of persons being home quarantined are clearly laid out. It says that only an assigned family member should be tasked with taking care of the person under quarantine.

Even within the room, strict guidelines have been issued. The quarantined person has to stay away from elderly people, pregnant women, children and persons with co-morbidities within the household.

Besides the movement has to be restricted and under no circumstances shall the person attend any social/religious gathering like wedding, condolence meet, etc.

The patient who is under treatment at Medical College isolation ward is learnt not to have complied with restrictions in movement within the house which may have resulted in his daughter developing symptoms.

In the first case, although the person didn't come out of house, he got in close proximity with family members like his wife, his wife's sister, brother in law, father in law. They shared same phone, ate together and shared common areas which was unadvisable, the collector had said.

He had said that those from all foreign countries should go to home quarantine for 28 days and it should be real home quarantine, They shall not come out during this period, use single toilet, single room and door shall not be kept open.This is very important, the authorities had pointed out.

As per the Union ministry guidelines, the assigned member of the family should avoid shaking the soiled linen or direct contact with skin. Disposable gloves have to be used when cleaning the surfaces or handling soiled linen.

In case the person being quarantined becomes symptomatic, all the close contacts will be home quarantined (for 14 days) and followed up for an additional 14 days or till the report of such case turns out negative on lab testing.

Title: Crowd control at markets a tough task for authorities
Content:
Overcrowded vegetable markets have become a major problem for the district authorities in maintaining the social distancing norms since the beginning of the nation-wide lockdown. As part of tackling the situation, the authorities have come up with a slew of ideas.

The district administration was forced to shut down the central vegetable market within a few hours after opening for business on the first day of the lockdown. Even police could not control the mad rush. The authorities have reduced the business hours, in vain.

Markings on the ground were introduced to keep safe distance between shoppers. But, people ignored the norms when it was announced that the market would be closed at 9am. Pandi, a vendor, said that people just rushed in during the closure time desperately to buy vegetables.

P S Murugan, president, Mattuthavani Vegetable Market Association, said that they had witnessed big crowd during weekdays. "It was only on Sundays that we saw such large crowds," he said.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan says that people should minimize their visits to the market at a crisis period. The corporation has the main markets and spread them out on empty roads. This has helped in controlling the crowds to some extent, but the response from the vendors was lukewarm as they had to move to new locations as the shops were spread out in the four zones. Now the corporation is using 100 of its LMV vehicles to distribute vegetables in each of the 100 wards.

Theni district administration has come up with a better solution. On the instructions from district collector Pallavi M Baldev bags of assorted vegetable were distributed. The bag priced at Rs 150, has around 18 vegetables. Sources said that they had arranged 50 such bags on Sunday that are sold out in one hour. From Tuesday they have planned to double the number of bags.

Title: Demand to promote varsity students
Content:
Aurangabad: As the academic time table of state universities has gone haywire due to the Covid-19 outbreak, demand is being raised to promote university students on the line of schoolchildren.

Advocacy group Marathwada Association for Students Aurangabad (MASA) has submitted a memorandum in this effect to Maharashtra Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari, who is the ex-officio Chancellor of the state universities.

MASA president Ulhas Udhan said that conducting examination for students pursuing higher education would be a herculean task, which he said will consume lot of time. “The conduct of examination requires a period of a minimum of two months. Once the lockdown is over and the next academic session beings, a lot of time will be wasted in carrying out examinations. It will result in collapsing of the next academic session as well,” he said.

Udhan said the student community at large was under mental stress due to uncertainty over examinations. The state universities, including Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (BAMU) and Swami Ramanand Teerth Marathwada University (SRTMU), Nanded have indefinitely postponed their examinations amid the outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic.

“The student community has been only guessing about possible dates of examinations. The uncertainty over examinations is naturally adding to their stress level. Also, four lakh students giving examinations post lockdown is not advisable as nobody knows to what extent the social distancing norm would be applicable post lockdown,” Udhan said.

Title: Samples of 25 high risk contacts of Buldhana victim sent for test
Content: Nagpur: Panic gripped Buldhana city on Monday after the authorities quarantined 60 people from the family and close contacts of the 45-year-old man who died of Covid-19 on Saturday. He was tested positive on March 29, and was the first death due to coronavirus infection in Vidarbha.“Buldhana citizens need to be assured because 25 high risk contacts have been traced, quarantined and their samples sent to Nagpur for testing. Contact tracing is still on. Everyone concerned is on the job,” district collector of Buldhana Suman Rawat Chandra said.Buldhana has no government medical college, so all the quarantined people have been taken to a facility created in city women’s hospital. “A fully functional and dedicated facility is now running at the 100-bedded hospital,” the collector said while appealing people not to panic and stay at home.Police imposed nakabandi at 33 places in and around Buldhana on Monday. Apart from family members and friends, those who attended the burial of the deceased were also asked to remain in quarantine and stamped on their hands.District health officer Dr Balkrishna Kamble too said that out of all the quarantined persons, samples of 25 high risk contacts have been sent for testing. “Twenty-seven persons are low risk contacts. They will be under quarantine observation for 14 days. If any of them develops symptoms during this period, we will send samples for testing,” he said.The health department is still clueless about the source of Covid-19 infection that claimed the life of the 45-year-old man. The department has issued an appeal to Buldhana residents to report if any of them have a travel history and having symptoms like fever or throat infection.The locality where the deceased used to reside has been sealed. The private hospital where he was treated for three days has already been sealed. Door-to-door surveillance too has started.Meanwhile, rescue and relief camps have been set up in the district for stranded labourers. “Currently, there are 3,511 migrant labourers at various camps in Buldhana. They have been provided medical, food and lodging facilities and told to observe social distancing,” the collector said.

Title: Blame game between cops, commuters over traffic fine
Content:
A cop stops two-wheelers at Railway Station Road on Monday

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam city and district police have registered around 1,400 cases in the past eight days in relation to the lockdown violation and collected Rs 67 lakh in fine for traffic violations.

The city police in the last nine days took 726 persons into custody, filed 381 cases against people for violating the lockdown and impounded 565 vehicles. They also registered 21,891 cases and collected Rs 53 lakh in fine for MV Act violations. Meanwhile, Visakha rural police registered 905 cases against lockdown-breachers, including 372 shops, and seized 508 vehicles. They registered 3,315 cases and imposed Rs 14 lakh as fine for traffic violations.

But commuters have accused the police of being over-zealous. “We can understand that many youths are violating the lockdown and roaming the roads. But cops are threatening even those who are out buying essential commodities,” said a commuter.

When TOI spoke to traffic cops, they pointed out that the lockdown cannot be an excuse for not wearing helmets and seat belts. “Traffic rules have not been relaxed,” said a traffic cop, pointing out that he found many have been citing excuses that they “forgot to wear a helmet or seat belt because they are in a hurry”.

“ The government has given relaxation to buy essential commodities. But few people are roaming the roads just for fun,” Visakha rural SP Babujee Attada said.

Title: Ichalkaranji under complete lockdown
Content: Kolhapur: With most people in Ichalkaranji continuing to violate the lockdown norms and coming out on the streets for non-essential reasons, the administration on Sunday decided to implement a complete lockdown in the town for three days starting Monday.The textile town has thousands of workers whose livelihood depends on the textile units that are now shut. On Monday, the first day of the complete lockdown, all the essential services, including supply and sale of milk, newspapers and vegetables, operated till 9 am. All the shops, including grocery shops, remained shut on Monday and will continue to do so for the next two days.Speaking to TOI, Dipak Patil, the chief officer of the Ichalkaranji Municipal Council, said, “Since the nation-wide lockdown was announced, we had exempted certain essential services from its purview. However, over the past few days, the police realised that people were still unnecessarily coming out on the roads citing different — often non-essential — reasons. We also noticed that people were crowding the vegetable markets, which was not the case before the lockdown. This was completely going against the spirit and purpose of the lockdown. That is why we have increased the policing activity to keep a check on various roads and take action against the violators. We have decided to completely lock down the town from Monday and no one would be allowed to come out on road for any reason. On Monday, we have received a good response. We expect people to support us over the next two days as well.”“We have, however, exempted essential services like banking, hospitals and medical stores from the complete lockdown. People had already purchased groceries that should be sufficient for these three days. On Monday, milk, vegetable and newspaper distribution began from 6 am and wrapped up by 9 am. Since then, police have been patrolling the roads and streets of Ichalkaranji to ensure that the people stay in their houses. This will continue for the next two days, he said.

Title: Power utility to pay staff to buy mask & sanitizer
Content:
Aurangabad: The Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited ( MSEDCL ) has announced financial aid of Rs 1,000 to Class III and Class IV employees, and its contract workers, for purchasing masks and sanitizers.

MSEDCL public relations officer for Aurangabad Zone Dnyaneshwar Ardad on Monday said that the sum of Rs 1,000 for purchase of masks and sanitizers will be reflected in salaries for March to be credited early next month.

“A considerable number of staff has on-field duties, especially of trouble-shooting and maintenance. They would need these essential items amid the COVID-19 crisis,” he said.

Among other policy decisions, MSEDCL has also asked all zones not to carry out planned power-cuts during the current lockdown in the country. “The top-brass has also asked not to undertake routine activities such as noting down of meter reading , bill recovery, drive against power theft and disconnections. The instructions have been issued in keeping with the norms of social distancing,” power utility official said.

As per directives issued by the government, MSEDCL offices will have only 5% attendance of employees as far as possible and the work-from-home culture will be practiced till April 14.

“All employees will be encouraged to use tools such as e-mail, video conferencing, WhatsApp, Twitter and Facebook to streamline the daily working till the lockdown gets over,” MSEDCL officials said.

The state power utility has once again appealed to consumers to submit meter reading towards monthly power consumption by using the mobile app, failing which they have to pay average bill.

The mobile application can be downloaded from Google Playstore and offers a wide range of benefits to customers, including viewing and paying of monthly bills and routing complaints besides self-submission of power reading.

Title: In Jabalpur, 23 samples test negative in past 24 hours
Content:
Jabalpur: After samples of 14 suspected patients tested negative for Covid-19 on Saturday, nine more samples whose reports were received on Sunday tested negative in Jabalpur. As things stand, there are only eight positive patients whose treatment is underway at different hospitals of the city.

Meanwhile, with locals facing issues over treatment of common ailments due to the nationwide lockdown, district administration has fixed the timings for private hospitals to remain open. District collector Bharat Yadav in his briefing to media on Sunday said, “Some private hospitals which are of different specialisations will remain open. The specifications of which hospital will remain open for which treatment has been made clear so that the common people are not deprived of essential medical care.”

He added, “We have also decided that people who are living in rented accommodation in the city will not have to pay rent till the lockdown period is over in Jabalpur. Instructions have been issued to ensure that norms of social distancing are followed at every shop. Those flouting these norms will be shut and FIR would be registered against the respective shopkeepers. It is the responsibility of the shopkeepers to ensure that social distancing norms are adhered to”.

Stricter restrictions have been imposed in the three kilometre radius of the area where the eight positive patients of the city were found, Yadav said. On March 20, four people were tested positive for Covid-19 in Jabalpur. Later, four more were tested positive. Treatment of these eight patients is going on and they all are in stable condition.

Of the eight, seven patients were related to the first positive patient of the city. Since then, no new positive case has been reported in the city while curfew has been enforced.

Title: With two more in Nagpur, Vidarbha has 21 confirmed cases
Content:
Nagpur: A 44-year-old woman and her 14-year old son tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday in Nagpur. This took total number of Covid-19 cases in Nagpur to 16 and in Vidarbha to 21. Both are family members of patients who had tested positive earlier.

“The woman is wife of 45-year-old ailing brother of a first patient in Jaripatka who works as assistant in Khamla businessman’s shop,” informed district collector Ravindra Thakare.

This man from Jaripatka tested positive on March 28 and his brother and daughter on March 29. Now, his brother’s wife and son have also tested positive on Monday taking total number in Jaripatka to 5, all members of one family.

The two new positive Covid-19 patients are from the same family living in the same house in Jaripatka. This is biggest tally of Covid-19 patients from a single family thus far. The 33-year-old man was the first in the family to test positive on Saturday. He was working at the shop of Khamla businessman, who was city’s 5th positive case.

After the 33-year-old Jaripatka resident was confirmed as Covid-19 patient, NMC containment team had picked up 14 people including his family members, maid and neighbours on Saturday. Jaripatka man’s elder brother was admitted to GMCH after suffering a stroke. Besides both of them, the younger brother’s 12-year-old daughter and the paralyzed man’s wife and son are positive now. None had any travel history.

On Monday, NMC picked up more people who had come in close contact of new positive cases. A couple of neighbouring kids would also be tested on Tuesday while tracing of wife’s close contacts is underway.

The Khamla businessman tested positive on March 26. His wife, mother, son and manager on March 27. Manager’s 17-year-old daughter on March 28. Khamla area has six patients now.

Including a 55-year old man from Central Nagpur, the city now has 12 Covid-19 patients admitted in two government hospitals. Four patients have already recovered and have been discharged.

No family member or close contact of 55-year-old patient in Central Nagpur has tested positive so far. This man had travelled to UP along with his wife and son and returned Nagpur on March 18. In a major relief for affected family, flat owners in housing society and ISKCON members, reports of 15 of total 35 persons who were in close contacts came negative. As reported by TOI on Monday, the person along with wife, son and daughter is a resident of a housing society near Gandhisagar lake. He was tested positive on Sunday.

His son is studying in a residential school run by ISKCON at Vrindavan, UP. He along with wife and daughter went to Vrindavan on March 15 and returned with the son on March 18. They reportedly offered services at ISKCON temple that witnesses a large number of foreign tourists. Between March 18 and 28, he was at home and office which is also in a flat and ISKCON temple situated in the society.

His wife, son and daughter tested negative. One of three housemaids too came negative. NMC is tracing two more housemaids of which one was working at home and the other at office. The remaining negative ones are ISKCON members. Parents of this man, residents of Kamptee, are yet to be brought for testing. Reports of 20 others are still awaited.

NMC sources told TOI, “One friend of the person could not be contacted as his mobile was switched off and he is not at home.”

Apart from these cases in Nagpur, a 23-year-old youth is under treatment at Gondia GMCH. Authorities have tested some 13 contacts of this youth in the last three days and all were negative.

In Buldhana, active surveillance of the city is under way after a 45-year-old man died of Covid-19 on March 28. Authorities have collected 25 samples on Sunday and sent them to Nagpur IGGMCH. Their results are expected on Tuesday.

Till now, Vidarbha has registered total 21 cases of Covid-19. Of these seven have recovered and have been discharged, 13 are admitted in Nagpur and Gondia and one had died in Buldhana. With 21 cases in Vidarbha, total number of confirmed cases in Maharashtra has escalated to 215 on Monday. These include 35 patients who are recovered and eight deaths.

IMPORTANT BOX

Covid-19 suspect dies in IGGMCH

A 55-year-old Covid-19 suspect died within hours of being admitted in Indira Gandhi Government Medical College Hospital (IGGMCH) on Monday. The patient who hails from Chandrapur was suffering from viral pneumonia and was taking treatment at a private hospital in city for two days. As he was the patient of pneumonia, the doctor asked him to get tested in IGGMCH for Covid-19 as per the latest ICMR testing criteria. The patient reached IGGMCH on Monday afternoon in a serious condition. His swab samples were collected but his condition deteriorated and he died in two hours, confirmed the authorities at IGGMCH.

The private practitioner treating the patient said he was suffering from viral pneumonia and was having problems of hypertension and obesity. Authorities are now waiting for the lab test results of the person.

Title: Patient forces 14 MCH docs into isolation
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: As many as 32 more Covid-19 positive cases were reported in the state on Monday taking the total number of reported cases to 234. Also authorities are yet to trace the source of the positive case reported from Thiruvananthapuram’s Pothencode on Sunday. Sources said he had not been in direct contact with anyone who had travelled from abroad. He had also attended several functions, including a marriage and a burial.This 69-year-old person had also availed treatment at a primary health centre and a private medical college hospital in Venjarammoodu. Doctors of both these hospitals have been asked to proceed to home quarantine. In addition, 14 doctors of Thiruvananthapuram Medical College hospital have also been asked to self-isolate themselves since they had come in direct contact with the person.Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said his condition is critical and he is undergoing dialysis. Thus, tracking the person’s contacts has become near impossible.Now, Kasaragod has the largest share of fresh cases, at 17 and 97 patients are undergoing treatment in the district. In addition, seven persons from the district are admitted in different hospitals in Kannur and two in Kozhikode. This takes the total number of positive cases from among Kasaragod natives to 106.Among the 32 new patients, 17 had travelled from abroad and 15 are primary contacts. Kannur (11), Wayanad (2) and Idukki (2) were the other districts that reported cases on Monday. At present, 1,57,253 people are under observation in the state, of which 623 are admitted in designated isolation wards of hospitals. On Monday alone, 126 persons with suspected symptoms were admitted to various hospitals.However, the CM denied reports that community spreads have occurred in Idukki, Kasaragod and Thiruvananthapuram.The source of the Congress leader, who tested positive in Idukki, has not yet been identified. However, the only solace for the Idukki administration is the fact that most of his primary contacts have tested negative. The results of 24 samples that were received on Monday were negative.Meanwhile, the elderly couple who were admitted to Kottayam MCH have now tested negative. Their discharge has not yet been finalized. They had come into direct contact with their son and family who had returned from Italy. The two had been on ventilator support.

Title: AMC to start control room to provide food to affected families amid lockdown
Content:
Aurangabad: The civic body will soon open a control room to ensure cooked food is supplied to those families whose income has been badly affected by the lockdown.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey said that no one in the city should go to bed empty stomach, hence the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation has decided to initiate a control room which will have seven helpline numbers handled by 7 officers of a team.

“As soon as we receive requests for food, we will inform Iskcon Annamrita Foundation then they will cook the food,” Panzade said. The food will include khichdi, bhaji and chapati. Sudarshan Potbhare, the branch manager of Annamrita Foundation said that they have can to cook more than 16,000 meals a day ensuring the hygiene and follow social distancing guidelines.

The discussions on the delivery and timing of food supply will be held on Monday.

The AMC has joined hands with the Aurangabad First, which comprises representatives from the industry. Under the initiative, the people can place a request on emergency-needs.com or by calling on 9654535041. Following which the residents can get doorstep delivery of grocery, bakery, frozen foods and medicines.

In order to ensure food is provided to drivers carrying essential products, Satish Lodha of Satish Motors has agreed to provide food packets to them at Nagar Naka and the two toll nakas at Solapur Highway.

Meanwhile, all 5 of the night shelters of the AMC are witnessing full occupancy.

Donation of 2 cardiac

ambulances

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey and his wife Aurangabad superintendent of police (rural) Mokshada Patil have decided not take their salaries of one month in order to get two cardiac ambulances for the AMC health department. Subsequently, all officers and employees of the AMC will contribute one day of their salary for the cause.

Title: With no ration cards, migrants struggle to make ends meet
Content:
Aurangabad: Jaya Thorat, a resident of Harsul and mother of four children, is struggling to make ends meet owing to the lockdown.

“My husband is a daily wager and used to load goods in trucks before the lockdown was announced by the state government around 10 days ago. We do not have sufficient food to eat,” she said, adding that they hail from Pachora in neighbouring Jalgaon district and do not have a ration card.

Sumita Mhaske is another resident going through the same ordeal. “We hail from Jalna district and moved to Aurangabad in search of livelihood around five years ago. We heard that the government is providing essential food items through ration shops, but we do not have a ration card,” she said.

A considerable number of migrant population from neighbouring districts and living on the city outskirts is struggling for food amid current lockdown due to lack of ration card. Many of these families were seen roaming on the streets every day with a hope of getting some help.

Economist HM Desarda said the number of poor families that do not have ration card could be huge and the government should reach out to them during the ongoing crisis.

“Aurangabad has huge population of unorganized sector workers who have migrated from neighbouring districts as well different parts of the region in search of jobs. Many of them do not have ration card or other essential documents as they are not aware of its importance. Such population was engaged in menial jobs, but lost employment due to Covid-19 outbreak,” he said.

Aurangabad has industrial areas at Waluj, Chikalthana and Shendra providing jobs to migrant workers. The lockdown in the industrial sector has also posed survival issues before this workforce.

Desarda said affected families must be supplied with cooked food instead of providing grains.

When contacted, Aurangabad divisional deputy commissioner Varsha Thakur-Ghuge said the district-level authorities have been asked to extend all possible help to the affected migrant families at the earliest.

“Even if the migrant families do not have ation cards, they will receive grains and other essentials. The government authorities are on their toes to reach out to all those who are starving during the current crisis,” she said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Two held for murder
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Police on Sunday arrested two people for murdering a 45-year-old woman in a village near Thirumangalam .

The accused were identified as P Arunkumar,23, and M Kathiresan, 45, from Periyavagaikulam near Thirumangalam. They murdered K Selvi from the same village on Saturday night and fled the village.

According to police, Selvi was in involved in a relationship with a man named Murugan. The duo were staying at a farm house owned by Murugan. The accused were Selvi’s relatives. They were opposed to the Selvi’s relationship with Murugan .

As Selvi did not pay heed to their warning, the duo decided to kill her. They went to the farmhouse where Selvi was staying and attacked her using a machete and iron rod. She died while being taken to a hospital.

Based on a complaint, a case was registered with the Sindupatti police station. A police team arrested the accused on Sunday.

Title: Volunteers help the elderly by delivering essentials home
Content:
Help at hand

Bhopal: A group of volunteers has formed an emergency service helpline for senior citizens living alone in Bhopal.

The volunteers ensure that the elderly do not have to step out to get supplies like medicines and groceries during the lockdown. With more than 40 volunteers across the city, the helpline has served more than 100 senior citizens by taking medicines and groceries to their doorstep without extra charges.

On Tuesday, the volunteers also took a senior citizen residing in Anand Nagar and suffering from fever to a doctor.

IT consultant Rajneesh Khare, who came up with the emergency service idea, gathered the volunteers through a social media message. “I realised that our Prime Minister had requested senior citizens to stay inside their homes, even before the lockdown, as they are at a greater risk of being affected by coronavirus. In such a situation, when only the old parents are living in the house and their children are out of the city, it will become difficult for them to get things like milk, vegetables, medicines etc. So I decided to ask the youth for their help,” said Khare.

Khare shared the idea on social media and has gained more than 40 volunteers across the city who have so far served around 100 senior citizens in need.

“In a matter of hours, I had volunteers all across Bhopal who would not have to go further than 3-4 kilometres to deliver the necessary items. From Ayodhya bypass to Katara Hills, we have volunteers at all major areas. We then purchased a separate phone and SIM card to receive the requests and forward it to the concerned volunteer,” he added. The volunteers do not charge for delivery and only ask for reimbursement of the expenses.

Khare added, “It has been made absolutely clear that we are doing this to help people, not to take advantage of them in this situation. Whenever we get a request, we ask the people to just pay us for the items either online or through cash if their parents have the money.”

So far, the volunteers got requests from Kolar, Anand Nagar, Katara Hills and other areas of the city. Khare and the other volunteers of the group have got passes made to move out of the house in such cases.

Title: Calcutta University mails teachers, asks them to take classes online
Content:
Calcutta University

KOLKATA: An email sent to all the departments of Calcutta University last week termed the lockdown as a crisis that may seriously affect the teaching-learning process. The faculty members were requested to help the students while their classes remain suspended for a long time.

The pro-vice-chancellor (academics) Asis Chattopadhyay asked everyone to use online electronic facilities available with them. “You may send study materials, lecture notes, assignments, video lectures and other related materials to the students through mails,” he wrote to the faculty members.

Teachers have also been asked to make sure that the mails reach all the students. For this purpose, students have been asked to share the study materials with those, who don’t have access to internet.

Teachers were suggested to use Google (online class) or any other open sources to deliver online lectures to students, provided they had access to online facilities.

“Teachers can also send files to registrar or librarian for uploading on our university website in order to maintain an inventory and students can download those materials, if necessary,” said Chattopadhyay. “Some teachers of the zoology department are trying to reach out to students by sharing resources like lecture presentations, reading materials in students’ mail groups and clarifying their doubts through mails. One of the teachers has taken an online class. Some others are going to decide the next course of action after getting clarity on whether there would be any change in the academic calendar, which seems to be inevitable and imminent,” said Parthiba Basu, a teacher of this department.

Earlier, the Calcutta University Teachers’ Association had also sent a letter to the CU officials, suggesting some proposals on holding online classes.

Title: Day 6 of lockdown brings relief as grocery shops open in Goa
Content: PANAJI/MARGAO: Sixth day of the lockdown witnessed some marked improvement in the availability of supplies across the state. Horticulture stores and grocery shops were open in most parts while arrangements were made by municipalities and panchayats with the assistance from their respective MLAs to supply groceries and vegetables to all wards, if not to all homes.Vegetable trucks were seen moving about, stopping at popular junctions to sell vegetables. However, the demand far exceeded the supply in most towns.The exercise of supplying essentials through politicians, however, invited criticism from several quarters terming it as an attempt to derive political mileage.In many towns, youth groups came forward to make arrangements to supply essentials. In Bandora, some youth made arrangements to supply milk and vegetables to people. “Stock was limited, but if government help is received, we can make proper planning so that nobody comes out of their homes,” one youth volunteer said.Several organisations also contributed in relief arrangements. While Karmali Samiti was engaged in stitching face masks for distribution as masks remain in short supply, the Humanitarian Relief Society of Goa started distributing free groceries to the poor and needy families across Goa.In Panaji, doorstep delivery of groceries by the Corporation of the City of Panaji commenced on Monday. CCP tweaked its practice and has now asked residents to get in touch with their local councillor for groceries.Fresh fish has also begun to show up in Panaji though fishermen have chosen to sell at certain locations instead of heading to the fish market.Despite bars remaining shut, complaints of liquor being made available on order and delivered at chosen places at Curchorem were received by South Goa police over the last few days, sources said.

Title: Influx of natives from Surat puts Amreli, Bhavnagar admns at wits end
Content: RAJKOT: Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, around seven people were enjoying ‘bhajiya’ party deep inside a field in Jira village near Savarkundla last week. But the enjoyment was short-lived as a team of Amreli police raided the farm and booked them for violating public notification. These persons were among lakhs, who are natives of Amreli, but settled in Surat for job or business.The massive influx of Amreli and Bhavnagar natives from Surat after rising COVID-19 cases there has left the district administrations perturbed. They are at their wits end over screening such large number of people, many of whom could be potentially infected and could transmit the virus to others.Their worry has aggravated after the death of a 45-year-old woman, who had returned from Surat, to her native village Jesar taluka of Bhavnagar. Official sources said that she had returned few days ago but not informed any authority until she was referred to a government hospital on Sunday morning. “Had the district administration known about her condition, we could have isolated her and begun treatment,” said VK Baranwal, Bhavnagar DDO.Amreli and Bhavnagar collectors told TOI that roughly 3.5 lakh people from Surat have returned to their natives in villages here in the last fortnight. People are hiding in farms, locked themselves up in the house and living at relatives’ place.Police and administration officials said many have smartly skipped the checkposts and taken internal roads to enter the district, while others came in private vehicles like cargo vehicles, bikes tankers and even on foot.Amreli collector Aayush Oak told TOI: “We have deployed a team of 3,500 people for house-to-house survey to know if there are people from Surat, Ahmedabad or Rajkot. It’s a mammoth task to survey all 16 lakh people of the district. People are finding convenient hiding spots or locals are shielding them. Our staff is not welcome in the village and sometimes we have to take the help of police.”He has now now asked sarpanchs to give the details of non-residents after identifying those villages who have more number of people working in Surat. There are nearly five lakh people from Amreli district alone who are engaged in Surat’s diamond and textile industry.The situation in adjoining Bhavnagar is no different. DDO Baranwal said, “There are lakhs of people who have came from Surat to their natives, but we don’t have adequate staff to trace them. We are tired of appealing people to register themselves if they have come from other districts. These people are posing high risk of spreading infection.”Surat collector Dhaval Patel said, "Many people left Surat for their native villages in Saurashtra even before the lockdown was enforced. These people had not left city because of scare of corona-virus but they wanted to enjoy their village life on their farms and escaped every enforcement efforts and took interior routes to reach their hometowns and villages,''

Title: Canacona taluka: With rabi crop ready for harvest, farmers in a fix
Content:
Representative image

POINGUINIM: Farmers in Canacona taluka are staring at an uncertain future as the 21-day lockdown is coinciding with the rabi crop harvesting season. They are afraid of their efforts for a better produce going in vain.

Most of them called upon the zonal agriculture office seeking help in harvesting the crop yield.

Most paddy crops are ready for harvesting, but the farmers are facing labour scarcity in view of corona outbreak.

In Canacona, around 30 to 40 hectares of land is under cultivation. “It's high time,the government came up with relief measures for the farming community,” said farmers.

Mechanised harvesting in some pockets may not work owing to high terrain locations, and so, farmhands were essential, said a group of farmers from Khola village. “The government should provide farm machinery and manpower to reap the crop, besides threshing and winnowing,’’ they said. Director of agriculture Nevil Alphonso told TOI that the government is not in favour of allowing migrant labourers, but farmers can use available machinery.

“Guidelines to all the zonal agriculture officers have been issued on the availability of machinery to farmers,” he said.

Title: Sanitation drive in EG after two more test +ve
Content:
Kakinada: The East Godavari administration has taken up a massive sanitation drive after two people recently tested positive for Covid-19. Three people from the district have tested positive for the virus so far.

The two who tested positive are aged 47 years and 70 years. Twentysix people who attended an event in New Delhi and returned via Tamil Nadu Express, Duranto Express and GT Express have been hospitalised. Their samples were taken on Sunday and results are awaited.

Speaking to TOI, East Godavari DMHO Dr Satya Suseela said that 34 people known to the two patients have been put in isolation wards and will be tested. She said a 3km radius around the homes of affected people has been declared as containment zone.

East Godavari SP Adnaan Nayeem Asmi said 300 cases have been booked in the last five days for violation of lockdown orders and 7,000 under the MV Act.

Meanwhile, in West Godavari, 22 people who attended an event in New Delhi, have been admitted in government hospitals. Their samples have been sent and test results are expected on Tuesday.

Title: 32 teams to lead action against virus in district
Content:
Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai has appointed bureaucrats, health department officials and several others to lead the action against coronavirus across the district.

These officials, mostly heads of their respective departments, will act as task force members and have been appointed with specific responsibilities to look after and streamlining the functionality of the administration.

The task force involves around 32 teams of either individual officials or two to four officials to look after different sectors of the administration. They will address the assignments related to essential services, which include managing the medicines, blood supply, liaison between the Centre, state, and the district, managing supply of fruits, vegetables, and other essential commodities etc.

Desai told TOI that the arrangement has been made to address the issues that citizens might face during the lockdown period.

“The officials will look after all the essential services during the lockdown and any issues that may arise during it,” he said.

While Shravan Kshirsagar, deputy collector (revenue), Kolhapur, has been assigned essential services such as internet, mobile and telecommunication services, electricity supply, banking services, warehouse management and e-commerce among others. He said anybody having any issues can now directly communicate with the officials or the respective department.

“The idea is to have a comprehensive approach to deal with this unprecedented incident. The respective officials will look into different aspects and try to assess the impact and provide some kind of resolution,” he said.

The Kolhapur city has had two positive Covid-19 cases, while another patient is being treated at the Government Medical College in Miraj.

Title: Blood donor stopped, vehicle seized
Content:
Bengaluru: Police on Monday stopped a donor heading to a blood collecting drive and seized his motorcycle despite repeated requests. Rajesh (Name changed), a resident of Rajajinagar and private company employee, was heading to Gandhinagar to donate blood when police flagged him down near Ramamandir in Rajajinagar around 11 am.

“I told police about my purpose. But they seized my motorbike. Another donor took me to the blood bank in his motorbike. After donating the blood, I returned and collected the bike by evening,” he said.

Asked why they had stopped the blood donor, Rajajinagar police said “Whoever we catch come up with one or the other reason. If we let them, our seniors will shout at us. If we catch them, media and public blame us. Please understand our position.”

Title: Ajit Pawar seeks Rs 25k-cr central package
Content: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar , who also holds the portfolios of finance and planning, on Monday requested union ministers Nirmala Sitaraman, Nitin Gadkari and Prakash Javdekar to grant a special package of Rs 25,000 crore to tackle Covid-19 . “We are yet to receive a central grant of Rs 16,654 crore. It should be released before March 31,” Pawar said in a letter to the three leaders. tnn

Title: Delhi: GB Pant, Lok Nayak doctors to stay in The Lalit hotel
Content: NEW DELHI: Doctors treating Covid-19 patients at Lok Nayak and GB Pant hospitals will be boarded at The Lalit hotel for the next few days so that there is no chance of the virus spreading to their families, in case they get infected. Delhi government has decided to book 100 rooms in the luxury hotel for the purpose as it is less than 2km from the hospitals located on Jawaharlal Nehru Marg.The AAP government took the decision to quarantine these doctors as they are on the frontline in the battle against novel coronavirus. “It has been decided that doctors working on Covid-19 duty at Lok Nayak and GB Pant hospitals will be provided accommodation at The Lalit hotel and the payment of the same shall be borne by Delhi government,” an order by the health department reads.Doctors, nurses and paramedical staff treating novel coronavirus patients in designated hospitals will now work in two shifts of 10 hours (8am to 6pm) and 14 hours (6pm to 8am) continuously for 14 days followed by a 14-day break. Nurses and paramedical staff will also be provided accommodation by the government.Health minister Satyendar Jain said, “Doctors are working 24x7 to treat Covid-19 positive patients. It is our duty to ensure a suitable and safe arrangement for them. This is a quarantine facility so that the family members are not at risk of infection. Each of them will get a separate room in the hotel and they will work in shifts.”The New Delhi district magistrate will make 100 rooms available at the hotel on Barakhamba Road, the order added. Lok Nayak, GB Pant and few other hospitals are among the facilities where doctors have been deployed round-the-clock for attending to positive or suspected cases of Covid-19. Sources said the government may book more hotels close to the other hospitals for doctors on this job.

Title: Infected Ajmer family refuses to cooperate with authorities
Content:
Doctors brief health staff on how to screen people in Ajmer on Monday

JAIPUR: Four Covid-19 positive cases in Ajmer from the same family have alerted the authorities to prevent community spread of the virus in the densely populated Dargah area.

Local authorities have expressed concern that the infected family is not disclosing the places its members visited and the people they met in the recent past.

A 23-year-old man with travel history of 20 days to Punjab and Haryana was declared positive on March 28, following which his parents and elder brother tested positive on March 29. “We have requested the local community leaders to intervene by urging the members to approach us in case they came in contact with the Covid-19 patients,” K K Soni, CMHO, said.

The authorities are collecting clues by using all possible means including call details.

Since the news of three more positive cases was declared late last night, community leaders were on toes tracking those who were close to the family.

The authorities have also informed the community leaders that three positive members of the second family had visited grocery, milk and vegetable stores and offered prayers in the nearby mosque.

Syed Annudin Chishti, a member of the Anjuman committee, has shot a video and audio message post midnight and made an announcement from the mosque around the house of the positive persons.

“In the densely populated areas, even if you do not know each other you happen to cross each other frequently,” Chishti said. The efforts yielded results and health workers tracked six persons who had come in contact with the infected persons. While 2-3 persons, who were zeroed in on with the help of community leaders, are yet to be tracked by the authorities.

Title: Property tax payment date extended till June 30 in Kolhapur
Content:
Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has extended the deadline for payment of property tax to June 30.

The property tax bills are issued once in a year and the owners have to pay the tax before March 31. However, due to the lockdown and financial turmoil due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, the civic administration has decided to extend the deadline.

Sanjay Bhosale, property tax superintendent, said, “During the lockdown we don’t expect people to make tax payment. We have received directions from the state government to provide relief to the people in whatever way possible. Many owners have called us and said that they are facing financial crisis and are unable to pay the tax. Currently, 60% of target has been achieved and little delay in payment will not make much difference.”

He added, “The citizens are demanding tax holiday for couple of months. However, a decision regarding this has to be taken by the general body which cannot be called owing to lockdown.”

Meanwhile city MLA Chandrakant Jadhav has demanded waiver in property tax, water tax, estate fees and license fees. He has submitted a petition of his demands to civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti after a meeting at district collector’s office on Sunday evening.

“The source of revenue for citizens and traders has stopped due to the lockdown. We have to take measures to provide relief without considering any financial loss. For property tax, the deadline has been extended. I, however, have demanded to waive all taxes at least during the lockdown period and no forceful collection of taxes should be carried out,” said Jadhav.

Title: Online classes keep students busy, teachers say difficult to evaluate
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: With a 21-day lockdown at the time when the new academic session normally starts, has really thrown up many challenges for the educational institutions. The first few months is also crucial because this is when the teacher-student equation is set in place, especially among those who come in contact for the first time.

Mona Singh, principal of Guru Nanak Public School in Model Town Extension, said, “Simply sending assignments is not the solution, because not all parents can help their wards in studies. Also, books have not been purchased by the students yet. Giving them assignments is not difficult, but expecting the students to attempt the same without clearing any concepts may not work out. We can post solutions online but that’s not enough.”

However, according to the principal, the school is planning to send assignments just to keep the students busy. “These will be in the form of crossword or writing a diary to maintain a record of their feelings and emotions during the lockdown period. A document that can be preserved for posterity. We are working on other such improvised assignments, which can be done without a textbook.’

Keeping in view the delay in the commencement of the classes, principal Singh said, “We have curtailed our syllabus and the first exam or any other form of formal testing will not take place before September. We intend conducting classes during June.”

Navita Puri, principal of KVM School, said, “It’s very obvious that distance and online study can never match the physical presence in the classroom. The teachers are not fully satisfied with the class interaction. Usually, they take into consideration the different levels of understanding of different students. The students who need extra help could not be detected and helped so far. The students are missing their sports periods, extra curricular activities and, above all, their school friends.”

The biggest challenge according to principal Puri is that some students and teachers haven’t really gotten to know each other, especially the kindergarten and primary class students. “Though technology has made its presence felt in the classroom for the last 15-20 years, the teachers in most Indian schools and colleges are most comfortable still using the board and chalk method. For them suddenly shifting to recording and sending their lectures and not being able to oversee if the student (especially the slow learners) have completed the assigned task is a great mental adjustment and we are happy to see the staff is still going all out to adapt to this online medium of teaching and researching new online methodology and material to provide an enriching learning experience to our students in these adverse circumstances.”

Divjot Kaur, a student of Class X, said, “We are able to manage well in our studies through online videos and assignments uploaded by our school teachers through the e-care app of our school. I am thankful to our school principal and vice-principal for making learning easily available during this period of crisis.”

Vansh Gupta, one of the toppers of Commerce stream, said. “I spend four hours attending the online classes being organ ised by my school. Lessons are very effective and useful, but I miss being in the school. Being at home 24/7 is becoming boring.”

The solution to boredom, according to Vansh’s father, Sumit Bharti could be that schools covering more lessons to keep students occupied for the whole day.

Adabjot Singh Dhillon, a senior KG student at Mount Litra Zee School, said he maintains his daily school work habits with the help of online learning techniques. His father, Satjot Dhillon , said, “These online modules not only help in covering school curriculum, but also keep the kids busy with enjoyable and educating activities.

He is also of the opinion that the school authorities are providing impressive extra study material to help students develop an overall personality. “We, as parents, are grateful to the class teachers for their wonderful efforts. We are sure school will take all the steps for timely completion of the course curriculum,” added Dhillon.

Title: Goa: Fishing vessels at sea have to unload catch by March 31
Content: PANAJI: Fishing vessels that have been in the sea and are now returning to the jetties to unload their catch have only until March 31 to carry out this activity. The fishing activities will now completely stop from April 2 onwards, till further intimation.On March 24, the fisheries department issued a notice in view of the coronavirus advising fishermen in the state against fishing until further notice. However, with some fishing vessels already having ventured into the sea, the department was informed about their return, only to be greeted with lack of ice for the fish and lack of ration for the crew.The department has now permitted these vessels to unload their catch at their respective jetties until March 31.“All the vessel owners are hereby informed that after unloading their catch from the fishing vessels, shall leave jetty with crew members to safe zones offshore and vessel should remain anchored. They will not be allowed to return on the jetty till lockdown period is lifted by government,” the order signed by fisheries director, Shamila Monteiro read.In addition to this, the vessel owners have been directed to ensure that the crew is provided with sufficient ration, water and other materials required while they remain in the fishing vessel or at sheltered places.“All the activities on the jetty shall be stopped from April 2, except providing ration and other material required for the safety of the crew. Also, social distancing and other precautionary direction issued by various government authorities shall be maintained and followed.” the order read.

Title: Village socially ostracised, dist admin steps in
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The district administration has stepped in to take corrective steps after reports of a village close to Visakhapatnam city facing social ostracisation due to Covid-19 outbreak.

The villagers alleged that they were not getting essential commodities such as vegetables, milk and other groceries. In a video, a group of youngsters alleged that nearby villagers were denying access to roads close to their villages.

A Birmingham-returned youth and two of his family members had tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday. This, allegedly, has led to the village’s social ostracisation.

In the video, the youngsters urged the authorities to provide them essential commodities. They have accused that village revenue officer (VRO) and village secretary were not visiting their village. “If the situation is like this, who will help us. After the youth tested positive, even milk supply has been cut off. We have been asked not to visit other villages and not pass through the roads in the vicinity by the neighboring villagers,” the youngsters alleged. They urged the government to take immediate action.

Joint collector Loteti Siva Sankar told TOI that the district administration has taken measures regarding the village.

“We have sent revenue divisional officer (RDO) and tahsildar to take immediate measures. We have asked the authorities to provide essential commodities to the village,” said the joint collector.

Title: Centre, Goa get two days to reply on CISF deployment
Content: PANAJI: The Goa human rights commission on Monday took cognizance of a petition against the deployment of Central Industrial Security Force ( CISF ) in Goa amid Covid-19 outbreak and sought replies from the Union and the state government on April 1.The rights panel issued notices to the government and posted the matter for hearing on April 1. Complainant Kashinath Shetye besides six others, claimed that the deployment could lead to uncontrollable civil unrest if hungry citizens are dealt with sternly by the CISF.During the hearing, assistant solicitor general of India, Pravin Faldessai assured the commission that proper care and caution would be taken to avoid any incidents of violence.The commission’s member Pramod Kamat stated that it is a fit case for the rights panel to take cognisance of the complaint based on the averments made in the complaint.The group of seven social activists in their complaint to the commission requested for guidelines to be framed to prevent brutality and merciless beating without interrogation by the CISF personnel, especially when the government notified that one person per family can go to the grocery shop and purchase daily essentials Objecting to the request for deployment of CISF, the activists have stated that the government is treating a humanitarian crisis as a law and order problem. The use of force will cause further human rights violations, they said.In the current situation, CISF should have been used to assist the supply chain in disaster management and in “…ensuring a robust service delivery of essentials and helping the stranded people get home,” the activists stated.Deploying CISF in Goa, they say, could lead to “uncontrollable civil unrest if hungry citizens are met with by CISF ‘disciplining’ them,” the activists stated in their complaint.To blame the situation on people found on the roads, is to “absolve the state’s own responsibility to multilingually disseminate information about Covid-19 and measures being taken in Goa and the failure to comply with the human rights to food security of the people,” they added.The activists also raised questions about whether the CISF force brought in from outside the state have been tested for Covid-19 and warn that they could in turn be a threat to Goan public.

Title: Shelters for women from other states
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The district administration authorities who have been on their feet taking up various initiatives as part of Covid-19 management are also taking care of women who ended up in the city without any disease symptoms or foreign travel history.The authorities have arranged shelters and food for these women since they couldn't leave the city due to travel restrictions.A woman hailing from Vishakapatnam had left her home with two children to Tirupathi.While returning, she boarded the wrong train and got off at Kochuveli. After going through regular screening procedure, the authorities came to know that she had reached the capital by mistake and by that time lockdown was in effect.The women and her two children were shifted to a rest house and arrangements were made for their food. In another case, a woman from Tamilnadu had to go to Malappuram and she travelled by road and the private vehicle made her disembark at Parassala.The woman who got stranded first approached panchayat authorities who later got her in contact with the district administration. She is now being housed in a care home run by nuns.Earlier, a Tamil Nadu native, who currently resides in Bengaluru, arrived at airport and she had to be housed at Samethi care home.“When we came to know about the plight of these women, we arranged temporary shelters for all of them. None of them had disease symptoms and they hadn't travelled from countries with reported cases of local transmission. They were stranded here and we had to ensure that they stayed safe until restrictions are lifted for their smooth return to their homes,'' said Anu S Nair, deputy collector, disaster management.Along with local bodies, the district administration has already set up Covid-19 care homes in the district.Hostels and other facilities were converted into care centres and necessary facilities and supply of food were ensured with the support of local authorities.The care homes now house persons who arrived in the city by air and have to travel to other states or districts.

Title: Couple from Pune booked for cheating women of Rs 33 lakh
Content:
KOLHAPUR: A Pune-based couple has been booked by Jaysingpur police for allegedly cheating women associated with the self-help groups of Rs 33 lakh by promising them help in starting their own businesses.

According to police, the complainant — identified as Vaishali Vinaykumar Mane — came in contact with the couple in 2016. The couple had floated a company that was working for training women in rural areas and help them start their own business.

“The couple informed the victim that they only help women belonging to self-help groups and they need to become members of their company to get assistance. Following this, the complainant managed to gather around 100 women from different social-help groups and every one deposited Rs 200 in the company’s account to become members,” a police officer said.

“Since then, the company lured the women by floating different schemes like lottery, annual supply of cheap groceries, among others and collected around Rs 33 lakh from them till September 2018. After the complainant realised that they are being taken for a ride she raised a voice against the suspects following which they stopped replying to her queries,” he added.

The woman finally lodged a complaint with the police. “We have registered a case and booked them under sections 406 (punishment for criminal breach of trust) and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) of the IPC. We have not arrested them yet, but will soon initiate action,” Dattatraya Borigidde , police inspector in-charge of Jaysingpur police station, said.

Title: ‘People who came in contact must test’
Content: Ajmer: The district administration has asked people of Kharikoi region, who came in contact with the infected family, to come forward for a test.Four members of a family had tested positive for coronavirus in Kharikoi.The administration said this will help treat them on time. After the family tested positive, curfew was imposed in the area as well as in the jurisdiction of four police stations.In Ajmer, a 23-year-old salesman was found infected with coronavirus on Saturday and the next day his father, mother and brother also were found coronavirus positive.District collector Vishwa Mohan Sharma told reporters on Monday that the administration is appealing to those who came in contact with the infected family. He said there is no need to fear.“They should come out and help the administration by undergoing the test,” said the collector.He said if they are infected then there are possibilities that their families will also get the infection. Medical teams in Kharikoi region are identifying people who came in contact with the infected family, including the maulana of the Kharikoi Masjid. The district collector said the tests for coronavirus are being conducted in JLN Hospital and samples are also being sent to SMS Hospital for verification.

Title: Birds take a liking to the city again
Content:
Visakhapatnam: With people mostly confined to their homes due to the lockdown in view of coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak, birds and small animals seem to have regained lost ground, especially in parks and wooded areas of the city.

From Kites to Barn Owls, Parakeets, Squirrels, Kingfishers, and Woodpeckers are slowly coming back to the green patches of the city and also to homes with garden space. Even large animals such as Sambhar are seen some colonies.

Explaining the phenomena, Visakhapatnam district forest officer (DFO) Selvam said, “Usually birds and animals travel in search of water, but in and around Visakhapatnam their movement is highly restricted mainly because of urbanisation and continuous traffic movement on either side of the national highway. However, the lockdown has changed things and we have noticed Sambhar herds heading back to their old pastures beyond Seethakonda and the old dairy farm. Visalakshinagar was also a part of their orginal habitat, connecting the Kambalakonda-Seethakonda range with Simhachalam.”

He further said that the Sea Eagle, which was once commonly sighted near the Bheemili Beach Road, is also making its presence felt. “The lockdown can actually show us the extent of these animals’ original habitat. It is good that for a change, animals feel safe,” Selvam added.

“Birds are the first to take advantage of open and free spaces. Once birds show the way, other animals follow suit. It may not be surprising, if animals actually venture into residential areas,” said PV Sivaram, an amateur bird watcher.

Title: ‘Doctor, I’m scared of Covid-19’
Content: Ahmedabad: A Vastrapur resident under 14-day quarantine after a foreign trip recently called up his psychiatrist, reporting extreme distress on two counts – he felt stifled in his flat after a couple of days, and when he ventured out, he felt peering eyes of his neighbours, silently accusing him of putting others in risk. The man started popping pills to get a good night’s sleep.Monday will mark sixth day of the national lockdown to fight Covid-19 and the psychiatrists are already receiving distress calls from the citizens – complaining about issues ranging from anxiety to fear. In an initiative to combat the blues, Government Hospital for Mental Health has launched TeleMIND with a team of five psychiatrists – Dr Deepti Bhatt, Dr Ramashanker Yadav, Dr Kevin Patel, Dr Sasvinder Kaur and Dr Sudeshna Mukherjee – with the message ‘Don’t let the virus invade your mind.’“I received seven calls from persons under home quarantine, primarily anxious about their future, monetary aspects after the lockdown or even fear that they might contract the infection. However, the most common complaint we get nowadays is lack of proper sleep,” said Dr Yadav.Dr Patel said that few realize that the persons under quarantine also feel responsible for putting their families through quarantine. “It’s needed to spread positivity about their act ,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra government quarantines all 1.8 lakh outstation workers in state
Content:
Migrant workers from Madhya Pradesh were seen walking along the Mumbai-Ahmedabad highway in Palghar on Monday

MUMBAI: Alarmed by a spurt in Covid-19 cases, the state government on Monday quarantined all 1.8 lakh migrant workers and labourers across the state till April 14.

A senior bureaucrat told TOI that following the 21-day nationwide lockdown declared by Prime Minister Narendra Modi last week, all the districts were sealed and a ban imposed on movement of migrant workers .

“Directives were issued to all district collectors to ensure that migrant workers and labourers do not move out of their respective districts and that relief camps be set up for them where food must be provided. It has been decided to quarantine them,” he said.

The measures are in keeping with norms prescribed by the World Health Organisation, said the bureaucrat.

Elaborating, the bureaucrat said the workers have been lodged at relief camps, marriage halls and schools across the state. “Our doctors examine them at least once a day and a distance of at least five feet is maintained between two migrants. It is a difficult task but we have no option. At certain camps, we did face a law-and-order problem, since a large group was insisting on leaving,’’ he said.

The bureaucrat said while the maximum migrants are in the Pune division at over a lakh, Nagpur division has 11,132, Konkan 42,717, Aurangabad 11,435, Amravati 7,420 and Nashik 1,257. The largest number of migrant workers are in Kolhapur at 46,171, followed by Sangli at 45,913, Raigad at 18,326 and Pune 12,460, while there was none in Satara. The district administration will make arrangements for them till the lockdown ends.

Title: Private schools in Punjab asked to submit RTE file by today
Content:
LUDHIANA: The department of education, Punjab, has issued a letter to private schools of the state to submit the Right to Education files before March 31. The letter was issued on March 21. Now, directors and principals of private schools are objecting, and saying it is not possible for them, as there is imposition of curfew.

JP Bhatt, media organiser from Associated Schools Joint Action Front (Punjab), and director of Rukmani School at Samrala Chowk, said, “The education department is irresponsible, and performing mean activities to demoralise private schools, which is not acceptable. In this day, when whole world has tension for their survival, the education department is busy destroying the rhythm of Punjab with its discriminatory behaviour.”

Prithipal Singh, director of Adarsh Vidya Mandir and secretary- general of Joint Action Front, said, “At present, schools are not in a position to submit any documents to the department because of total lockdown. But school owners are under pressure due to the letter.”

They urged the department to extend dates, like CBSE has done until September. The department has all the documents, and they said it can proceed on the basis of the already submitted documents.
