PSEB too had given time to take practical exams of middle class from March 18 to March 26, and now when school officials opened their PSEB portal, they were told the time is over for entering marks for final submission.

A teacher, Pooja, from BDM Senior Secondary School , said, “When teachers have not taken the practical exams during lockdown and curfew, how can we submit the marks? And if we fill the marks just like that, it won’t do justice to students.”

DEO Swaranjeet Kaur said, “This has not come to my notice, and if such a thing is happening, we will raise the matter with the board authorities.”

Education minister Vijay Inder Singla said, “Till the lockdown, everybody can keep the reports with them, and after the lockdown, we will give suitable dates, so that everyone can amicably understand about how much time is required for these private schools to submit documents. We would be issuing a circular at the earliest. No one will be promoted without conducting exams.”

He added, “Till the time there is lockdown, all the exams stand postponed. Once schools open, we will announce a new schedule of the new academic session and conduct of exams. Nothing is happening for now.”

Title: Rising temp claims 1, city moves indoors
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The onset of summer has come as a boon to the police as it is keeping people indoors. The state registered the highest maximum temperature of 42.7° Celsius in Renigunta at Chittoor district, as per the weather bulletin issued on Monday.

A total of 772 areas in 13 districts recorded maximum temperature between 35°C-40°C while 163 areas registered temperature between 40°C and 45° Celsius.

Visakhapatnam city additional deputy commissioner of police Ch Adinarayana said nearly 450 traffic cops are on duty to prevent crowds and monitor traffic. “The hot weather conditions for the last few days in the city have played a role in decreasing public gathering in the daytime,” Adinarayana said.

Visakhapatnam joint collector L Shiva Shankar said a senior citizen in the district died owing to the high temperature. Sixty-five-year-old Meerabhi died of sunstroke at Chodavaram in the district, Shiva Shankar said.

Shiva Shankar dismissed allegations that a woman died while standing in the queue for free ration. “She collapsed near the Anganwadi centre, which some 100 metres away from her home, while on her way to the fair price shop. Her grandson was also with her” the joint collector told TOI.

Title: Elderly couple from Ranni set for discharge
Content: Kottayam: Government Medical College Kottayam , ( MCH ) is on the verge of a great achievement as an elderly couple from Ranni in Pathanamthitta who were critically ill after being confirmed with Covid-19 recovered and are set to leave the hospital. The good news doesn’t end there. Their son’s family, who were first tested positive after arriving from Italy on February 26, were discharged from Pathanamthitta General Hospital on Monday.The three-member family (father, mother and son) from Italy was tested positive on March 8 along with the father’s elder brother and his wife. All five were admitted to Pathanamthitta General Hospital on March 6. These were the first positive cases reported in the state after three students who came from Wuhan tested positive in last week of January.“Now, four more people from the same family are undergoing treatment,” said district collector P B Nooh. Among the four, two are admitted at the general hospital in Pathanamthitta and two at the medical college hospital in Kottayam.The two in the medical college hospital are the aged parents of the person who came from Italy. Considering their age (93 and 88), the aged couple were in the high-risk category, said health minister K K Shailaja. The granddaughter of the aged couple and her husband had got discharged from MCH the other day. These two had gone to receive the family from Italy at Nedumbaserry airport.The couple had old-age related health issues which made the treatment all the more difficult. They had diabetics, hypertension and cardiac issues. They were shifted to the VIP room in the medical ICU. They started showing uneasiness as both were admitted in separate rooms. Following this, they were shifted to transplant ICU where both could see each other. The health condition of the 93-year-old man deteriorated and he had to be put on ventilator. He also suffered a cardiac arrest during this period. They both also had urinary infections which was later cured. Once their health condition improved, test was conducted and both were found negative. According to doctors, both are only weak due to their old age and can be discharged from hospital soon.One of the staff nurse who looked after the couple was tested positive for Covid-19.The general hospital staff had arranged a warm send-off for the five who were discharged on Monday.“They will have to remain in home quarantine for 14 more days before starting normal life. Hence, we arranged all essential commodities for them for the coming days,” said Nooh.The five people thanked the district health authorities and the hospital staff for taking care of them. “It was due to our ignorance that we made a mistake. Everyone should pardon us,” said one of the patients.

Title: Mostly sunny from here on, but expect drizzle on Tuesday: Met
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Weather continued to be sunny in the city and the temperatures were recorded on higher side on Monday. But the met department is predicting rain on Tuesday and mostly clear sky after that for many days.

Monday morning began on a grey note with clouds, but as the day unwounded itself, sun caught up with it and stayed in Ludhiana’s sky for most part of the day.

The impact of sunny weather reflected on the maximum (day) temperature on Monday, as it was recorded at 27.7 degrees Celsius, which was two degrees less than normal. On Sunday the day temperature was recorded at 27.1 degrees Celsius, which was three degrees less than normal.

The minimum (night) temperature in city on Monday was recorded at 14.5 degrees Celsius, which is around normal but 1.5 degrees Celsius less than on Sunday.

“On Tuesday, there are chances of western disturbance arriving in city. There may be drizzle because of that. Weather is likely to remain clear and dry in the first week of April and there are chances of increase in day temperatures in that week whereas night temperature might remain around normal,” said Surender Paul, director of Met department Chandigarh.

Meanwhile, met department predicts day temperature to rise to 31 degrees Celsius by April 5 whereas the night temperature might rise to 15 degrees till April 1 and then fall to 14 degrees till April 4.

“We were fed up of the frequent changes in weather, as after every few days of sunny weather, it would rain. However, last few days have been good and mostly sunny. In the curfew, this is a blessing as our could bask under the shining sun in the afternoon hours for a while,” said Manish Kumar, a trader from Chandigarh road.

Title: Ban on sea fishing may lead to shortage of fish in state
Content:
Visakhapatnam: With the state government imposing a ban on fishing as part of the measures due to the 21-day Covid-19 lockdown, there are now fears over scarcity of fish in the market by mid-April.

While the AP government on March 23 imposed the ban on sea fishing for Andhra fishermen till April 14 as a precautionary measure to check the spread of Covid-19, the Union ministry of fisheries’ mandatory 61-day on fishing ban starts from April 15 and will be in force till June 14 across the east coast of the country, including the Andaman and Nicobar islands.

“It literally means there won’t be any deep sea fishing activity in the state for almost 80 days. Normally, Andhra fishermen spend more time in the sea during March-April to compensate for the 61-day mandatory ban period. But this year, they won’t get that opportunity,” said Arijili Dasu, executive director of Fisherfolk Foundation, a community based fishermen association in the state.

The local fishermen are worried as they won’t get to venture into the sea till mid-June. All their fish stock has already been sold to wholesalers and traders. “Going by the quantity the wholesalers and traders are hoarding now, it would last hardly till the end of April. There would be shortage of fish in the open market at least till end of June, a fortnight after the fishermen venture into the sea again,” added Dasu.

Though traditional fishing boats are exempted from the mandatory annual 61-day fishing ban, the catch volume for these boats has reduced considerably over the years.

“We cannot venture out for more than five to 10 nautical miles with these boats. In those areas fish population is very less. Our total catch is not enough even for the household consumption in Visakhapatnam district,” says M Bulayya, a local fisherman.

Also, with the government stopping daily auction of fish in all coastal districts in the state, it won’t count for much even if they are allowed to go out for fishing.

“This is because they don’t have any storage facilities and whatever they catch can hardly last for a few days,” says Dasu.

Title: Relatives wait to immerse ashes of deceased in Haridwar
Content:
Ajmer: Amid lockdown, people who had deaths in their families could not hold the last rites properly. In the absence of means of transportation, the ashes of the deceased have been lying in the nearby temples or in their houses.

Their families are waiting for the lockdown to be over so that they can take the ashes to Haridwar .

In the last one week, several deaths were reported in the district. But, after the funeral the ashes were kept at the temples.

Chand Verma of Ramganj whose father died on March 23 conducted the funeral. But the last rites will only be completed only after immersion of ashes at Haridwar. The rituals till the 13th day after death were also pending.

Mohan Kumar of Paharganj said that his mother died on March 21 and they performed the funeral. But, they have to take the ashes to the Ganges for ‘moksha’ of the soul.

There is a direct train from Ajmer to Haridwar as well as a roadways bus operating between Pushkar and Haridwar. But they stand stalled amid the lockdown.

Officials said that they were awaiting guidelines in the matter.

Title: Meet the loco-pilot who risks his life so you can get essentials at doorstep
Content: LUDHIANA: It will not be possible for India to lock itself down, without the help of people like Dharshan Singh, 47, a loco-pilot, who defeat all odds, so we could get our essential items.Ever since lockdown has been announced, Dharshan is on move driving different long-route goods train for ferrying the essential commodities , including medicines, from one state to another, amid corona scare.His shifts last anywhere between 12 and 15 hours, and he drives goods train mostly on northern railway route. Dharshan is worried, of course. He lives with aged mother and two really young daughters. But he is a sole bread-winner of his family after the death of his father a few years ago — his wife takes care of the home — so he has no choice but to work when called.But what makes Dharshan stand out is the fact how quickly he embraced the situation, bringing cheer to his colleagues by narrating positive aspects of the much-dreaded virus. Like the fact that how it is uniting people in fighting it.When TOI met Dharshan, he was about to embark to Rajasthan . “After the outbreak of coronavirus in country, a sense of fear has gripped the workers of various departments of the railways. I realised that there is no point in dwelling on this — except of course to take necessary precautions. The need of the hour is delivering essential commodities to the doorsteps of people so they stay inside and we defeat the virus. For this, my skills of running goods train for several hours are essential. So there is no point in being fearful.”Dharshan is also appreciative of his supportive family. “I receive such positive strength from both my daughters. This really helps in going out there and do the necessary thing,” he added.It helps too that the railway authorities are also taking every possible step to ensure the safety of drivers. “But i feel more can be done. For one, there is a need to sanitise the engines of goods trains requently, as several of us drive to complete a trip,”said Dharshan.

Title: No patient from slums yet, but experts fear the scenario
Content: Nagpur: Even with 16 positive cases of Covid-19 as of Monday, the city has been fortunate not to witness any patient from slums, which are considered high risk zones due to dense population and unhygienic conditions. The administration is yet to announce any plan in case patients are detected from slums, which would require large number of beds, staff, equipment for treatment and many quarantine centres like MLA Hostel , which is the only centre currently.Whenever a patient tests positive, close contacts are brought in for testing. After Khamla businessman and his three family members tested positive, two housemaids, who are from Gautam Nagar slums and Jaitala village, were also brought in for testing. Fortunately, they tested negative and were shifted to MLA Hostel.Similarly, one of the three housemaids of the 14th positive patient , who is from a housing society in front of Gandhisagar Lake, tested negative and is in MLA Hostel. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) is searching for the remaining two housemaids.There are around 453 slums in city comprising around 1.50 lakh houses and population of around 9 lakh. Houses in slums are in narrow lanes, and so congested that persons keep coming in close contact easily. Also, slum residents are known to mingle and socialize a lot.Therefore, suspected contact persons are likely to be large in number in case a patient comes from the slums.Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe said, “Already all measures have been taken to control Covid-19, including in slum areas. Containment drive is done in 3km radius of house of patients. Also, NMC is first to launch door-to-door containment drive across the city, including in slums. It is helping to identify suspect patients, high-risk patients and create awareness among people to prevent it. Also, we are ensuring high cleanliness in almost all parts of the city,” he said.Mundhe said, “Administration has chalked out a plan and also kept ready more locations like MLA Hostel. We will reveal them and bring them into use if situation requires,” he said.Experts of epidemiology and infectious diseases said that densely populated areas are more at risk for Covid-19.“In Sangli, 25 members of single family have tested positive. Even authorities have agreed that they lived in a congested set up and hence get infected. Just imagine what will happen if Covid-19 enters Indian slums,” said a senior epidemiologist in GMCH, who is following up the spread and tracing sources of infection in Nagpur since the beginning.The doctor said cases are on the rise in crowded localities, but fortunately not spread out of families so far. “First cluster in Nagpur was limited to only one member of the family while in recent cases more family members have been infected. This could be because of their congested pattern of living. Thankfully, no member living in slums has been detected positive so far. Otherwise situation would be dangerous,” he said.Deans of GMCs and health officials are not ready to talk on record about the preparations in case Covid-19 spreads in communities or slums in city. But, off the record, they have expressed concerns about it. It will be difficult to handle the rush if more number of suspects reach hospitals, they said. GMCH and IGGMCH are already loaded with patients from across Central India. How these two government hospitals will deal in case of community spread is still unknown.One dean said the government must think of acquiring a 200-300 bedded private hospital. “In Rajasthan, the state government has acquired 84 private hospitals on Monday. If coronavirus spreads in slums, our state health department will have to do the same,” said the dean.

Title: Fishermen rescued from M’luru, 7k stuck in Guj
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The state government has rescued 1,310 local fishermen and 24 fishermen from Odisha who got stranded at the Mangalore Port in Karanataka owing to Covid-19 lockdown.

The government has made arrangements for special APSRTC buses, which left Chittoor in the wee hours of Monday and dropped the fishermen at their respective villages in the seven coastal districts.

Officials said, the fishermen were stranded at Mangalore Port since the Janata Curfew on March 22.

On March 24 their respective boat owners had made arrangements and dropped them at Palamaner in Chittoor district. Since then, they were in quarantine at different government schools and colleges.

“Around 2.30am on Monday special buses left Chittoor with all the fishermen and dropped them at their respective villages,” said Arijili Dasu, a fishermen activist from Visakhapatnam.

Meanwhile, around 7,000 more fishermen from Srikakulam are stranded at Veraval Port in Gujarat.

Title: Corona Deaths in West bengal: Death in north Bengal, new positive in Kolkata
Content:
Customers line up in front of a half-open sweet shop in south Kolkata

KOLKATA/KALIMPONG: The 44-year-old Kalimpong woman, who tested positive for Covid-19 at North Bengal Medical College and Hospital on Saturday, died early on Monday morning, taking Bengal’s toll to two. Another 77-year-old man from Sovabazar tested positive for the disease on Monday, taking the number of Covid-19-positive people in the state to 22.

Health officials would also be waiting to get the swab test result of a pavement dweller, who died at NRS Medical College and Hospital’s isolation ward on Monday, to know whether she would be an addition to Bengal’s toll; she was admitted to the hospital on Sunday with respiratory distress.

The state’s healthcare sys-tem continued to grapple with more bad tidings: the 59-year-old from Hooghly’s Sheoraphuli and the 66-year-old from Baranagar had to be put on ventilation at AMRI, Salt Lake and Apollo Gleneagles Hospital, respectively, after their respiratory distress worsened on Monday even as the 66-year-old Nayabad patient continued to be critical at Peerless Hospital.

But Monday ended with some positive news from Beliaghata’s Infectious Diseases Hospital: Kolkata’s first three Covid-19 patients, including the first (the bureaucrat’s and paeditrician’s son who returned from England with the disease), all tested negative in the second con-firmatory test as well. “They may be released soon,” a senior health department official said.

All 16 patients being treated at ID Hospital, including three children from Nadia’s Tehatta, were stable, doctors said; another Covid-19 patient’s brother, admitted to Peerless Hospital with symptoms of typhoid, tested negative on Monday.

But the state’s healthcare system would be closely monitoring the latest positive case from Kolkata: the 77-year-old trader from Sovabazar. He was admitted to hospital on Saturday with pneumonia and his swab sample report on Monday confirmed he was suffering from Covid-19. He is on ventilation — like the two other patients admitted over the last few days — and his travel history has so far not revealed any contact with foreigners.

He has neither travelled abroad nor to any other state in the recent past, say officials, and it’s still not clear whether he has come in contact with anyone with a foreign travel history.

The state’s healthcare machinery moved fast, putting in quarantine 15 people who came in contact with the Kalimpong woman who died on Monday. She was cremated in Sahudangee on the outskirts of the town after cops intervened and pushed back a mob that tried to stop the hearse from entering the crematorium. The health department is also tracking people who came in contact with her in Siliguri.

The 44-year-old’s husband owns a jewellery shop in Kalimpong, which has a corner space offering money transfer services. All the employees have gone in for 14 days’ self-isolation. The couple have a son and a daughter staying in Kalimpong and another daughter who lives in Mumbai.

Title: Mamata Banerjee: Strictly enforce lockdown along West Bengal border
Content: KOLKATA: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Monday called for the strictest enforcement of the lockdown along Bengal’s borders to keep migrant workers out of the state. She even directed the administration not to entertain requests from MLAs and MPs on this issue.At the same time, she also took a number of steps to restore the supply of commodities: sweet shops will stay open four hours each day and kirana stores and home deliveries will be allowed to function as normal. And, to cope with hospital bed shortage, each district has been asked to identify and requisition private hospitals, university campuses, forest tourism centres, youth hostels and other centres for use as isolation wards for fever patients.Around two lakh migrant workers from Bengal are held up in other states. “We are getting in touch with them so that they can survive during this two-week lockdown,” Banerjee said. “These two weeks are very crucial. We will sit again on April 13 and may give some relaxation on April 14.” April 14 is Poila Baisakh, the Bengali New Year.The chief minister also pointed out that 40,000 migrant workers from other states are caught up in Bengal. “We are arranging basic amenities for them, like food and shelter,” she said in a video-conference from Nabanna with medicine experts, health officials, district magistrates and superintendents of police. She directed district magistrates to provide food to even those who don’t have the ration cards to collect the earlier-announced relief of five kilos of foodgrain from ration shops.The chief minister said she feared that a fresh influx of migrant workers — such as the one at the Delhi-NCR region a few days ago — would make the rural population of Bengal extremely vulnerable.“As many as 200 migrant workers have entered Islampur in Uttar Dinajpur; how could they enter?” she asked. The North Dinajpur SP replied that the group took a different route and entered through Gajole in Malda. “I don’t want to hear whether they entered through Gajole or Chanchol. This should stop,” she replied.The CM’s other steps — to restore the supply chain — were to ensure the lockdown didn’t descend into chaos. She lifted the lockdown on sweet shops, allowing them to remain open from noon to 4pm, in a bid to help milkmen cater to the demand for milk. Milk traders are among the worst hit because of the lockdown. A lot of milk has remained unsold because milkmen couldn’t market it to households, dairies and sweet shops. “Babies should get milk; milkmen shouldn’t waste their produce,” Banerjee said. She also announced a bonus on the commodity front saying that commodity shops (kirana shops) should be allowed to function normally, along with home deliveries.She also reassured traders, particularly those dealing in food and medicine, after they said police excesses were preventing proper goods delivery. She said that the government was trying for the last three days to remove bottlenecks. The chief minister named a policeman on duty at Alipurduar during her interaction with the Alipurduar SP. “Find out what he is doing. Eta korakori noi, barabari (This is not strict law enforcement, this is excess),” she commented.To citizens, she appealed against panic-buying. “There is no need to stock food and medicine,” the CM said.The chief minister directed the district administrations to identify and requisition each district’s private hospitals, university campuses, forest tourism centres, youth hostels, hospitals run by Bharat Sevashram Sangha away from towns, and set up isolation wards for fever patients. The chief secretary has issued a circular stating that the government will requisition not only the infrastructure, but also the services of doctors and nurses working there. The government plans to bring all of them under novel coronavirus insurance: the chief minister increased the insurance cover from Rs 5 lakh to Rs 10 lakh till May 15.Banerjee also fixed responsibility on individual officers to coordinate with Swasthya Bhavan on an emergency basis and assigned a senior officer for the five districts of north Bengal. She appeared unhappy with the arrangements so far. The relatives of the Covid-19 victim from Kalimpong have gone public with their experience in such quarantine centres. She talked in great detail about the health infrastructure in each district.Aware of the deficit in the pool of doctors in a state where the patient-doctor ratio is below the national average, the chief minister granted a proposal from North Bengal Medical College authorities to absorb 30 MBBS pass-outs as house staff on stipend. Mamata extended this principle to all medical colleges in the state.The chief minister appealed to citizens to bear with the lockdown for another two weeks to break the virus chain. Chief secretary Rajiva Sinha seized the opportunity to mention that the administration was getting written requests from MLAs and MPs, urging the administration to let the migrant workers to return. “Do not entertain letters from MLAs and MPs,” the CM said, asking the district administration to beef up border surveillance. She assigned senior IPS officer Ajay Kumar to oversee Siliguri, which shares borders with multiple countries.

Title: How can parents guide children without punishing them?
Content: It is important for parents to guide and reprimand their children whenever required. However, is punishment the only way to discipline your child? On the contrary, spanks and timeouts do not make your child more disciplined. It, in fact, paves the way for more misbehaviour. The best way of teaching kid is to behave with them the same way we would like them to behave with others. It might be possible that harsher ways of punishment may make your child more aggressive. Time outs, too, are a counter-productive way of parenting. We are leaving kids to deal with their own feeling when they may need us to guide them the most.However, it can be hard to imagine being able to put children on the right path without punishment or time out. Here are 10 ways you can connect more with your kids and teach them important life lessons without any punishments.Resists the urge to act on the first emotion. Instead, wait till you calm down before you address the problem. You will be able to find better solutions. Moreover, watching you is how your kid will also learn to control their emotions. You are their role model. They will pick up a lot of habits, good and bad, by observing you.Sometimes, to prevent a potential outburst of emotions and adrenaline, it is important for you and your child to recognize their emotions well. The best way is to sit with them to talk about what they are feeling. However, you should not make them feel intimidated. Instead, the idea is to create a safe environment where your child can open up about their emotions. This will fill gaps that exist between your relationship and urge your child to come to you for guidance more often.It is important that your behaviour urges your child to be the best version of themselves. While it is necessary to correct your child, it should not be at the cost of your connection. Work towards making the connection first. Always remember most of the indiscipline stems from a feeling of being left out and feeling disconnected.It is necessary for parents to create some kind of boundaries and limits. That is given. However, the same can be done with more empathy. Take time to know how your child is feeling and what they think should be done. Make it sound more like a discussion rather than a command. This prevents feelings of defiance from festering and the child feels more confident and understood. Give your child a choice for solving the problem at hand.Even if you don't find the reason to be reasonable enough, your child’s behaviour reflects what they are feeling at that time. They might want to spend more time with you. Is he is acting terribly? It might be possible that he is feeling terrible. It is important that you recognize what he is feeling and try and find a solution to his problem rather than his behaviour. You can eliminate the behaviour by addressing the underlying need.

Title: Nushrat Bharucha is doing what most of us are engaged in during the Coronavirus lockdown, exploring Instagram filters!
Content: The use of social media is at its peak as almost the entire world is under lockdown to stop the spread the Coronavirus . Several celebs have been sharing pictures and videos on their respective handles of what they are doing the lockdown period.Meanwhile, Bollywood beauty Nushrat Bharucha is doing what most of us are engaged in amid the lockdown, exploring Instagram filters. The actress took to her Instagram story to share videos using different filters and added songs to it. Dressed in a black cami top and hair tied into a high bun, the actress looked absolutely pretty!Check out the posts here:COVID-19 has brought the whole world to a standstill. For now, there is no cure to the disease and hence everyone has been advised to stay home.On the work front, Nushrat was last seen in 'Dream Girl' with Ayushmann Khurrana . The film scored huge at the box office. She will next star in Hansal Mehta 's next co-starring Rajkummar Rao

Title: Virtual meetings help cops stay safe
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

SURAT: While ensuring social distancing is followed across the society, cops too are taking measures to avoid coming in direct contact with each other. Police officials are now holding ‘tech-enabled meetings ’ to discuss status of law and order in the city and also issues related to other crisis within their jurisdictions.

Police are using social media applications freely available on mobile phones and hassle free. In the normal mode of video conference, a whole set-up of electronics is required, but through the mobile application, video conference on the phone is possible anywhere and everywhere. It merely requires a good quality mobile data coverage.

"In current times, while the officers are multitasking, their presence on the road is imperative. Considering all these factors, we found holding video conference meetings over the phone to be more feasible,” said Vidhi Chaudhary, deputy commissioner of police, zone III, Surat. By installing the Zoom app, 100 participants can hold a meeting for 45 minutes.

Through Zoom, police officers can know the exact locations of their colleagues participating in the meeting. This helps seniors verify location of the junior officers and instruct them instantly to go to a specific location to assess the situation live even while the meeting is going on.

Starting from the police inspectors to the city police commissioner R B Brahmbhatt, all officers of the city police are using the application.

Police officers are not only saving time but also reducing the risk involved in holding physical meetings at one place. “Using the mobile application we can reduce time spent on reaching the meeting spot. By this we can also ensure that we follow the guideline of social distancing," Chaudhary added.

Title: Covid 19 India tracker: 11 more deaths, 157 new cases
Content: NEW DELHI: Both the number of deaths due to Covid-19 as well as new cases reported across the country surged to a new single-day high on Monday, with 11 people succumbing to the infection and 157 fresh cases reported from the states.The coronavirus death toll in the country is now 43 while the total number of cases hase risen to 1,280, as per reports till late Monday night. Telangana reported the maximum five deaths followed by Maharashtra (three), Madhya Pradesh (two) and West Bengal (one).The previous highest single-day count of cases was on Sunday, when 130 new infections were reported from the states. On Monday, Kerala confirmed maximum the 32 new cases, followed by 25 cases in Delhi, 17 each in Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu and 16 new Covid-19 from UP. The health ministry has confirmed total 1,251 cases and 32 deaths so far.Many of the new Covid-19 cases reported in Delhi and Tamil Nadu are linked to a religious congregation organised in New Delhi by an Islamic missionary group, Tablighi Jamaat. In Delhi, for example, 18 of the 25 new cases were among followers of the Jamaat who were staying in its headquarters in NIzamuddin West. This includes some foreigners also who came to India in first week of March. More than 300 other followers of the Jamaat are admitted in the isolation ward of Lok Nayak hospital which is run by the state.In Telangana, five new deaths confirmed on Monday have been linked to the religious congregation in New Delhi too. The state government has launched a massive operation to locate anyone who may have come in the contact with the deceased and others who had visited Delhi to attend the event. Tamil Nadu has reported 17 new cases; all of them had visited Delhi for the Jamaat event.Kerala reported fewer cases on Monday but its total tally remains the highest, 234, in the country. Maharashtra has reported 220 Covid-19 cases so far. The Covid-19 mortality in Maharashtra is also high.Two octogenarians from Mumbai and a 50-year-old man from Pune succumbed to covid-19 on Monday, pushing the state’s death toll to ten. West Bengal reported its second death, a 44-yr-old woman, on Monday.After a day of zero new Covid-19 patients, Madhya Pradesh reported eight Covid-19 cases on Monday, with seven in Indore and one in Ujjain. Two of the patients died – one each in either city, officials said. MP’s total tally is now 47 with four deaths.At least 16 new coronavirus positive cases were reported in UP in last 24 hours taking the state’s tally to 96 on Monday. Of the new cases, seven were reported in Noida, six in Meerut and one each in Lucknow, Agra and Bulandshahr.The total cases in Gautam Buddh Nagar have gone up to 38 while 19 cases have been reported from Meerut. Agra and Lucknow have reported 11 and 9 cases, respectively. Noida-Ghaziabad and Meerut have emerged as Covid-19 hotspots in UP as 61% of total cases have been reported from these three districts. Rajasthan reported 10 cases of Covid-19, highest in a single day in the state, on Monday.

Title: 5 Feng Shui tips to keep in mind while redecorating your home
Content: In today’s time when everyone is caught up in their everyday life and jobs, it is only our home which provides us peace. Coming back to our homes filled with positive energy, helps us relax and keep our peace of mind. Feng Shui, which is basically a Chinese practice of creating positive energy flow in our environment also suggests several things to incorporate in our homes.Here are a few Feng Shui tips to keep in mind while redecorating our homes.Fen Shui says that if you have a large window opposite a door, then the energy of the room will be pushed right out of the window. In order to maintain a room’s energy several blocking techniques could be used.You can place curtains or blinds on the window to contain the energy, but the best way to partially block the energy is by using plants. Placing potted plants on the sides of the window will not only attract positive energy but will also keep you close to nature.Colors play a very important role in lifting or dropping the energy of a place. Bright color combinations can instantly lift the dull and negative energy of your home. If you are redecorating your home, then you must color coordinate your home by using light colors.You can incorporate shades of white, grey, blue and green and contrast them according to your wish. You can also take into consideration pastel colors which are the happy-go-lucky colors of all time.Feng Shui products not only add more beauty to your house but also helps in maintaining a positive aura around it. You can add a fountain along with small bonsai plants to complement it. Feng Shui paintings and artworks are some other good options to fill your house with positive energy.A Buddha statue can also be placed on your living room shelf or office table to attract good vibes.Quite old and well-known Feng Shui to attract positive energy in the bedroom is by leaving space on both sides of the bed. It applies to both double and single bed owners. You must never stick your bed’s one side to the wall, keeping only the other side open.It is said that when you leave space on both the sides, the flow of good energy is maintained in a proper manner. On the other hand, when you are sticking your bed’s side to the wall you are blocking your positive energy flow.Feng Shui is all about creating space for easy flow of positive energy. It is said that you must not fill things in your room just for the sake of keeping them. Take out unnecessary items which are lying idle and are requiring negative space in your room. Place your sofa in such a way that the main door is visible from there and never place it the other way round, as it is said to block positive energy.Decluttering your room will make it airier and more relaxed which will further attract only good vibes.

Title: In Nanjangud, 753 pharma staff home-quarantined; kin of patients in public facilities
Content:
Mysuru: Family members of eight Covid-19-infected Jubilant Pharma employees based in Nanjangud have been moved to public quarantine facilities set up in government buildings. Authorities ruled out shifting of all employees of the company and has home-quarantined them instead, assigning one constable to monitor 10 of them to ensure they stay indoors.

Since Friday, 10 employees have tested positive and results on 30 samples are awaited.

As of Monday, 753 workers of the company have been home-quarantined. Groceries and other essential supplies would be reached to them, authorities said. After the infections were classified as a “cluster case”, the district administration had planned to quarantine all employees of the firm at choultries and other public buildings but health experts advised against it, saying it could cause virus to spread further.

The district administration has got the company to pay 30% of employees’ salary in cash to ensure those home-quarantined can buy essential commodities. District minister V Somanna, who held a meeting with officials, said the employees will get at least Rs 5,000 in cash from the company within a couple of days.

A sense of fear pervades Nanjangud, a temple town of 60,000 people just over 20km from the city. Located on the national highway, it is now out of bounds for people while Nanjangud Industrial area, 3km from town limits, is closed. Only a few units deemed essential are allowed to operate. The administration has cancelled the car festival of Lord Sri Srikanteshwara scheduled on April 3 — the first time ever, recall residents. Though essential services, such as grocery shops and pharmacies are allowed to open, many chose not to.

While family members of those who tested positive are quarantined at facilities set up in public schools in Mahadevapura, Hura and Sinduvahalli in Nanjangud taluk, a community hall in the town is also being readied for a potential spike in infections.

Residents of KHB Colony in Nanjangud gathered in front of a government hostel on Monday, opposing arrangements to turn it into a quarantine facility.

‘Quarantine breakers to be booked’

Referring to flyers who were stamped for quarantining themselves and still stepped out, district minister V Somanna said strict action would be taken. Many of the rubbed off the mark to evade public scrutiny. “Given that some of those home-quarantined have flouted norms, police will file criminal cases against them,” the minister said. A flying squad comprising senior officials has also been tasked with enforcing the quarantine.

Title: 96 held for rioting in Surat, given bail
Content:
RAF did a flag march in Vadod on Monday

SURAT: Pandesara police arrested 96 migrant labourers on Monday on charges of allegedly rioting and attacking the police during lockdown at Vadod locality on Sunday night. However, in order to avoid creating further tension, cops later released them on bail and were also counselled not to panic.

Three police personnel had suffered minor injuries in the stone pelting and three police vehicles were damaged. Rapid Action Force and police teams also conducted a flag-march of in the area on Monday to ensure peace.

"Police released those arrested on bail soon after completing the formalities and also counselled them to share their experience with others. We asked their support to create awareness among other migrants that they are safe wherever they are instead of travelling in current situation," city police commissioner, R B Brahmbhatt told TOI.

"They are now our messengers for the other migrants and we are also making efforts that such migrants don't face issues related to food and other essential items," he added.

More than 1,000 migrant workers clashed with the police in Vadod at around 10.30 pm on Sunday. The migrants were demanding permission to go to their native places, while police teams were enforcing lockdown and asking people to stay in their homes. The workers alleged that they are not getting food supply regularly and are also not being allowed to go to their native places. A majority of labourers in Pandesara area hail from Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Odisha.

During the clash the crowd pelted stones and damaged a few police vehicles. To control the crowd police lobbed 19 tear-gas shells and fired in the air. Police force comprising over 250 policemen, battalions of state reserve police (SRP) and cops from special operation group, prevention of crime branch and detection of crime branch rushed to the spot to control the situation.

"The residents were demanding permission to be allowed to go to their natives while the police were requesting them to stay put. The situation was immediately brought under control by the police," said the police.

Following the incident police teams increased patrolling in the area. Senior police officials have expressed concerns in past couple of days about the rising demand of migrant labourers to be allowed to go to their native places.

Title: Bank EMI News: Banks yet to act on EMI relief, spark confusion
Content:
Representational photo.

MUMBAI: With just two days left for the next EMI cycle to begin, most big lenders are unprepared to follow the Reserve Bank of India ’s blanket order allowing borrowers to hold back from paying instalments for the month. Top lenders such as State Bank of India, HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank, Kotak Bank and Axis Bank have not activated any channel for customers to exercise an option.

As a result, there was confusion among borrowers on Monday as many received text messages alerting them that their loan EMIs would be debited from their accounts and they needed to maintain adequate balance. Starting Wednesday, borrowers are due to pay their monthly instalment but banks are not ready yet to implement the special facility created by the RBI, which allows borrowers to avoid paying three EMIs without being classified as a loan defaulter.

Read our coronavirus live blog for all the latest news and updates

Most bank branches have not received any instructions from their headquarters on deferment of instalments and many are reluctant to accept requests. On their part, bankers suggested, deferring EMIs is an option for borrowers, but there is no benefit for those who can pay.

The SBI, source told TOI, will put in place an option for borrowers to repay failing which the EMIs will be deferred. Mortgage player HDFC will reach out to borrowers over the next few days through emails and SMSs, informing them about the option, which can be through a link on its website, a spokesperson said. Borrowers will also have the option to continue with the EMIs.

Coronavirus outbreak: Complete coverage

Another private bank executive said that it may take a couple of days to operationalise the deferment option. One bank said that it is considering delaying EMI debits for the first few days until a system is in place.

More on Covid-19

Coronavirus pandemic: Complete Coverage 21-day lockdown: What will stay open and what won't How to quarantine yourself at home Trust the newspaper for your daily verified news

In case banks do not pause standing instructions for debiting bank accounts and the transaction fails, most banks have a penalty equal to that of a cheque bounce, with charges ranging from Rs 200 to Rs 400. For most retail loans, including housing, auto and other personal loans, banks obtain standing instructions to debit monthly EMIs from a customer’s salary account. A bulk of the deductions happen in the first week of the month.

“Customers must realise that this is not a waiver but just a facility provided to avoid being classified as a defaulter if they miss their instalment due to liquidity problems. There is no advantage in delaying as interest charges will continue to accrue for the three months even if it is collected later,” said a banker.



In Video: Banks yet to act on RBI's EMI relief order, spark confusion

Title: Govt’s plan to home-deliver groceries runs into trouble
Content: Guntur: The much-publicised door delivery of groceries is yet to pick-up in the city as merchants are refusing to take orders of small quantities. A majority of the large stores are willing to take up door-delivery only for orders above Rs 25,000-Rs 30,000 while the commoners’ monthly grocery bill is around Rs 3,000-Rs 4,000.The lukewarm response of the big retailers has upset the authorities’ plans to doorstep-deliver groceries. Initially, all the big retailers and branded grocery stores had expressed willingness to supply stocks to homes when district collector Samuel Anand Kumar reviewed the situation last week.The district administration had circulated the WhatsApp numbers of the retailers through media asking people to post their grocery requirements with the respective shoppers to get the stocks door-delivered. Authorities thought that such an arrangement would help keep people indoors.People dependent on retail stores in the past, heaved a sigh of relief and hurriedly posted their needs. To their utter shock, the customer service numbers of the malls became unresponsive. There was no response from the stores even on the WhatsApp numbers.Sources said that they became unresponsive as they were flooded with requests. A few of the stores finally responded, stating that they are unable to handle individual requests for door-delivery. “We can send stock to the apartments where at least 20-30 flat owners together post their requirement as sending the groceries to the door-steps of individual houses is a big task, particularly with police restrictions in place,” said a senior executive of a branded retail store on condition of anonymity. He said they have agreed to extend the door-delivery facility only when there is sufficient volume of order.Unlike in metro cities where apartment complexes have 100-150 flats, apartment complexes in Vijayawada and Guntur cities have 20-30 flats. A few places, the complexes have 40-50 flats. Moreover, residents welfare associations are not involved in booking groceries for all. So, many residents are posting their individual needs prompting the stores to refuse.Following the development, the district collector directed the joint collector to convene another round of meeting with the grocery merchants and rope in small merchants to supply goods to the door-steps of customers to prevent people from stepping out during the lockdown.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Stepfather beats 3-year-old to death in Kurnool
Content:
Representative image

TIRUPATI: A three-year-old boy was beaten to death by his foster father in Kurnool on late night Sunday.

According to Kurnool IV Town police, a building construction worker, identified as Farooq, who lived at Weaker Section Colony in the town, befriended a married woman on Facebook about six months ago.

The woman then divorced her husband and moved in with Farooq with her three-year-old son Jhulsi. On Sunday night, when the couple was having an altercation the three-year-old boy who could not stand his mother being thrashed, tried to hit his stepfather with a stick.

Enraged, Farooq severely caned the child, who then collapsed to the ground unconscious. Although he was immediately rushed to the government general hospital at Kurnool, doctors declared him brought dead.

Following a complaint registered at the Kurnool IV town police station, a case was registered and police sent the boy’s body for postmortem. They have taken Farooq into custody.

Title: Amara Raja donates Rs 5cr to relief fund
Content: Vijayawada: Tirupati-based Amara Raja group said on Monday that the company has donated Rs 5 crore to the Andhra Pradesh CM Relief Fund and Rs1 crore to the Telangana CM Relief Fund to support the fight against Covid-19 . The funds include the donation of one day’s salary by employees..Meanwhile, Jayadev Galla, Lok Sabha MP from Guntur and managing director and vice-chairman of the group said that he will use Rs 2.5 crore from his MPLADS funds to combat the spread of Covid-19 in his parliamentary constituency. TNN

Title: Health minister takes stock of arrangements
Content: Tirupati: State health minister A Kali Krishna Srinivas said on Monday that the decision to lockdown the state was taken by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to protect the people from falling prey to the novel coronavirus.The health minister, accompanied by deputy CM K Narayanaswamy and minister P Ramachandra Reddy reviewed the arrangements of the Chittoor district administration in Tirupati Speaking to the media, the minister said, “In order to reduce the inconvenience of common people during the lockdown, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has launched the free rice and dal distribution scheme, along with which, the state government will hand over financial assistance of Rs4,000 to white ration card holders on April 4.”The health minister said that the state government has identified 29,672 foreign returnees and they have been isolated. Samples have been collected from 649 people, of which only two have tested positive, the minister said.

Title: VMC to use drones to sanitise red zones in city
Content: Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has decided to use technological support to contain the spread of Covid-19 . In such an attempt, the VMC is now employing drone sprayers to sanitise containment zones in the city.VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh inspected the trial run of the drone sprayer at the new government hospital on Monday. Officials sprayed Sodium Hypochlorite using drone sprayers inside the hospital premises.Speaking about the experiment, the VMC commissioner said, “We are trying hard to stop the spread of coronavirus in the city. It is getting difficult for our staff to reach every corner of the containment areas and spray disinfectants. This drone will cover localities in the half-km area. We can fill 10 litres of chemical once and that will cover a huge area.”“We have engaged five drones which will be used from Tuesday. These drones will be utilised to sanitise the government hospital, its nearby areas and other red zones and containment zones in the city,” the VMC commissioner said.

Title: SMC general board allots commissioner purchase power
Content:
SURAT: Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) general board met today through online and decided to allocate purchasing power to the municipal commissioner to combat Covid-19.

"In our general board meeting, we decided to give municipal commissioner Banchhanindhi Pani purchasing power to fight Coronavirus in this time of crisis. Hence, if the civic body requires to purchase any medical equipment, ventilators, mask or anything essential, it now no longer requires to go through all the necessary approvals from the general board,'' said Dr Jagdish Patel, mayor, Surat, while talking to TOI.

“SMC is leading from the front in the fight against the global pandemic and we will do everything to defeat the COVID-19,” Patel asserted.

The civic body has also started distributing food from its school campuses in the city so that people can come and get their food. “We received messages that in some areas people were going hungry, while in many others voluntary organisations were feeding the people. So, we started operating food distribution system in our school campuses where Akshay Patra as well as NGOs provide food and people living in nearby areas can come and eat. Our purpose is that no person should go hungry,” the mayor added.

Title: Global lockdown: What’s in store for applicants to foreign varsities?
Content: Vijayawada: The Covid-19 outbreak has added to the worriers of people who were gearing up to study abroad and were waiting for the admissions processes to begin. With countries imposing restrictions on immigration, travel and foreign universities suspending academic work, aspirants are anxious.With the situation as it stands, foreign universities are expected to alter admission guidelines and set new deadlines. Some prominent B-schools in USA have already announced that if students can’t make it to USA due to visa issues then their academic programme will be deferred to spring 2020 or fall 2021 cycle from the fall 2020 semester.Speaking to TOI, Prof VSRK Prasad, director of Indian Institute of Petroleum and Energy (IIPE) tried to allay fears of aspirants. “I am very confident that the pandemic may end sooner or later. Meanwhile, it has brought the education sector to a standstill. Foreign institutions may also change the admission process,” he said.“So it is just going to be a delay, not a permanent lockdown situation,” Prof Prasad added.M Siddharth, a representative of an overseas education consultancy based out of Vijayawada said that the consequences of the pandemic on education are yet to be fully ascertained. “The pandemic has brought several European countries and the US to their knees. These countries are struggling a lot.”“While some countries have declared national emergencies till May 1, other countries have completely suspended academic activities. Admission results or acceptance letters of this cycle were supposed to be released or issued within March to May. But in the current situation, it may take a few more months to know what’s in store,” Siddharth added.KNS Pranav, who has applied to several universities in USA, Canada and Europe said, “Even if I were to secure admission in an university, I am not sure how restrictions in the respective country of the varsity or in India would allow me to reach campus.”

Title: Toddy tappers seek help from govt
Content: Vijayawada: Measures to contain the spread of Covid-19 have hit hard toddy tappers in the state who are seeking compensation from the government citing loss of livelihood this season.Demand for the naturally-brewed liquor rises in summer, and between March to May toddy tappers climb palm trees thrice a day to collect the sap from the top of the tree. This year, production has been halted, following restrictions by the excise department in view of the rising number of Covid-19 cases.In Andhra Pradesh, around four lakh persons are involved in the collection and sale of toddy. Production and consumption are especially high in East Godavari, West Godavari, Krishna and Guntur districts, said K Krishna, a toddy tapper. “During the summer, we can collect 10 to 15 litres of toddy from a palm tree in a day,” he said.Speaking to TOI, secretary of Andhra Pradesh Kallugeeta Karmika Sangham (Toddy Tappers Association) Y Demudu said that though the demand for foreign liquor was growing, toddy remained popular in summers.“The threat involves everyone and we have to win the war against Covid-19, so we stopped collection and sale of toddy following government instructions. But it was our only source of revenue and we are requesting the government to announce Rs 75,000 for each toddy tapper in the state for the sake of their families. Toddy is not like other liquors, we can’t collect and sell once the season is over,” said Demudu.The price toddy is cheap when compared to beer and other liquors, selling between Rs 80-Rs 100 for 1,000 ml against over Rs 160 for 650 ml of beer and over Rs 250 for 180 ml of liquor. A senior officer with the prohibition and excise department said that all liquor shops and bars and restaurants in the state have been closed as part of measures to control the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Covid-19 in Karnataka: Quarantined? Upload selfie every hour
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

BENGALURU: The Karnataka government directed on Monday those in home quarantine to take a selfie every hour and upload it to a newly launched app, Quarantine Watch. This has been done to prevent foreign returnees from violating self-isolation protocols related to Covid-19.

According to a release from state medical education minister K Sudhakar, the selfie will contain GPS coordinates telling the authorities the exact location of the home-quarantined person. The app, which has been launched by the revenue department, can be downloaded from Google Play Store.

"If the home-quarantined person fails to send a selfie every hour (except sleep time — 10pm to 7am), a government team will reach the person and can shift him or her to the government mass quarantine facility," the minister stated. The selfies will be examined by a verification team and falsifications, including sending wrong or fudged photos, will result in the person being shifted to mass quarantine.

Title: This bride's breathtaking lehenga is proof pale gold is the wedding colour of 2020
Content: It's a distressful time for each one of us as we practice social distancing to fight the deadly Coronavirus. While we are caught up at our homes, it's the internet that is proving to be the sole companion and we are spending our days looking at the throwback pictures of beautiful Indian brides. We came across one such beautiful bride, and we can't get over her pictures.We are talking about South African resident, Hasita Bhavanbhai, who made the most beautiful bride as she got ready to tie the knot with beau Yashiv Ramdarie.The wedding which took place at Johannesburg's picturesque venue Summer Place Hyde Park had the duo looking resplendent and we bet you will fall in love with the duo's wedding refinery.Hasita looked regal in a pale gold tulle and silk lehenga at her wedding ceremony. The lehenga by designer duo Harpreet and Rimple was wrought with resham, Kashmiri tilla, hand cut sequins and crystals along with dabka-nakshi zardozi and kasab-dori marodi ka kaam, used in a painterly way to render gently floating lotus blossoms and floral buttis derived from Pichhwai paintings which were further interspersed with baroque motifs, chandeliers and curios. The lehenga was paired with a resham rendered choli and sheer tulle dupattas.Well, a look at Hasita's beautiful lehenga is enough to prove that pale gold will be the wedding colour of the season, isn't it girls?Handsome groom Yashiv complemented Hasita in a green sherwani, which he teamed up with a churidar and a traditional golden safa.We loved the duo's beautiful pictures, tell us how did you like their wedding refinery in the comment section below.Photo: Designer Photo

Title: Virus fear denies woman cremation in Midnapore
Content:
Midnapore: A 45-year-old woman who died after a heart attack in a Bengaluru hospital had to be buried in a forest near her home in West Midnapore’s Kalaikunda on Monday after her family faced resistance at two burning ghats over unfounded suspicions of Covid-19 infection.

Homemaker Mira Mahato was taken to Bengaluru for treatment on March 19 after doctors in Midnapore failed to make her better, her daughter Rina (28) said.

“My mother was a cardiac patient. She passed away on Saturday afternoon (around 1.40pm) and doctors there mentioned cardiac arrest in her death certificate.”

Mira’s body was brought in an ambulance to their village home in Kalaikunda’s Hariyatara. “Locals prevented us from cremating my mother in the crematorium adjoining our village. They said since she had died in Bengaluru, they feared she might have died of Corona virus,” Rina said. “We tried to reason with them and showed the death certificate. But they wouldn’t listen.”

The family then took Mira’s body to Midnapore town’s Padmavati crematorium. “There too we faced similar resistance,” Rina said.

After residents informed police, the family was told to bring the ambulance carrying the body to Kotwali police station. “Police checked my mother’s death certtificate and asked us to take the body back to Kalaikunda. We sought police help and took my mother’s body to Poradiha forest nearby where we buried her,” Rina said.

According to a senior police officer, “people were scared of the Corona virus though the deceased did not die of the disease”. “We took measures to ensure peace but also helped the family bury the body,” the officer added.
